DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN PRESIDENT WELCOMES NEW ROC AMBASSADOR
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By M.H. Huang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Martin Torrijos on Monday welcomed the Republic of China's new envoy to Panama, expressing the hope that friendly relations between his country and Taiwan will be further strengthened.
The president made the remarks while receiving credentials presented officially by Hou Ping-fu, the ROC's new ambassador to Panama, at the Presidential Office in Panama City.
Welcoming the new ambassador, Torrijos said that he has learned that Hou had served before as the ROC's third and second secretary at the ROC Embassy in Panama.
In response, Hou conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's greetings to the Panamanian president.
Panamanian First Vice President and Minister of Foreign Affairs Samuel Lewis Navarro was also on hand to witness Hou's submission of his credentials to Torrijos.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 1, or the 23rd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1650: Rene Descartes, French mathematician and philosopher known as the "father of French philosophy," dies at the age of 54. His philosophy is based on the rationalistic premise: "I think, therefore I am."
1893: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, opens the first film studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
1901: Clark Gable, American film actor who became an international heart throb, is born. He played Rhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind."
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games are held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of the 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the United States following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The U.N. General Assembly condemns the Chinese Communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The U.N. General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1958: The first U.S. satellite, the Vanguard-1, is successfully launched into orbit.
1963: Taiwan's `king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is named secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu-tung is named deputy secretary-general.
1973: One hundred and four members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan, 20 mayors and magistrates and the 73 members of the fifth Taiwan Provincial Assembly are sworn in.
1974: An economic mission headed by Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chang Kwang-shih leaves for Saudi Arabia for a five-day visit.
1978: The Central Daily News, the oldest newspaper in the country, marks its 50th anniversary.
1979: Iranian religious leader the Ayatollah Khomeini ends 16 years of exile, returning from Paris to a frenzied welcome at Tehran airport.
1980: Taiwan's North Link (Suao-Hualien) Railway is opened with ceremonies in Nanshenghu, near Ilan, and Hualien. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1982: Alfred Britain III, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, opens the bank's branch office in Taipei.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1991: An earthquake rocks Pakistan and Afghanistan, killing more than 1,200 people.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Camp David declaration stating that their two countries no longer regard each other as adversaries.
1995: Communist Vietnam and the United States begin a new chapter in their relationship by opening liaison offices in each others' capitals.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew presides over a ceremony to unveil the name plaque of the newly established Coast Guard Administration and swear in CGA Director-General Yao Kao-chiao.
2001: Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, arrives in Taiwan from Hong Kong.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE SECRETARY-GENERAL ASSUMES POST

TEXT.P: Former Premier Yu Shyi-kun took over as secretary-general of the Presidential Office Tuesday.

Yu, who just stepped down from the premiership earlier in the day, took over the official seal of the presidential chief of staff from Su Tseng-chang in a changeover ceremony presided over by Vice President Annette Lu at the Presidential Office.
Su has been elected chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Earlier in the day, new Premier Frank Hsieh and other Cabinet members took their oath of office at a swearing-in ceremony presided over by President Chen Shui-bian.

Also on Tuesday, 225 newly elected legislators were sworn in for a three-year term. Shortly afterwards, Wang Jin-pyng, an opposition Kuomintang vice chairman, was re-elected Legislative Yuan president by winning 123 votes. Wang's sole rival, Ker Chien-ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, won only 101 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMBERS OF SIXTH LEGISLATURE SWORN IN

TEXT.P: The new members of the sixth Legislative Yuan were sworn in Tuesday for a three-year term.

The 225 legislators, which were elected in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, took their oath of office under the supervision of Grand Justice Yang Jen-shou at 9:40 a.m. at the legislature's main conference hall.

The most conspicuous among them was independent lawmaker Li Ao, a historian and prolific writer, who refused to face a portrait of the founding father, Dr. Sun Yat-sen, and instead chose to face his own picture, to take the oath.

Li had earlier issued an open letter to all his colleagues in which he criticized the contents of the oath that legislators must take when being sworn in, saying that they are the legacy of the previous Kuomintang regime. He also said the portions of the oath asking the lawmakers "not to be corrupt" and "not to accept bribes" are "ridiculous" and should be abrogated.

After the swearing-in ceremony, the most important matter on the legislators' agenda was the election of a speaker and a vice speaker of the legislature, set for 10: 30 a.m. and 2: 30 p.m., respectively. The voting for each is expected to take two hours, and the counting should take 30 minutes.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) the People First Party (PFP) said after demanding that its legislators toe the party line or face party discipline that it is optimistic about its candidate, incumbent speaker Wang Jin-pyng, being re-elected.
Legislator Ker Chien-ming, candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said "the result will not be final until the last minute."
Regarding its vice speakership candidate, the "pan-blue alliance" said that "the situation of David J. C. Chung is stable" and that it is hoped that he can pass the first round of voting.

The DPP has yet to announce its candidate for the vice speakership, and the DPP legislative caucus said that it is not ruling out the possibility of Ker running for vice speakership in the hopes that he can win by a slim margin.
The "pan-blue alliance" commands a slim majority of 114 seats in the 225-member legislature, while the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, has 101 seats.

The red carpet was rolled out for the new legislators in the swearing-in ceremony in the morning, with Wang and Chung walking the red carpet hand-in-hand to drum up support for their bid for the speakership and vice speakership.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG JIN-PYNG RE-ELECTED LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) was re-elected Tuesday by defeating his opponent, Ker Chien-ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , 123-101 in a vote held by the sixth Legislative Yuan shortly after its members were sworn in.

Wang, 64, was able to win thanks to the support of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party, which demanded that all members toe the party line or face expulsion from the alliance, as well as of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU). Wang has held the post since 1999.
The "pan-blue alliance" commands a slim majority of 114 seats in the 225-seat legislature.
Ker obtained all 101 votes of the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) . The DPP has 89 seats in the legislature, and the TSU has 12 seats.
The DPP, which has yet to announce its candidate for vice speakership, is not ruling out the possibility of having Ker run for the post. The vice speakership election is set for 2:30 p.m.
If Ker runs, he will face David J. C. Chung of the People First Party, who has the support of the "pan-blue alliance."
During the speakership election, all of the lawmakers, except for Legislator Li Ao, displayed their ballots to show that they had supported their party's candidate.
Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the KMT said he was surprised to see that he himself got a vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Chinese syllabus from Pr1 to Sec 4 cut.
The Ministry of Education has slashed the syllabus of all Chinese Language students from Primary 1 to Secondary 4, including those doing Higher Chinese, with immediate effect.
The cutback is most severe in two key years. In Primary 6, it has been reduced by 61 per cent; in Secondary 4, 27 per cent.
However, there will be no change in the exam format for the Primary School Leaving Examination and the O levels.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Employment increased by 66,200 for all of last year.
Employment increased by 66,200 for all of 2004, raising the total number of people employed to a record high of 2.2 million, the Manpower Ministry said on Monday.
The large increase meant the economy had more than made up for the 35,900 jobs lost in the three years before 2004, the government said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ADVOCATES HUMBLE GOVERNANCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that only a humble ruling party can request that the opposition rationally oversee the work of the government.
Chen's remarks came following the swearing-in ceremony presided over by the president for the members of the new Cabinet at the Presidential Office the same day.

Voicing his expectations concerning the new legislature and new administration as well as inter-party reconciliation and policy decision-making processes, Chen said that the Taiwan people have clearly expressed since the end of last December's legislative elections their strong will for solidarity and stability rather than division and contention in the country.
The members of the new Legislative Yuan were also sworn in Tuesday.
Chen said that all the political parties should work to realize the people's wish by resolving their political differences and striving for stability and prosperity for the country.

The president noted that he expressed in his New Year's Day speech that the administration must undergo self-examination and govern the nation humbly. Only by doing so will the administration be qualified to create a climate for inter-party reconciliation and harmony.

Chen said the ruling party has the responsibility to bridge the differences among the various parties and work for consensus in order to allow the government to operate smoothly for the well-being of the people.
He also said that humble governance means listening to different opinions and actively inviting the opposition to particiate in the decision-making process.

With the swearing in of the new legislature and the new Cabinet, Chen said he hopes that their can be inter-party dialogue and consultations so that Taiwan can march toward a brighter and more peaceful future.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREEN CAMP' SELECTS TSU LAWMAKER AS VICE SPEAKERSHIP CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), reached consensus early Tuesday on fielding Huang Tsung-yuan of the TSU as the camp's candidate in the Legislative Yuan vote for a new vice speaker set for 2:30 p.m.

Huang, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, said in the hours before the vote that TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang informed him that he would represent the "pan-green camp" to run for the vice speakership against David J. C. Chung of the People First Party (PFP) , the candidate supported by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP.

Knowing that the "pan-blue alliance" commands a majority of 114 seats in the 225-member legislature, Huang said that it will be a "daunting task" to win the vice speakership but added that the "pan-green camp" should not be absent from the race.
Huang said his participation means that "the native regime has its own candidate, " adding that this "also represents the solidarity of the native regime."
Earlier in the afternoon, the "pan-green" speakership candidate, DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming, lost to the incumbent speaker, Wang Jin-pyng of the KMT, by a vote of 123-101.
The outcome of the vice speakership vote is expected to be announced by 5 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRANK HSIEH SWORN IN AS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh was sworn in as premier on Tuesday, inaugurating a new Cabinet which Hsieh said will make consultations and coexistence its cornerstone.
With senior presidential adviser Peng Ming-min looking on, Hsieh took over the official seal from Yu Shyi-kun, who has been appointed secretary-general of the Presidential Office.
Hsieh said the new Cabinet must be humble because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is the largest but not the majority party in the Legislative Yuan.
In the future, the Cabinet will step up communication with the opposition, society and the DPP to try to generate a new political landscape in Taiwan through consultations.

Hsieh pledged his Cabinet will give equal priority to economic development, social justice and sustainable environmental protection and will seek to improve law and order, enhance fairness in taxation and resolve problems concerning the National Health Insurance program.

Yu, meanwhile, said -- tongue-in-cheek -- that the heavy burden of the premiership has made him almost one centimeter shorter and that he is greatly relieved now that he is able to let go of the burden.

Over the past three years, Yu said, his Cabinet has succeeded in its efforts in boosting the country's economic growth, lowering the unemployment rate, easing traffic congestion, slowing down the industrial exodus to mainland China, expanding civil rights, downsizing the government and preventing financial crisis.
Yu said he believes Hsieh's new Cabinet will outperform his own.
Immediately after Hsieh's inauguration, members of his Cabinet were sworn in.

Almost all members of Yu's Cabinet have been retained with the exception of Executive Yuan Secretary-General Arthur Iap, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan and Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang.
The ceremony was completed after Iap, Chen and Lee handed over official seals to their successors Lee Ying-yuan, Shih Mao-lin and Chang Chun-yen.
The post of vice premier, however, remained vacant at the time of the swearing-in. Hsieh had previously said that he would not rule out the possibility of naming an opposition member as his deputy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February lost two points to close at 5,980, with 18,624 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March lost three points to finish at 5,985, with 948 contracts traded, while June futures lost five points to close at 5,975, with six contracts traded. September futures lost 19 points to close at 5,885, with 13 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,982 for February, 5,988 for March, 5,980 for June, 5,904 for September and 5,898 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

February TE futures moved up 0.4 points to close at 225.85, with 4,572 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 0.4 points to finish at 225.9, with 157 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 2.25 points to finish at 224.25, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.
February TF futures lost 2.2 points to finish at 1,007, with 3,041 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved down 2.8 points to finish at 1,006, with 336 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December. 3By Nick Huang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 12.69 points to close at 5,981.54.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,015.78 and hit a low of 5,979.92 during trading. A total of 3.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.54 billion (US$2.34 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares gaining 0.1 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent, textile stocks at 0.2 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 595 to 220, with 166 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES FOR NEW BEGINNING OF DIALOGUE AFTER LEGISLATIVE RACE

TEXT.P: Ker Chien-ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who earlier lost the legislative speakership election Tuesday, congratulated Wang Jin-pyng of the Kuomintang (KMT) on his victory, saying that it could usher in better dialogue and cooperation between the ruling and opposition camps.
Accompanied by DPP Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung, Ker made the remarks after he was defeated 101-123 in the speakership election earlier in the day.

Ker thanked the support of the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and its ally, Taiwan Solidarity Union, adding that although faced with a strong contender such as Wang, who is well-rounded and has held the post since 1999, the DPP couldn't surrender without a fight.

He also said that during the election, he thought about a lot of things, including the future of Taiwan. He said that on reflection, it was apparent that the KMT has been mean-spirited, and KMT Chairman Lien Chan has made inappropriate remarks, although he has maintained a good manner throughout.
He urged the KMT not to fall back on its old mindset in these modern times or there will never be reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties.

He also expressed the hope that Wang will play a neutral role, saying that the DPP threw its weight behind Wang for the speakership three years ago, but he lamented there the most serious violations of constitutionality have also occurred over the past three years.

In addition, the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) have only put forward "money-pit" bills, and not those that would benefit the nation or the people, which he termed the "decadence" of the legislature.
He also appealed for an end to the seemingly endless wrangling between the ruling and opposition parties, expressing the hope that Wang helps establish a new culture in the legislature.

Legislator Chang also said that the DPP accepts the decision by the 225 legislators, and wishes that Wang leads legislative reforms to earn accolades from the people and not to repeat the dereliction of duty seen by the refusal to screen the qualifications of the members of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, nominated by President Chen Shui-bian.

Tsai Hao, caucus whip of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (TPSU) , also congratulated Wang on his victory, saying that his winning was natural and the TPSU's support for Wang is only the "icing on the cake."
The TPSU pledged all eight votes for Wang, but in the end seven voted for Wang, and one for Legislator Ting Shou-chung, which Tsai attributed to a possible "mistake" by a new member.
Tsai also said that the TPSU would support David J.C. Chung of the PFP, for the vice speakership, saying that the support for Chung means "lending a hand in need."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS OFFICIALS ARRIVE TO PAY TRIBUTE TO LATE SEF CHIEF

TEXT.P: Three senior officials from mainland China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) arrived in Taipei Tuesday to attend a memorial service for the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu.

ARATS Vice President Sun Yafu, who is concurrently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council, ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei, and Ma Xiaoguang, director of the ARATS research department were greeted by SEF Chief Secretary Lin Shu-min upon their arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway.
Sun and Li said they were requested by ARATS President Wang Daohan to convey his last respects for Koo.
In addition to expressing Wang's esteem for Koo, the duo said, their arrival also symbolized mainland China's respect for the people of Taiwan.
Lin extended a warm welcome to the three ARATS officials, saying that the SEF is grateful that they came to pay their last respects to the late top Taiwan negotiator with mainland China.

Wang, who is in his late 80s, asked Sun and Li to convey a letter of condolence to Koo's widow. During his meeting with his deputies in Shanghai Monday, Wang was quoted as having said that he felt nostalgic about his old friend Koo, and very much wanted to pay his last respects at Koo's memorial, but was prevented from doing so by ill health.
Koo's funeral is scheduled for Wednesday at the National Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.

Koo, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen, held a groundbreaking meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993 in the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades. He died Jan. 3 just days before he would have turned 88.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the framework for the quasi-official SEF and ARATS to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. In 1998, the two envoys met again when Koo traveled to Shanghai and Beijing to boost further rapprochement. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue in July 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as "state-to-state" in nature.

On Sunday, Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the State Council, said in Beijing that the three ARATS officials' Taipei trip is not only aimed at expressing the mainland's esteem for Koo's contributions to the promotion of cross-strait relations but also at symbolizing the mainland's respect for the people of Taiwan.
"We hope the trio will convey our remembrance and condolences during their trip to Taipei," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RE-ELECTED LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HOPES TO PROMOTE INTER-PARTY HARMONY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who was re-elected earlier Tuesday, said that it is "his unshirkable duty" to promote harmony between the ruling and opposition parties for the sake of political stability.

Wang, who defeated Ker Chien-ming, the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 123 votes to 101, said that with the new mandate, he will push for legislative reforms, and formulated "good bills and policies" in the legislature.
He also pledged to "pull out all the stops" for the sake of national solidarity and harmony between legislative caucuses.

But Wang, who is a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), did not reveal whether he would run for KMT chairman or seek a higher position, saying only that he "has not thought about the matter."

Noting that the DPP is extending an olive branch for inter-party reconciliation, Wang also said that he would help promote harmony between the ruling and opposition parties and upgrade the quality and efficiency of the legislature.

President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, National Security Bureau Director Hsieh Shih-min, KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong called to congratulate Wang upon hearing of his re-election.
Wang expressed his appreciation for Lien and Soong, saying that because of the full support of the KMT and the PFP, which combined hold 114 seats, he was able to win a majority in the first round.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAVID J.C. CHUNG ELECTED LEGISLATIVE VICE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator David J.C. Chung was elected vice speaker of the 225-member Legislative Yuan on Tuesday, becoming the first non-Kuomintang (KMT) vice speaker.
Chung garnered 122 votes with the joint support of the PFP and the KMT as well as the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union.
Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Huang Tzung-yuan, the candidate jointly fielded by the TSU and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, had 102 votes.
There was one invalid ballot.
Earlier in the day, two-term speaker Wang Jin-pyng from the KMT was re-elected to his third term with 123 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-NUCLEAR GROUP PRESSES NEW PREMIER TO STICK TO NUCLEAR-FREE IDEAL

TEXT.P: An anti-nuclear group on Tuesday demanded that newly inaugurated Premier Frank Hsieh stick to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) long-standing ideal of making Taiwan a nuclear-free country.

The group led by former DPP Chairman Lin I-hsiung, which is campaigning for a referendum on the country's Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project, marched around the Executive Yuan and Legislative Yuan in demonstration of their appeal soon after Hsieh was sworn in as premier.

Chang Kuo-lung, convener of the group, pointed out that Hsieh had expressed his approval of the nuclear-free ideal when he ran for DPP chairman five years ago and during his re-election bid for Kaohsiung mayor two years ago.
However, Chang said recent remarks by Hsieh indicate that he has somewhat deviated from his original concepts.
In an open letter to Hsieh, the group urged him to make a nuclear-free Taiwan a reality during his term to protect the life and property of the Taiwanese people.

It said amending the Referendum Law and achieving the goal of making Taiwan a nuclear-free country are President Chen Shui-bian's commitments and that the DPP must stick firm to its platform in order to continue to win the support of the people.

Meanwhile, Chang criticized the Executive Yuan as being "totalitarian" for sending riot police to greet the demonstrators at its gate and he urged the ruling party to abandon such an undemocratic mind-set so that Taiwan can become a modern country.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANG MING UNIVERSITY PROFESSOR BECOMES TAIPEI HEALTH CHIEF

TEXT.P: Sung Yen-jen, an anatomy and cellular biology professor at National Yang Ming University, was sworn in as director of the Taipei City Government's department of health Tuesday.

Sung filled the post vacated by Chang Hang, who resigned last month to assume responsibility for a medical incident involving the Taipei Municipal Hospital's Jen Ai branch. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said at the changeover ceremony that as the Taipei Municipal Hospital has long maintained a cooperative program with National Yang Ming University, Sung's joining of his administrative team will be conducive to the integration of the university and the municipal hospital and thus contribute to the upgrading of the city's medical service system.

Chang will from now on exclusively serve as Taipei Municipal Hospital superintendent. Ma said he hopes Chang and Sung will work hand in hand to plug holes in the city's emergency medical service system and streamline its patient transfer operations to prevent recurrence of the tragedy of an abused girl who was first refused admission to the municipal hospital's Jen Ai branch after being critically injured by her abusive father and ended up being transported to a hospital more than 100 kilometers away in the central county of Taichung for surgery.

The 4-year-old girl, surnamed Chiu, was pronounced brain dead and died two weeks after the surgery failed to improve her condition. Her family later donated her kidneys and liver, which have each been successfully transplanted to two female patients.

Chiu's ordeal triggered an uproar which led to an investigation into why the 4-year-old was refused treatment when there were sufficient beds in major Taipei hospitals. The Jen Ai hospital's superintendent and a neurosurgeon at the hospital have been disciplined over the incident.
The Cabinet-level Department of Health announced after the tragic incident that it would overhaul the existing system for patient transfers. The new system will take effect in June.

DOC.TEXT:
Washington Post: Pentagon to Raise Death Benefits.
Under pressure from Congress, the Pentagon yesterday announced plans to increase death payments by nearly $250,000 to families of U.S. troops killed in combat zones.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PARTICIPATE IN APEC ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan will participate in the activities of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum this year, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

Chieh Wen-chi, deputy director of the International Organizations Department said at a news conference Tuesday that APEC will have four regular conferences for senior officials, five conferences for ministers, an annual conference for ministers and a summit of APEC leaders.
Taiwan will join in all of these, most of which will take place in South Korea, the host for the APEC activities this year, Chieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECRUITMENT DRIVE FOR VOLUNTEER SOLDIER GETS GOOD RESPONSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense said Tuesday that the response to a program to recruit young people to serve voluntarily in the military has been enthusiastic, with the number of those registering surpassing 1,000 on the first day.

Fu Mao-yao, director of the defense ministry talent recruitment center, said Tuesday that the ministry intends to recruit 6,561 young people, including 90 women, in February, April, June and August this year.
The military had hoped to register 1,826 people in the first stage between Jan. 31 and Feb. 4, but was pleasantly surprised to find that more than 1,000 signed up on the first day alone, Fu said.

Noting that the defense ministry has only recruited 399 young men over the past two years, he said that the ministry has continued to better the salary and benefits for the recruits, making signing up more attractive to young people.

Volunteer privates will receive a monthly wage of NT$27,105 (US$857.75) and various stipends, and they will enjoy half off for water and electricity bills during the service in the military. After their service period, they can also obtain a retirement pension and government agencies will assist them in gaining professional licenses related to their posts.

Fu said that because of the generous offer, the recruitment center has received many inquiries recently, and that there have been more than 17,000 hits on the Web site set up by the ministry in less than a month.

Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien announced last week that under a conscription system reform program, the mandatory military service period will be shortened from the current 22 months to 18 months, effective July 1, while recruitment of volunteer soldiers will be accelerated in the years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO EARTHQUAKES RATTLE NORTHEASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two earthquakes with preliminary magnitudes of 5.2 and 5.3 on the Richter scale rattled northeastern Taiwan Tuesday, according to the Central Weather Bureau.

Weather bureau officials said that the first tremor hit at 9: 59 a.m., with its epicenter located 155 kilometers south of the Nanao seismology station in the northeastern county of Ilan at a depth of 8.2 kilometers.

The earthquake was felt as an intensity of 5.0 in Hualien County and Ilan County; 3.0 in Ilan City and Taoyuan County; 2.0 in Hualien City, Nantou County, Taichung County and Taipei County; 1.0 in Taipei City, Miaoli County, Keelung City, Miaoli City, Changhua City, Tainan County and Chiayi City and Hsinchu, the officials said.
The second earthquake took place at 12: 56 p.m., with its epicenter situated 10.6 kilometers north of the Nanao seismology station at a depth of 74.9 kilometers, the official said.

The temblor had an intensity of 3.0 in Ilan County, Hualien County, Nantou County and Taichung County; 2.0 in Taoyuan County, Hualian City; and 1.0 in Ilan City, Taipei County, Changhua County and Yunlin County and Miaoli, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI PERFORMS BRILLIANTLY IN 2004

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) made significant progress in terms of its research and development and operations in 2004 and will continue to promote foresighted research this year to create new opportunities for Taiwan, ITRI President Johnsee Lee said Tuesday.
Lee pointed out that the ITRI obtained patents for a record 1,146 technologies in 2004, which represented a rise of nearly 50 percent from 2003.
While the volume of value-added technology services increased 44 percent from 2003, that of industrial services also rose 20 percent, Lee said.
In addition, the ITRI assisted with the establishment of six new enterprises last year and successfully brokered 325 new investment projects worth NT$19.3 billion (US$6.08 billion), Lee said.
Also in 2004, the ITRI set up the Creativity Lab to encourage the innovative application of technologies and the Technology Transfer Center to seek to commercialize technologies, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TAKE PART IN WORLD PHYSICS YEAR ACTIVITIES: PSROC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Physics Society of the Republic of China (PSROC) will participate in the 2005 "International Year of Physics," the society's chairman said Tuesday.
Chang Ching-juei made the remarks during the PSROC annual meeting held from Feb. 1-3 at National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung.

Chang noted the international event is a worldwide celebration of physics that was initiated by the European Physics Society to mark the 100th anniversary of Albert Einstein's release of his three groundbreaking papers on photoelectric effect, Brownian motion and the theory of relativity that led to his most famous equation -- E = mc2.

This year's centenary will also be the 50th anniversary of Einstein's death, he said, adding that the global "Year of Physics" is also dedicated to efforts to give impetus to education and research in physics, as well as to public understanding of physics.
According to the PSROC, Taiwan will take part in a so-called "lighting up the world with the light of physics" slated for April 18.

On that day, Chang said, the PSROC and the Opto-Electronics and Systems Laboratories of the Industrial Technology Research will jointly switch on a laser beam at the National Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei, and then move the light around the island.
Similar beams will be set off at the same time in other countries around the world after the first is turned on at Einstein's former residence in Princeton, New Jersey.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW SECRETARY-GENERAL OF DPP BEGINS WORK ON WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Lee Yi-yang, who has been named secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , will begin Wednesday to handle the daily affairs of the party as its acting chief of staff, acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said Tuesday.

Ker, who has been acting as the party's chief since President Chen Shui-bian resigned from the DPP chairmanship in December, said Lee, who was the director-general of the Central Personnel Administration in the Cabinet of former Premier Yu Shyi-kun, is supposed to take over on Feb. 15 when the new chairman, Su Tseng-chang, takes the reins of the DPP.

However, Ker said, routine party affairs cannot be left unattended as former secretary-general Chang Chun-hsiung has been appointed as a non-elected lawmaker while his lieutenant, Lee Ying-yuan, has assumed his new job as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan.
In order to address this problem, Ker said he has asked Lee to attend to DPP affairs as acting secretary-general before he is officially sworn in on Feb. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER'S PERFORMANCE WINS PUBLIC APPROVAL: POLL

TEXT.P: Most respondents to a recent poll expressed approval of the achievements of former Premier Yu Shyi-kun over the past three years, with 57 percent saying he helped President Chen Shui-bian win re-election last year, according to the results of the survey released Tuesday.

According to the survey, conducted by the Taiwan Thinktank, 48.9 percent of the respondents were impressed by the transport development projects promoted by Yu, while 42.3 percent were impressed by his efforts to promote culture and tourism and 38.1 percent were impressed by his efforts in environmental protection.
Meanwhile, approximately 68 percent of the respondents said they support the appointment of Frank Hsieh as the new premier.

More than 70 percent of the respondents said they felt it will be Hsieh's priority during his term to promote economic development, educational reform and social welfare, while 69.9 percent said the "Cabinet of consultation and stability" that Hsieh has pledged to set up will be helpful to inter-party cooperation and 11.9 percent disagreed.
The survey was conducted from Jan. 26-27 among 1,096 adults, with a 3 percent margin of error.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Vote Over, Iraq Faces Task of Forming a Government.
The ballots are still being counted, but the hard bargaining to form a new Iraqi government has begun.
The Wall Street Journal: Military Is Facing Wide Budget Problem.
With military costs rising in Iraq, the top U.S. commander in Baghdad is facing what he call an "unaffordable" budget gap of at least $4 billion between what Halliburton Co. says it will cost to provide food, housing and other services for U.S. troops for a year and what the government has budgeted.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER NT$900 BILLION APPROVED FOR PRIVATE SECTOR INVESTMENT: MOEA

TEXT.P: A total of NT$903.3 billion (US$28.3 billion) worth of investment from the private sector was approved last year for 2,511 plans in the country's manufacturing sector and relevant services, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials reported Tuesday.
The figure greatly exceeds the NT$840.4 billion target set by the government early last year, statistics compiled by the ministry show.

Some NT$551 billion has already been plunged into investment projects, while about NT$198.7 billion will be in place this year. Around NT$117.4 billion and NT$36.2 billion is slated to be invested in 2006 and 2007, respectively, the officials said.

The Cabinet's flagship "two-trillion, two-star" program lured NT$468 billion worth of investment last year, outpacing the government target of NT$466.9 billion, including NT$270.4 billion for 157 plans in the semiconductor industry, NT$161.7 billion for 56 plans in the flat panel display industry, NT$11.5 billion for 133 projects in the digital content industry and NT$24.3 billion for 140 biotech projects.
The ministry aims to woo NT$866 billion for fresh private sector investments this year, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNAR NEW YEAR CHARTER FLIGHTS POPULAR: CARRIERS

TEXT.P: With the special Lunar New Year holiday charter flights kicking off between Taiwan and mainland China last Saturday, Taiwan-bound flights from Shanghai have been extremely popular, aviation companies said Tuesday.

Tickets on flights from Shanghai to Taiwan offered by Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL), Far East Air Transport Corp., Trans Asia Airways and the mainland's Xiamen Airlines have all been fully booked by mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families wishing to spend the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday at home, they said.
For instance, more than 300 seats on a CAL A330-300 flight slated to take off from Shanghai for Taipei Saturday have all been reserved, with a large number of passengers on a waiting list.
Xiamen Airlines will provide the next charter flight Wednesday from Guangzhou to Kaohsiung, with about 80 percent of its tickets booked. However, only a few tickets on the return trip have been sold.

On Friday, Trans Asia Airways will inaugurate its maiden charter flight from Taipei to Guangzhou. Only some 20 percent of the tickets on the Guangzhou-bound flight have been sold, while nearly 80 percent of the tickets on the Taipei-bound flight have been booked.

On Saturday, Far East Air Transport Corp. will also launch its maiden charter service between Taipei and Guangzhou, with the Guangzhou-Taipei flight fully loaded. Seats on its Feb. 7 round-trip flights connecting Taipei and Shanghai have also all been booked.

The special charter flights were designed exclusively for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their dependents flying between the two sides -- Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai, Guangzhou and Beijing in mainland China -- from Jan. 29 - Feb. 20.

A total of nine flights were provided by eight aviation companies from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the first day of the service, which marked the historic landings of mainland carriers on Taiwan soil in more than 55 years.
Direct transport, trade and postal links across the strait have been banned since 1949, when Taiwan and the mainland separated in the wake of a civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY INVESTIGATING OFFICER'S SUICIDE IN U.S.

TEXT.P: The ashes of a non-commissioned navy officer who committed suicide in the United States last week were brought back to Taiwan Tuesday.

Naval authorities said the Navy General Headquarters (NGH) has assigned staff to assist Chief Petty Officer Wu Chin-chung's family in handling their affairs. Wu's ashes have been placed in a makeshift memorial hall at a military hospital near the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan.
The NGH has also formed a special task force to investigate the possible cause of Wu's suicide, a Naval Fleet Command official said.
"We'll get to the bottom of the incident and find out who should be held responsible for it," the official said.

Wu was a member of the Republic of China Navy staff working at a U.S. shipyard in South Carolina in preparation for taking delivery of four Kidd-class destroyers that Taiwan purchased from the United States in 2001. The four destroyers were originally built for the Shah of Iran in 1979, but were later mothballed when Iran canceled the deal. The four warships are being refurbished and are undergoing maintenance in the United States before being delivered to Taiwan.

Wu was found to have strangled himself aboard one of the destroyers by his colleagues Jan. 26, according to naval sources. Wu's colleagues immediately performed emergency first aid and informed their superiors of the incident.
After receiving the information from the U.S. naval base, the Naval Fleet Command immediately notified Wu's family in Taiwan of the tragedy and sent staff members to provide assistance.

In the past, Taiwan has sent special naval teams to the United States to receive training and take delivery of U.S.-built warships. As the work is very complicated and stressful, military sources said, some incidents involving naval staff have been reported in the past.

Wu's grandmother was heartbroken when she saw her grandson's ashes at Kaohsiung International Airport. Wu's uncle said Wu had faxed a suicide note to his parents, complaining about his extremely heavy workload, long working hours and his superiors' frequent fault-finding. The uncle said the naval authorities should find out the cause of his suicide.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY DENSEST-POPULATED ADMINISTRATIVE AREA: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City is the most densely populated administrative area in Taiwan, with 9,849 residents per square kilometer registered in 2004, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Taipei City ranked second with 9,649 residents per square kilometer and Taichung City occupied third place with 6,249 residents per square kilometer, the tallies show.

In comparison with figures posted in 2003, Kaohsiung City 's population density increased by 23 residents per square kilometer last year, while Taichung City's surged by 73 residents per square kilometer and Taipei City's fell by 17 residents per square kilometer.
The population of the Taiwan area, including the two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, totaled 22.68 million as of the end of last year, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES LEGISLATURE ON ELECTION OF NEW CHIEFS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian relayed his congratulations Tuesday through his chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, to Wang Jin-pyng and David Chung on their election as president and vice president, respectively, of the Legislative Yuan.
Yu quoted the president as urging Wang and Chung to help reconcile the differences between the ruling and opposition parties in the legislature and to facilitate their communication and dialogue.
The president said the public has high expectations for the legislative president and vice president and that he hopes Wang and Chung will serve in their posts with new ideas and concepts.
The president also congratulated the 225 lawmakers sworn in Tuesday, urging them to enact bills efficiently and set a good example for future legislatures.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER UNDERLINES COEXISTENCE AS CORE VALUE OF ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh unveiled coexistence as the core value of his administration Tuesday in the first Cabinet meeting after his swearing-in earlier in the day.
The former mayor of Kaohsiung City told his Cabinet that coexistence means tolerance toward different views and does not run contrary to the idea of giving Taiwan predominance over everything else.
Hsieh said his administration will follow the principle of "live and let live" and iron out its political differences with the opposition parties through negotiation and compromise.
He said coexistence will not damage the principle of Taiwan predominance and compromise will not lead to the regression of the country.

Giving Taiwan priority will not prohibit people from showing their individual preferences for other countries like Japan, South Korea, or even mainland China, although Taiwan's interests must be served first should there be a conflict of interests between Taiwan and those other countries, Hsieh went on.
Only coexistence can nurture a sense of "esprit de corps" among the Taiwan people, according to the premier.
Hsieh said Taiwan's status as an independent political entity should be established by action rather than through fruitless quarrels.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN GROUP PLANNING WIND POWER INVESTMENT IN CHIAYI

TEXT.P: Chiayi Magistrate Chen Ming-wen agreed Tuesday in principle to a wind energy investment project proposed by the Germany-based Infra Vest Group, which plans to set up 97 wind turbines in coastal areas of the southern Taiwan county.
Chen gave the nod to the investment plan with conditions attached after hearing a briefing by Infra Vest officials.

The magistrate stipulated that the group must cooperate unconditionally in future infrastructure construction and must fully communicate with local residents and environmentalists. He also demanded that the group come up with compensation and feed-back measures before moving into further negotiations.

According to Infra Vest officials, the group has decided to invest NT$16 billion (US$500 million) in setting up 97 wind turbines in Chiayi's coastal areas after carrying out various in-depth inspections of the area.

Stressing that the Tungshih and Putai areas are extremely rich in wind power and resources, they said the group is planning to install six turbines there in the initial stage. Each will have the capacity of between 12 million and 18 million watts, generating 51 million kilowatt-hours per year, they explained.

They said the plan will cause no pollution, low noise, and no exhaust gas or waste water, and pointed out that electricity generated by wind energy is increasing at a fast pace of between 15 percent and 30 percent every year in advanced countries such as Germany and Denmark.

In these strictly eco-friendly nations, wind energy has largely replaced traditional coal, gas, nuclear power or other fossil fuel for power generation, they said, adding that the group has made similar investment plans in Brazil, France, mainland China, Spain, Sweden and Turkey.
Investment in wind energy should bring fourth profit. This is necessary for a sustainable development of renewable energies, a distinct goal of many governments, Infra Vest said at its Website.

It is our strong belief that this goal can only be achieved by proper plans and commercially viable projects that can also create local economic benefits, it said, calling wind energy clean, competitive and inexhaustible that will heed public concerns over environmental protection and conservation.

Infra Vest has already held a seminar in Putai township to explained the investment plan to local residents. It has gained security confirmations from the Ministry of National Defense and the Civil Aeronautics Administration, as well as initial land use approval from the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau.

At present, the state-run Taiwan Power Company maintains four wind power turbines in offshore Penghu County and is considering adding another four due to its better-than-expected capacity, in line with the Kyoto Pact that will become effective this summer in several parts of the world to cut emissions of greenhouse gas.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 2 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, Feb. 2:

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JUSTICE MINISTER VOWS TO CRACK DOWN ON CRIME

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will pool the resources of the prosecution, investigation, police and coast guard authorities to fight corruption, violence, drug trafficking, sexual assault, telephone fraud and financial crimes, its new minister said Tuesday.
Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin made the pledge at his first news conference after assuming office earlier in the day.

Noting that the public have high expectations of the MOJ and its subordinate prosecution and investigation agencies, Shih said he will reinforce coordination among various law enforcement authorities to crack down on crime.
Priority will be given to economic crimes and cross-border drug trafficking because they damage social justice and tarnish the national image, he said.

Pointing out that economic and financial crimes can directly affect the average investor's interests and rights, Shih said the MOJ will organize more professional training courses for criminal investigators and prosecutors to upgrade their abilities to investigate and collect evidence.
"By so doing, we'll be able to better maintain overall economic and market order and achieve social justice," Shih said.

He further said the manpower and equipment of the drug-fighting center under the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) will be expanded to facilitate a crackdown on drug trafficking and abuse.

Amid mounting concern about women and children falling victim to domestic violence and sexual abuse, Shih said the MOJ will cooperate with police, social welfare and medical administrative agencies to create a safer living environment and better protect victims of crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS LOOKS FORWARD TO POSITIVE DEVELOPMENT IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A senior official from mainland China's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) said in Taipei Tuesday he hopes cross-strait relations can develop in a positive direction.
ARATS Vice President Sun Yafu made the remarks after paying his tribute to the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, who used to be Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China.

Sun, who is concurrently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the mainland's State Council, ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei, and Ma Xiaoguang, director of the ARATS research department, arrived in Taiwan earlier in the day to attend Koo's funeral scheduled for Wednesday.
Sun said he and Li are representing ARATS President Wang Daohan to attend Koo's memorial service.
Shortly after their arrival, the three ARATS officials paid a visit to Koo's home and convey Wang's letter of condolence to Koo's widow.
"We have conveyed Wang's heartfelt esteem to Koo," Sun said, adding that Wang gave high marks for Koo's outstanding contribution to promoting cross-strait relations and dialogue.
Sun said he has also conveyed TAO Director Chen Yun-lin's esteem and remembrance of Koo.
Asked whether his arrival could usher in a new era in cross-strait relations, Sun said he would not touch on any cross-strait issue during his brief visit.
"We are here simply to pay our last respects for Koo," Sun said. But he added that he hoeps cross-strait ties can move in a positive direction in the long run.
The three ARATS officials were greeted by SEF Chief Secretary Lin Shu-min upon their arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Lin extended a warm welcome to the three ARATS officials, saying that the SEF is grateful that they came to pay their last respects to the late top Taiwan negotiator with mainland China.

Wang, who is in his late 80s, asked Sun and Li to convey a letter of condolence to Koo's widow. During his meeting with his deputies in Shanghai Monday, Wang was quoted as having said that he felt nostalgic about his old friend Koo, and very much wanted to pay his last respects at Koo's memorial, but was prevented from doing so by ill health.

Koo, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen, held a groundbreaking meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993 in the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades. He died Jan. 3 just days before he would have turned 88.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the framework for the quasi-official SEF and ARATS to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. In 1998, the two envoys met again when Koo traveled to Shanghai and Beijing to boost further rapprochement. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue in July 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as "state-to-state" in nature.

On Sunday, Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council, said in Beijing that the three ARATS officials' Taipei trip is not only aimed at expressing the mainland's esteem for Koo's contributions to the promotion of cross-strait relations but also at symbolizing the mainland's respect for the people of Taiwan.
"We hope the trio will convey our remembrance and condolences during their trip to Taipei," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL TAPPED FOR DEPUTY PREMIER REQUIRES KMT APPROVAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang said Tuesday that he will serve as deputy premier in the administration of Premier Frank Hsieh only with the approval of the KMT.

In an interview with a local radio station Tuesday, Chiang, who has been tapped by Hsieh as his favorite choice for his deputy, said negotiations between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the KMT on overall policy is necessary before he will agree to serve in the administration.

As a technocrat, Chiang has accumulated wide experience in the economic sector during the period of KMT rule. He gave Hsieh a favorable comment recently, describing him as a pragmatic and respectful political leader.
Meanwhile, KMT lawmaker Lee Chia-ching claimed that the only way his party will allow Chiang to join the administration is for the DPP to agree to a coalition with the KMT.

If Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang, who is set to take the post of DPP chairman, pay a call on KMT Chairman Lien Chan before Chinese New Year, "it is quite possible that Lien will give a green light" to Chiang's appointment, he went on.

A coalition between the DPP and the KMT would give the government a broad basis, Lee said, adding that if Chiang joins the administration as deputy premier, "the premier should give him a free hand in dealing with economic affairs for the benefit of the country."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EYES KMT VICE CHAIRMAN FOR DEPUTY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh confirmed Tuesday that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang is still his first choice for deputy premier.
In an interview with the media, Hsieh said he has approached Chiang, as well as the KMT, about the possibility of Chiang serving in his Cabinet and is waiting for a response.

Noting that Chiang has served in various posts in the economic sector of the government as well as a vice president of the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said his economic background would help the Cabinet to deal with economic issues and his relationship with the lawmakers would help rally their support for Executive Yuan policy.

Some KMT heavyweights had suggested that Chiang should join the administration as a representative of his party rather than as an individual, and Hsieh said he was trying to find out from the KMT the exact meaning of this statement.
The issue is not pressing, but should be settled before the Executive Yuan presents its general administrative report to the Legislative Yuan two weeks from now, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S CROSS-STRAIT POLICY EXPECTED TO REMAIN UNCHANGED IN 2ND TERM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States' policy on cross-Taiwan Strait relations is expected to remain unchanged in President George W. Bush's second term, the White House spokesman said Tuesday.

White House spokesman Scott McClellan was asked at a regular press briefing whether the White House has any comments on China and Taiwan exchanging the first direct cross-strait flights in 56 years and what President Bush's plans are in his second term regarding Taiwan.

McClellan answered that the president's views are still the same. "They have not changed, " he said, adding that "certainly dialogue -- cross-strait dialogue is important for moving forward to resolve some of these issues."
"But the president's views on Taiwan and China are very well known, and they remain unchanged," McClellan noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 2, or the 24th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine-year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
2003: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian offers condolences over the loss of space shuttle Columbia and the seven astronauts aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

The Times: Vaccine could wipe out deadly cervical cancer.
Every woman in Britain could be protected against cervical cancer by a vaccine available within five years.
Two vaccines against the second deadliest cancer among women under 35 have proved so successful in trials that experts are convinced that they will soon be licensed for widespread use.
They prevent infection with strains of the human papilloma virus (HPV) that are known to cause more than 70 per cent of cervical cancers, and promise to cut Britain's annual deaths from it to less than 300.
Financial Times: Barroso to focus on jobs and growth.
Jose Manuel Barroso will on Wednesday set out a more business-friendly programme as president of the European Commission, when he presents a plan for economic reform in the European Union that focuses heavily on jobs, research and growth.
EU targets on social policy and the environment will take a back seat, as Mr Barroso attempts to persuade national leaders to adopt and implement national growth plans when they meet for an EU economic summit in Brussels next month.
In an interview with the Financial Times ahead of Wednesday's presentation, Mr Barroso outlined an agenda that seeks to boost competition, free Europe's single market in services and regulate only where necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PAYS TRIBUTE TO TOP CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that seeking consensus is the spirit of the groundbreaking "Koo-Wang talks" of 1993 and also the most precious legacy left to the people across the Taiwan Strait by the late Koo Chen-fu, who once served as Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China.

The president made the remarks at the memorial service held at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Wednesday for Koo, who died Jan. 3 at the age of 88. Koo, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen, served as the chairman of the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) from 1991 to 2004.

In 1993, Koo met with Wang Daohan, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , in Singapore for the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades, better known as the landmark "Koo-Wang talks."
At the memorial service, President Chen offered his condolences to Koo's family and praised Koo's exceptional contributions to Taiwan's economic prosperity as well as cross-strait exchanges.
Chen said that as SEF chairman, Koo had been on the frontline of dialogue and communications with mainland China, helping usher cross-strait exchanges onto a regular track.

The 1993 "Koo-Wang talks" were an unprecedented ice-breaking rendezvous between top negotiators authorized by the governments of the two sides, while the 1998 "Koo-Wang meeting" was a historical event representing a step-forward in cross-strait relations, Chen said.
The president lamented the fact that cross-strait dialogue was suspended indefinitely later in 1998 as a result of changes in the political climate on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

He quoted Koo as saying at the 10th anniversary of the "Koo-Wang talks" in April 2003 that because of political differences, it is imperative that the two sides continue to engage in dialogue based on respect for each other's differing opinions.

He added that bearing Koo's legacy in mind, the two sides should re-start the long-stalled dialogue and thus unveil a new era in cross-strait relations, which will pave the way for eventual peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Alluding to Koo's renowned career as an amateur Peking opera singer, Chen noted that the current cross-strait impasse is like a drama on stage. He said the key point is whether the leaderships of the two sides will have the wisdom and insight to jointly face the cross-strait situation and try to resolve their differences so that they can, in the words of Koo, "leave the audience impressed when they leave the stage."
Finally, Chen said that he was told by Koo during their last brief meeting late last year that one thing which always preoccupied him was not being able to meet with Wang again.
In this spirit, Chen said that he extends his personal invitation to Wang in the hope that Wang will come to visit Taiwan at anytime in the future at his convenience.

Chen also offered his welcome to the two ARATS senior officials -- Vice President Sun Yafu and Secretary-General Li Yafei -- who arrived in Taipei Tuesday to pay their last respects to Koo on behalf of ARATS President Wang Daohan. Sun is also currently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council.

Officials and dignitaries also on hand at Wednesday's memorial service included Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Democratic Progress Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party Chairman James Soong, Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Ching-chiang, and Douglas Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office, as well as more than 50 Japanese politicians and business executives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO VISIT KMT CHAIRMAN OVER VICE PREMIER APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday he will visit opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to discuss his offer to name one of the KMT's vice chairmen, P.K. Chiang, as his deputy.
In an interview with a local radio station, Hsieh said he hopes the meeting can take place before next week's Lunar New Year holiday.
Hsieh said he contacted Chiang indirectly to extend his offer and Chiang said he must obtain his party's approval before he can accept the offer.
The KMT has previously ruled that no party member will be allowed to join the Cabinet in their personal capacity and that they will have to do so as a representative of the party.

Hsieh said he has no idea if the KMT requires simply its approval or party-to-party negotiations with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for such an appointment and that he hopes the meeting with Lien will help.

He pointed out that he promised to visit Lien when he assumed the position of DPP chairman in August 2000, but this promise was never realized because of the rivalry between the ruling and opposition parties.
Hsieh first disclosed Tuesday that Chiang was still his first choice for vice premier and that he was waiting for a response from Chiang and the KMT.
Asked about the issue by the press earlier in the day, Lien said he had not considered the matter.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, another KMT vice chairman, said Hsieh also expressed his hope of recruiting Chiang to the Cabinet during a meeting with him the previous day, but he had not discussed the details with Lien.
However, KMT legislative caucus leader Huang Teh-fu insisted that any arrangement for KMT members to join the Cabinet must be based on a party-to-party agreement.
Huang said that if the DPP had been sincere about inviting any KMT members to join the Cabinet, it should have negotiated with the KMT before the Cabinet lineup was finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT IMPASSE THAWING BUT ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT: MAC

TEXT.P: Several recent developments indicate that the cross-Taiwan Strait political impasse has thawed a little, although there is still room for improvement, Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland China policy said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu was referring to Beijing's decision to send two senior officials to Taipei to attend a memorial service for Koo Chen-fu, the late chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , who died Jan. 3 at the age of 88.
Wu was also referring to the recent opening of direct cross-strait charter flight services for the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 Lunar New Year holiday period, the first of their kind in 56 years.

Despite these latest developments, Wu said, cross-strait relations are still fragile, with Beijing drafting an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, continuing to contain Taiwan in the international community and continuing to mount pressure on Taiwan militarily.

President Chen Shui-bian led the country to pay tribute to Koo at the memorial service held at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall that day. During the service, Chen praised Koo's unparalleled contributions to Taiwan's economic prosperity as well as cross-strait exchanges in his capacity as a business tycoon and as Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland.

The president also extended an invitation at the service to Koo's counterpart in Beijing, Wang Daohan, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to visit Taiwan. Koo and Wang met in Singapore in 1993 for the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades, better known as the landmark "Koo-Wang talks."

Commenting on Chen's invitation, Wu reiterated that the MAC has on numerous occasions, including several during his tenure, invited Wang to visit Taiwan. Noting that the invitation still stands, Wu said the government will roll out the red carpet for him should he decide to pay a visit.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the arrival of two ARATS senior officials -- Vice President Sun Yafu and Secretary-General Li Yafei -- to pay their last respects to Koo on behalf of ARATS President Wang Daohan, indicates that cross-strait relations are improving. Sun is also currently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council.
Wang Jin-pyng said that should the opportunity present itself, he would not exclude the possibility of visiting the mainland to help facilitate cross-strait reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ISSUES WARNING ON OUTBREAK OF MENINGITIS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) officials cautioned people planning to travel to mainland China Wednesday about an outbreak of epidemic cerebrospinal meningitis in Anhui, Hebei, Henan, Jiangsu and Sichuan provinces.
The officials urged travelers to avoid going to crowded places to prevent infection and to consider vaccination if they plan to stay on the mainland for an extended period.
According to the DOH, 800 to 1,000 doses of vaccine are available through any Center for Disease Control (CDC) office and should be obtained two weeks before departure for the mainland.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting said the DOH has notified the Veterans Affairs Commission to pass on the message to retired soldiers who plan to visit their relatives on the mainland during the Lunar New Year holiday.
Lin pointed out that the symptoms of epidemic cerebrospinal meningitis are similar to those of flu and that treatment with anti-biotics can help lower the fatality rate of the disease.

With a prevalence rate of less than 100 in every 100,000 people, the mainland is not one of the epidemic areas of epidemic cerebrospinal meningitis announced by the World Health Organization, according to the DOH.
While approximately 2,200 to 2,600 cases of epidemic cerebrospinal meningitis were reported annually from 2001 to 2004 on the mainland, a total of 546 cases have been reported over the past month.
In Taiwan, 20 to 45 cases are reported every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 37.15 points to close at 6,018.69.

The bourse opened at 6,016.33, with the index fluctuating between 6,064.66 and 6,010.76 during trading. A total of 4 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.71 billion (US$2.94 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement as well as machinery and electronics stocks moving up the most at 1.0 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, construction issues at 0.6 percent, and textile stocks at 0.3 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 382 to 379, with 223 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN TO MEET PRESIDENT ON INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Wednesday he will meet with President Chen Shui-bian after the Chinese New Year holiday to discuss the political situation and inter-party reconciliation.

Soong made the remarks after attending a memorial service for the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, a respected business tycoon known for his diplomatic acumen who served as Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China.

Before the service at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall, Soong shook hands with Chen to express mutual goodwill. Chen delivered an eulogy in recognition of Koo's contributions to Taiwan, including promoting cross-Taiwan Strait relations, at the memorial service.

Soong said he plans to meet with Chen after the Lunar New Year to exchange views on issues regarding reconciliation among the nations' three major parties -- the PFP, the Kuomintang and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- as well as the current political situation.
Asked whether he will succeed Koo as SEF chairman, Soong did not respond.
PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung said later that to the best of his understanding, the DPP administration has not brought such a proposal to Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained 43 points to close at 6,023, with 35,326 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March rose 42 points to finish at 6,027, with 2,313 contracts traded, while June futures gained 60 points to close at 6,031, with five contracts traded. September futures moved up 46 points to close at 5,931, with 27 contracts traded, while December futures gained 64 points to close at 5,960.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,980 for February, 5,985 for March, 5,971 for June, 5,985 for September and 5,896 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

February TE futures moved up two points to close at 227.85, with 4,691 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 1.30 points to finish at 227.20, with 445 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 0.15 points to finish at 226.20, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

February TF futures gained 9.2 points to finish at 1,016.2, with 6,361 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 8.8 points to finish at 1,014.8, with 935 contracts traded.
