Washington Post: Infighting Cited at Homeland Security; Squabbles Blamed for Reducing Effectiveness.
As its leadership changes for the first time, the Department of Homeland Security remains hampered by personality conflicts, bureaucratic bottlenecks and an atmosphere of demoralization, undermining its ability to protect the nation against terrorist attack, according to current and former administration officials and independent experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER PLEDGES TO CONTINUE ANTI-CORRUPTION EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Newly inaugurated Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin pledged Wednesday to continue the government's anti-corruption operations.

Shih said he hopes the anti-corruption operations center under the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court will be institutionalized soon to better distinguish its function from that of the anti-corruption task forces under district prosecutors' offices.

Shih proposed that the organic law be amended to include a clause stipulating that the anti-corruption operations center will be responsible for investigations during the second and third trials of a corruption case.

Trying to clarify reports that suggested the ministry has earmarked a NT$7 million (US$218,750) budget for the anti-corruption operations center this year, Shih said the budget is not for the center but for the ministry's anti-corruption services as a whole.
He pointed out that the center is an ad hoc organization and does not receive any regular funding.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.099 to close at NT$31.699.
A total of US$767 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.798 and hit a low of NT$31.660.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR PREDICTED TO STRENGTHEN 21 PERCENT IN 2005

TEXT.P: Lehman Brothers Bank, a global investment bank, predicted Wednesday that Asian currencies, including the new Taiwan dollar, will largely pick up in value against the U.S. dollar in 2005.

Speaking at a world economic meeting in Taipei, the bank's leading economists forecast that the U.S. dollar will continue to weaken in the future due to the country's huge federal and trade deficits and a low savings rate. Such a situation, they said, will in turn prop up the values of Asian currencies this year rather than the euro, which surged sharply last year.

They forecast that the new Taiwan dollar will strengthen the most against the greenback by 21 percent in the months to come on the grounds that the local currency appreciated less than the Japanese yen and the South Korean won last year.

The new Taiwan dollar finished at 31.699 against the greenback in the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday. The local currency has appreciated against the U. S. unit by more than 6 percent over the past year.
At the same time, they contended that mainland China's renminbi will ease its peg to the U.S. dollar to gain in value in a range between 5 percent and 10 percent in the initial stage.

At the end of this year, the yen and the won will climb to 90 and to 900 to the U.S. dollar, respectively, they said, adding that the Hong Kong dollar will be the sole Asian currency to maintain a fixed currency exchange rate.

Meanwhile, the economists are optimistic about the prospects of Asian economies except for Japan. They estimated that Taiwan's gross domestic product will grow by 5 percent for 2005 and that the Japanese economy will expand by only 0.6 percent.

They opined that Taiwan will still be competitive thanks to its relatively advantageous currency exchange rates and labor division strategy in terms of mainland China. Assessing Taiwan's economic growth rate at 5 percent for 2005, they pointed out, however, that Taiwan's fragile relations with the mainland and a bubble property market that might burst are likely to hinder its economy.

They also gave a positive view about the markets of Hong Kong, the mainland and South Korea, citing reasons such as strong local demand, a booming middle class, fast urbanization, a freer financial market and lavish consumers among the younger generation for their optimism.

They said that mainland China will succeed in a soft landing to stem its high flying economy with an economic growth rate of about 8.8 percent this year and that the mainland will allow its currency to freely float against other currencies in order to strike a balance with a continued influx of foreign investment capital. They predicted that these changes will take place in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CABINET SPOKESMAN SWORN IN AS ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: Former Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai was sworn in as acting Kaohsiung mayor Wednesday.
Chen pledged to continue the policies of former mayor Frank Hsieh and work to develop the port city into the best maritime capital of Taiwan.

He reiterated that he will stabilize the city government's relations with the city council through constant consultation and make the "Kaohsiung experience" a model for other counties and cities around Taiwan.

Chen said the so-called "Kaohsiung experience" established by Hsieh means the replacement of confrontation with consultation and communication and that Hsieh's philosophy of coexistence has made Kaohsiung a more beautiful and efficient city and its residents happier.
Chen said he hopes all city government staff will learn to be creative and innovative and take the initiative to discover and solve problems for residents in the future.
He said he will try his best to exceed Hsieh, whose approval rating stood at as high as 83 percent.

The position of Kaohsiung mayor became vacant after Hsieh was appointed premier by President Chen Shui-bian. It is widely believed that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's decision to name Chen as acting mayor is aimed at paving the way for his bid to run for Kaohsiung mayor in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND ENVOY TO REPORT TAIWAN'S INVITATION TO ARATS CHIEF

TEXT.P: A visiting mainland Chinese envoy said Wednesday he will report Taiwan's invitation to mainland China's top negotiator with the island after his return.

Sun Yafu, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) who is concurrently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council, made the remarks at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport prior to his departure for home.

Sun, ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei and Ma Xiaoguang, director of the ARATS research department, arrived in Taiwan Tuesday to pay their last respects for the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, a respected business tycoon who once served as Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland.

Speaking at Koo's memorial service earlier in the day, President Chen Shui-bian publicly invited Koo's mainland counterpart, ARATS President Wang Daohan, to visit Taiwan. It marked Chen's first public invitation to Wang.
Asked about his view on Chen's goodwill gesture, Sun said he will pass on Taiwan's invitation to Wang.
"We'll report to Mr. Wang Daohan what we saw, heard and felt here," Sun told a pack of reporters following him.

Sun and the two other ARATS officials didn't personally heard Chen's invitation to Wang as they didn't show up at Koo's official memorial service at the National Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall. The trio arrived at the memorial hall around noon to skip meetings with President Chen and other Taiwan political figures.

SEF Secretary-General Liu Teh-hsun who is concurrently vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, and SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng greeted the ARATS officials when they arrived at the memorial hall to pay their tribute to Koo. They shook hands and exchanged courtesy chats. The brief encounter marked the first high-level SEF-ARATS contact since the two sides suspended regular dialogue in mid-1999 over former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "state-to-state" remarks.

Sun and Li were Wang's personal representatives to pay his tribute to Koo. They presented flowers and bowed their heads before Koo's picture. Thye then extended their condolences to Koo's widow, Cecilia Koo, who asked the duo to convey her "thank-you" letter to Wang. Shortly after their arrival in Taipei Tuesday, they handed Wang's letter of condolence to Koo's widow. Wang, who is in his late 80s, said in his letter that he felt nostalgic about his old friend Koo, and very much wanted to pay his last respects at Koo's memorial, but was prevented from doing so by ill health.
Koo held a groundbreaking meeting with Wang in Singapore in 1993 in the first formal cross-strait contact in more than four decades. He died Jan. 3 just days before he would have turned 88.

The historic Koo-Wang meeting laid the framework for the quasi-official SEF and ARATS to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. In 1998, the two envoys met again when Koo traveled to Shanghai and Beijing to boost further rapprochement. However, Beijing unilaterally suspended regular SEF-ARATS dialogue in July 1999, when then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as "state-to-state" in nature.

After all these years, Sun and Li said prior to their departure that they feel more and more that the two sides should continue to promote peaceful and stable cross-strait development and safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait.
"That will help us promote exchanges between both sides and push cross-strait relations to a good, positive direction," Sun said.

For his part, Li said:"We join the people of Taiwan to mourn Mr. Koo Chen-fu. We can feel the respect he enjoyed in Taiwan society. I have been impressed by Koo's active efforts to promote cross-strait relations."
In his eulogy on Koo, President Chen said: "Now it's impossible for Koo and Wang to meet again. But if Chairman Wang's health and time allow, we still welcome him to come and visit Taiwan."

Chen further said the current cross-strait stalemate like a drama. Noting that the curtain will eventually fall, Chen said top leaders on both sides should jointly work for cross-strait peace based on the legacy left by Koo.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Dean Emerging as Likely Chief for Democrats.
Howard Dean is almost assured to be the new leader of the Democratic National Committee after a main rival quit the race.
The Wall Street Journal: American Express Plans To Spin Off Advisory Unit.
American Express Co. said it was spinning off its financial-advisory unit, in the latest sign that some big financial "supermarkets" that aim to pitch a wide range of products to consumers are scaling back and rethinking their strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LOOKS FORWARD TO MEETING WITH OPPOSITION LEADERS: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has ordered preparations for his meetings with top leaders of opposition parties after the Chinese New Year holiday, Chen's chief of staff said Wednesday.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun made the remarks in an interview with Formosa Television Co.

Yu, who stepped down from the premiership to take over as Chen's chief of staff a day earlier, said the president has directed him to arrange for meetings with opposition leaders after the lunar new year holiday.
According to Yu, Chen wants to forge cooperative ties with opposition parties to facilitate implementation of his major policy initiatives and reform agenda.

Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong told a news conference earlier in the day that he doesn't rule out meeting with chen after the lunar new year. But he said working-level staff members from the two sides should first meet to narrow the gap between their differences on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

On Taiwan's political spectrum, the PFP and Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are at opposite ends, with the PFP prefers to cross-strait unification and the DPP wants Taiwan independence.

If the DPP fails to adjust its pro-independence party charter, Soong said, he sees little possibility for the two parties to cooperate. Should this be the case, he added, a meeting between him and Chen would be meaningless.

Responding to Soong's statement, Yu said that if necessary, he would be willing to meet with opposition leaders, including Soong and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, to seek their opinions about the format for the proposed high-level meetings.

"President Chen has no bottom line. He will fully respect opposition leaders' opinions. He can either meet with Lien and Soong simultaneously or hold separate meetings with them. It's all up to them to decide on the format," Yu said.
As to the agenda, Yu said Chen will respect opposition leaders' opinions.

"The president has given only some principles. He hopes to shelve controversial topics and focus on major policy issues that are closely related to people's livelihood, such as crime, improvement of the national health insurance system and tax reform," Yu said.

Asked whether Soong is likely to assume any post related to cross-strait affairs, Yu said that to the best of his understanding, new Premier Frank Hsieh has many formal and informal interactions with PFP and KMT heavyweights in the process of forming the new Cabinet. Such engagements mainly focused on seeking the possibilities of cooperation in major legislative bills and didn't touch on any horse trading, Yu added.

There has wide speculation that Chen intends to name PFP chairman Soong to head the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) which is authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties. The first SEF chairman, Koo Chen-fu, died from renal cancer Jan. 3 at the age of 88.
At his news conference, Soong clarified that nobody has ever asked whether he would take over the SEF chairmanship.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IMPORTS AND EXPORTS HIT 51-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports registered US$174 billion and US$167.9 billion, respectively, in 2004, the highest level since 1953, officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Wednesday.

DGBAS officials attributed the booming trade to the recovery of the world economy last year. The exports and the imports in 2004 represented a 20 percent and 30 percent growth over the previous year, leaving a trade surplus of US$6.1 billion for the country, the lowest level since 1999.
Hong Kong and mainland China were the major sources of Taiwan's trade surplus last year, with its trade surplus with the two areas registering US$45.1 billion.

Japan was the largest source of the island's trade deficit in 2004, with a record high of US$30.4 billion. DGBAS officials noted that the sharp increase of imports from Japan made the island's trade surplus shrink to US$6.1 billion last year, the lowest level since 1999.
South Korea has become Taiwan's second-largest source of trade deficit since 1998.

Taiwan's efforts in developing high technology in the 1990s have made its exports of related products, including machinery, electronic and electrical articles, the island's major source of trade surplus, exceeding that registered by the textile industry in 1995. The exports of those products have created an average of US$17.5 billion in trade surplus during the last 10 years, according to DGBAS statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIRWAYS TO OPEN TAIPEI-VIENTIANE ROUTE

TEXT.P: EVA Airways will open a route from Taipei to Vientiane, Laos, on Feb. 24, with three flights per week, EVA Air officials said Wednesday.
EVA Air will offer three flights every Monday, Thursday and Saturday. The flying time from Taipei to Vientiane is three-and-a-half hours.
The officials said the Taipei-Vientiane flights will link with other routes in Indochina, and tourist spots in southwest China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI TO BUILD NEW TOWN IN SRI LANKA FOR TSUNAMI VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Singapore and Malaysia branches of the Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation will build a new town in Sri Lanka's Kajuwatta area to accommodate displaced survivors of the Dec. 26 tsunami catastrophe, a spokesman for Tzu Chi's Singapore branch said Wednesday.
The spokesman said Kajuwatta will be one of the 15 new townships to be built along Sri Lanka's southeastern coast, one of the hardest tsunami-hit areas.

Tzu Chi will build housing units for 1,000 affected families, in addition to medical service centers, schools and a community activity center on a 20-acre plot of land, the spokesman said, adding that the cost for building the housing units will reach an estimated NT$200 million (US$6.33 million) . The whole project is scheduled to be completed in six to eight months.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO OFFICIALS IN TOWN TO UNDERSTAND TAIWAN'S TRADE POLICY

TEXT.P: A group of trade policy review officials from the World Trade Organization (WTO) arrived Wednesday in Taipei to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's trade policies and practices that have attributed to its success for future reference for other WTO member states.

Clemens Boonekamp, director of the WTO's Trade Policy Review Division, and Michael Daly and Masahiro Hayafuji, took part in a seminar sponsored by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) the same day under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to serve that end.

In the meeting, Boonekamp explained the WTO's trade review mechanisms and process to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Financial Supervisory Commission, the Central Bank of China and the Council of Agriculture, with BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng promising to provide the WTO visitors with all relevant information.

Boonekamp highly praised Taiwan's outstanding performance in foreign trade and said that many WTO member countries have a keen interest in getting to know Taiwan's market exploration strategies -- an issue that needs cooperation from the country. Taiwan is an important economic power, he noted.
Daly stressed that the WTO's trade policy review aims to increase policy transparency among its member states and to step up their understanding of the body's regulations and rules.

According to WTO regulations, the world's four largest economies must have their trade policies reviewed every two years, while the economies ranking between fifth and 16th undergo a review every four years.

Taiwan is rated as the world's 14th-largest economy and the WTO is slated to carry out its first trade policy review of Taiwan in June 2006 after the country entered the world trade regulatory body in January 2002.

In line with the schedule arranged by the WTO, its secretariat will send another group of officials to conduct inspections in November in Taiwan, where they will exchange views with government officials, enterprise executives, business leaders and academic researchers.

The secretariat will issue a draft report in January 2006, while Taiwan will have to submit a government report in April the same year before the WTO calls an official review meeting on June 20 and June 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE HELD MORE THAN 5,000 RALLIES IN 2004

TEXT.P: Police authorities approved 5,459 rallies across the country last year, up by nearly three fold compared to the 2003 number, according to the newest tallies made public by the Ministry of the Interior.

The ministry's statistics showed that about 11.96 million Taiwan people participated in public rallies in 2004, up by more than six fold compared with the previous year's level -- an equivalent of 2,192 people in each activity that marks double the 2003 scale.
Some 4,739 were political gatherings, while 671 were social activities. More than 371,000 policemen were mobilized to maintain order for the whole of last year, almost triple the number in 2003.

In terms of administrative region, Taipei City, where most central government agencies are headquartered, had the largest number of 644 activities, followed by Kaohsiung City's 478 and Taipei County's 407.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Feb. 3:
10:00, The signing ceremony for a program to sponsor children in tsunami-affected areas will be held at the Government Information Office (GIO).
10: 00, The ruling and opposition camps will hold a consultation meeting on the agenda of the new legislative session at the Legislative Yuan.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, The results of a survey on Taiwan's image in the eyes of foreigners in the country will be issued at the GIO.
11: 00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
12: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will host a luncheon at the Presidential Office to honor winners of the President's Education Awards.
12: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a luncheon marking the upcoming Lunar New Year at the Executive Yuan.
16:00, The Ministry of National Defense will hold a tea party in celebration of the upcoming Lunar New Year at the Armed Forces Officers Club.
17: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONGRATULATES IRAQ ON SUCCESSFUL PARLIAMENTARY ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulated the Iraqi government and people Wednesday on their successful Jan. 30 parliamentary election.

The ministry said in a statement that the Republic of China has been concerned about the developments in Iraq since March 20, 2003, when the war between Iraq and the United States erupted, and has participated in the international efforts to aid Iraq in rebuilding.

Noting that the parliamentary election is a milestone in the history of Iraq, the ministry said Taiwan will continue its aid to Iraq and would like to share its experience in developing democracy with the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS WITH VISITING CHINESE OFFICIALS TOOK PLACE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Two Chinese officials who came to Taiwan to pay homage to the late chief of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Koo Cheng-fu, talked with their Taiwan counterparts during their brief stay in Taiwan, an SEF official said Wednesday.

The anonymous official said Sun Yafu, the vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , and ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei exchanged views with SEF officials for "a considerable time" although they said before their departure for Taiwan that they were not going to engage in any form of dialogue in Taiwan.
The official said Sun and Li exchange views with SEF officials on the alleged "consensus" reached between China and Taiwan in 1992 on the definition of "one China."
Both sides agreed to relay the other side's opinion to their superiors, according to the official.

Taiwan officials also extended President Chen Shui-bian's invitation to ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan at whatever times Wang thinks appropriate, and Sun and Li promised to relay this to Wang.
The official said he believes the two ARATS officials should be satisfied with their reception in Taiwan.
Sun and Li were asked by Wang to come to Taiwan to pay his personal tribute to Koo who died on Jan. 3. They arrived in Taipei Tuesday and left Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF AGRICULTURE COMMENTS ON MAINLAND FUR RANCHES

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture has condemned the cruel treatment in mainland China of its ranches that raise animals for their fur.
Although Taiwan has no fur farms, the council said it supports animal right groups and would like to call for people to refrain from using products made from natural furs.

The council made the comment after a local animal rights group urged local people Wednesday to boycott the use of products made from furs. In order to highlight their call, the group released a documentary film purporting to show the cruel treatment animals suffer at a fur ranch in Hebei province, in northern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 3, or the 25th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: One hundred and fifty practitioners and supporters of Zhong Gong, a form of Chinese kung fu which emphasizes the use of inner strength to toughen one's body, stage a parade around Guam to call for the release of founder Zhang Hongbao.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:

Self-proclaimed 'righteous thief' swindles fraud rings out of tens of millions a year.

Pork from sick hogs finds way into major shopping malls.

Intermediary bodies across Taiwan Strait meet for first time in six years.

Envoys avoid Koo's memorial service.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER'S 'CONSULTATIONS, COEXISTENCE' COMMITMENT WELCOMED

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng expressed welcome Thursday to Premier Frank Hsieh's commitment to create a new political landscape in Taiwan through "consultations and coexistence, " saying that it will be conducive to interactions between the administration and the legislature.
Wang urged Hsieh, former Kaohsiung mayor who was sworn in as premier two days ago, to deliver on his promise and stick to it during his tenure.

"By doing so, Hsieh's Cabinet will earn the trust and respect of the Taiwan public and the Legislative Yuan, where the opposition maintains a majority, will try to be neutral and impartial as a counterbalancing force," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: First Miyake returnees welcomed home
After an overnight ferry trip, the first group of returning Miyake evacuees set foot on their island home early Wednesday, many for the first time since volcanic activity forced everyone to leave in September 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Pope rushed to hospital
ROME (AP) -- Pope John Paul II spent a restful night in a Rome hospital, Italian news reports said Wednesday. The Pontiff rested "quite well," news agency ANSA said, quoting an unnamed Vatican source. The news agency Apcom also reported that the Pope had spent a "quiet night."
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Oil firms favor VAT bill
THE BIG three oil firms are amenable to the lifting of the exemption of petroleum products from the existing 10-percent value-added tax (VAT) rate, but they warned that this would cause pump prices and power rates to go up.
The Philippine Star: 'Economy first before con-ass'
Malacanang called on lawmakers yesterday to prioritize the passage of its economic measures to help address the country's financial problems before tackling political reforms, and asked Congress to shelve moves to amend the Constitution by convening a constituent assembly (con-ass).
The Manila Times: Me apologize? Not on your life -- Miriam
Sen. Miriam Defensor Santiago will not apo-logize to the governors she accused of conniving with illegal loggers and will not bother to respond to their "unintelligent" responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Shiite Alliance Claims Victory.
Leaders of a predominantly Shiite Muslim list of candidates said that their slate had won more than 50% of the votes cast for Iraq's transitional national assembly, but reaffirmed that they would refrain from using their power to install clerics in the new government.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE RESOLUTION URGES E.U. NOT TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution Wednesday saying that a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against mainland China would endanger the security of Taiwan and U.S. troops stationed in Asia.
The resolution urging the European Union to maintain its ban on arms sales to China was passed by a vote of 114-3.
Both the United States and the European Union implemented a ban on arms sales to China following the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre.

According to the resolution, China has been engaged in an extensive military buildup, including the deployment of approximately 500 short range ballistic missiles near the Taiwan Strait. China's military-industrial complex has also been involved in the transfer to Iran of certain controlled equipment and technology.

British Foreign Minister Jack Straw recently informed Condoleeza Rice, the new U.S. secretary of state, that the European Union is ready for a removal of the arms sales ban and that the ban would be replaced by a"Code of Conduct" regulating E.U. arms exports to third countries. Several heads of state of E.U. member countries have also said recently that the ban is expected to be lifted within six months.

During the debate before the resolution was put to a vote, Rep. Elton Gallegly (R-Calif.) said that a lifting of the E.U. ban would directly threaten Taiwan, which he called one of the dynamic democracies in Asia and a close partner of the United States.

Meanwhile, Rep. Tom Lantos (D-Calif.) said during the debate that the European Union's shortsightedness and greedy manner have demonstrated that it has lost its moral character. He added that the security of U.S. troops will be directly threatened if the E.U. ban is lifted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: PM Wen calls for closer ties with S'pore.
China has said it wants to move forward its relations with Singapore and welcomes Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to visit the country frequently.
The call for closer ties was made by Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao, after a meeting with Singapore's Foreign Affairs Minister George Yeo yesterday. Mr Yeo, who wrapped up an 11-day trip to Japan and China yesterday, told the Singapore media that the Premier had received him warmly and welcomed an early visit to China by Mr Lee.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The Singapore police force's Special Tactics and Rescue unit has new capabilities to stop 'hijacking' at sea.
The 12-year-old Special Tactics and Rescue Unit has new capabilities now to handle and stop the event such as Taiwan fishing boat.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LEGISLATIVE SESSION TO BEGIN FEB. 25

TEXT.P: Legislators from the various political parties have reached consensus that the new legislative session will begin Feb. 25, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
Wang made the remarks after presiding over a consultation meeting between the ruling and opposition parties on the opening date for the new legislative session.

Ker Chien-ming, acting chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said prior to the meeting that the Procedure Committee has continued to block the issue of confirmation of those appointed as members of the Control Yuan, the nation's top watchdog body, from being put on the legislature's agenda, which he said has resulted in constitutional conflict.
Ker expressed the hope that Wang will make the confirmation issue a top priority and that the review and confirmation will take place right after the Chinese New Year holidays.

However, Huang Teh-fu, legislative whip of the opposition Kuomintang caucus, claimed that the name list of Control Yuan nominees put forward by President Chen has failed to receive a positive response from the public. Huang said he hopes that President Chen will consult with the opposition parties and put forward a new name list after the opening of the new legislative session.
"Otherwise, President Chen's stated intention to work for inter-party reconciliation will prove to be just empty words, " Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY ISSUES TRAVEL WARNING FOR NEPAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has issued a travel warning for Nepal, where civil unrest is expected in the wake of recent political upheaval.

The ministry has advised Taiwan citizens to defer non-essential travel to the South Asian country, warning of the possibility of civil unrest after Nepal's King Gyanendra unveiled his own 10-member Cabinet Wednesday, a day after he sacked the prime minister for failing to hold elections and end an escalating civil war with Moist rebels.

Although Katmandu remains calm, Nepal has cut off contact with the outside world since Tuesday. All telephone landlines, and cell phone and Internet links have been out of service, while air traffic has been disrupted, according to wire service reports.

Currently, 11 Taiwan tourist groups are in Nepal and unable to be contacted, travel sources in Taiwan said Thursday. Three tourist groups, which were scheduled to depart for Nepal Thursday, have canceled their plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES U.S. HOUSE RESOLUTION AGAINST E.U. LIFTING ARMS EMBARGO

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed welcome Thursday for the passage of a resolution by the U.S. House of Representatives against a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against mainland China.

The foreign ministry once again urged the international community to pay heed to the fact that a lifting of the E.U. arms embargo against China would have a huge impact on regional security in the Asian Pacific.
The U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday overwelmingly passed the resolution, by a vote of 411-3, urging the European Union to maintain its ban on arms sales to China.
According to the resolution, a lifting of the E.U. arms embargo against China would endanger the security of Taiwan and U.S. troops stationed in Asia.
Both the United States and the European Union implemented a ban on arms sales to China following the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre.

One U.S. congressman even described some E.U. parliamentarians as "shortsighted and greedy" for seeking to have the embargo lifted. Several top politicians in E.U. member states have said the ban will likely be lifted within six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Schools crisis over standards and discipline fails children.
A growing discipline crisis and thousands of persistently failing schools are undermining efforts to raise education standards, the head of Ofsted gave warning yesterday.
David Bell said that one in ten schools had made no real progress between inspection visits in the past three years.
Of the 10,000 schools visited since 2001, a tenth had made "unsatisfactory, poor or very poor" progress. Applied to England's total number of state schools, this would produce a figure of 2,500 schools that had made no real progress nationwide.
Financial Times: Big three unions in talks on merger.
Three of Britain's biggest trade unions are expected to begin exploratory merger talks on creating a "super-union" that would match in size Germany's IG Metall, one of Europe's largest, and boast huge industrial and political clout.
The three private sector unions - Amicus, the Transport and General Workers Union and the GMB - have between them some 2.6m members in manufacturing, the financial services industry, energy and the public sector.
A merger could give them greater influence over policy debate in Tony Blair's Labour party because of the number of votes they would have at its annual conferences.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS FIND TAIWANESE TO BE 'FRIENDLY AND HARDWORKING': GIO POLL

TEXT.P: In the eyes of foreigners living or visiting the island, the Taiwanese people are "friendly, polite and hardworking, " a government- sponsored survey released Thursday indicated.

Lin Chia-lung, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), announced the results of a recent poll that showed that most foreign nationals visiting or living in Taiwan consider the Taiwanese people to be "friendly, diligent and polite."
The foreigners who responded said that Taiwan society is "diverse, dynamic, competitive and safe, with family values being the binding force of society," according to Lin.

The GIO survey was conducted by Shih Hsin University from Oct. 26 to Dec. 31, 2004 under a publicity program aimed at bettering Taiwan's image in the international community. The poll of randomly chosen foreign nationals, including tourists, business people, students and expatriates, was conducted via face-to-face interviews and gathered 1,033 valid responses. The survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.04 percent.
As for the government in Taiwan, the poll found that more than half of the responding foreigners thought that Taiwan's democratization and media freedoms are commendable.

In general, those foreigners who had stayed in Taiwan longer, were older, had higher educational backgrounds and frequently socialized with local people had a higher regard for the people of Taiwan and society in general, Lin said.

Taiwan is considered by nearly 70 percent of the responding foreigners as having outperformed most of the countries in the world in terms of economic growth and science and technological development, according to the poll.

When comparing to other "Asian tiger" countries, Taiwan is considered by more than half of the respondents as being better in areas such as science and technological development and democratization, the poll found.
More than 80 percent of the respondents thought that Taiwan surpasses mainland China in almost every aspect, particularly in democratization.
On Taiwan's tourist attractions, the foreigners said that local foods and snacks are the top magnet, followed by cultural aspects, shopping, nighttime activities and historical sites, in that order.
As to Taiwan's shortcomings, the foreigners said that environmental protection, globalization and facilities for tourists need to be improved.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained 22 points to close at 6,045, with 14,887 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March gained 17 points to finish at 6,044, with 2,116 contracts traded, while June futures gained seven points to close at 6,043, with 11 contracts traded. September futures gained 11 points to close at 5,950, with 10 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,023 for February, 6,027 for March, 6,036 for June, 5,939 for September and 5,952 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
February TE futures moved up 2.1 points to close at 229.95, with 2,980 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 1.8 points to finish at 229, with 409 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

February TF futures gained 3.6 points to finish at 1,019.8, with 4,199 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 5.4 points to finish at 1020.2, with 1,258 contracts traded. June TF futures gained 7 points to end at 1,018, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 1,015.2 with four contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OPEN TO MEETING WITH OPPOSITION LEADERS: TOP AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's top aide said Thursday that he hopes to arrange a meeting between the president and leaders of the opposition parties around the date of the opening of the new legislative session on Feb. 25.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, noted that President Chen, Premier Frank Hsieh, and Su Tseng-chang, chairman-elect of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), have repeatedly said that they are willing to cooperate with the opposition parties based on the interests of the nation and the welfare of the people.
President Chen wants to talk with the opposition to further administrative goals, Yu said.

With only three days before the beginning of the Chinese New Year holiday, Yu admitted, however, that it may be difficult to arrange for a meeting immediately, and it is more likely to happen after the weeklong holiday. Meeting around the time of the start of the new legislative session would also help contribute to the screening of bills, Yu said.
He also said that the format and meeting place is flexible and opposition leaders' views will be respected.
The issues to be discussed will focus on major policies related to the nation, and will put aside controversial issues, such as the DPP's platform of Taiwan independence, Yu said.
President Chen has suggested discussing such things as the national health insurance system and tax reforms, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 15.91 points to close at 6,034.6.
The bourse opened at 6,028.94 and fluctuated between 6,044.43 and 6,006.23 during trading. A total of 3.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$73.25 billion (US$2.31 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by banking and financial shares and cement stocks both at 0.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues both at 0.2 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.
Two other major stock categories -- plastics and chemicals shares and textile stocks -- remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 369 to 364, with 250 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.060 to close at NT$31.639.
A total of US$937 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.750 and hit a low of NT$31.590.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA SAYS THANK YOU TO TAIWAN FOR AID TO TSUNAMI VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Indonesia's top liaison officer in Taiwan mailed a thank-you letter to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs recently, extending gratitude to the people of Taiwan for their generosity and compassion by raising funds for Asian children affected by the Dec. 26 tsunamis.

Ferry Yahya, director of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei, wrote to offer appreciation on behalf of the Indonesian government to the government and people of Taiwan after more than NT$400 million (US$12.54 million) was raised in two weeks after the killer tsunamis struck, government spokesman Lin Chia-lung said Thursday.
Yahya also said that the Indonesian government will assist the designated Taiwanese NGO organizations in using the donated money and executing related plans in Indonesia, according to Lin.
More than half of the Dec. 26 tsunami victims were in Indonesia, which will be the major recipient country of the Taiwanese funds. Sri Lanka, also hard-hit by the tsunamis, is another recipient.

The Taiwan public opened their hearts and wallets as well when the Government Information Office (GIO) called for donations to raise funds to sponsor 10,000 children affected by the tsunami catastrophe in South and Southeast Asia.

In two weeks, NT$400.95 million in cash was raised after the GIO launched its "Day after Tomorrow, 10,000 Hopes" fundraising drive, hoping to sponsor 10,000 tsunami-affected children for one year, Lin said.
The GIO signed a contract with Hua Nan Commercial Bank Thursday for the formation of a trust fund to manage the donated money and ensure that the donations are used correctly and wisely.

The GIO also forged contracts with three private organizations; namely, the Taiwan Fund For Children and Families, World Vision Taiwan and the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, which are commissioned to plan how to use the funds.
Part of the funds will also be used to finance programs benefiting poor children in Taiwan, according to GIO officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIFFERENCES OVER 'ONE CHINA" ISSUE KEY TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the issue of "one China" are key to cross-strait relations, an official in charge of Taiwan's mainland China policy said Thursday.
Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks during an interview by the pro-Beijing daily Wen Wei Po in Hong Kong.

He said that if both sides of the Taiwan Strait can take a cue from the launch of the cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday, leave political factors out and try to understand the problems and pressures faced by each side, then cross-strait relations are bound to be improved.

He also stressed several times that Beijing has no need to formulate an "anti-secession law," which he said he was worried could only lead to cross-strait tensions. The proposed law will be screened and put before the full National People's Congress in March for approval.

The mainland should use "new thinking, " Chiu said, adding that both sides have no need to continued wasting their energies by needlessly going in circles on the "one China" issue; otherwise, Taiwan's maneuvering space in the international community could shrink and thereby increase the calls by those in Taiwan for independence.
Chiu said the basic tone of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is clear, and that President Chen Shui-bian made this clear in his second inaugural address on May 20, 2004.

The chances of Taiwan acting upon its underlying sentiments regarding "one China" are slim, Chiu said, adding, "We understand that the mainland has misgivings about Taiwan's writing a new constitution in 2006."

The DPP will soon unveil the content of the revised constitution, which will prove non-controversial, Chiu said, citing as examples whether the nation will follow "the presidential or Cabinet system, " or if absolute majority or simple majority should be followed in the presidential election, or whether to continue to promote legislative reforms.
"If the mainland puts on a tough face during this period, it will by no means be good timing or a shrewd move," Chiu said.
He also said that Taiwan thinks that the mainland is "continuing to be tough, " so that Taipei has to make assessments on another level.

Taiwan thinks being heavy-handed is unnecessary and that it will undermine the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, and the 'anti-secession law', whatever it contains, is certain to bring more risks to cross-strait exchanges, especially its definition of 'secession,' Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN REJECTS OFFER TO BECOME VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang turned down Premier Frank Hsieh's offer Thursday to assume the position of vice premier.

Chiang told reporters that any such appointments should have been arranged through party-to-party negotiations before the new Cabinet was formed and that it would be meaningless for him to enter the Cabinet as an individual who enjoys no support or endorsement from his party.

Hsieh has openly expressed his intention to name Chiang as his deputy over the past two days and said he hoped to visit KMT Chairman Lien Chan before next week's Lunar New Year holiday to discuss the matter.
According to Chiang, Hsieh had before that inquired as to his attitude towards the appointment through a friend and he immediately rejected the offer.
Chiang said he did not expect the matter would remain a news item.

Chiang stressed that if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) intends to recruit any opposition members to join the Cabinet, it must negotiate with the concerned party for a party-to-party agreement, which he said is a symbol of ruling and opposition cooperation.

Otherwise, Chiang said, the same old story will be repeated of former Premier Tang Fei, who accepted President Chen Shui-bian's appointment in 2000 without the KMT's blessing and stepped down months later over disagreements with the DPP over the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project.

Through party-to-party negotiations, the KMT could at least make sure that the DPP would not put forth any controversial policies that are likely to lead to partisan confrontations and tensions, Chiang said.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, another KMT vice chairman, said Hsieh had asked him to help talk to Lien about his plan to appoint Chiang vice premier but Lien had shown little interest in such an arrangement.
According to Ma, Lien does not think appointing Chiang vice premier will be of any help to inter-party consultations and cooperation.
Lien believes that any form of inter-party cooperation must be attained through party-to-party negotiations, rather than by recruiting an individual opposition member to join the Cabinet, Ma said.
Meanwhile, acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming said whether the KMT will allow Chiang to enter the Cabinet is a matter of whether it is willing to adjust its way of thinking.
Ker said he will do his best to help Hsieh with the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE HEAD OFFERS TO TALK WITH MAINLAND ON 'ANTI-SESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that he is willing to lead a legislative delegation to visit mainland China to ease cross-strait tensions.

Wang said that the Legislative Yuan is willing to play a more positive and active role in breaking through the cross-strait impasse, but this will require goodwill on the part of the administrative branch, and such goodwill will have to include its attitude toward the issue of Taiwan independence, something that could trigger an attack by Beijing.

He said that a cross-strait crisis contingency team in the legislature will be formed as soon as the new legislative session opens on Feb. 25, and that it will discuss how to restart stalled cross-strait dialogue and build cross-strait mutual trust.
Wang also said that the mainland will start to discuss the legislation of its proposed "anti-secession law" in April, which he worries will increase cross-strait tensions if passed.

He also said that it is more feasible for the legislative bodies from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to communicate on the promotion of cross-strait peace, hoping that even if Beijing is set on creating the law, if could delay its legislation so that there would be more time and space for cross-strait peace.

As long as both sides can agree to put aside sensitive political ideologies, they can talk productively about the more substantive issues of direct cross-strait charter flights and the opening of mainland tourists to Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT LINKS HIGHEST HOPE FOR BUSINESSES: CICD

TEXT.P: A business group has urged the opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait trade, postal and transport links, saying that direct links best meet the hopes of the business sector.

Kuo Tai-chiang, president of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, made the remarks as he and Legislator Chu Feng-chi of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) released the results of a survey of more than 800 dome stic enterprises.
According to the survey results, most of the respondents think the nation most needs to solve its economic problems, followed by the bickering among the political parties and cross-strait issues.

On cross-strait rations, 85.9 percent of the respondents said they are dissatisfied, while 78.8 percent said cross-strait trade and economic exchanges are too slow and that direct trade, postal and transportation links should be at the top of cross-strait policy, followed by bilateral consultations.
Kuo said the respondents believe a good premier should have the attributes of vision and planning, followed by leadership and international perspective.

The respondents also said that KMT's P. K. Chiang, former legislative vice speaker and long-term chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and the new Premier Frank Hsieh best qualify for the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: BROADBAND USERS IN TAIWAN INCREASING IN NUMBER: TWNIC

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan's broadband subscribers is increasing continuously, reaching around 10.31 million users and 3.82 million family subscribers as of Jan. 10, according to a recent survey by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC).
The center reported that some 60 percent of Taiwan's residents are wired to the Internet, with those aged over 12 years accounting for 64 percent of the total.
About 65 percent of Taiwan families can connect to the Internet, while some 53 percent, or 3.82 million families, are broadband subscribers.

In terms of region, over 63 percent of the families in northern Taiwan have broadband access to the Internet, followed by 46.7 percent in the south, 44.4 percent in the central region and 42.1 percent in the east.
As high as 82.5 percent of the broadband subscribers use the Hinet service provided by Chunghua Telecom -- the country's largest telecommunications company.
The TWNIC carried out the poll from Dec. 1, 2004 to Jan. 10, 2005, recovering 3,001 valid questionnaires from citizens aged over 12 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Makes Case for Social Security Plan; Changes Needed To Save Program, He Tells Nation.
President Bush called last night for a historic restructuring of Social Security that would allow younger workers for the first time to invest some of their payroll taxes in the stock market, declaring in his annual State of the Union address that without change the venerable program is headed toward bankruptcy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK MIGHT RAISE INTEREST RATES IN LATE MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) might follow the United States by raising key interest rates in late March, probably within a range of between a quarter percentage point and an eighth percentage point, market watchers said Thursday.

Their comment came after the U.S. Federal Reserve (Fed) announced a fresh interest rate hike of a quarter percentage point a day earlier, pushing up its key interest rates to an average level of 2.5 percent.

The market analysts predicted that the CBC might follow in the footsteps of the United States after holding a meeting of its board of directors and supervisors in late March, when the Fed is expected to raise its rates by another one quarter percentage point.

The CBC will be more likely to increase rates by 0.125 percentage points at the end of next month and is expected to keep on doing so piecemeal in the future, they said, adding that power and water rate increases and possible fallout in the economy are factors that could contribute changes to the bank's moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS FOR NEGOTIATIONS OVER VICE PREMIER APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan set party-to-party negotiations Thursday as the condition for allowing one of the party's vice chairmen, P.K. Chiang, to join the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration as vice premier.

Over the past two days, Premier Frank Hsieh has openly expressed his desire to appoint Chiang as his deputy and has said he hopes to visit Lien before next week's Lunar New Year holiday to discuss the matter.

Responding to the issue through the party's spokesman Chang Jung-kung, Lien said he appreciates Hsieh's offer but believes such an appointment must be arranged through party-to-party negotiations in order to avoid a repeat of the mistake made by former Premier Tang Fei.

Lien was referring to Tang's decision to accept President Chen Shui-bian's offer to become premier in 2000 without the KMT's blessing. Tang stepped down just a few months after assuming the position over disagreements with the DPP over the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project.

Before the KMT accepts the DPP's offer to appoint Chiang, Lien proposed that the two parties negotiate first to clarify and seek consensus on divided issues such as the country's status, opening direct transportation links with mainland China, plans to change the official name of the country, investigations into last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, and attempts to liquidate the KMT's ill-gotten assets, in addition to the controversial power plant project.
Also, the two parties need to negotiate on how much authorization Chiang will enjoy as vice premier to ensure he will not be just a dummy in the DPP government, Lien said.
Lien said the KMT hopes for partisan reconciliation, cross-Taiwan Strait peace and economic prosperity for the sake of national development.

The KMT last proposed in December that the DPP form a coalition government through party-to-party negotiations, according to the results of the legislative elections in which the DPP failed to gain an absolute majority. The KMT also recommended that Chen appoint Chiang as premier.
The proposal was ignored by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: In Speech, Bush Sketches a Bold Domestic and Foreign Agenda.
President Bush challenged a wary Congress on Wednesday night to join him in reinventing Social Security for the 21st century, saying his generation had a duty to preserve the retirement system for those who follow and for the first time setting out details of the individual investment accounts at the heart of his proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO STRINGS ATTACHED TO OFFER OF CABINET JOB TO KMT LEADER: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that there are no strings attached to his offer of deputy premiership to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang.
Chiang's party would not be obliged to support his Cabinet's policies if it were to give the green light to Chiang to take up the offer, Hsieh said.

At an informal gathering held by the Executive Yuan, Hsieh said he asked Chiang to join the Cabinet because of Chiang's experience as one of the country's former economic architects, his knowledge would be put to better use in the Cabinet than in the legislature where Chiang serves as a lawmaker.
Furthermore, Chiang's participation in the Cabinet would demonstrate that there is the possibility of cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, Hsieh said.

The premier expressed reservations about some KMT lawmakers' idea that negotiations between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT should go forward before the KMT had even considered agreeing to Chiang's participation in the Cabinet, saying that negotiations would inevitable result in agreements covering each others' rights and obligations, which is not appropriate in this case.
What's more, Hsieh said, any negotiations involving the DPP should be carried out by the chief of the DPP, not by the premier.

Hsieh said his chief aide, Lee Ying-yuan, has contacted KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng with the view of lining up a meeting between the premier and KMT Chairman Lien Chan to study the possibility of having Chiang join the Cabinet.
The issue is not pressing, Hsieh said, but it's better to be settled one week before the Legislative Yuan gathers for its new session on Feb. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MUM ON RED ENVELOPE MONEY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has not disclosed how much money will be in the red envelops he traditionally hands out to neighbors in his hometown of Kuantien, Tainan County, at Chinese New Year, according to Ho Yuan-po, the Kuantien township chief.

With only five days to go before the Feb. 9 New Year's day, Ho said there is no suggestion as to how much money the president will put in his red envelopes, which are traditional gifts given to each other by Chinese on New Year's day.
Chen has handed out red envelopes to his neighbors every year since he was elected president in 2000, Ho said.

Usually, they contain NT$200 (US$6.25) , but the money was replaced last year by a NT$10 memorial coin because the presidential election in March sparked fear that the NT$200 might be considered by Chen's political rivals as vote-buying money.
The president's aides used to inform officials at the Kuantien Town Hall of how much money Chen would hand out, but Ho said he has not been informed this year.

Enthusiastic neighbors, who consider a red envelope from the president more of a charm than a windfall, did not seem to care about the money, judging by the long line of chairs -- each one representing a person's place in the line -- already formed in front of Chen's home.

Chen also used to host a lunch party for leaders of his home town on New Year's day. About 1,000 people were invited to the party last year, but only about 500 have been invited this year, according to Ho.
The party will be held in Liuying, Tainan County, and all guests will be subject to maximum security checks, which has not been the case in the past, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA SENDS PERSONNEL TO HELP TAIWAN TOURISTS LEAVE NEPAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has sent personnel from India to neighboring Nepal, which has been placed in a state of emergency, to help Taiwan tourists get out of the country, a MOFA spokesman said Thursday.

According to the MOFA official, Nepal remains stable and air travel has been reopened for the time being after being closed down by the monarch. No unrest or conflict has erupted, they said, noting that the ministry sent officials earlier in the day to help visitors from Taiwan to leave.
The ministry has issued a "red" travel advisory for Nepal and is cooperating with the Tourism Bureau in keeping a close watch on the country, he said.

As of Feb. 1, when the Nepal's King Gyanendra sacked the prime minister and declared a state of emergency for his failure to hold elections or halt a Maoist rebellion, a total of 165 Taiwan tourists were in the country at the time, 72 of whom had returned to Taiwan as of late Thursday, he said.
Information provided by Taiwan tourism agencies shows that the Taiwan tourists still in Nepal are safe. Nepal has imposed no restrictions on foreign visitors.
Gyanendar said that he would build a new government to rekindle multi party democracy in three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT PROJECTS TO REPRESENT TAIWAN IN INTEL ISEF

TEXT.P: A total of eight projects and 11 students have been selected to represent Taiwan in the 2005 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF) to be held May 8-14 in the United States, officials of the National Taiwan Science Education Center (NTSEC) announced Thursday.

The projects and students were selected from among the domestic participants of the 2005 Taiwan International Science Exhibition, which closed that day, for their excellent presentations and performances, the officials said.

A total of 145 projects presented by students from 12 countries and areas, including the United States, Chile, Canada, New Zealand, Hong Kong, Singapore and the host Taiwan, participated in the annual pre-college science competition organized by the NTSEC.
In addition to announcing Taiwan's representatives to the Intel ISEF, the organizers also presented awards to domestic and foreign winners in various categories at the closing ceremony of the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISAS FOR THAI WORKERS POSTPONED: CLA

TEXT.P: A visa rift between Taiwan and Thailand has created a new complication, as the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Thursday that Thai workers applying to work in Taiwan will not get their visas until 60 days later.
According to a CLA official, Thai workers who applied for a work visa Dec. 15 were originally to get their visas Wednesday after a 35-day processing period.

However, they will have to wait until April to receive their visas to enter Taiwan due to a failure by the Thai government to give an explanation about its refusal to grant a courtesy visa late last year to CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu, who was planning to take part in a bilateral labor affairs meeting in Thailand, the official said.
The Thai government failed to live up to a pledge it made earlier to Taiwan, and issued only a tourist visa to Chen, he explained.

On the grounds that Thailand has broken its promise to carry out two-way cooperation based on respect and reciprocity, the CLA has decided to postpone until April the issuance of the batch of visas that should have been due a day earlier, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES TO RAISE ALERT DURING CHINESE NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: The armed forces will raise their alert level but not as high as the status of readiness for war in light of the fact that there are no unusual troop movements in mainland China, a miliary officer said Thursday.

Lee Chieh-chia, director of the Joint Operations Department under the Ministry of National Defense told a news conference that in order to brace for the Chinese New Year holiday that begins Feb. 8, the armed forces will enter a mode of high alert on selective fronts from Feb. 7 to Feb. 11.
This defense mode will focus on guarding against sneak attacks from outside the country and unexpected internal upheaval, Lee explained.
All commanders and their lieutenants will stay at their posts in rotation and keep a close eye on the movement of troops across the Taiwan Strait, Lee said.
On the country's two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, the alert will also be edged up one notch during the Feb. 7-11 period.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF TAIWAN'S FOOD INDUSTRY INCREASES

TEXT.P: The production of Taiwan's food industry is estimated to amount to NT$444 billion (US$13.875 billion) in 2004, up 5.9 percent from the previous year's level, according to the latest statistics compiled by the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS).
Chen Shu-fang, an ITIS analyst, attributed the increase to domestic commodity price hikes caused by the outbreaks of bird flu in several countries.
The output of the industry will enjoy growth of 3 percent to 4 percent this year if both the domestic wholesale price and consumer price increase less than 2 percent, she predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MAINLAND CHINA CHARTER FLIGHTS LAY GROUNDWORK FOR DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China during the Chinese New Year holiday period have paved the way for dialogue between the two sides and offer an opportunity for positive engagement, the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan said Thursday.

The council made the statement in response to the results of a survey released the previous day that most businessmen believe that direct transport links with the mainland and the easing of strain with the mainland should be the top priorities of the government's economic policy.

In an attempt to ease local businessmen's clamor for direct transport links with the mainland, the council rattled off the mantra used by the government that it is an established policy to open direct transport links with the mainland on the condition that such talks do not compromise the country's safety and dignity.

The council noted in the statement that President Chen Shui-bian, in his Double Ten Day speech, asked related government agencies to push for charter flights between Taiwan and China for passengers and cargo, which resulted in the Chinese New Year holiday charter flights.
It assured the business world that Chen's administration will press for the opening of direct transport links with the mainland steadily and pragmatically.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 4, or the 26th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its te0ritories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon I his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon I.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: Dr. Raymond Jallow, senior vice president of the United California Bank, Los Angeles, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1988: The Executive Yuan passes a bill allowing high school graduates to study abroad.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEN PARTY TAIWAN TO TRY TO HALT CRACKER, STEEL MILL PLANS

TEXT.P: In an attempt to halt construction of Taiwan's proposed eighth naphtha cracking plant and a large steel mill, which recently received government approval, environmental activists from Green Party Taiwan are planning to solicit support from their Asian-Pacific counterparts.

A delegation of Green Party Taiwan activists, to be led by Prof. Yenwen Peng from Tunghai University, is scheduled to take part in the Asia-Pacific Greens Kyoto Meeting set for Feb. 11-13 in Kyoto, Japan, marking the establishment of the Asia-Pacific Greens Network, according to Peng.

During the meeting, the Green Party Taiwan delegates will exchange views with their Asian-Pacific counterparts on several issues, including reduction of greenhouse gas emissions as well as regional security.

The Green Party Taiwan members will also solicit support from meeting participants in their efforts to stop the proposed construction of Taiwan's eighth naphtha cracking plant by the Formosa Plastics Group as well as the proposed construction of a large steel mill by Chinese Petroleum Corp.

Peng claimed that these two projects will further pollute Taiwan's environment and that they run counter to the spirit of the U.N.-initiated Kyoto Protocol on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The Kyoto Protocol, which was negotiated in 1997 and has been signed by most of the U.N. member countries, is scheduled to enter into force Feb. 16 this year.
