DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Bogus 500 yen coins flood post office accounts Since late January, 5,583 500 yen coins that are believed to be counterfeit have been disco- vered in Tokyo, Fukuoka and Kumamoto prefectures, the Finance Ministry said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Bush Issues Call to Action on Social Security Makeover. President Bush used his State of the Union address to launch a determined push for sweeping changes in the nation's Social Security system, including new individual investment accounts for younger workers and potentially deep but unspecified cuts in benefits for future retires.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Cover-up row over £27 billion secret of Black Wednesday.
Highly sensitive Treasury papers on the events leading to Black Wednesday in 1992 are being kept secret at the request of John Major and Lord Lamont of Lerwick, Prime Minister and Chancellor at the time, The Times has learnt.
Senior Treasury officials are furious that the documents, which should have been published under the Freedom of Information Act on Tuesday, are being held back, apparently on the orders of Sir Andrew Turnbull, the Cabinet Secretary, to give Mr Major and Lord Lamont more time to study them.
The delay has raised fears among Treasury officials that publication could be delayed indefinitely, or that key passages will be removed to prevent embarrassment to figures in one of the most humiliating episodes in recent economic history, when Britain left the European exchange-rate mechanism on September 16, 1992, and the Bank of England reputedly spent £27 billion of reserves propping up sterling.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Mining safeguards assured
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday assured that the government will have a legal and administrative system of safeguards installed to achieve balanced economic development, social equity, and environmental protection should mining operations resume in the country.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Credit rating cut ruled out
WITH foreign investors finally getting to appreciate the gains made by President Macapagal-Arroyo's fiscal reforms, global credit firm Moody's Investor Services appears to be no longer in the mood to consider the Philippines a bigger credit risk.
The Philippine Star: US keeps CPP-NPA on int'l terror list
The Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) and New People's Army (NPA) will remain on the US government's list of foreign terrorist organizations, US Ambassador Francis Ricciardone said.
The Manila Times: Govs: Miriam must pay
The dispute between Sen. Miriam Defensor Santiago and the governors she has accused of being soft on illegal logging has sharpened: the governors threaten to file charges against her before the Senate Committee on Ethics.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Patients to pay higher initial amount from July.
From July 1, everyone on a CPF-approved health plan - whether MediShield or private - will have to pay more for their hospital bill before their insurance cover kicks in.
The initial amount, known as the deductible, would go up by S$500 for all hospital classes, said Health Minister Khaw Boon Wan yesterday.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Private insurers offer additional coverage for the basic MediShield not covered.
The market of private medical insurance will relax in the more changes to the MediShield framework by the Health Ministry revealed yesterday.
From July, MediShield will form the basic tier of health insurance at the Class B2 and C level.
While private insurers will provide enhancement plans offering additional coverage for conditions not covered by the basic MediShield tier.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ATTENDS U.S. NATIONAL PRAYER BREAKFAST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Senior presidential adviser Wu Li-pei, who headed the Republic of China delegation to the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast Thursday, said Taiwan can learn from the gathering which brought together people of different political views.

The prayer breakfast, held at the Hilton Hotel in Washington, D.C., was attended by U.S. President George W. Bush, many senior U.S. officials and members of Congress, as well as political, diplomatic, religious and business leaders from various countries around the world.

The members of the ROC delegation included Parris H. Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council; Chan Chi-shean, advisor to President Chen Shui-bian; Theodore M. H. Huang, chairman of the National Association of Industry and Commerce; Liu Shyh-fang, former secretary-general of the Executive Yuan; and Joanne J.L.Chang, ROC deputy representative to the United States.

Pointing out that he has noticed Beijing's recent goodwill toward Taiwan, including agreeing to launch special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights and sending envoys to participate in the funeral ceremony for Koo Chen-Fu, the late chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, Wu said that mainland China has finally responded to the goodwill that Taiwan has shown it for a long time.

Wu said the two sides should hold consultations and expressed the hope that Beijing would not use its proposed anti-secession law to escalate tensions in the Taiwan Strait. Wu also said he hopes the United States will work to prevent China from unilaterally changing the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, Parris Chang said that officials, legislators and the media in the United States should openly voice their opposition to China's proposed anti-secession law which is widely seen as being aimed at Taiwan.

Apart from attending the 2005 National Prayer Breakfast gathering, the delegation will also call on Washington-based think tanks, including the Heritage Foundation, as well as members of Congress and Bush administration officials to exchange views on issues related to China's proposed anti-secession law.
According to Chang, the delegation will also express Taiwan's wish to conclude a free trade agreement with United States as soon as possible.

Legislator Joanna C. Lei from the New Party, and Jason C. S. Yuan, representative of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) to the United States, also attended the national prayer breakfast.

Lei noted that the gathering demonstrated the possibility of reconciliation among people despite their political differences, expressing the hope that legislators in Taiwan can learn from this and work together for the common welfare of the people.
Meanwhile, Yuan said that he explained the KMT-PFP position on maintaining the cross-strait status quo to a political advisor to President Bush during the prayer gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES TO KNOW SOON IF KMT VICE CHAIRMAN WILL SERVE AS DEPUTY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh hopes to learn as soon as possible whether opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang will accept the position as his deputy, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday.
Wang made the remarks after Hsieh called on him at the Legislative Yuan.
The meeting was mainly to exchange views on the current political situation, as well as on the exchanges between the executive and legislative branches, Wang said.

Hsieh has offered the post of vice premier to Chiang, but the latter has said any such appointment should have been arranged through party-to-party negotiations before the new Cabinet was formed and that it would be meaningless for him to enter the Cabinet as an individual with no support or endorsement from his party.
According to Wang, Hsieh said that party-to-party consultations is a matter between parties and that it is therefore "not appropriate" for him to get involved.
Wang quoted Hsieh as saying that it would be best if Chiang could serve in the post, but if that's not possible, he hopes to know as soon as possible in order to consider other candidates.

Hsieh, during his second meeting with Wang since assuming office Feb. 1, also said the Executive Yuan will not ask the legislature to review several controversial bills so as avoid confrontation between the executive and legislative branches, according to Wang.
Hsieh also said the most pressing issue the Executive Yuan faces is revamping the financially troubled national health insurance system.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU, MONGOLIAN UNIVERSITY SIGN COOPERATIVE PACT

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) signed a cooperative agreement with the National University of Mongolia (NUM) Firday as part of its efforts to help promote academic exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.
It marked the first time that Taiwan's most prestigious university has ever forged cooperative ties with aMongolian university.

The agreement was signed in Taipei by NTU President Chen Wei-chao and his NUM counterpart, Dr. Tserensodom Gantsog. Chen said he is pleased to see the NUM become the NTU's first sister university in Mongolia.

Under the agreement, the two universities will strengthen academic exchanges and research cooperation. NTU's physics department will donate a batch of experimentation equipment to the Mongolian university. The two sides will also discuss several other cooperative programs.

Before the agreement was signed, Chang Kuo-lung, a retired NTU physics professor, traveled to Mongolia to lecture at the NUM for free. Chang Hsiu-jung, a retired NTU history professor, has also donated many Chinese and English books to the Mongolian university.

The NUM, founded in 1942, was Mongolia's first tertiary education institute. Located in the Mongolian capital of Ulaanbaatar, the university has 12 colleges in the humanities, social sciences and natural sciences.
Chen said the NTU is also planning to forge cooperative ties with the Halth Science University of Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Shiite Coalition takes a Big Lead in Early Vote Count in Iraq
Preliminary election returns released Thursday by Iraqi authorities showed that 72 percent of the 1.6 million votes counted so far from Sunday's election went to an alliance of Shiite parties dominated by religious groups with strong links to Iran. Only 18 percent went to a group led by Prime Minister Ayad Allawi, a secular Shiite who favors strong ties to the United States. Few votes went to Sunni candidates. Although the early votes were drawn only from Baghdad and from five southern provinces where the Shiite parties were expected to score strongly, and from only 10 percent of the 5,216 polling stations, the scale of the vote for both religious and secular Shiites underscored the probability of a crushing triumph and a historic shift from decades of Sunni minority rule in Iraq.
Wall Street Journal: Deep in Sahara, BP Tries to Put Dent in Global Warming
British Petroleum, one of the world's biggest energy companies thinks it has found a cheap way to get rid of its global-warming problem: Bury it. At a new natural-gas processing plant in Sahara, BP PLC and two partners have spent US$100 million to take carbon dioxide that otherwise would be sent into the air and put it back where it came from: a mile underground. With the Kyoto Protocol, the treaty limiting global-warming emissions in most industrialized nations, set to enter into force Feb. 16, companies that will have to curb their emissions in compliance with their countries' caps are scrambling to figure out how to do so without killing their bottom lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SCHOLARS DISCUSS INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY COOPERATION IN SPAIN
DOC.DATELINE: Madrid, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By D.L. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A group of fifteen scholars from the Republic of China attended a seminar in Spain earlier this week to discuss with their Spanish counterparts the possibility of future cooperation in the field of information technology between their two countries.
The "ROC-Spain Information Science and Technology Exchange Seminar" was held at Baleares University in Mallorca, the capital of the Baleares Islands.
The ROC group was headed by Chen Wei-jao, president of National Taiwan University.

According to Liu Ting-i, vice chairman of the European Cultural and Educational Exchange Fndation, who had actively pushed for the holding of the seminar, the scholars from Taiwan and Spain successfully exchanged views on how to promote future cooperation between their two countries in information technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR LEGISLATIVE SUPPORT TO SAVE HEALTH PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh called Friday for support from the Legislative Yuan for several proposed amendments to related statutes to help save the national health insurance program from bankruptcy.

Hsieh met with Legislative Yuan Speak Wang Jin-pyng to seek legislative support for several proposed amendments to several existing laws to allow for transferring tobacco and liquor tax revenues to support the financially troubled national health insurance program.

Hsieh said that the health insurance program's reserve funds will run out by the end of March and that the program is expected to be on the brink of collapse should no extra funds be infused after March.

The premier noted that implementing a proposed second-generation health insurance program -- currently in the pipelines at the Department of Health (DOH) -- under which premiums would be calculated based on a person's total income as opposed to just their salary, also requires the Legislative Yuan's support to be passed into law.
Under this proposed new health insurance program, premium ceilings would be adjusted upwardly, requiring that people with higher incomes share a greater burden in supporting the program.
Commenting on the proposed second-generation program, Wang said that it makes sense to him and that the issue can be brought to the Legislative Yuan floor for discussion.
The Department of Health said recently that it will adopt austerity measures to save the shaky national health insurance program from bankruptcy without raising premiums for a year or so.

DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen said the department will respect the consensus reached by participants in public forum in mid-January rejecting a proposed hike in health insurance premiums. He said the DOH will refrain from raising premiums this year.

Pointing out that there is room to reduce the program's costs by 5 percent to 10 percent through cost-saving measures and curbing waste, Chen said that if this can be achieved, the program should be able to continue operating for another year or so without an increase in premiums.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG WANTS BARGAINING AUTHORITY FOR M'LAND VISIT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng reaffirmed Friday that he is willing to lead a delegation to visit mainland China to ease cross-strait tensions, but only if he is given some bargaining authority from the administration.

Noting that mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law" will have a damaging effect on Taiwan if it is passed into law, Wang said that if the chance arises, he will visit the mainland to communicate with Beijing on the matter.
However, he stressed that "without any bargaining authority, there is no use in making such a visit."

When asked about opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong also intending to visit the mainland to help re-start the stalled cross-strait dialogue, Wang said that he is for anyone willing to contribute to the nation's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION APPEALS COURT RULING ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION DISPUTE

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) appealed to the Supreme Court Friday after its bid to have last year's presidential election nullified was rejected by the High Court.

The alliance alleges that the results of the election were swayed by various electoral scandals, a referendum held on the same day of the election, the activation of a "national security mechanism" that they claim barred a number of police and military servicemen from going to the polls, and the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

However, the Taiwan High Court ruled Dec. 30 that the claims made by the two plaintiffs -- KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong, who were beaten in the presidential election by Chen -- could not stand up in court.
A legal team led by Lee Tzung-teh said it lodged an appeal claiming that the ruling is "in violation of the law."
According to Lee, the High Court unlawfully turned down the plaintiffs' requests to review the electoral rolls and to obtain audio CDs recording the court hearings.

Lee further accused the court of taking unlawful command of the lawsuit and failing in its duty for not making a judgment on whether it was lawful for the Central Election Commission (CEC) to hold the referendum simultaneously with the presidential election.

Also, Lee said, the court rejected evidence put forth by the plaintiffs that the secrecy of the vote was compromised because the referendum was held alongside the election, but did not provide any rationale for its decision.
Lee said the points mentioned above are only a few among the numerous irregularities in the case and that it is inconceivable that such an important judicial case was processed with such low quality.
Commenting on the development, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman-elect Su Tseng-chang said his party respects the KMT's and PFP's right to lodge an appeal.
He also urged the two parties to respect the court's judgment and the judicial system.
Incoming DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said the "pan-blue alliance" set a bad example by suggesting there was political influence behind the court's ruling.
Lee said he hopes the KMT and PFP will accept the final result to be released by the Supreme Court and put an end to partisan confrontation to meet public expectations for political reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO FOLLOW SUNSHINE POLICY

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Ch-mai said Friday that his administration will follow a sunshine policy.

Chen, who has been listening to briefings and inspecting infrastructure construction sites over the past days, made the remarks in his first administrative meeting since assuming post as acting mayor of Taiwan's second-largest city Feb. 2.
According to Chen, sunshine stands for "health and transparency." He added that all administrative work, policy-making and promotions in the future will be made apparent in line with this policy.
Chen held the meeting at a fisherman's wharf at Kaohsiung Harbor to signify his determination to build the port city into an "ocean capital."

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. WELCOMES CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The European Union issued a statement Thursday welcoming the agreement between Taiwan and China on the launching of cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flight services.
"This type of practical cooperation will help promote dialogue and understanding between the parties," the statement said.
Although the European Union maintains its one-China policy, it also attaches great importance to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, according to the statement.
"Within its one-China policy, the E.U. continues to take the view that the Taiwan question should be settled peacefully through cross-strait negotiations," the statement said.
"We welcome any efforts by the two sides to lower tensions and to find a mutually acceptable basis for a resumption of peaceful dialogue," the statement further said.
It also said that the European Union would urge both sides to avoid taking any unilateral steps that might heighten tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED CROSS-STRAIT PEACE PROMOTION LAW MAY POSE ADDITIONAL TROUBLE

TEXT.P: A cross-Taiwan Strait peace promotion law proposed by the opposition People First Party (PFP) could be caught up in the existing political disputes and pose additional problems, an official in charge of mainland China policy said Friday.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , made the remarks amid reports that President Chen Shui-bian was irritated about the proposed law, believing it will seriously infringe upon the rights of the president with regard to decision-making on cross-strait issues.

According to the draft law unveiled by the PFP in October, a cross-strait peace consultation special committee would be established under the law that would be able to negotiate and consult with the mainland authorities without the authorization of the president.

Any cross-strait peace agreement signed by the committee and approved by the Legislative Yuan would become effective after being put to a public referendum. The resolutions and suggested laws passed by the committee and approved by the legislature would be binding for government agencies, according to the draft law.

Chiu noted that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have tried to put aside political differences that are unlikely to be resolved in the short term. If the PFP promotes its proposed law, it will only jump right into yet another political dispute that will only add unnecessary trouble without providing substantial assistance, he said.

On a proposed "anti-secession law" on the mainland designed to prevent Taiwan from declaring independence, Chiu said the proposed law will not help create an atmosphere favorable to cross-strait goodwill.
The international community also thinks it is unnecessary to formulate such a law and that it will not be conducive to the development of cross-strait relations, he continued.

On Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's expressed intention to go to the mainland to communicate with Beijing on the proposed "anti-secession law, " Chiu said that any individuals or political parties who want to contribute to the positive development of cross-strait relations, as long they act in line with the pace and direction of the government, are welcome to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Divided Senate Confirms Gonzales; Vote Reflects Concern Over Detainee Policy.
The Senate voted 60 to 36 yesterday to confirm Alberto R. Gonzales as attorney general, but only a handful of Democrats backed him after days of often strident debate over his role in setting controversial interrogation policies for detainees.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOODWILL RHETORIC NEEDS BACKUP WITH ACTION: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san expressed welcome Friday to remarks made by a senior Beijing official in charge of Taiwan affairs that "the two intermediary bodies across the Taiwan Strait are expected to continue to maintain good relations in the future, " saying that it is definitely a goodwill overture.
Chiu added, however, that goodwill rhetoric needs the support of action to make it a reality.

Chiu was referring to remarks made by Sun Yafu, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Thursday after Sun returned to the mainland from Taiwan, where he and ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei paid their last respects Wednesday to the late Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, a respected business tycoon who served as Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.
Sun told the Chinese media that ARATS and the SEF are expected to "continue to interact, engage and negotiate in a favorable atmosphere" in the future.

Chiu said that the MAC keenly hopes that both organizations will transform rhetoric into action while trying their utmost to remove or at least "properly handle" barriers in the way of bilateral engagement.

The visit to Taiwan by Sun, who is also concurrently deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland's State Council, marked the first high-level Beijing official visit to Taiwan since the two sides suspended regular dialogue in mid-1999 over former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's "state-to-state" remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE BUREAU PLANS TO RAISE PREMIUM CEILINGS

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) is planning to raise the ceiling of premiums of the national health insurance program in an effort to raise funds to save the program from bankruptcy, a BNHI official said Friday.

BNHI Vice President Lai Chin-hsiang said the bureau is planning to raise the ceiling of premiums from the current level of NT$87,600 to NT$130,000 in an attempt to increase revenues to support the financially troubled national health insurance program.

If the ceiling is raised to NT$130,000, an extra NT$1.3 billion is expected to be generated per year to help with the program, which is doomed to bankruptcy if no extra funds are infused after March this year, Lai said.

Meanwhile, the BNHI hopes that the tobacco tax will also be raised to accelerate this effort, Lai said, adding that another NT$4 billion to NT$6 billion is expected to be generated should the tobacco tax be increased from the present NT$5 to NT$8 or NT$10 per pack of cigarettes.

Implementation of both the premium ceiling raise and the raise in tobacco tax needs the consent by the Legislative Yuan by amending the current national health insurance law, as well as the tobacco and liquor law, Lai added.

Earlier in the day, Premier Frank Hsieh called for support from the Legislative Yuan for several proposed amendments to related statutes to help save the national health insurance program from bankruptcy.

Hsieh met with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to seek legislative support for several proposed amendments to existing laws to allow for transferring tobacco and liquor tax revenues to support the national health insurance program.

Hsieh said that the health insurance program's reserve funds will run out by the end of March and that the program is expected to be on the brink of collapse should no extra funds be infused after that time.

The premier noted that implementing a proposed second-generation health insurance program -- currently in the pipelines at the Department of Health (DOH) -- under which premiums would be calculated based on a person's total income as opposed to just their salary, also requires the Legislative Yuan's support to be passed into law.
Under this proposed new health insurance program, premium ceilings would be adjusted upward, requiring people with higher incomes to share a greater burden in supporting the program.
Commenting on the proposed second-generation program, Wang said that it makes sense to him and that the issue can be brought to the Legislative Yuan floor for discussion.
The Department of Health said recently that it will adopt austerity measures to save the national health insurance program from bankruptcy without raising premiums for a year or so.

The then DOH Minister Chen Chien-jen said the department will respect the consensus reached by participants in a public forum in mid-January rejecting a proposed hike in health insurance premiums. He said the DOH will refrain from raising premiums this year.

Pointing out that there is room to reduce the program's costs by 5 percent to 10 percent through cost-saving measures and curbing waste, Chen said that if this can be achieved, the program should be able to continue operating for another year or so without an increase in premiums.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT GIVES PRIORITY TO CRACKDOWN ON PHONE FRAUD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that a crackdown on telephone fraud and coercion is one of the government's priorities.
Hsieh made the remarks at a special Cabinet meeting aimed at curbing crime and improving public order during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday.

Noting that many people have complained about rampant telephone fraud and coercion, Hsieh said law enforcement authorities should cooperate closely in investigating the sources of fraudulent telephones and figurehead bank accounts in order to prevent criminal rings from using phones to swindle money from ordinary citizens or coerce them into joining criminal operations.
Law enforcement authorities should also cut red tape and simplify administrative measures to assist victims in retrieving their lost funds.

Hsieh further said President Chen Shui-bian has directed the Cabinet to give priority to clamping down on criminal activities. Relevant government agencies should pay more heed to average citizens' feelings about public order and work even harder to raise the crime-fighting-related approval rating, Hsieh said.

While the number of burglary, fraud, firearm and drug trafficking cases increased last year, Hsieh said the crime solution rate also rose proportionally. "We recognize police efforts in this regard," he added.
Meanwhile, Hsieh urged police to respond quickly to crime reports and recruit volunteers to strengthen services for victims of crime.
Law enforcement authorities should also step up publicity to let the public understand the progress in crime-fighting campaign and allay their misgivings, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN PROSECUTOR'S OFFICE TO STEP UP INVESTIGATION INTO BAD PORK

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CAN) The Justice Department has instructed the Yunlin County Prosecutor's Office to step up an investigation into pork from sick and dead pigs finding its way into major meat markets.

Vice Justice Minister Yen Ta-he made the remarks in a press conference Friday as the nation continued to focus on the problem pork following the arrest of a meat supplier in Yunlin County and a major distributor in Taichung, who reportedly made a lot of money by selling pork from sick or dead pigs Wednesday.

Reports said that nearly 10,000 kg of the bad pork has found its way into major hotels, restaurants and shopping malls in Taipei city and county, Taichung city and county and Yunlin and Kaohsiung counties.

Yen said that the Yunlin Prosecutor's Office found that some illicit rings are collecting the pork and that investigators have found that five slaughter houses in Yunlin are involved in the case and are tracking down on their distribution networks.
Yunlin County raises more than 1.3 million hogs annually. Judging from the survival rate of about 75 percent of the raised hogs, the number of sick or dead pigs could be large, reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC RELEASES COMMERCIAL FOR 'NEW CROSS-STRAIT TIES'

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) released an infomercial Friday urging mainland China to work with Taiwan to overcome their mutual obstacles to make way for "new cross-Taiwan Strait relations."
The 30-second film, titled "New Year, New Cross-Strait Relations" will be aired on major TV networks in Taiwan from Friday, according to the MAC.

With no narration, the film is presented with a subtitle reading "unconditional, practical, put disputes aside, respect each other" and images of two drivers together braving a storm to remove a fallen tree that blocks their way.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said both Taiwan and the mainland are well aware of the fact that it will be impossible to achieve a mutually acceptable resolution to their political disputes in the near future.
Therefore, like the two drivers who remove the barricade, both sides should think of a way to bypass their disputes, Chiu said.

Chiu urged the Beijing authorities to cherish the present "amiable" cross-strait atmosphere, seek to reopen cross-strait negotiations and dialogue and abandon their plan to enact an "anti-secession law," so as not to miss the opportunity of peace.
The infomercial was released after special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights were launched last week.

Sun Yafu, vice president of mainland-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , and ARATS Secretary-General Li Yafei also visited Taiwan earlier this week to attend a memorial service for late Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
Both developments are considered by Taiwan as signs of cross-strait relations tempering after tensions over the past few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA FLIGHT TO GUANGZHOU RETURNS WITH 122 PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: A TransAsia Airways Lunar New Year direct charter flight from Taipei to Guangzhou, in mainland China's Guangdong Province, returned to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Friday with 122 passengers aboard.
It was the second TransAsia direct charter flight between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for the Lunar New Year holiday, TransAsia President Sun Hung-hsiang said.

TransAsia Airways is among six Taiwan carriers authorized to operate the special flights from Jan. 29-Feb. 20 to transport Taiwanese businessmen operating on the mainland home for the Chinese New Year holiday.
The authorities, as well as private airline operators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, reached a consensus Jan. 15 on the long-awaited direct air links.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.016 to close at NT$31.623.
A total of US$741 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.740 and slid to a low of NT$31.590 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL PRODUCTION MAKES UP 11.5 PERCENT OF GDP

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's financial sector increased to 11.5 percent of the country's gross domestic product in 2003, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported Friday.

The ratio is a similar level to those of Hong Kong and Singapore, two of the world's key financial centers, CEPD officials said, adding that in an effort to balance the country's finances, the government imposed a reform package in April 2003.

The new Cabinet led by Premier Frank Hsieh pointed out clearly in a Feb. 1 meeting that financial reform will continue to be a key issue on the Executive Yuan's agenda and that relevant government agencies will keep on working toward that end.

Stressing that financial reform is a long-term goal of the government to bolster Taiwan's economic development, CEPD officials said that the reform has showed initial improvement. For instance, mergers in the banking industry have been conducted smoothly and the banks' overdue loan ratios have been noticeably reduced, they noted.

They said the council has worked out five strategies containing 51 measures and 160 reviewed rules and regulations that are being followed by the relevant government agencies after being approved late last year by the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TAIWAN FLOWER EXPO OPENS

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan Flower Expo opened Friday in Changhua, central Taiwan.
The show will for the first time provide visitors with the opportunity to take a hot air balloon trip to view the various colorful blossoms from the skies.

Also featured in the show is a huge rainbow garden, an animal zone for children, as well as a series of singing and music performances, celebrity autographs and Chinese talk shows daily throughout the show, which will end March 13.
Changhua Magistrate Wong Chin-chu said at the opening ceremony that the Executive Yuan approved the national flower zone project, which is an honor and responsibility for the county.
Premier Frank Hsieh also lauded the efforts of Changhua to develop its horticulture industry, saying that it will help improve the unemployment rate and upgrade the living environment of the people.

He also said he was impressed by the beauty of the flower expo when he visited it last year, adding that the central government provides subsidies to local governments on a competitive basis, meaning that if a local government performs better, it will also get bigger subsidy from the central government.

Hsieh and Wong then took to the sky in a hot air balloon. Both expressed the hope that Taiwan people will take the chance of the weeklong Chinese New Year holiday next week to go to Changhua for the flower show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO APPEAL COURT RULING ON LIBEL SUIT AGAINST DPP

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou announced Friday his decision to appeal a court judgment that rejected a libel claim he had made against the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
However, Ma said he will drop the case if the DPP apologizes to him.

The dispute was triggered by a TV commercial produced by the DPP in October 2003 to promote a referendum for a new Constitution, which Ma claims libelously painted him as a pro-mainland China politician.

In the film, footage of Ma attending a National Day flag-raising ceremony was edited together with images showing people raising the People's Republic of China national flag, with a voice in the background shouting "long live Hu Jintao."
Ma filed his lawsuit with the Taipei District Court, asking for NT$1 million (US$31,646) in compensation and demanding that the DPP print an apology in newspapers.
The court rejected Ma's claim last month on the grounds that the content of the commercial was protected by freedom of speech.
Calling the result regrettable and disappointing, Ma said the judgment will set a dangerous precedent because it encourages mud-slinging.
Ma said he is not pro-mainland, which he said can be seen from his constant criticism of the communist regime.

Also, Ma pointed out that he has never missed the annual event commemorating the pro-democracy activists massacred by mainland troops in Tiananmen Square June 4, 1989, and has spoken up for the Falun Gong members who have been persecuted by the Beijing authorities.
In response to Ma's decision to lodge an appeal, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan urged Ma to respect and trust the judiciary.

Cheng said the footage used in the commercial was taken from TV news reports and he claimed that the DPP had "no intention" of painting Ma as a pro-mainland politician but was only trying to highlight Beijing's suppression of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN CAPITAL UP ON STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Foreign capital continued flooding into the domestic stock market, with its combined value hitting US$81.6 billion as of the end of January, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reported Friday.
The figure represents a rise over the US$80.1 billion recorded in late December, with about NT$1.5 billion funneled into the domestic stock market in January, FSC officials said.

Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose on every trading day since the beginning of this month, with overbought value reaching more than NT$10 billion per day, creating a positive sentiment for the reopening of the market after the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday, market watchers said. The market closed on Feb. 4 and will reopen Feb. 14.

The independent FSC was set up in 2004 to oversee the domestic banking insurance, securities and futures industries, which were exercised in the past by the Ministry of Finance, the Central Bank of China and the Central Depository Insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH SAYS HE'S NOT ABLE TO MEET KMT'S CONDITIONS FOR VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday he is not in a position to negotiate with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) over its conditions for one of its vice chairmen to join his Cabinet as vice premier.

"As a premier, I cannot fulfill the KMT's prerequisite for party-to-party negotiations for KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang to join the Cabinet as vice premier, " Hsieh said after attending the opening ceremony for the 2005 Taiwan Flower Exposition in the central county of Changhua.
With a view to promoting inter-party reconciliation, Hsieh has so far left vacant the vice premier post and has repeatedly expressed his desire to invite Chiang to serve as his deputy.

However, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said Thursday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must negotiate with the KMT to clarify and seek consensus on certain critical policy issues before the KMT accepts the DPP's offer to appoint Chiang.

The issues to be discussed should include the country's status, the opening of direct transportation links with mainland China, plans to change the official name of the country, investigations into last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, and attempts to liquidate the KMT's ill-gotten assets, in addition to the controversial Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project, Lien said, adding that the two parties also need to negotiate on how much authorization Chiang will enjoy as vice premier to ensure he will not be just a dummy in the DPP government.
In his first response to Lien's proposal, Hsieh said that as he is not DPP chairman, he is not in a position to conduct party-to-party negotiations on those issues.

Hsieh said he keenly hopes that Lien can reconsider his offer to Chiang during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday and change the KMT's stance. "I'm hopeful that Lien will change his mind during the lunar new year holiday that will run from Feb. 9 through Feb. 13. After the holiday, I would be willing to meet with Lien to express my thanks to his consent to Chiang's participation in the DPP administration," Hsieh said.
If Lien still insists on the KMT's stance and is unwilling to meet with him, Hsieh said he will look for another suitable person to serve as vice premier.
Meanwhile, the DPP's traditional ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), panned the KMT for proposing what it called "absurd and outrageous" conditions for Chiang's participation in Hsieh's Cabinet.
TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang said the KMT's conditions run counter to the present mainstream public opinion for inter-party reconciliation.

"It is regrettable that Lien put the KMT's partisan interests, such as ill-gotten party assets, above national interests and public aspirations for political stability, " Su said, adding that the DPP should not compromise its core values simply for promoting inter-party reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD DEVELOP THREE METROPOLISES: CEPD

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planning agency has suggested that the government pool its resources to develop one metropolis each in northern, central and southern Taiwan.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) noted that although Taiwan has continued to make progress in a global competitiveness report by the World Economic Forum in 2004, which is positive about Taiwan's efforts to improve its economic fundamentals and investment environment, it is not given a high score in terms of business competitiveness.

CEPD officials said that with strong international competition triggered by globalization, Taiwan should make focusing its resources into developing the metropolises into its top priority so that the overall competitiveness and the attraction of the three cities would be higher than those of foreign countries.
The three metropolises would then play a magnet effect and become the three development centers of Taiwan, the officials claimed.

They also said that the metropolises would each have the goal of becoming a world-class city, taking into consideration the development of the cities and counties they encompass so as to turn into regional economic bodies with local features.

Each would have a world-class harbor and airport so that they can easily be integrated into the global traffic network, and each would develop competitive industries so as to lead the development of the national economy and integrate it into the global economic system.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT VISITS CANDY WORLD FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu paid a visit Friday to the Candy World 2005 festival being held in Chiali township in the southern county of Tainan.
Lu handed out lollipops to children and said the festive event reminded her of her childhood.

The festival, co-organized by the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Tainan County Government and the Taiwan Agricultural Strategy Coalition, has 11 sections, including candy exhibitions from 25 countries, music and theater for children, celebrity autographs, a candy parade, fireworks, a Taiwanese candy cultural showroom, a science fun house, a children's playground, a 3D ARC animation theater, a Yami cultural gallery and an outdoor carnival.
Three of the most popular attractions are the International Candy Exhibition Hall, the Candy Fun House and the International Chocolate Exhibition Hall.
The festival will run through Feb. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-FIFTH OF SUICIDE VICTIMS WERE JOBLESS BEFORE DEATH: FOREIGN STUDY

TEXT.P: While local National Health Insurance and Labor Insurance data show that the risk of jobless people dying in a year is double that of working people, and a foreign study also identifies unemployment as a possible factor leading to suicide, a local researcher said Friday.

Cheng Tai-an, a research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Institute of Biomedical Sciences, said recent a study conducted by foreign researchers indicates that one-fifth of suicide victims were unemployed before their death.
No similar study is available locally, Cheng said.
According to Cheng, suicide is a complicated phenomenon involving both social and psychological dimensions, and unemployment does not always lead to suicide.
Many people are depressive or alcoholic before attempting suicide, which could be caused by a sense of loss resulted from the loss of jobs, close relatives and health, Cheng said.
Physically, these people may complain of insomnia and tiredness, he said.
Special occasions such as birthdays, marriage anniversaries and death anniversaries of relatives are when these people are most likely to attempt suicide, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SALT MUSEUM OPENS IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Salt Museum opened Friday in Chiku township in the southern county of Tainan.
Vice President Annette Lu cut the ribbon at a ceremony to open the museum and later looked at various exhibits featuring salt-related articles. Lu also tried her hand at collecting salt.
The museum, currently run by a group of retired employees of the Taiyen Biotech Co., formerly known as Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp., is a four-story building with around 10,000 artifacts on display.
Aside from display sections, the salt museum is scheduled to set up a children's playground and a "salt culture park."

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO AGRICULTURAL EXPERTS RECEIVE PRESIDENTIAL AWARDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday the establishment of the Presidential Agriculture Awards is aimed at honoring those who have dedicated themselves to farming and agricultural development.
Chen made the remarks at the presentation of the awards to two outstanding agricultural experts for their lifelong dedication to agriculture.

It marked the first time that the government has set up the top-level presidential awards to honor the nation's agricultural professionals. The presentation ceremony took place at the Council of Agriculture headquarters in Taipei.

Chen personally presented the Agricultural Peace Award to Hsieh Shun-ching, 77, for his remarkable contributions to international cooperation in the agricultural sector, and the Agricultural Service Award to Hsu chin-hsi, 66, for his long-term contributions to water productivity enhancement.

The first Presidential Agriculture Awards honor dedicated professionals in five categories -- food safety, agricultural innovation, agricultural service, ecological conservation along with an agricultural peace award. The awards in the three remaining categories were not given because the jury didn't find qualified candidates.

Noting that the five award categories form core values of Taiwan's agricultural development, Chen said he was moved by the two winners' professionalism, dedication and perseverance. "Their achievements glorify the presidential awards," he added.

The president further said he hopes the awards can help encourage agricultural professionals to redouble their efforts to further upgrade the competitiveness of the nation's agricultural sector and create yet another economic miracle in Taiwan.
For his part, Hsieh, an expert on rice cultivation, said the award is a great honor for him.

"I was born in a rural town, majored in agriculture during my university and graduate school years and then worked at agricultural agencies. My whole life has been closely related with agriculture. I feel honored to receive the award," an emotional Hsieh said.

Hsieh, now a professor of tropical agriculture at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan, was one of the leading people promoting agricultural technology transfer to developing countries.

Hsu, head of the Tainan-based Chianan Irrigation Association, has contributed much to the improvement of irrigation systems and flexible allocation of water resources to different sectors for households, industry and agriculture to counter droughts. (By Sofia Wu) ednitem/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS CALL FOR RECTIFICATION OF DICTUM ON STUDENTS' NOTEBOOKS

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers urged the Ministry of Education Friday to rectify the decades-old adage printed on elementary and junior high school students' standard notebooks to avoid confusing their sense of national identity.

Legislators Trong Chai and Chuang Ho-tzu said at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan that a large number of local elementary and junior high schools still distribute notebooks printed with the maxim urging students to be "a good student and a decent Chinese citizen."
The two DPP lawmakers said they are afraid that the slogan could confuse local young students regarding their concept of national identity.

"The term of 'ethnicity' should be clearly distinguished from that of 'country.' For instance, Singaporeans would probably say they are ethnic Chinese, but they would never say they are Chinese citizens," Chai said.
He urged the Ministry of Education to change the saying to read "be a good student and a decent Taiwanese" to signify Taiwan's national identity distinct from that of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL REFUSES TO ACCEPT HONG KONG'S REPORT ON 1999 CRASH

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, refused Friday to accept the results of an investigation by the Hong Kong civil aviation authorities into a CAL jet crash in August 1999 at Chek Lap Kok Airport, arguing that wind shear, rather than human error, was behind the accident.

CAL public relations director Liang Han-chung said that the aviation company cannot accept the investigation results that ascribed the fatal accident to pilot error on the grounds that Boeing Corporation, the maker of the MD-11 jet plane, found new evidence during the investigation that a wind gust suddenly changed direction 1.5 seconds before the plane touched down.

Evidence collected from the plane's flight data recorder (FDR) showed that swift wind changes, triggered by a tropical storm sweeping through Hong Kong at that time, made the pilot unable to control the aircraft's sudden descend, Liang said, pointing out that wind, not the pilot, caused the accident.
According to Liang, CAL forwarded the evidence to the Hong Kong Civil Aviation Department and asked it to attach the information to its investigation report.

CAL CI642 from Bangkok with 300 passengers and crew on board plunged into the runway of Chek Lap Kok Airport Aug. 22, 1999 while trying to land during a typhoon. It flipped and burst into flames, killing three and seriously injuring 50.

Taiwan's Aviation Security Commission, which helped in the investigation, pointed out that the FDR showed that the pilot tried hard to keep the airplane aloft when the gust hit. But the wind was too strong for the pilot to respond, it concluded.
The plane crashed at the airport of Hong Kong, and the Hong Kong government was in charge of carrying out the plane in line with international norms.

According to the Hong Kong investigation report, the cause of the accident was the commander's inability to arrest the high rate of descent, a foreign wire service reported. The pilot was descending too fast as he tried to touch down during a tropical storm, the services reported, citing the Hong Kong's Civil Aviation Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS FORM 'BEGGARS ALLIANCE' TO FOCUS ATTENTION ON POVERTY

TEXT.P: A group of activists formed a "Beggars Alliance" Friday to focus public attention on the increasingly serious issue of poverty.

Fang Cheng-ping, convener of the Beggars Alliance, said the alliance has over 20 founding members from various walks of life, including SOHO (small office/home office) entrepreneurs, engineers and homemakers.

"We are not beggars. We have become friends through the Internet. Our main purpose of forming the Beggars Alliance is to generate public interest in poverty, which has become increasingly serious in our society. By forming the alliance, we hope to promote social welfare benefits for the unemployed and the impoverished, " Fang said at a news conference.

Fang and other founding members presented a petition to the Executive Yuan after announcing the formation of the Beggars Alliance, urging the government to designate Feb. 4 as Beggars Day to remind local people not to forget the issue of poverty.
"'Feb. 4' sounds like 'starving to death' in Mandarin Chinese. We hope to designate the day as Beggars Day to symbolize concern and care for poor people," Fang said.
Noting that poverty is not just a personal problem, Fang said the government should assume the responsibility of helping find ways to address the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN REVEALS MAIN ADMINISTRATION GUIDELINES FOR THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan sent a report to the Legislative Yuan Friday outlining four main administration guidelines for this year.
They are: pursuing a Taiwan-centric identity, improving the social security network, establishing a normal political landscape and promoting economic strategic alliances.

The report said that the guidelines are based on the four main administration targets set by President Chen Shui-bian: unite the people of Taiwan, stabilize cross-Taiwan Strait relations, maintain social order and bring prosperity to the country's economy.
The real challenge facing Taiwan is no longer in sharpening the country's economic competitiveness, but in the establishment of a Taiwan-centric culture and national identity, it noted.
The country's political and economic achievements should be channeled into the re-establishment of Taiwan's spiritual cultivation and cultural values, it stressed.
On political developments, the report said the Executive Yuan is seeking to establish a timely, suitable and feasible constitutional framework for Taiwan and improve the government's efficiency.

The Executive Yuan will do what is necessary to see that legislative reforms are carried out and address problems in the Constitution. The report goes on to list various goals; among them, promoting the legislation of sunshine laws, enacting an international human rights code as domestic law, reorganizing the government, establishing a creative and dynamic administrative culture, and creating an innovative mechanism for public services.
On social security and social order, the government will increase the care it gives the elderly, children in need, and the sick and handicapped.

Regarding the economy, the government will seek to establish international strategic alliances, explore new trade opportunities through a global deployment campaign, create momentum in economic growth by promoting investment in Taiwan, make use of the advantages that Taiwan has to create a profit-making foundation for the manufacturing industry, create additional job opportunities for improving social security and form a plan for sustainable use of the country's land.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Feb. 5:
09:00, The Minister of Economic Affairs will visit and extend her greetings to Taipower personnel who are on duty during the lunar new year holiday at No. 75, Keelung Rd., Sec. 4, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO GIVE OUT 20,000 'RED ENVELOPES' ON LUNAR NEW YEAR'S DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will distribute 20,000 specially designed "red envelopes" in his hometown in the southern county of Tainan on the Feb. 9 Chinese Lunar New Year's Day, a Presidential Office spokesman said Friday.

Each red envelope, or "hungpao" in Chinese, contains a new year greeting card with the signatures of President Chen and his wife, Wu Shu-jen. At the center of the card is attached a golden NT$10 coin.
In addition to carrying auspicious words on its two sides, the cover of the envelope features a golden rooster at its center as 2005 is the Year of Rooster on the Chinese zodiac.

Residents from around the island have already begun to line up in front of Chen's home in Kuantien township with empty chairs holding their places. At noon Friday, the line was already a kilometer long. A citizen from Taipei City, identified as Lin Chien-yuan, heads the long line.
It has become a custom for Chen to distribute special red envelopes at his home in Kuantien on Lunar New Year's Day since he assumed the presidency in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PARTICIPATING IN U.S. COLLEGE BOARD'S AP CHINESE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been actively participating in preparations for the United States College Board's advanced placement (AP) Chinese program, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Friday.

Tu said that his ministry and other government agencies jointly donated US$300,000 to the U.S. College Board last year to help finance the preparatory activities and sent a representative to take part in meetings on the implementation of the program.

The Ministry of Education, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Council for Cultural Affairs, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and other government agencies have jointly established a task force for promoting the teaching of Mandarin overseas, he said, adding that helping the U.S. College Board implement the AP Chinese program is one of the ad hoc group's main goals.
According to Tu, the U.S. College Board will begin to organize AP Chinese tests for high school students in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 5, or the 27th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1788: Sir Robert Peel, British prime minister and founder of the Metropolitan Police, is born.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1914: Andreas Papandreou, Greek prime minister, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federated republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a 100 million Swiss franc Holocaust memorial fund.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."
