DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Senate Ratifies Attorney General. After strong protest from Democrats,the Senate voted 60 to 36 to confirm the nomination of Alberto R. Gonzales as attorney general--the smallest margin for confirmation of any of President Bush's second-term Cabinet choices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DOESN'T CONFIRM REPORT ABOUT KMT CHAIRMANSHIP BID

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , would not say Saturday if he intends to run for the party's chairmanship in May.
Ma said while he is willing to assume a heavier share of the responsibilities, there are some other matters that he needs to take into consideration.
He did not elaborate.
A local daily reported Saturday that Ma will officially announce his decision to run for the chairmanship after next week's Lunar New Year holiday.
On former KMT heavyweights Lin Yang-kang's and Hau Pei-tsun's plan to rejoin the party, Ma said the KMT must prepare itself for more former members to return to the party in the future.

Ma said the party must make proper planning on how it is going to deal with its assets and map out its vision for the future development of the party to encourage more people to take part in party reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOOD INDUSTRY EYES INDONESIA'S CHINESE MARKET

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) opened Taiwan food exhibitions at Indonesia's major supermarkets Saturday, focusing on ethnic Chinese customers with high incomes.

TAITRA officials noted that Indonesia has been economically and politically stable during the last three years, with its currency and stock market remaining strong with interest and inflation rates dropping gradually.
With a population of 211.7 million, the fourth-largest country in the world, Indonesia registered an economic growth of 5.4 percent in 2004 due largely to its strong domestic consumption.
The "Taiwan Food Festival" held in seven major supermarkets in Indonesia will last 30 days, hoping to attract Chinese consumers, who play a leading role in Indonesia's economy.
This was the first time TAITRA has held food festivals in Indonesia. Taiwan's major food companies are also participating.
An Indonesian importer of Taiwanese products has reached agreements with local supermarkets to put the Taiwanese food on the shelves for long-term sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES HOPE TO ATTRACT HONG KONG STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Presidents of several local universities will visit Hong Kong later this month to participate in a higher education exhibition with an aim to attract more Hong Kong students to study in Taiwan.
This will be the first time in 15 years that Taiwanese universities will participate in the large education exhibition to be held Feb. 19-22.
There were 1,500 Hong Kong students pursuing higher education in Taiwan in 1990; however, the number dropped to only 248 last year.
The Ministry of Education has put emphasis on making Taiwan's universities more diverse and attractive to international students.

The leaders of the Taiwan universities include National Taiwan University President Chen Wei-jao, Fu Jen Catholic University President Bernard Li, and National Chi Nan University President Chang Chin-fu.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Senate rushes budget bill
The Senate will wind up the ongoing debates on the proposed national budget by Tuesday, Feb. 8, in time for its projected presentation and approval by President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo on or before Valentine's Day, Senate President and Liberal Party head Franklin Drilon said yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Senators cry blackmail over oil price hikes threat
WARNINGS from oil firms that pump prices and power rates will rise if tax exemptions of petroleum products are lifted are a form of blackmail the Senate cannot accept.
The Philippine Star: Peso strengthens to 54.68:$1
The peso continued to rally yesterday, hitting a new 15-month high of 54.680 against the US dollar as investor sentiment remained upbeat following a series of positive developments in the economy.
The Manila Times: Miriam backs down
Sen. Miriam Defensor Santiago on Friday tried to defuse her simmering row with provincial governors, saying her real enemies are the illegal loggers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Dengue alert goes out as cases hit a high.
Dengue fever in Singapore looks set to reach a new peak and the authorities are worried, especially with Chinese New Year drawing near.
They fear it will worsen because of the popular custom here of celebrating the festive season with masses of such potted plants as Cherry Blossoms, Pussy Willows, Celosias and Lucky Bamboos.
These plants are 'potential lush breeding grounds' for the dengue-causing Aedes mosquito, warns the National Environment Agency (NEA) , which notes that the threat lies in letting water in vases or flower-pot plates becoming stagnant. 'We urge the public to be vigilant and prevent water from stagnating in their homes,' said NEA's environmental health department head, Mr Dalson Chung.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Nicoll Highway Circle Line MRT station moves a hectometer to the south because the safe bored tunneling.
The Nicoll Highway Circle Line project restarts now, the Land Transport Authority changes to the safety way.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Appellate court Backs Companies in Tobacco Case
A U.S. federal appeals court delivered a major victory to the nation's leading tobacco companies on Friday, ruling that the government cannot force them to turn over US$280 billion in profits if a trial court finds that the company engaged in a conspiracy of fraud and deceit to promote smoking. The 2-to-1 decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia strikes at the heart of the government's biggest legal effort ever to punish cigarette makers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Iraqi Shiites take strong lead in first official election returns.
Iraqi officials released the first partial returns from national elections Thursday, showing a commanding lead by candidate backed by the Shiite Muslim clergy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REMAINS HOPEFUL ABOUT VICE PREMIER OFFER TO KMT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday he is still hopeful that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang will become his deputy, and he urged the KMT to consider his offer seriously.
Hsieh said he will not consider other candidates before Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Yi-Yang and KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng meet on Feb. 17 over the matter.
Hsieh has openly expressed his desire to appoint Chiang as vice premier after assuming the premiership early this week.

However, KMT Chairman Lien Chan insisted that such an appointment could only be considered through party-to-party negotiations. Lien said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT must first sort out their differences through negotiations on issues such as the country's status, opening direct transportation links with mainland China, plans to change the official name of the country, investigations into last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, attempts to liquidate the KMT's ill-gotten assets, and the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project.
Lien also asked to discuss how much authorization Chiang would enjoy as vice premier.
On this issue, Hsieh said the power of vice premier is dictated by law, which is to assist the premier in administering government affairs.
The power of the vice premier will not surpass that of the premier and does not extend to national defense and foreign affairs, Hsieh pointed out.

While cross-Taiwan Strait relations are under the command of the president and the National Security Council, the premier does not have a final say in such policies, not to mention the vice premier, according to Hsieh.
Therefore, Hsieh said, some of the issues proposed by the KMT for negotiations are beyond the Executive Yuan's jurisdiction.
As to the KMT's request for party-to-party negotiations, Hsieh said this would have to wait until DPP Chairman-elect Su Tseng-chang is sworn in on Feb. 15 before any negotiations could start.
Hsieh said he invited Chiang to enter the Cabinet because he believes Chiang's talent would be of great help to the country and that he hopes there will be good news from the KMT soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABUSED KIDS GET A BIT OF NEW YEAR'S CHEER FROM COUNTY MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: Several abused or abandoned children in the care of foster parents got an early Chinese New Year's gift Saturday from the head of Changhua County, who gave them each a red envelope containing money.

The event, which brought together 14 volunteer families, was organized by the Social Affairs Bureau under the Changhua County Government and the Changhua Chapter of the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families.
Changhua County Magistrate Wong Chin-chu also gave dolls to the children. The children, in return, thanked her with kisses.
The families will give the children the best of care, Wong said, adding that she wished them all a happy lunar new year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABUNDANT FISH, VEGETABLE SUPPLY BEFORE NEW YEAR FESTIVAL: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Fishery authorities said on Saturday that there should be a sufficient supply of fish at markets around the island to meet increased demand during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday since aquaculturalists have been encouraged to up production and imports.

About 7,000 tons of fish are expected to reach the 24 major markets around the island during the five-day period prior to the Lunar New Year, which will falls on Feb. 9, according to the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture.
The amount is a 30-percent increase over normal days, officials of the agency said, noting that 6,566 tons of fish were put on the market during last year's holiday.
Prices are expected to rise slightly to average NT$85 per kilogram, a 10 percent to 12 percent increase over non-seasonal days, according to the administration.
Officials suggested consumers purchase high-quality Taiwan-farmed tilapia at reasonable prices to add to their New Year's dinner.
Meanwhile, there have been abundant fruits and vegetables at markets recently thanks to good harvests, according to the Hsiluo fruit and vegetable market in Yunlin County, central Taiwan.

As a result of the good supply, prices of fruits and vegetables were lower over the past days, market dealers said, but indicated they expect that prices will move higher in the next few days because of increased demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG FLOWER SHOW KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: People flocked to the opening day of the Kaohsiung Flower Show Saturday.
Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai and Dai Cheng-yao, vice chairman of the Council of Agriculture jointly cut a ribbon to open the show Saturday. The show runs until March 6.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Chen said that nature, the arts and life are the major themes of the activity, whose goal is to promote the idea of protecting the natural environment of the island. He also called on citizens from around the nation to visit the flower show.
The venue of the exhibition, covering an area of eight hectares, is divided into eight theme areas. The exhibition features 400,000 items related to horticulture, according to organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TANGERINES HIT SINGAPORE'S FRUIT MARKETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's large and sweet tangerines have made inroads into Singapore's fruit markets during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.
According to a Singaporean fruit importer, tangerines serve as indispensable gifts for the people of Singapore who intend to extend new year's greetings at their friends' or relatives' homes.
With the approach of the Chinese Lunar New Year, the price of domestic tangerines had gradually risen. To check the rise, local fruit sellers decided to import Taiwan's sweet tangerines.
The tangerines sold in Singapore were grown in Hsinchu, in the north, and Taichung, in the center of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG, TAIPEI COUNTY MOST PRONE TO TSUNAMI DISASTER

TEXT.P: Keelung City and Taipei County are Taiwan's most tsunami-prone areas, according to a rating system designed by the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center.

The center decided to hammer out a tsunami warning system after tsunamis triggered by a strong earthquake beneath the Indian Ocean devastated a dozen South and Southeast Asian countries late last December.

The center classified the nation's 25 cities and counties into three levels in terms of the risk of being hit by tsunamis. According to the newly completed rating system, Keelung and Taipei County in northern Taiwan rank at the first level as the riskiest areas.
In contrast, Nantou County, Chiayi City, Taichung City and Taipei City are rated as "free of tsunami threat" because they are far away from the sea.
Three northwestern counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli as well as two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu rank at the third level with limited tsunami risk.
The remaining cities and counties, including northeastern Ilan County and two eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung, rank at the second level, with a bit higher risk than the third-level areas.

Kuo Kai-wen, director of the Seismology Center, said Taiwan has been rattled by 36 magnitude-7 or stronger earthquakes since 1900. While more than 20 of them originated below the shallow seabed, Kuo said, none of them ever caused disastrous tsunamis.

Nevertheless, Kuo said that judging from the Dec. 26 Indian Ocean tsunamis, nobody can make assurances that Taiwan will never be hit by tsunamis. Therefore, he said, Taiwan should still work out response measures to cope with any possible tsunami disasters.
In the future, Kuo said, the Seismology Center will issue a tsunami warning whenever a magnitude-7 earthquake undersea at a depth of less than 35 kilometers is reported.
Meanwhile, government agencies are scheduled to unveil regulations before the end of February to govern ship and train control and evacuation of coastal areas after a tsunami warning is issued.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS FREEWAY BUREAU FOR HOLIDAY TRAFFIC BRIEFING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh visited the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau Saturday and was briefed on traffic controls and conditions that motorist should expect during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday beginning Feb. 8.

Officials of the National Highway Police Bureau told Hsieh that they will mobilize 15,080 policemen to patrol the highways, from the air and on the ground, during the holiday that will run through Feb. 13.

Noting that improving traffic and social order, as well as cracking down on substandard foods are priority jobs for the government during the most important Chinese festival, Hsieh urged all public servants to work hard to reach these goals.

Hailing officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications for their efforts in overseeing traffic on the highways during the last three Chinese New Year holidays, Hsieh encouraged them to continue the good work.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA STEPS UP CRACKDOWN ON SALES OF TAINTED PORK

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) has decided to quadruple its reward to NT$2 million (US$63,291) for information concerning the sale of tainted meat after a large quantity of unhealthful pork from pigs dying of sickness was recently uncovered, an official said Saturday.

At a news conference held by the Consumers' Foundation, Lin Shih-yu, deputy director-general of the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, said 32 cases of unwholesome pork sales have been uncovered around Taiwan since 2001.
They include the latest three cases in Yunlin County on Feb. 1, in which more than 4,500 kilograms of pork from pigs dying of sickness were found, Lin pointed out.
In these cases, the carcasses of the dead pigs were illicitly processed for human consumption. They should have been buried, cremated or processed into animal feed, Lin said.

Members of the ROC Swine Association said the problem exists because the penalty for the offence is too light, and they urged prosecution authorities to charge violators with creating a public hazard and fraud.

Meanwhile, Consumers' Foundation Secretary-General Huang Yi-teng proposed that the government set up a system to monitor the origin, breeding, inspection, slaughtering, packaging, delivery and marketing of meat to ensure its quality.

To increase the incentive for pig farmers to dispose of their dead pigs lawfully, the government should establish an insurance system or a system under which the dead animals will be paid for according to market prices, according to the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN WARNS EUROPE AGAINST PLAN TO LIFT CHINA ARMS EMBARGO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. House Representative Sherrod Brown has warned the European Union against lifting its arms embargo against mainland China, saying the move will upset the military balance across the Taiwan Strait.

In his testimony before the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission on Thursday, Brown said the fact that the EU has maintained the embargo for 15 years indicates Europe's ongoing dissatisfaction with the pace of political reform and the human rights record of China, and he urged the EU to reconsider the matter.
"Lifting the embargo will alter the current fragile military balance across the Taiwan Strait and will rapidly tip the balance in China's favor," Brown warned.
"Lifting the EU-China arms ban sends only one signal: Democratic Taiwan will be staring down the barrel of guns manufactured by EU democracies," he added.
The EU is considering lifting the arms embargo and replacing it with a code of conduct on arms exports.
Washington has expressed its opposition to the move out of concerns over China's human rights record.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PREMIER URGED TO FORM CONSULTATION CHANNEL WITH LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Several politicians from the opposition camp urged Premier Frank Hsieh Saturday to establish a channel between the Cabinet and the Legislative Yuan to facilitate political harmony.

Hsieh, who assumed his post on Feb. 1, has promised to make his team a "Cabinet of consultations, " stressing the importance of the Cabinet's being humble in dealing with opposition parties since the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) does not have a majority in the legislature.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jung-kung noted that the DPP had said many sweet words in the past, giving the public high expectations, but the final results always frustrated the people. He expressed hope that this time a real "Cabinet of consultations" can be realized.

Dubbing the former Yu Shyi-kun administration as a "fighting Cabinet, " another KMT official, Tseng Yung-chuan, criticized Yu as causing the confrontation between the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan by prohibiting high-level officials from attending meetings of the opposition parties, which hold a majority in the legislature.

Unlike other opposition politicians that have shown little faith in the ruling party, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng gave high appraisal to the idea of forming a "Cabinet of consultations, " saying that he has experienced the sincerity of the new premier.
Wang said he is confident that there will be a benign interaction between the executive and legislative branches under the leadership of Hsieh.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also one of the KMT's vice chairmen, said he supports Hsieh's idea to establish a Cabinet focusing on consultations, but suggested Hsieh present concrete measures regarding how this was going to happen.

Although there were rumors before the formation of the new Cabinet that members of the opposition People First Party (PFP) could join the DPP administration, PFP Legislator Sun Tai-Chian stressed that the pro-unification "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP will not cooperate with the pro-Taiwan independence DPP unless the ruling party makes clear its stance on the nation's identity.

Newly elected PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao said that whether the Cabinet is one receptive to dialogue or one based on a coalition, political cooperation must be conducted through party-to-party negotiations, and not via secret negotiations by individuals.

Although Hsieh has invited certain KMT members to join his Cabinet as a way of showing goodwill, it remains to be seen whether Hsieh can thaw the long-term rift between the ruling and opposition parties in the new legislature, a political observer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOMELESS PEOPLE ARE FED AND ENTERTAINED

TEXT.P: Three social welfare organizations held large banquets around Taiwan Saturday for homeless and elderly people who live alone.
The organizations offered the banquets in Taipei, Taichung, Hsinchu and Kaoshiung for some 4,000 homeless and elderly people ahead of Chinese Lunar New Year Day on Feb. 9.
Each person at the feast also received a NT$500 red envelope, a tradition for Chinese Lunar New Year, and the organizers also offered some entertainment.
The organizations routinely help some 1,600 homeless people at any one time, with 90 percent of them male and in their 30s to 50s.

DOC.HEADLINE: 869 UNAUTHORIZED MAINLAND-BOUND INVESTMENT CASES UNCOVERED IN 2004

TEXT.P: A total of 869 unauthorized mainland China-bound investment cases were uncovered last year, with investors in 564 of those being fined, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.

To encourage local corporate owners to voluntarily report their mainland investment projects, the MOEA adjusted fines on investment rules violators last March. The fines were adjusted to between NT$50,000 to NT$25 million from the previous NT$1 million to NT$5 million.

Of the 869 unauthorized investment cases uncovered last year, 729 were reported by investors themselves, 22 were discovered with information provided by informers and 118 were uncovered by the Investment Commission itself.
The commission slapped fines on investors in 564 of those cases, of which 539 had paid fines totaling about NT$30 million as of the end of last December.

Encouraging local entrepreneurs to faithfully report their unauthorized mainland investment projects is part of the MOEA's efforts to substantiate the government's policy of "active opening and effective management" regarding mainland-bound investments, a senior official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS EXTENSIVE CRACKDOWN ON SALE OF TAINTED PORK

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh ordered law enforcement authorities on Saturday to launch extensive crackdown raids on pork traders to check the sale of pork from pigs dying from sickness.
The directive was issued after the recent discovery of a large quantity of such unhealthful pork in Yunlin County, which has sparked a public scare.

Hsieh also asked agricultural authorities to step up publicity to provide guidance for consumers to select meat with official quality certification and to ensure pork supply is not affected during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, according to Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai.

DOC.HEADLINE: 55 PASSENGERS BARRED FROM BOARDING AIR CHINA CHARTER FLIGHT

TEXT.P: Fifty-five local holidaymakers were barred from boarding an Air China charter plane bound for Beijing Saturday because they were not legally registered "taishang" -- Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.
They were the first groups of passengers denied embarkation on a cross-strait charter flight since the special Chinese Lunar New Year holiday flight services were launched Jan. 29.

The passengers were recruited by five local travel agencies. They claimed that they joined the tour groups after travel agencies assured them that they were qualified to use the special charter flight services. However, immigration officers intercepted them due to "identity" problems. None of the passengers were legally registered investors or employees of Taiwan-invested firms in mainland China.

After negotiations between China Airlines -- Air China's ground service agent in Taiwan -- and travel agencies, 53 of the passengers agreed to take a China Airlines flight to Hong Kong at 6: 25 p.m. for a free overnight transit stop. They are scheduled to take an Air China flight to Beijing from Hong Kong Sunday for a sightseeing tour. Two other passengers canceled their mainland travel plan after being denied embarkation on the special direct non-stop cross-strait charter flight.
As a result, only 23 passengers managed to take the Air China's Saturday charter flight to Beijing from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Relevant government agencies said they will look into why the 55 passengers with no proper documents proving their identity as "taishang" managed to obtain flight tickets in the first place.

According to a landmark cross-strait deal reached in Macau Jan. 15, six carriers from each side will operate a total of 48 round-trip, non-stop charter flights during the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period between Taipei/Kaohsiung in Taiwan and Shanghai/Beijing/Guangzhou in mainland China to accommodate home-bound "taishang" for the upcoming Lunar New Year celebrations. The Lunar New Year falls on Feb. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER VICE PREMIER TO SERVE AS SENIOR ADVISER TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan has been appointed to serve as a senior adviser to Presieent Chen Shui-bian, according to a presidential decree issued Saturday.
Meanwhile, Chen's close aide Ma Yung-cheng has been appointed to serve as the Presidential Office deputy secretary-general.
Former Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Yi-fu and former Cabinet Secretary-General Arthur Iap have been appointed national policy advisers to President Chen, the presidential decree said.
Former Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang has also been appointed a senior adviser to the president.
All of the above-mentioned appointments took effect Feb. 1, the presidential decree said.
Su, who has been elected chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said earlier that he will resign as the presidential senior adviser after he assumes DPP chairmanship Feb. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL TO TAKE UP DPP POST

TEXT.P: Yen Wan-chin, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , will serve as deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) after the Lunar New Year holiday, party sources said Saturday.
DPP Chairman-elect Su Tseng-chang said Yen, 41, has been familiar with the DPP affairs and has played an important role in many previous electoral campaigns.
"Yen will assist me in intra-party coordination and expanding the DPP's support base, " Su said, adding that he is lining up a DPP working team in preparation for assuming office Feb. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Court Rejects Tobacco Penalty; U.S. Sought $280 Billion in Past Profits.
A federal appeals court yesterday rejected the government's attempt to recover $280 billion in past profits from the tobacco industry, wiping out the most powerful penalty that could have been imposed in the landmark racketeering case against cigarette manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 6 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Feb. 6:
09:00, Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san will inspect the traffic control center of the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau in Taishan, Taipei County.
09:30, The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party will hold a news conference.
10:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a "nostalgic activity" at Chinhsi Park in Taipei.
17:00, Premier Hsieh will inspect a senior citizens' home in Kaohsiung County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 6, or the 28th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1665: Queen Anne, last Stuart ruler of Britain, is born.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1804: Joseph Priestley, British chemist moted for work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen (1774), dies at the age of 71.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up its settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous batting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1917: British women over 30 get the vote.
1922: The Washington Conference ends with the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan agreeing on restricting the use of poison gas and submarine warfare.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The ROC National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up a Political Department, with Chen Cheng serves as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, a German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: American General Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers, as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: The Manchester soccer team of Britain, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an air crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France, with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, noted Taiwanese painter, dies at the age of 82.
1999: The Taipei District Court sentences Hong Kong business tycoon Lin Por-yen to three years and two months in prison for his role in a bribery scandal.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski says that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
2000: Tarja Halonen becomes first woman president of Finland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: More than 100,000 students in Taichung and Nantou have unwittingly consumed sick-pig meat.
The United Daily News: NT$120 million was stolen from Kaohsiung District Court.
The Liberty Times: 500 Taiwanese businessmen stranded overnight in airport in Hong Kong after mist in Shanghai forced the postponement of many Hong Kong-bound flights.
The Taiwan Daily: James Soong to attend the ceremony when DPP swears in new chairman Su Tseng-chang.
The Central Daily News: Toll Highways will charge no fees during New Year Holidays.
The China Post: Authorities offer rewards for tip-offs regarding sick pigs.
The Taiwan News: Appellate court backs firms in tobacco case.
The Taipei Times: Government confident of traffic plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Pope recovering but doubts continue
ROME, Italy (AFP) -- Pope John Paul II yesterday began a fourth day in hospital where the Vatican says he is continuing to recover from an acute respiratory infection, but doubts continue about his real state of health.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Rights victims lose US case against Marcos For 19 years, they have fought for what they call justice. On Friday, by a stroke of an American judge's pen, all their efforts seem to have come to naught.
The Philippine Star: 3 oil firms to raise prices
Major oil player Pilipinas Shell and minor players Eastern Petroleum Corp. (EPC) and Flying V will raise their diesel and gasoline prices by 30 centavos and 40 centavos, respectively.
The Manila Times: Up next: 20% tax on luxury goods
After approving two separate bills on the value-added tax, the House of Representatives is considering a 20-percent excise tax on " nonessential"services -- cosmetic surgery and luxury goods such as yachts and jewelry.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Court guts U.S. tobacco lawsuit. Attempted forfeiture of $280 billion in past profits rejected
WASHINGTON -A federal appeals court Friday rejected the government 's attempt to recover $280 billion in past profits from the tobacco industry, wiping out the most powerful penalty that could have been imposed in the landmark racketeering case against cigarette manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO MEND FENCES WITH TAIWAN VIA WHO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An adviser to President Chen Shui-bian called for Beijing Saturday to mend its fences with Taiwan via the World Health Organization (WHO) , saying that the WHO is the best starting point for the two sides to seek reconciliation.
Former Health Minister Chan Chi-shean said that Taiwan's participation in WHO activities benefits the 23 million people of Taiwan and has nothing to do with the issue of sovereignty.

Chan, one of the members of the Taiwan delegation attending the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast in Washington, D.C., Feb. 3, urged Beijing not to be an obstacle to Taiwan in the country's efforts to join the World Health Assembly (WHA), the WHO's top decision-making body, as an observer.

Currently superintendent of the Chi Mei Foundation Medical Center, Chan reiterated that the WHO's general assembly in May would be the most opportune time for the two sides to improve their relations, which have experienced a slight thawing since the beginning of this year after years of political impasse.

Chan said that Taiwan's bid for WHA observer status does not involve the issue of sovereignty. Besides, he continued, the mainland Chinese leadership has said that matters which are to the benefit of the "people" should be handled first. Based on this, Chan said, mainland China should grasp the opportunity to better its relations with Taiwan by allowing Taiwan to become a WHA observer this coming May.

Chan made the remarks at a press conference held at the Twin Oaks Garden where members of the Taiwan delegation to the U.S. National Prayer Breakfast made known their goals and achievements during their current visit in the United States.
Chan said that he has met with relevant U.S. officials over the past two days and asked them to render the greatest possible assistance to Taiwan in its efforts to become a WHA observer.

Also attending the press conference were all the other members of the Taiwan delegation, including senior president advisor Wu Li-pei, who is heading the delegation; as well as Parris H. Chang, deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council; Theodore M. H. Huang, chairman of the National Association of Industry and Commerce; and Liu Shyh-fang, former secretary-general of the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Leading Shiite Clerics Pushing Islamic Constitution in Iraq.
With religious Shiite parties poised to take power in the new constitutional assembly, leading Shiite clerics are pushing for Islam to be recognized as the guiding principle of the new constitution. The clerics say that the constitution should ensure that legal measures overseeing personal matters like marriage, divorce and family inheritance fall under Shariah, or Koranic law.
Wall Street Journal: G-7 Ministers Promise Up to 100 Percent Debt Relief.
The world's richest nations signaled a willingness to forgive billions of dollars in Third World debt, but left unresolved vexing questions about how to pay for their good intentions.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW VOICES TAIWAN CONCERNS ABOUT EXCLUSION FROM REGIONAL INTEGRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Emerson Lim and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew voiced Taiwan's concerns about being excluded from participation in the various major regional economic blocs that have been taking shape.
Siew, currently chairman of the Taipei-based Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, took part in an international symposium on the future of Asian regional integration held in Manila Feb. 4-5.

During the symposium, entitled "An Integrated Road Map to East Asian Free Trade Agreement, " Siew reiterated that Taiwan has made hefty and diverse investments in East Asia and Southeast Asia and has maintained close business and trade links in the region.

Taiwan has initiated and contributed in various technology transfer and industrial cooperation programs in the region, playing a constructive role as "lubricant" in regional economic and industrial development, Siew noted.

These are some the reasons why Taiwan should not be excluded from the process of regional economic integration, Siew said, urging political and economic leaders in the region to let Taiwan participate in the formation of regional economic blocs, such as the ASEAN Plus Three, which groups members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations with Japan, China and South Korea.

Taiwan has not been invited to any of the talks on the formation of regional free trade blocs. It is foreseeable that by 2010, when the ASEAN and Plus One (China) free trade bloc is formed, Taiwan will be seriously marginalized, Siew said.
This is an issue which Taiwan government and opinion leaders and many private sectors are gravely concerned about, Siew noted.

During the symposium, Siew promoted the idea that Taiwan -- unable to take part in official regional engagements or meetings because of certain political realities -- could have its voice heard via a "second track" formed by private think-tanks from various countries.
Symposium participants, including retired ministers, sitting high-ranking government officials, and leaders from various academic and research bodies, responded favorably to Siew's calls.

According to Siew, the symposium reached three major conclusions. Firstly, relevant countries should make the East Asia Free Trade Agreement (EAFTA) a high-level official plan. Secondly, EAFTA member countries should maintain partner relationships, and in addition to trade liberalization, these countries should also cooperate in service industry, investment and other economic areas. Thirdly, it is hoped that Taiwan can be invited to join the EAFTA.

Jointly organized by the Asian Institute of Management Policy Center and the Japan Economic Foundation, the symposium was aimed at providing Asian business leaders with an opportunity to exchange views and to deepen their mutual understanding of current regional integration in Asia.
Former Philippine President Fidel Ramos, who delivered a keynote speech at the symposium, led a long list of distinguished panelists.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Shiite Welcomes Overtures By Sunnis; Iraqi Candidate Sets Conciliatory Tone As Violence Picks Up.
The leading Shiite candidate to become Iraq's next prime minister welcomed overtures on Saturday by groups that boycotted national elections and declared that he and others were willing to offer "the maximum" to bring those largely Sunni Arab groups into the drafting of the constitution and participation in the new government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU OFFERING GIFT BAGS TO VISITORS FROM HONG KONG, MACAU

TEXT.P: Lai Sechen, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, handed out gift bags containing special Taiwan produce to a group of tourists who arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport from Hong Kong Sunday.

Accompanied by an official from the Council of Agriculture and the Taiwan agent of the Hong Kong travel agency which organized the tour group, Lai said the gift bags are part of her bureau's program to attract more tourists from Hong Kong and Macau.
From Sunday to March 15, Lai said Hong Kong and Macau tourists who join tour groups to Taiwan will be presented with a bag of Taiwan agricultural specialities upon their arrival.
The government set the goal in 2002 of doubling the number of tourist arrivals by 2008, and tourism officials believe Hong Kong and Macau are two of the sources with the most potential visitors.
The specialty product offered to the tourists who arrived Sunday was yams produced in Hsinhua, Tainan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REINSTATES MEMBERSHIP FOR FORMER HEAVYWEIGHTS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan reinstated party membership for former Justice Yuan President Lin Yang-kang and former Premier Hau Pei-tsun by recruiting them as members of the KMT Advisory Council.

Lin and Hau were expelled from the party in 1996 after they teamed up to run as independents against the KMT ticket of Lee Teng-hui and his running mate Lien Chan in the presidential and vice presidential election that year.

Lin insisted on entering the race at that time, claiming that he and Lee had come to an understanding in 1992 that Lee would support him to run on the KMT ticket in 1996 in return for his support for Lee's presidential bid in 1992.
Lin and Hau quit politics after they were defeated by Lee and Lien in the 1996 election.
Lin was not present at Sunday's ceremony in which Lien lauded Lin and Hau for doing their best to help the KMT in the 2004 legislative elections despite not being KMT members.

Lien, who has tried to revive the KMT by bringing back into the party fold former KMT members who had left the party because of their political differences with former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, said he offered Lin and Hau the positions on the KMT Advisory Council to demonstrate the party's respect for them and its determination to reconcile with them.
For his part, Hau said he joined the KMT in 1931 and has never felt that he has left the party in "mentality".
He called on all those who support the "Three Principles of the People, " which was established by KMT founder Dr. Sun Yat-sen as a guideline for building the country, to rally behind the KMT.
Asked by journalists whether his call was directed at James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, Hau said he would certainly like to see Soong and his supporters return to the KMT fold.

Soong was expelled from the KMT after he decided to run against KMT candidate Lien Chan in the 2000 presidential race. Soong founded his own party after the Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian won the election.

Several other former KMT heavyweights who were kicked out of the party after falling out with Lee Teng-hui during Lee's term as KMT chairman between 1988 and 2000 were among the 18 members named to the KMT Advisory Council Sunday.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said these former KMT heavyweights' party membership will be restored automatically by serving on the KMT Advisory Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSIEH STILL WAITING FOR RESPONSE FROM JIANG ON APPOINTMENT AS DEPUTY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday that he has already extended an invitation to opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Jiang to serve as his deputy and that he will not contact any other potential candidates ahead of the Feb. 17 deadline for a response from Jiang on the appointment.
Hsieh said that he will have no choice but to invite someone else after Feb. 17 to serve as vice premier if Jiang refuses the post.
Meanwhile, leaders of six federations of industrial and commercial associations in Taiwan jointly ran an advertisement in major newspapers Sunday, calling for Hsieh to appoint Jiang to be his deputy.
Hsieh, formerly Kaohsiung mayor, was sworn in as premier Feb. 1, inaugurating a new Cabinet which Hsieh said will make consultations and coexistence its cornerstone.

All the members of the previous Cabinet under former Premier Yu Shyi-kun were retained, with the exception of Executive Yuan Secretary-General Arthur Iap, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan and Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang.
The post of vice premier, however, has remained vacant.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHICS MUST BE STRENGTHENED TO REBUILD PEOPLE'S TRUST: PREMIER

TEXT.P: As the scandal surrounding the sale of pork from diseased pigs continued to unfold, Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday that "morality and ethics in society must be rehabilitated."

Premier Hsieh told journalists while visiting his childhood neighbor in Taipei City that he was astounded to learn that many people in a position to prevent the scandal had turned a blind eye to the illegal sales of pork from sick and dead pigs.
In order to rebuild people's confidence, the premier said, "we need to refurbish and strengthen our morality and ethics and see to it that any person who flouts them will be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE-EUROPEAN MEDICAL GROUP TO ASSIST TAIWAN'S WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese-European medical group pledged Saturday to help Taiwan pursue its goal of joining the World Health Organization.

At a board meeting held in Bern, Switzerland, the European Federation of Taiwan Health Alliance (EFTHA) elaborated a plan to support Taiwan's bid to attend as an observer the gathering of the World Health Assembly -- the WHO's decision-making body -- to be held in Geneva in mid May.
Under the plan, the EFTHA will write to the health ministers of the European Union member states to appeal for their support for Taiwan's WHO bid.
The alliance will also increase its contacts with medical groups in European nations, making them aware of the importance of Taiwan's participation in the WHO.
The EFTHA also decided to hold a news conference April 7 in Brussels to call for international support for Taiwan's WHO bid.

It will also join groups from Taiwan in Geneva in mid May to conduct lobbying activities and stage demonstrations to appeal for international support for Taiwan's WHO bid in line with this year's World Health Assembly which opens May 16.
Speaking at the meeting, Wang Shih-rong, Taiwan's representative in Switzerland, thanked the Taiwanese expatriates for their support for Taiwan's efforts to participate in international activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC REMINDS TRAVELERS TO BE ON GUARD AGAINST CONTAGIOUS DISEASES

TEXT.P: The Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health reminded Taiwan citizens traveling overseas during the Lunar New Year holidays to be on guard against contagious diseases.

In a statement released Sunday afternoon, the center urged travelers to be vigilant about their health and to contact local health officials if they develop fever, diarrhea, rashes, or any other symptoms of disease upon their return to Taiwan.
The center pointed out in the statement that diarrhea is the most common disorder suffered by travelers and could be a sign of dysentery or cholera which are potentially fatal diseases.
The officials cautioned people against eating any uncooked food while traveling abroad and to only drink bottled or boiled water.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Doctors: cancer care is in crisis.
The government's £2 billion scheme to revolutionise the treatment of British cancer sufferers has failed, with much of the money wasted on creating 400 bureaucrats. A damning report by Britain's biggest independent group of NHS doctors says many patients are waiting longer for treatment than they were when the programme was launched five years ago. The proportion facing"appalling"delays for radiotherapy that could cure their cancer has doubled. Many new machines are waiting in boxes because of staff shortages.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION HITS US$12.32 BILLION FOR 2004

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural production reached US$12.32 billion for 2004, up 11.8 percent over the previous year's level, according to the latest government tallies.

The statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics also showed that agricultural exports and imports totalled US$3.52 billion and US$8.8 billion, respectively, for 2004, leaving Taiwan with an agricultural trade deficit of US$5.28 billion, up by US$740 million over the previous year's figure.
Fishery and livestock exports accounted for nearly 76 percent of total agricultural exports, while produce and livestock imports made up nearly 80 percent of Taiwan's agricultural imports.

By country, Japan was Taiwan's largest market for agricultural exports, purchasing US$1.37 billion worth of products, up by 13.9 percent over the previous year. Meanwhile, the United States was the main source of Taiwan's agricultural imports, totaling US$2.59 billion, for an 0.9 percent increase over the 2003 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES E.U. TO PLAY BIGGER ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: Taiwan welcomes the European Union to play a bigger role in cross-Taiwan Strait issues and hopes that the international community can voice its opposition to Beijing's proposed "anti-secession" law, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The MOFA said in a statement issued late Saturday that Taiwan expects the European Union to play a more prominent role in a broad range of cross-strait issues to help boost peace and prosperity in the region. It also called on the international community to take concrete measures to stop Beijing from creating a legal basis for an invasion of Taiwan.

The MOFA's statement came days after the European Union expressed in a declaration its welcome for the agreement between Taiwan and mainland China for the launch of special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights to serve mainland-based Taiwan business people and their families during the Jan. 29-Feb. 20 period.

The European Union said that it strongly believes that cross-strait peace is of utmost importance to the rest of the world and that it supports dialogue between the two sides to bolster bilateral understanding and communications. It said that it welcomes Taiwan and mainland China reopening peace talks as soon as possible.
Direct transport, trade and postal links across the strait were banned since 1949, when Taiwan and the mainland split in the wake of civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE INTENSIFY CRACKDOWN ON IPR INFRINGEMENTS

TEXT.P: Police have arrested 282 people around Taiwan over the past four days in a total of 262 cases involving the sale of counterfeit brand name products or pirated goods, National Policy Administration (NPA) officials said Sunday.

A police task force in charge of intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and police stations around Taiwan launched a special operation Feb. 3 to intensify the government's crack down on IPR infringements, the officials said.

The goods seized, including counterfeit brand name hand bags and wallets and pirated CDs, DVDs and video games, have a combined market value of about NT$530 million (US$16.5 million), the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASH NOT ENOUGH TO ENCOURAGE TAIWAN PARENTS TO HAVE MORE CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Cash subsidies are not enough to encourage parents in Taiwan to have more children, experts said Sunday.
Taiwan has one of the lowest birth rates in the world.

The central government and various local county and city governments, including those of Hsinchu City, Hsinchu County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Miaoli County, Yunlin County and Chiayi County, offer cash subsidies to encourage parents to have more children, the experts said.

Taking Hsinchu City as an example, they said that the city government in northern Taiwan offers a subsidy of NT$3,5000 (US$1,100) to parents for their first baby, and NT$20,000 and NT$25,000 for their second and third babies, respectively. The city also offers NT$50,000 and NT$100,000 to parents who have twins and triplets, respectively, they added.

However, the incentives have not been effective, they pointed out. According to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior, Hsinchu City registered the highest birth rate among all cities and counties in Taiwan last year. Nevertheless, the figure marked a decline over previous years' levels, they noted.

Citing the results of recent public opinion polls, the experts said that more than 60 percent of Taiwan women expect the government to put in place more concrete measures to help reduce the burden of raising a child, such as providing day care facilities and greater health care assistance for children aged up to six years old as well as lowering their tax burden.
Despite the fact that the government has implemented some measures to help parents, the public thinks that the government can still do more, the experts said.

Chien Tai-lang, vice minister of the interior, said in a recent seminar that the government is gravely concerned about Taiwan's population growth rate, which is expected to dip into negative figures around 2022.
Quoting academic studies, Chien said that Taiwan citizens aged over 65 years will account for 39 percent of the country's total population by 2051.

As encouraging parents to have more children is an established government policy, relevant government bodies, including the Ministry of Education, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and the Interior Ministry, will join forces to iron out a "population white paper" next month to serve as the guidelines for building a favorable atmosphere to encourage parents to have more children, Chien said.
Taiwan women gave birth to an average of 1.24 babies last year -- one of the world's lowest rates.

Couples in France and the United States had an average of 1.9 and 1.2 babies in 2004, while the figures for Sweden and Italy were 1.2 and 1.5, respectively, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior. (By Flor Wang) ENDTIEM/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES INCREASE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$242.7 billion at the end of January, up US$1 billion from a month earlier, according to the latest statistics released by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The CBC officials attributed the increase mainly to dividends generated from the reserves and inflow of foreign capital.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rank third in the world, behind only those of Japan and mainland China, they added.
According to the same statistics, Japan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$824.2 billion at the end of last year, while those of the mainland were US$609.9 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MACHINERY INDUSTRY PRODUCTION GROWS 11% FOR 2004: ITIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's machinery industry is estimated to have experienced growth of 11.2 percent in production value for 2004, hitting NT$501.4 billion (US$15.7 billion) for the year, according to the latest government statistics.

Tallies released by the Industrial Technology Intelligence Services (ITIS) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs showed that machinery imports and exports reached NT$ 675.7 billion and NT$418.1 billion last year, both posting positive growth.

Despite the noticeable expansion, the fallout from mainland China's efforts to cool its high flying economy will be a key issue affecting the domestic industry this year, ministry officials said, pointing out that the mainland's financial policy, such as its interest rate adjustments, and the oil price in the international market, will also have a significant effect on the export-oriented sector.
In essence, the macro economy will be the main factor to influence the prospects of the industry, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 7 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, Feb. 7:

10: 50, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will visit a low-income family at No. 6, Lane 4, Alley 136, Hoping East Rd., Sec. 2, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 7, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland, and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well-loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Communist Chinese troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1976: Emanuel O. Gardiner, Liberian deputy minister of planning and economic affairs, and Lafayette Kwie Johnson Jr., assistant minister of the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Transportation, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Ministers of Europe formally sign the Maastricht Treaty of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.TEXT:
