DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Iraqi Cleric Takes Center Stage. Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, the black- turbaned cleric who was the architect of what appears to be a landslide victory by Shiite Muslims in last week's landmark Iraqi elections, is now poised to shape the new government, including its choice of prime minister and the drafting of the country's constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Palace welcomes proposal to appoint village officials instead of holding polls
Malacanang yesterday welcomed the proposal of Comelec Chairman Benjamin Abalos that barangay officials should be appointed by the city and municipal mayors to save the government millions of pesos, but at the same time said that Congress must be consulted first on such move.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: US ruling on Marcos money elates Imelda
A US appeals court ruled that American courts cannot overturn a Philippine Supreme Court ruling forfeiting $683 million in Marcos-linked assets to the Philippine government. Imelda Marcos exulted at the news while those who suffered during her husband's rule either took it with resignation, despaired, or simply gnashed their teeth.
The Philippine Star: Palace: P8 B for FM victims
Some P8 billion has been earmarked by the government as indemnity for the nearly 10,000 human rights victims who suffered under the Marcos dictatorship, Presidential Spokesman Ignacio Bunye said yesterday.
The Manila Times: Word war flares at DOJ
A row is brewing between Justice Secretary Raul M. Gonzalez and the president of the National Prosecutor's League of the Philippines (NPLP). Angry words have been exchanged and the NPLP chief, Manila Assistant City Prosecutor Ferrer Co has threatened to withdraw the group's endorsement for Gonzalez when he seeks confirmation before the Commission on Appointments this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Thaksin scores big win in Thai polls.
Thailand's Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra scored a historic landslide victory yesterday, becoming the first Thai leader to be elected to asecond term, and by a record margin too.
Television exit polls released promptly after voting booths closed at 3.30pm projected his Thai Rak Thai (Thais Love Thais) party winning 399 seats in the 500-member Parliament, giving it an unassailable majority.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Thaksin wins the big victory in Thai election.
According television exit polls released after vote yesterday, Thailand's Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra claimed his Thai Rak Thai (Thais Love Thais) party winning 399 seats in the 500-member Parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOGGY WEATHER CONTINUES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a thick fog warning for northern and western Taiwan for the second straight day Monday.

Thick fog, caused by warm and damp air from the Pacific Ocean, has hampered air traffic in Taiwan and the Taiwan Strait area since Sunday, and the situation is not expected to improve until late Tuesday, the eve of Chinese New Year, CWB meteorologists reported.
The weather bureau forecast rainy days for the first couple of days of the Lunar New Year holiday.

Some 150 flights of foreign and domestic airlines have been delayed or canceled since Sunday morning at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan as a result of poor visibility. At least 15,000 passengers have been affected, according to CKS airport authorities.
Meanwhile, Chiayi Airport in southern Taiwan was closed Monday morning due to the thick fog. The airport will not re-open for air traffic until it turns sunny, according to airport authorities there.

On the outlying island of Kinmen, air traffic was not noticeably affected by the thick fog, thanks to use of the cutting-edge ILS system which allows aircraft to land or take off accurately despite low visibility.

All Taiwan-bound flights from Kinmen have been full since Sunday as large numbers of Kinmen residents as well as mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople and their families headed home for the Chinese New Year holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC CONSUL-GENERAL TO COLON, PANAMA TO ASSUME POST
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The newly appointed Republic of China Consul-General in Colon, Shih Cheng-mao, arrived in Panama Sunday to assume his post.

Shih, together with his wife and two children, were warmly greeted at the airport by Republic of China Ambassador Ho Ping-fu, staff of the ROC embassy in Panama and Taiwanese expatriates residing in Colon.
Shih served as vice consul between 1987 and 1991 at the Consulate of the Republic of China, Colon. The Consulate was later upgraded to Consulate General, and Shih was promoted to the post of consul.
Shih served as a commissioner at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs before his new post. He will replace Hsin Ying-huei, who will leave his post Feb. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS CANDY WORLD 2005 FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Chen Hsui-bian on Monday paid a visit to the Candy World 2005 festival being held in Chiali township, Tainan County.
President Chen arrived at the festival at around 10 a.m. to the warm welcome of tourists as well as children.

While handing out candies, the president reminisced about his impoverished childhood when he saw a sugar cane vehicle pass by. Chen, the son of a poor tenant farmer, talked about how he had to cook meals as a child while his parents were busy working out in the fields.
The president said the more affluent young generation of today can't imagine the difficulties that his generation had to face.

He also said that the prosperity that Taiwan now enjoys is the result of the efforts and contributions of the 23 million people of Taiwan, adding that everyone should cherish the hard-earned fruits of their labor.

The festival, co-organized by the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Tainan County Government and the Taiwan Agricultural Strategy Coalition, has 11 sections, including candy exhibitions from 25 countries, music and theater for children, a science fun house, a children's playground, a 3-D animation theater, a Yami cultural gallery, and an outdoor carnival.
Three of the most popular attractions are the International Candy Exhibition Hall, the Candy Fun House and the International Chocolate Exhibition Hall.
The festival will run through Feb. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET URGED TO PAY CLOSER ATTENTION TO AGRICULTURAL SECTOR

TEXT.P: The new Cabinet under the leadership of Premier Frank Hsieh was urged Monday to pay closer attention to the interests and development of the farming and fishery sectors.

Professor Yang Ping-shih from National Taiwan University called for Premier Hsieh and his Cabinet ministers to visit farming and fishery communities often in order to deepen their understanding of the needs of Taiwan's farmers and fishermen.

Yang said that Taiwan's agricultural sector has been ignored for too long. He noted that although the agricultural sector's output only constitutes about 1.6 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) , agriculture is the bedrock of national development, with a large number of people making a living from it.
He urged the administration not to judge the value of the agricultural sector based solely on its output, which he said is only part of the picture.

Yang offered several suggestion on how the administration could help facilitate development in the agricultural sector, including drafting policies to better protect farmer's and fishermen's interests and welfare; helping increase agricultural exports; ensuring food safety and sanitation for consumers; and bolstering collaboration between the research and production fields.

Asserting that the "sun is not setting" on Taiwan's agriculture sector, Yang said that if the government can collaborate with the farmers and help them find new niches in the market, then the agricultural sector will have a bright future and in turn help sharpen Taiwan's international competitiveness.

Meanwhile, Lee Chin-lung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that one of the priorities of his council this year is to step up promotion of Taiwan's agricultural exports as well as the development biotechnology parks.

Lee also spelled out five core agricultural policies that his council plans to carry out this year: namely developing added-value agriculture in order to raise the island's international competitiveness; promoting "safe" agriculture to protect consumers' rights; integrating the tourism and leisure and agriculture sectors to raise living standards in rural areas; developing environmentally-friendly agriculture; and facilitating overall development in the farming and fishery sectors to help boost incomes and living standards for farmers and fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY HELPS TSUNAMI-AFFECTED OVERSEAS CHINESE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education has taken the initiative to provide relief assistance and counselling to overseas Chinese students studying in Taiwan whose families have been affected by the Dec. 26 tsunami tragedy.

Education officials noted that the ministry had asked colleges and universities to investigate the situation of the overseas students in the wake of the tsunami disaster that hit 11 countries in Southeast Asia and South Asia.

The study found that six overseas Chinese students in Taiwan come from Aceh, Indonesia and that their families suffered the most serious losses. In response, the ministry gave each of the students NT$50,000 (US$1,587).
Six other students whose families also suffered losses in the tsunami tragedy received NT$30,000 each.

In addition, the ministry has asked the student counseling centers at each college and university to provide necessary assistance to help overseas students affected by the tsunami tragedy to tide over their difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXPRESSES APPRECIATION TO HARD-WORKING POLICE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh expressed his appreciation Monday to all police officers around Taiwan for continuing to carry out their duties of maintaining social order during the week-long Chinese New Year holiday period.

The premier made the comments while visiting the police department in Taichung, central Taiwan. During the visit, he also presented cash awards to police officers who have helped solve major criminal cases.

Hsieh was accompanied by Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan; Cho Jung-tai, spokesman of the Executive Yuan; Liao Yung-lai, executive director of the Central Office of the Executive Yuan; and National Police Administration Director General Hsieh Yin-tang.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, in welcoming Hsieh's entourage, expressed his appreciation for the premier's concern about social order in his city.
Social order has been a major concern for Taichung's residents, Hu said, noting that the problem of a shortage of police officers in the city persists.
The premier said that as Hu is a good friend, he chose Taichung as his first stop in visiting the police departments around the island.

Hsieh also said that as a former mayor of Kaohsiung, he is aware of the tremendous pressure faced by local chiefs regarding social order, adding that he used to wake up in the middle of the night when he heard sirens of the fire trucks and would immediately call the fire department to learn about the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR REAFFIRMS RESOLVE TO WORK FOR KMT REFORM AND UNITY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Monday reaffirmed his commitment to working for reform and unity of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Ma, a vice chairman of the KMT who reportedly is planning to run for the party's chairmanship in the next election set for this May, said he has always been concerned about the development of the party and that his plans will not change despite some party heavyweights supporting incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan to continue in his post.

Ma has not openly announced his decision to run for the KMT chairmanship. Speaking on the matter over the weekend, Ma said he is willing to take a greater share of the responsibilities but added that there are some other matters that he needs to take into consideration.

While it is widely believed that Lien will step down in May, senior KMT member Hsu Li-nung expressed upon rejoining the party Sunday his support for Lien to run for re-election. Hsu said Ma is too young for the position.
The 54-year-old Ma said people his age are always too young in the eyes of the older generation and not young at all in the eyes of the younger generation.
Ma said that the KMT is a pluralistic party and that he believes a consensus on the direction of the party will be reached among its members through communication and consultation.

Ma made the remarks while visiting low-income senior citizens who live alone in the city ahead of Lunar New Year. The mayor presented each of the seniors with a red envelope containing NT$500 (US$15.78) and some Lunar New Year gifts including glutinous rice cakes and ginseng tea.
According to the city's Department of Social Welfare, there are 230 low-income senior citizens who live on their own in the city.
The department has handed out food, quilts and red envelopes to these citizens ahead of the Lunar New Year in cooperation with private social welfare organizations, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERVIEW REQUIREMENT FOR VIETNAMESE BRIDES RECEIVED POSITIVELY: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government's reinstated measure requiring Vietnamese women intending to marry Taiwan men to undergo face-to-face pre-marriage interviews has received a positive response from Vietnamese authorities and Taiwanese businessmen operating in Vietnam, diplomatic officials said Monday.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) made the remarks after Chen Wen-chuan, president of a private association dedicated to helping intermarried couples, committed suicide last week and left a suicide note for Premier Frank Hsieh calling for government attention to what he called the "troubles and confusions" brought about by the reinstated interview requirement.
Chen claimed that the measure has affected the rights of foreign brides and intermarriage brokers.
According to the MOFA officials, the number of Taiwan nationals marrying Vietnamese women has been increasing significantly in recent years, with the figure now standing at about 10,000 per year.

In 1999, the officials said, Taiwan's representative office in Ho Chi Minh City in southern Vietnam replaced its face-to-face interview requirement for would-be Vietnamese brides with a "group presentation" requirement.

With social problems resulting from Taiwanese-Vietnamese intermarriages getting ever more serious, the Control Yuan, Taiwan's top watchdog body, asked the Executive Yuan last November to prudently address the social and legal problems involving foreign and mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals.

Against this backdrop, the MOFA directed the nation's representative offices in the Vietnamese capital of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City to stringently screen suspicious visa applications and to reinstate face-to-face interviews for would-be Vietnamese brides.

Acting on the latest MOFA directive, the representative office in Ho Chi Minh City reinstated the face-to-face interview requirement Jan. 4. Since then, the rejection rate for intermarriage-related visa applications stands at about 30 percent, MOFA officials said, adding that those who fail to secure a visa the first time they apply can re-apply after three months.

MOFA officials said the ministry will invite all relevant government agencies to a Feb. 18 meeting to discuss issues regarding screening of visa applications for would-be brides from Southeast Asian countries.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) expressed its regret over Chen's suicide in a press statement.
The ministry also said in the press release that the government has always paid much attention to the well-being of foreign and mainland spouses of Taiwan citizens.

Noting that the government has long been implementing a special project to help foreign and mainland spouses adapt to Taiwan's lifestyle, the press statement said the Executive Yuan has set up a NT$3 billion fund for various relevant educational and welfare programs. Those programs have been carried out by the MOI, the Ministry of Education and the Council of Labor Affairs, respectively, the statement said.

It added that the face-to-face interviews of would-be foreign brides are mainly aimed at protecting the rights and interests of legally married couples and at blocking entry for those who intend to come to Taiwan through marriages of convenience to engage in criminal operations. Mainland Chinese citizens intending to marry Taiwan nationals are also now required to undergo face-to-face interviews.
Meanwhile, MOI officials urged unlicensed private intermarriage brokers to apply with responsible government agencies as soon as possible to become legal brokerages for legal protection.

According to media reports, more than 86,000 Vietnamese women have married Taiwan men over the past few years. Quoting statistics compiled by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Ho Chi Minh City, the reports said the divorce rate among Taiwanese-Vietnamese intermarried couples surged to 13 percent last year from an average of about 8 percent in previous years.

A MOFA official stationed in Ho Chi Minh City said an average of about 20 Taiwan men per week approach his office for assistance in locating their "missing or lost" wives and children. He said an estimated 3,000 Taiwanese-Vietnamese mixed-race children may now be "languishing" somewhere in Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINTAINING ECONOMIC STABILITY IS CHALLENGE FOR NEW CABINET: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: With Taiwan's economic growth expected to slow down this year, it will be a challenge for the new Cabinet led by Premier Frank Hsieh to maintain economic stability, analysts said Monday.

According to the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the economic growth rates forecasted by various research institutes for 2005 range from 4 percent to 5 percent, which are lower than the 5 percent to 6 percent that was projected for 2004.

Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said it is important for Hsieh to avoid conflicts between the ruling and opposition parties to minimize the influence from political factors over the economy.
Wu said executive ability is crucial to the performance of the new Cabinet and that Hsieh should avoid any drastic policy shift during his term.
A lot of the good policies put forth by former Premier Yu Shyi-kun, such as the "10 new major development projects, " should be continued, Wu suggested.

Wu Hui-lin, a research fellow at the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research, pointed out that while Hsieh has pledged to promote consultations between the ruling and opposition parties, stability and improvement of the economy is still the issue that people are the most concerned about.
Though Yu laid a solid foundation for the economy during his three-year term, the development of Taiwan's hi-tech industries remains an urgent issue that Hsieh needs to deal with, Wu Hui-lin said.

Wu Hui-lin said it is time the government reconsidered whether hi-tech industries should continue to enjoy exclusive preferential treatment when these industries have contributed to only 1.4 percent of indirect tax revenue of the country.

Meanwhile, citing the results of a recent survey, Taiwan Thinktank analyst Chou Yung-hung said Hsieh's premiership is supported by the majority of people in Taiwan owing to his brilliant performance during his term as Kaohsiung mayor.
Most respondents of the survey expect Hsieh to make economic development and social welfare his priority policies while establishing a "Cabinet of consultations," Chou noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MAGISTRATE ADVOCATES FURTHER OPENING OF 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng expressed the hope Monday that the government can further ease its policy on direct trade, postal and transportation links, commonly known as the "mini three links, " between the two outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu with mainland China's Fujian province.

Lee made the remarks as he inspected Shuitou Wharf in Kinmen -- the jumping off point for Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland plying the shipping route between Kinmen and Xiamen, Fujian province.
The Kinmen County Government has estimated that from Jan. 29 to Feb. 6, 13,748 passengers made the trip between Kinmen and Xiamen, and that the number could top 15,000 by Feb 7.
Just over 65 percent departed from Xiamen to Kinmen, while 35 percent came the other way. The passengers were mostly Taiwan businessmen and their families returning to Taiwan proper via Kinmen.

Lee was satisfied with the situation, saying that the government has since March 2004 further opened the " mini three links," allowing Taiwan businessmen operating in places outside Fujian to shuttle between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait via the channel.

Because of this, 405,000 trips were made last year, Lee said, adding that he believes that if the government can further open its policy, the "mini three links" will become a shortcut for Taiwan people shuttling between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Wu Chin-chung, president of the Taiwan Businessmen Association in Xiamen, took the first ferry from Xiamen to arrive at Shuitou Wharf, Kinmen Monday.

Wu said that although there are charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China this year between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 to facilitate Taiwan businessmen in the mainland to return to Taiwan for the Chinese New Year, the Kinmen-Xiamen direct link has its own advantage, saying that he knows personally that Taiwan businessmen in Zhejiang and Guangxi provinces choose to ply the route to return to Taiwan.
"The route is especially favored by those Taiwan businessmen who reside in central Taiwan," he said.
The government opened the "mini three links" in January 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: HELPING HANDS REACH OUT TO VILLAGE OF MISFORTUNE

TEXT.P: One small village in central Taiwan has had more than its fair share of misfortune -- being decimated by the 7.6-magnitude earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999 and then having their homes and bridges swept away by flooding from a typhoon last summer.
But in the end, it was the helping hand of compassionate strangers that got the people -- particularly the children -- back on their feet.

The 921 Earthquake, as it has come to be known, killed over 2,400 people, mostly in the central part of the island, and the small Lileng Atayal tribal village in the rural Hoping township in Taichung was hard hit.

In an effort to rebuild, one of the teachers at the only elementary school put out a call last May on the Internet for people to donate books. Within a short time the school had received 12,000 books; but a new problem arose -- where to keep them all.

The teacher behind the Internet plea, Chang Chien-hua, went back online and soon a woman from Changhua County gave the school 15 wooden bookcases. Even so, the shelves could only hold about one-third of the books.
Chang said he was astounded by the overwhelming generosity and compassion demonstrated by people around Taiwan after he received so many books in such a short time.
The school children were happy to sort and arrange the books, Chang said. "It was the first time in their lives to see so many books in one place," he recalled.
Things were looking up for the school until last July when a typhoon hit the island, triggering numerous mudslides and flooding.
Some village residents, still living in "temporary" housing of converted shipping containers saw their houses swept away, along with the only two bridges linking the village with the outside world.
Most importantly, the village's farming and cultural settings -- the lifeline of the aboriginal people -- were ruined.
For a time, the books were the only source of solace, Chang said.
Finally, Chang made a final appeal on the Internet for help, this time for more aid than just books.
Top Taiwan pop singer A-mei, who is an aborigine from eastern Taiwan, gave a benefit concert exclusively for Lileng village, raising NT$110,000.
Chang used the money to build an audio-visual theater at the village's activity center.
The Cultural and Educational Foundation of the International Commercial Bank of China donated some NT$400,000, enabling the village to be equipped with computers and English-teaching facilities.

In addition, according to Chang, students from Taichung Normal College and the city's Providence University have taken turns visiting the village at weekends to teach the villagers and children computer skills and English.
Chang is pragmatic about the ups and downs of the village: "Even at the darkest times, we always find that there is light at the end of the tunnel."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO PASS TEMPORARY 'VISA-FREE' MEASURE FOR TAIWAN SOON
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Perry Hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Despite mainland China's repeated protests, the upper house of Japan's Diet is expected to pass a special bill Wednesday to offer visa-free privileges for Taiwan tourists during a world exposition to be held in Japan later this year, major Japanese news media reported over the weekend.

With a view to attracting more foreign visitors to the Aichi World Expo to be held in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi from March 25 to Sept. 25, the Japanese government has decided to waive visa requirements for Taiwan and South Korean tourists during the six-month period.
As Japan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, it will have to revise its existing law to allow visas for Taiwan tourists to be waived during the Aichi Expo.

According to the latest Japanese media reports, the Japanese House of Councilors, or the upper house of the Diet, will pass the revision bill proposed by lawmakers from the ruling coalition of the Liberal Democratic Party and the New Komeito Party at its plenary session Wednesday.

As part of its Aichi Expo promotional campaign, the Japanese government has also decided to issue visas for prospective visitors from all mainland Chinese provinces and cities during the six-month period. At present, Japan only accepts visa applications from residents in three major mainland cities and five coastal mainland provinces.

However, Beijing authorities have on many occasions protested Japan's allegedly discriminatory measures. Among others, a senior mainland tourism official told visiting Japanese Land, Infrastructure and Transportation Minister Kazuo Kitagawa in Beijing late last month that it was unacceptable for Japan to require visas for mainland nationals while exempting Taiwanese tourists from visa requirements.

Japanese media reports said Japan has decided to offer visa-free privileges for Taiwan tourists mainly because Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea and because few Taiwan tourists overstay their visas. In contrast, Japanese news media said, there have been a lot of cases involving mainland Chinese tourists overstaying their visas since Japan opened its doors to mainland tourists a few years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WANTS LOCAL CHIEFS' INPUT ON NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said in Chiayi county, southern Taiwan, Monday that he will soon invite the chiefs of local governments to discuss the financially troubled national health insurance program.

Hsieh made the remarks in Chuchi township, Chiayi County. Accompanying him were Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, and legislators Tsai Chi-fang and Chang Hua-kuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Hsieh noted that in five years, one out of every five people will be a senior citizen; therefore, the government should complete legislation of an annuity for the elderly and revamp the national health insurance program.
However, he lamented the fact that the Legislative Yuan is constantly mired in partisan confrontations and never seems to manage to have a serious discussion on the matter.
He stressed that the national health insurance program could go bankruptcy in three months judging from the fact that the program is losing more than one billion NT dollars every month.
He said that he wants to meet with the chiefs of cities and counties to sound them out on the problems and possible solutions this month or early next month.
The venue is temporarily set for Taitung in the hopes that a scenic backdrop will be conducive to reasoned argument on the subject, Hsieh added.

Hsieh called on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng last week to solicit his assistance for several proposed amendments to related statutes to help the national health insurance program stay afloat, including amendments to existing laws to allow for the transfer of tobacco and liquor tax revenues into the financially strapped program.
Hsieh said that the Executive Yuan is also mulling raising the ceiling of the national health insurance premium, and is leaning toward having those who have higher incomes pay a higher premium.
Meanwhile, Magistrate Chen introduced sweet jujubes, succulent pears and October longans, which are distinctive agricultural produce, to the premier.

Hsieh said Taiwan's fruits are world famous, but that farmers have to upgrade their quality and study how to better distribution channels to meet the challenges that will come from the current and upcoming World Trade Organization talks.
Hsieh also visited the only mobile medical "hospital" in Taiwan -- which cost the Chiayi County Government NT$20 million (US$634,920).
The unit caters to remote villages and towns in Chiayi. But since there are over 100 such remote areas, the vehicle will only be able to stop in each place once every several months.
Magistrate Chen suggested to the premier that the central government subsidize the NT$20 million needed to add another vehicle to better care for people in remote areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: VARIOUS ENTERTAINING EVENTS AWAIT VISITORS DURING LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: For those people who still wonder where to go during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, visiting some of the large festivals and exhibitions being held on the island may be a good idea.

In Pingtung County, the Kenting Windbell Feast 2005 is being held on the beach of Hsiatiyu until Feb. 20. Items on display include solar-powered windbells and those highlighting the seasonal theme -- the 12 animals representing different Chinese lunar years.
There are also booths decorated to represent the 12 zodiac signs where visitors can pray for luck.

In Tainan County, the Candy World 2005 is being held at the Hsiaolung Cultural Park in Chiali township until the end of February. Ten booths have been set up to exhibit international and local candies.
In Tainan City, the 2005 Taiwan International Drum Festival is set to open on the eve of the lunar new year on Tuesday, featuring performers from the United States, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.
While the opening show will start at 10 p.m. and run through midnight, four shows will be available each day from the afternoon to nighttime between Wednesday and Sunday.
In Changhua County, the 2005 Taiwan Flower Expo is being held in Hsichou until March 13.
In Taipei County, the Sky Lantern Festival is being held in Pinghsi township until Feb. 23.
Meanwhile, the Janfusun Fancy World in Yunlin County and the Hualien Ocean Park will extend their business hours during the lunar new year holiday.

The Leofoo Village Theme Park in Hsinchu County and the Window on China Theme Park in Taoyuan County are offering their tickets at discounted prices of NT$690 and NT$399, respectively, during the holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL FERRY SERVICE HELPS STRANDED PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: People stranded on Matsu by heavy fog that grounded planes were helped out Sunday by special ferries.
Two ferries sailing between Keelung and the outlying island of Matsu went into operation after the closure of Nankan and Peikan airports in Matsu due to heavy fog.
Matsu's Lienchiang County Government went into action after the fog set in to help passengers eager to go back to their hometowns to spend the Chinese New Year holiday with their families.
According to Hou Pao-chuan, a manager of the Lienchiang Maritime Corp., one of the ferries belongs to the county government and can seat 380.
The ferries were coordinated through local government agency chiefs and the military.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI LIBRARY PROJECT IN THE PIPELINE

TEXT.P: The proposal to build a library to keep personal effects and historical records related to former President Lee Teng-hui's 12-year presidency is in the pipeline, sources close to Lee said Monday.

Former Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Cheng Chen-lung said Lee's friends have begun preparations for raising funds to set up a Lee Teng-hui Library Foundation to build and manage the proposed library.

It has been tentatively decided that the library will be located in Lee's hometown of Sanchih, a coastal township on Taipei's northern outskirts, Cheng said, adding that the building will concurrently house the library and classrooms for the Lee Teng-hui School.

As official documents, archives and artifacts regarding retired presidents have been kept at the state-run Academia Historica, Cheng said the proposed Lee Teng-hui Library will mainly display Lee's personal letters, books and historical records.

Once the project is realized, it will be Taiwan's first library dedicated to a former president. Lee served as the Republic of China president from 1988 through May 20, 2000. As the first Taiwan-born president, Lee contributed much to Taiwan's transformation from authoritarian rule to a democracy and the shaping of Taiwan's national identity distinct from that of China.

The Lee Teng-hui School is run by Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank headed by Lee, to enhance local people's knowledge about Taiwan's history, culture and developments over the past 400 years. According to Cheng, every class opened by the school has invariably received enthusiastic response.

"There have been no empty seats in any class. The current classrooms at the Taiwan Research Institute are not spacious enough to meet the demand. We need a new place to accommodate more students, " Cheng said, adding that a blueprint for the Lee Teng-hui Library project will be unveiled later.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER NOT TO ANNOUNCE CHOICE OF VICE PREMIER BEFORE FEB. 17

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday he is still waiting for a response from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to his invitation to one of its vice chairmen to serve as his deputy.
Hsieh made the remarks during an inspection tour of the emergency relief command center at the National Fire Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

With a view to promoting inter-party reconciliation, Hsieh has so far left vacant the vice premier post and has repeatedly expressed his desire to invite KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, who is concurrently a legislator-at-large, to serve as his deputy.
However, KMT Chairman Lien Chan has demanded party-to-party negotiations on a number of critical issues as prerequisites for Chiang to join Hsieh's Cabinet.
Hsieh disclosed that his invitation has so far not made any progress.
As Lien will go abroad Tuesday for a vacation, Hsieh said the two sides are not expected to have further contacts during the upcoming Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, which will run through Feb. 13.
Hsieh said he will honor his promise to give the KMT more time to consider his offer.

"I'll wait for a goodwill response from the KMT. But as the new Legislative Yuan will begin its new session Feb. 15, I cannot wait too long. I'll wait until Feb. 17. If the KMT fails to give me a response by that time, I'll then announce who my deputy will be, " Hsieh said.

Lien said last week that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must negotiate with the KMT to clarify and seek consensus on certain critical policy issues before the KMT accepts the DPP's offer to appoint Chiang.

The issues to be discussed should include the country's status, the opening of direct transportation links with mainland China, plans to change the official name of the country, investigations into last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian, and attempts to liquidate the KMT's ill-gotten assets, in addition to the controversial Fourth Nuclear Power Plant project, Lien said, adding that the two parties also need to negotiate on how much authorization Chiang will enjoy as vice premier to ensure he will not be just a dummy in the DPP government.
In a previous response, Hsieh said that as a premier, he cannot fulfill the KMT's prerequisites because those terms go beyond his authority.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL IN INDIA WRITES TO PAPER OF TAIWAN'S ISOLATION

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official's appeal in an Indian weekly to end the international isolation of the Republic of China was echoed in a letter to the same broadsheet.

Reader John Alexander from Nagpur, Maharashtra, wrote that the opinion piece by Simon C. Hsieh, the director of the Information Division, Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi, should "find sympathetic echo in the hearts and minds of people across the world."

Noting that Taiwan has pledged to donate US$50 million in relief to the tsunami-stricken countries around the India Ocean -- the world's 11th-largest donor -- the letter regretted that Taiwan was not invited to the international meeting on tsunami aid in Jakarta on the grounds that it is not a UN member.
"Ostracization of Taiwan by the international community is painful, to say the least," the letter went on.
The letter was a response to Hsieh's appeal carried in the Jan. 22 issue of the Sahara Time.

In his appeal, Hsieh touted Taiwan's generous aid to the tsunami-ravaged countries after the Dec. 26 disaster, including a program initiated by its Government Information Office to raise funds to "adopt" 10,000 children from the disaster area, providing for their needs for three years.

However, Hsieh's letter said, Taiwan's significant contributions to the relief operation didn't earn it a seat at the Jan. 6 conference when the heads of the world's major donor countries gathered in Jakarta, Indonesia to coordinate their relief operation, because Taiwan is not a UN member.
"We are living in a global village where all the members are interdependent on each other, " Hsieh wrote, adding that Taiwan's exclusion from the aid effort was unwise.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MINI LINKS PASSENGERS HIT SINGLE DAY HIGH OF 1,992

TEXT.P: With only two days left until the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday, a record high of 1,992 passengers for a single day traveled between Xiamen and Kinmen Sunday, according to tallies made public Monday by Kinmen authorities.

More than 90 percent of the passengers were mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families returning home for the lunar new year holiday -- 1,381 from Xiamen to Kinmen and 611 vice versa, statistics compiled by the Kinmen harbor authorities showed.
Meanwhile, more than 1,600 people used the ferry service between the two sides Monday -- 1,142 from Xiamen to Kinmen and 523 in the opposite direction.

As of the same day, a total of 15,413 passengers had sailed between Kinmen and Xiamen since Jan. 29, a number exceeding the harbor's target, an official said, noting that passengers' willingness to use the direct Kinmen-Xiamen shipping links were not affected by the special charter flight service between Taiwan and mainland China during the lunar new year festival period through Feb. 20.

The figure stood at 13,748 as of late Sunday, the official said, adding that most of the homecoming travelers from mainland China, about 10,000, used the service to transfer to destinations on Taiwan proper.

The Kinmen-Xiamen shipping links form part of the so-called "three mini links" -- along with direct trade and transport links -- between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands connecting Xiamen and Mawei ports in mainland China's Fujian province. The links were established on Jan. 1, 2001 to help promote economic development on the two frontline islands.
Full direct links across the Taiwan Strait have been absent since 1949, when the nationalist forces retreated to Taiwan after a civil war with Chinese communists in mainland China.

In response to a call by the international community to reduce tensions between the two sides and an enthusiastic call by a large number of Taiwan business people operating in mainland China, representatives from the two sides agreed upon a ground-breaking pact in the middle of last month in Macau on the direct charter flight service during the Chinese New Year holidays.
The landmark agreement, involving six carriers from either side, permitted the first landings of mainland carriers on Taiwan soil in more than 55 years.

The charter flights were limited to Taiwan business people and their dependents based in the mainland, who have repeatedly called for setting up regular commercial flights across the Taiwan Strait in view of two-way close and frequent exchanges despite long-standing political feuding between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECULATION ON RENMINBI BOOSTS VALUE OF NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar is expected to continue to surge after the lunar new year holidays on rampant speculation that mainland China will allow its currency to freely float within a narrow range, market sources said Monday.

Backed on continued influx of cash from foreign investors over the past few weeks, the local currency may continue to rise and challenge the level of NT$31.50 to the U.S. dollar after the lunar new year holiday period, market watchers said.

Amid sluggish trading in the pre-holiday period, the new Taiwan dollar kept its robust rising streak against the U.S. dollar during the trading session Saturday -- the last trading day before the Chinese New Year Holiday -- in the Taipei foreign exchange market. But the local unit gave way by NT$0.057 to finish at NT$31.68 against the greenback as a result of strong intervention by the central bank.

They said that the local unit is expected to see a noticeable jump in value by that time, boosted by a widely expected stronger renminbi. They claimed, however, that Taiwan's central bank may intervene if the local currency approaches the NT$31.50 mark. The new Taiwan dollar has picked up in value against the U.S. currency by more than 6 percent over the past year.

The analysts made the comments after mainland China signed on Sunday in London a comunique endorsed by Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States, agreeing to greater exchange rate flexibility for countries with fixed currency exchanges regimes.

Although key mainland officials fell short of setting a timetable to loosen the exchange rate formulation system for renminbi, analysts said that a change of attitude on the mainland side is an indication that the mainland currency is likely to appreciate from 3 percent to 5 percent in the initial stage.

They also predicted that mainland China will not rashly make the appreciation announcement for its currency before the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday. But they said that they are convinced that the mainland will sooner or later permit its dollar-pegged currency to gain in value this year.

The mainland currency has been rigidly pegged at 8.3 to the U.S. dollar since 1995. But the renminbi's exchange rate on forward contract delivery shows that it will appreciate by 5 percent to 7.88 against the greenback in one year, market dealers said.
Mainland China has long resisted pressure from the United States and the European Union to float its currency, thus giving the country an unfair advantage in foreign markets.

European Central Bank President Jean-Claude Trichet said after the London meeting that the G-7 was convinced that "some appropriate changes" could be foreseen in mainland China's exchange rate policy, according to a foreign wire service report.

Ministers and bankers from the G-7 wealthy nations said in the comunique that "more flexibility in exchange rates is desirable for major countries or economic areas that lack such flexibility, " the report said.

"The Chinese continue to emphasize their commitment to move to a flexible exchange rate and we have seen steps that are consistent with a move in this direction, " U.S. Treasury Secretary John Snow said, according to the report.

The G-7 Group also forecast sound economic growth and eased consumer product inflation in 2005 and reiterated currency declarations that have been viewed by some economists that could stem the U. S. dollar's fall.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO PURSUE STABILITY THROUGH CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed on Monday to pursue political stability through consultations and dialogue with opposition political parties.

Flanked by Vice President Annette Lu, Chen told a group of sailors at a dinner party at a Naval base in Keelung, northern Taiwan, that stability is the general sentiment of the people, and his administration will do its best to meet that desire.
Creating political stability through consultations and dialogue is not only a vision and a promise made by him to the people but also the government's firm response dictated by the people, Chen said.

However, the president said, political reconciliation and cooperation among different political parties will be elusive unless the parties set aside their differences and subordinate their partisan interests to the benefit of the people and the goals of the nation.

Recalling that he has likened the country's 23 million people to travelers on the same boat in a speech to mark Armed Forces Day on Sept. 3, 2003, the president said the metaphor is still valid, and so is the motif of that speech that "we should united to fight for the country's sustained development and for Taiwan people's wellbeing."
The president said the country owes its security and peace to the armed forces, and as the supreme commander of the armed forces, Chen thanked them for doing their best.

He urged the armed forces to sharpen their awareness of the military threats posed by mainland China to Taiwan, strengthen the country's defense, support the country's arms purchase from the United States and be safety conscious during their routine training.
The president also wished the armed forces a happy new year at the end of his speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Feb. 8:

street cleaners at No. 77, Zhongzheng Road, Taipei City.
10: 30, Premier Frank Hsieh will inspect a community in Tungshih,
Taichung County.

appreciation to the workers of the city's disaster prevention

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: New controls to stem flow of immigrants.
Strict new controls for migrant workers involving compulsory fingerprinting and an Australian-style points system will be announced today.
Charles Clarke, the Home Secretary, will tell MPs that would-be migrants must prove that they will bring economic benefits to Britain before they are allowed into the country. The initiative is widely seen as an attempt to outflank the Conservatives, whose immigration policies have struck a chord with voters. Financial Times: IMF weighs gold sale option.
The International Monetary Fund is preparing a report on the potential sale of a portion of its gold reserves in a move that would help fund debt relief for poor countries but could unsettle the markets by threatening a drop in the price of gold. Finance ministers from the Group of Seven countries, meeting in London at the weekend, asked Rodrigo Rato, IMF managing director, to make proposals to the fund's shareholders at its April meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: $2.5 Trillion Budget Plan Cuts Many Programs; Domestic Spending Falls; Defense, Security Rise.
President Bush plans to unveil a $2.5 trillion budget today eliminating dozens of politically sensitive domestic programs, including funding for education, environmental protection and business development, while proposing significant increases for the military and international spending, according to White House documents. (By Jorge Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Prods Israel for Hard Choices on Palestinians
U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, conferred with Prime
Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel on Sunday and called on Israel
to make "hard decisions" in negotiations with Palestinian
leaders as they wage their own fight against militants. Bush
administration officials say Israel needs to proceed with its
withdrawal of forces from West Bank cities, its lifting of
roadblocks and checkpoints throughout the occupied territories,
and the possible release of Palestinian prisoners. An Israeli
official said Ms. Rice also asked Israeli leaders not to
undermine the political standing of Mahmoud Abbas, the new
Palestinian president.
Wall Street Journal: Grim Harvest, Farms Destroyed, Stricken Sudan Faces Food Crisis Sudan Faces Food Crisis
After the killings, the rapes, and the expulsion of nearly two million farmers from their land, the people of Darfur are now facing a new threat -- the worst food shortage in decades. The grim harvest bears witness to the consequences of the intentional destruction of farms across this vast region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 8, or the 30th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the U.S. film actor and cult hero who died at the age of 24 in a road accident while driving his Spider convertible, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1962: The U.S. military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Dr. George L.B. Pratt, director of the Office of Education and Manpower, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1976: Guatemalan Ambassador Agustin Donis Kesler calls on Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan to thank the government for helping earthquake victims.
1980: Louis Vorster, new ambassador of the Republic of South Africa, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, dies at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from mainland China's Xinhua News Agency who have been granted permission to be stationed in Taiwan arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY(EMBARGOED FOR RELEASE ON WEDNESDAY, FEB. 9)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 9, or the first day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Hostilities between Britain and the American colony of Massachusetts become imminent as the British Parliament announces the state is in rebellion and approves new laws to control the situation.
1799: The U.S. Navy draws first blood in a war with France.
1801: France signs the Peace of Luneville with Austria, dissolving the Holy Roman Empire.
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and who advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1830: Explorer Charles Stuart discovers the source of Australia's longest river, the Murray.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed," and "The Brother Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege to the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russians, and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty by a vote 64-6.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the U.S. took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the U.S. returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stocks Exchange formally begins operations.
1964: Beatlemania hits the United States as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1973: H.E. Hisham Muhiuddin Nazer, state minister of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Six winners of the Second Cathay Children's Music Contest leave Taipei for Hong Kong to attend the Arts Festival.
1981: General Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Polish Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
1999: A 352-page collection of news photographs depicting historic moments in ROC diplomacy over the past six decades is published by the Central News Agency, which was founded in 1924.
1999: The Republic of the Marshall Islands opens an embassy in the Republic of China, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.
2000: The Taiwan Stock Exchange performs well on the first trading session after the Chinese New Year holiday, with the market's weighted price index breaking the 10,000 point level at the close.
2001: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Deputy Director-General Francis K.H. Liang, leaves Taipei for Beijing to attend a senior officials meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY(EMBARGOED FOR RELEASE ON THURSDAY, FEB. 10)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 10, or the second day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikhs at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In an historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1974: An all-star women's basketball team leaves Taipei for a tour of the United States.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1981: The 32 new ROC Control Yuan members are sworn in.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President-elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann dies. He is considered a founding father of the European Union.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Fan Liqing and Zhen Binhua, the first two mainland Chinese reporters allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, cover their first story, with themselves being the center of attention among the local press.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, striking a note of optimism on her first visit to the Middle East as the top U.S. diplomat, urged Israeli leaders to make the "hard decisions" needed to promote a democratic Palestinian state and put the peace process back on track.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY LEGISLATORS PLAN TO RUN FOR MAYORS, MAGISTRATES

TEXT.P: With the elections for city mayors and county magistrates set to be held at the end of this year, a number of incumbent and former legislators are prepared to join the races to seek to advance their political careers.

The posts of mayors and magistrates have always been a favorite among lawmakers planning a career shift. The high success rate is just as encouraging: of the 23 sitting mayors and magistrates around Taiwan, 12 used to be legislators.
The elections, which are considered a litmus test for the 2008 presidential race, will also be the main battlefront between the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" camps.
In the coming elections, cutthroat competition within the "pan-green" camp is expected in Yunlin County, where sitting magistrate Chang Jung-wei will step down after finishing two terms.

While three former Yunlin-elected legislators of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) -- Su Chih-fen, Kao Meng-ting and Lin Kuo-hua -- have expressed their intention to vie for the party's nomination for Yunlin magistrate, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) reportedly is planning to nominate Legislator Cheng Chen-lung to run in the race.

Former DPP legislators Tsao Chi-hung and Lin Feng-hsi also gave up their legislative re-election bids last year to pave the way for running for Pingtung magistrate and Taichung magistrate, respectively. Chiu Yi-ying, another former Pingtung-elected DPP legislator, is being pushed by supporters to run for Pingtung magistrate after losing her re-election bid in December.

Also, former TSU legislators Chen Chien-ming and Chien Lin Whei-jun, who both lost their re-election bids, have expressed their interest in the post of Taipei magistrate and Tainan mayor, respectively.

As far as the "pan-blue" camp is concerned, competition will be the fiercest in Taipei County. The contestants for Taipei magistrate include opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislators Hung Hsiu-chu, Lee Chia-chin and Huang Teh-fu as well as opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chou Hsi-wei.
In Keelung City, the re-election bid of Mayor Hsu Tsai-li from the KMT is expected to be challenged by PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung.
While KMT Legislator Liu Cheng-hung is preparing to run for Miaoli magistrate, former KMT Legislator Liao Feng-teh is reportedly planning to run for Ilan magistrate.
KMT Legislator Cho Po-yuan, who is a former deputy Changhua magistrate, has also expressed his intention to run for Changhua magistrate.
To coordinate these ambitious politicians within the "pan-blue" camp, KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu proposed that the KMT and PFP hold aprimary before the end of May to choose their candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RED CROSS SOCIETY TO ATTEND RELIEF CONFERENCE IN INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China has been invited to an international relief conference to be held in Indonesia next week, according to an anonymous source from the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in Geneva.
The source said that Taiwan was invited to the conference because of its generous aid to tsunami victims in South Asia.
The conference will also be attended by representatives from mainland China, giving the two sides of the Taiwan Strait a rare opportunity to rub shoulders at an international event.
The conference was jointly organized by the ICRC and the International Federation of Red Crescent (IFRC) to coordinate the relief efforts made by the Red Cross and Red Crescent across the world.

Taiwan took offence at the fact that it was shut out of an international relief conference organized by the Association of Southeast Asia Nations in Jakarta, Indonesia on Jan. 6 although it has promised to contribute US$50 million to help with relief operations. That figures makes Taiwan the 11th-largest donor state.

The ICRC doesn't recognize the Red Cross Society of the ROC, but invited it to the Indonesia conference anyway, "because the conference is a working meeting without any political overtones" the source said.
The Red Cross Society of the ROC has funnelled US$15 million to aid tsunami victims, including US$3 million to the IFRC.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING MOTHERBOARD-MAKERS EYE 100 MILLION SHIPMENTS IN 2005

TEXT.P: The four leading motherboard manufacturers in Taiwan are aiming to make a total of 100 million shipments in 2005.

As motherboard shipments by Asus topped 40 million units in 2004, Micro-Star International (MSI) and Elitegroup saw their shipments declined to 16.5 million units and 14.5 million units during the same period.
Meanwhile, shipments by Gigabyte Technology rose 5.2 percent to 14.5 million units last year.
Asus has set a goal for 2005 to expand its shipments further to 50 million units.
Facing the threat from Asus, MSI is targeting more than 17.5 million shipments this year, and Elitegroup is also ambitious to restore its market share with 20 million shipments.
The target of Gigabyte is 16.5 million units this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 16,000 PASSENGERS USE KINMEN-XIAMEN FERRY LINKS BEFORE NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: A total of 16,189 passengers have traveled between Taiwan and mainland China through the ferry service linking the outlying island of Kinmen and the mainland's Xiamen port during the 11 days before Chinese Lunar New Year, officials said Tuesday.

During the period from Jan. 29 to Feb. 8, 128 ferries were provided between the two ports, transporting 10,781 people from Xiamen to Kinmen and 5,408 people the other way round, according to statistics from the Kinmen County Government.
On Tuesday, the eve of the lunar new year, 776 passengers traveled via the service, county government officials said.

They included 500 passengers from Xiamen to Kinmen, most of whom were mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen and their families returning home for the holiday. The other 276 passengers from Kinmen to Xiamen comprised mainly mainland spouses of Taiwanese citizens and staff of mainland-based Taiwanese investors.
The officials said the ferry service will be suspended on Wednesday and reopen on Thursday.
The Kinmen-Xiamen ferry service is part of the so-called "mini three links" between Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/Fuzhou.
Since the service was launched in 2001, it has become a major means of transportation for Taiwanese businessmen based in the southern part of the mainland to travel between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM BUREAU WELCOMES VISA-FREE ENTRY TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: The expected move by Japan to give visitors from Taiwan visa-free status for a limited time was met with approval Tuesday from Taiwan's Tourism Bureau.

The Japanese House of Councilors, or the upper house of the Diet, is expected to pass a revision bill proposed by lawmakers from the ruling coalition of the Liberal Democratic Party and the New Komeito Party at its plenary session Wednesday.

An official from the Tourism Bureau said the measures have been long in coming as Taiwan has allowed Japanese tourists to come to Taiwan without first obtaining a visa for the last three years. Japan's move should boost private exchanges between the two countries, the official added.

Taiwan tourists will be allowed into Japan without a visa between March 25 and Sept. 30, which is timed to coincide with the Aichi World Expo to be held in Aichi prefecture in central Japan from March 25 to Sept. 25.
Taiwan tourists can stay in Japan for three months.
A similar visa waiver will be extended to South Korean tourists from March 1 to Sept. 30.

The official said the Japanese government had worked out the changes to the visa requirements last September but didn't asked for the Diet's approval until early this year because of badgering from Beijing, which frowns on any engagement between Japan and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECOVERY IN CONTRACT CHIPMAKING INDUSTRY EXPECTED IN H2 OF 2005

TEXT.P: The two leading contract chipmakers -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Co. (UMC) -- expect the contract chipmaking industry to recover in the second half of 2005, although sales are expected to continue to slip in the first half owing to inventory adjustments in the semiconductor sector.

Supported by the booming semiconductor sector in the first three quarters, the sales of TSMC rose 26.8 percent year-on-year to NT$255.99 billion (US$8.08 billion) in 2004. Net profit also jumped 95.3 percent to a record-high of NT$92.31 billion, with earnings per share standing at NT$3.97.
UMC also did well, posting record sales of NT$117.31 billion in 2004, up 38.2 percent from the previous year. Net profit amounted to NT$31.84 billion, with earnings per share registering at NT$1.89.
However, the impact from the inventory adjustments that started in the fourth quarter of 2004 is expected to continue well into the first half of 2005.
TSMC has projected a 10 percent fall in its shipments in the first quarter of 2005 over the previous quarter and has revised its gross margin down from 42.5 percent to 38 percent.
UMC has also predicted a 17 percent decrease in its shipments in the first quarter and a 10 percent drop in the prices of its products.
According to TSMC Chairman Morris Chang, the semiconductor sector is likely to see a 10 percent growth in 2006 after experiencing a recession in 2005.

Market analysts said the recession of the semiconductor sector is expected to hit bottom in the first half of this year and that the operations of TSMC and UMC will be boosted by seasonal demand and clients' need to stock up starting from the third quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HSIEH DISTANCES ADMINISTRATION FROM NAME-CHANGING CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: The campaign to change the country's official designation to Taiwan could be better advanced if it were spearheaded by private groups rather than by the administration, Premier Frank Hsieh said in Taichung County in central Taiwan Tuesday.
The administration would inevitably come under protest from Japan, the United States and mainland China if it came out to lead the campaign, the premier said.
However, the administration will keep a free hand to deal with the country's neighbors if the call to change the country's name comes from private groups.
Hsieh has vowed to steer his administration away from controversial policies to seek the support of the majority of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN EXTENDS NEW YEAR'S GREETINGS TO COUNTRYMEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian extended his traditional new year's greetings to his fellow countrymen on the eve of the Chinese Year of the Rooster Tuesday by sharing with them glimpses of his many sojourns around the island.

At the beginning of the 60-second black and white film, Chen said he used to look at photos of his friends over the new year holiday and now he would like to share his warm memories with his countrymen.
The film was a composite of videos of Chen's numerous trips around the country since he took office in 2000.
In the film, the president is seen rubbing shoulders with the common people, being reunited with his elementary school classmates, and holding a crying infant from an aboriginal family.
The film began to be shown on local TV stations and broadcast on radio from 6 p.m. Tuesday when most Taiwanese were beginning their traditional new year's eve feast at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 11, or the third day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1889: A constitution is granted in Japan with a two-chamber Diet, with the Emperor retaining extensive powers.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1922: A treaty for securing China's independence and maintaining an "open door" is signed in Washington by nine powers.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty, which gives Vatican City the status of an independent sovereign state.
1944: American war planes strike heavy blows against Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands.
1945: The Yalta Conference ends with an agreement for the establishment of the United Nations as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with France.
1967: Military rule is imposed in Beijing.
1968: Communist troops execute 300 civilians in South Vietnam during fighting for the city of Hue.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as the first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning underwater nuclear testing.
1973: Lic. Raimundo Guerrero, president of the Mexican Chapter of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1974: Archbishop Domenico Enrici, roving ambassador of the Holy See, arrives in Taipei on an inspection tour. He had served in the Apostolic Internunciature in Taipei 20 years earlier.
1974: Nineteen top Chinese golfers, including Melbourne World Cup Champions Lu Liang-huan and M.N. Hsieh, leave for Manila for the Asian circuit.
1974: U.S. Army Assistant Secretary Eugene E. Berg and a party of 2 arrive in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman as its leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed Edward Heath.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives the visiting Dr. N. B. Sommer, the first vice president of U.S. Cyanamid Corporation, and W. A. Liffers, the Pacific area general manager.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after strikes, riots, and mass demonstrations against his rule.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela is freed after being imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure be disbanded by April 1.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and U.S. President Bill Clinton fail to reach a critical trade deal.
2000: Liu Shao-tang, publisher of the Chinese-language monthly Biographical Literature, dies at the age of 80 after a long illness.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."

JOLO, Sulu -- Artillery and aircraft continued to pound Muslim rebels on Jolo island Thursday, the military said, as President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo vowed to push the fight against terrorism "to the limit."
