DOC.HEADLINE: ARRANGEMENTS FOR CHEN-SOONG MEETING UNDERWAY: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: Preparations and arrangements for a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will begin next Monday after the Lunar New Year holidays, Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Friday.

Yu said that no matters pertaining to when and where the meeting should be held have been decided, adding that President Chen is open to ideas regarding the meeting's format and discussion topics. He pointed out that the president will fully respect Soong's opinions in this regard.

Yu's remarks came after local media reported that Chen and Soong have agreed to meet on Feb. 23 in a gesture of reconciliation between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition forces in view of political instability over the past few years.
A Chen-Soong meeting has been much anticipated by the public since the president called for compromise and ice-breaking between the two camps in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Although Chen marginally won the March 20, 2004 presidential election for a second term, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), the PFP and the New Party retained its majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in the Dec. 11 elections, winning a combined 114 seats.
Many analysts predicted that this situation could prolong the bitter domestic political conflict over the next three years.

In an effort to put an end to this, the DPP, which garnered 89 seats in the legislative elections, has tried hard to entice the PFP, which won 34 seats, to form a stable majority with it in the sixth Legislative Yuan which opened Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PITCHES FOR CROSS-STRAIT PEACE, INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he looks forward to seeing inter-party reconciliation and cooperation as well as permanent peace across the Taiwan Strait during the Lunar New Year of the Rooster.
Chen made the remarks while attending a flower festival activity in Changhua County's Hsichou township in central Taiwan.

The president said he has two hopes for the new year. First of all, Chen said he hopes all the people of Taiwan will enjoy good fortune and prosperity. Secondly, Chen said he looks forward to permanent cross-strait peace and an end to hostile political wrangling between the ruling and opposition camps.
Noting that flowers come in many different colors, Chen said an open, democratic society needs to have a myriad of political parties in order to reflect the opinions of different segments of society.

"Flowers are beautiful because they have many colors. Eye-catching rainbows consist of seven colors. If our political landscape only has two 'colors' -- blue and green -- it will be too dull and monotonous. We need orange, yellow and other colors, " Chen said.

In Taiwan's political arena, green is the color of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , while blue is the color of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , and orange is that of the People First Party (PFP) -- the KMT's "pan-blue" ally.
The DPP administration has been seeking to forge a working partnership with the PFP and the KMT since it failed to garner a majority in last December's legislative elections.

In his speech at the floral deity worship ritual at the Changhua Lunar New Year Flower Show, Chen reaffirmed his determination to find a way to engage the KMT-led opposition, which holds a slim legislative majority.
"For the sake of the national interest and the people's well-being, the ruling and opposition parties have to reconcile and cooperate. We have to find a new model of working together, " Chen said.

Touching on cross-strait relations, Chen said he hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can stop pursuing policies and using rhetoric that provoke each other, and instead move toward reconciliation and cooperation.
Chen was accompanied Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang and DPP Legislator Chiang Chao-yi during his tour of the annual Changhua flower show.
The president noted that the flower show attracted a record 1.57 million visitors last year. "This time around, I hope the number of visitors will be even higher," he said.
"If you come, you'll find that the beauty of the Hsichou floral township can compete with the likes of Paris and Amsterdam, " the president added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US$500,000 DONATION FOR GUATEMALA, NOT PORTILLO: ROC AMBASSADOR
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A US$500,000 donation by the Republic of China government to Guatemala in 2000 was directed to its government, not to the then President Alfonso Antonio Portillo Cabrera, ROC Ambassador to Guatemala Francisco H. L. Ou clarified Thursday.

Ou's comments came after the Guatemalan media reported earlier the same day that the former Guatemalan president received US$500,000 from Taiwan in 2000 in a check bearing his personal name, instead of the Education Ministry or Presidential Office.

Pointing out that the ROC government contributed the money to Guatemala for the central American diplomatic ally to print handbooks for teachers, Ou said that the fund was presented to the Guatemalan government in a public ceremony.
Ou stressed that the ROC government made the contribution to the Guatemalan government to carry out the project and repeated that it was not a donation to a private individual.
The ROC Embassy is very willing to cooperate with the Guatemalan prosecution authorities if they decide to conduct an investigation into this case, Ou said.

According to an official at the ROC Embassy in Guatemala, the Guatemalan Education Ministry did send various teachers' handbooks to ROC Embassy officials as proof of the ministry's execution of the mission.

Portillo has been living in exile in Mexico since February 2004 after stepping down from his post the same year. He has been accused of graft, and the Guatemalan prosecution authorities are currently conducting investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION POLICE SEIZE NEARLY 250 KG OF ILLICIT DRUGS IN 2004

TEXT.P: The Aviation Police Bureau (APB) seized a total of 241.95 kilograms of illegal drugs last year, a record high in recent memory, a bureau official said Friday.
According to APB tallies, ketamine made up the largest portion of the total drugs seized, followed by heroin, marijuana, amphetamine and ecstasy, in that order.
The APB official said most of the seized drugs were brought to Taiwan via Southeast Asian, Hong Kong and Macau air routes, with concealing the drugs in luggage being the most common smuggling method.
In some cases, the illicit drugs were hidden in the soles of a trafficker's shoes or in bags in a trafficker's trousers, or fastened to their waist or legs.

In the past, the official said, drug trafficking rings recruited foreigners in Hong Kong, Macau and Southeast Asian nations to smuggle drugs into Taiwan. In recent years, he said, drug rings have often recruited local people, including students, with no previous criminal records, particularly unemployed persons or vagrants, to work for them.

With advanced detecting equipment, the official said, drug trafficking via air has become ever riskier. He urged local people not to get involved in drug trafficking, manufacturing, trading or abuse. He added that the maximum penalty for drug trafficking is death.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENTISTS SPREAD LOVE AND CARE IN MALAWI
DOC.DATELINE: Lilongwe, Malawi, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By H.J. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A group of dentists from Taiwan visited Malawi from Jan. 31 to Feb. 8, spreading their love and care to the southern African country and building a bridge between the peoples of the two countries.

The group's visit to Malawi -- its first to Africa -- was welcomed by the locals, the vast majority of whom are too poor to receive dental treatment at expensive private clinics. There are no more than 20 qualified dentists in Malawi, with only two of them serving in public hospitals -- for a population of more than 12 million people.

In addition to providing charitable services at schools, residential communities and orphanages in the capital, the group also donated various sets of portable equipment to their Malawian counterparts and carried out academic exchanges with them.

Dr. Su Chen-tai, leader of the group who has practiced dentistry for many years in Taiwan's eastern county of Hualien, claimed that the most important aspect of their visit to Malawi was to set an example for their local counterparts to learn to serve the poor.
The group is also considering the possibility of establishing an institute to help foster dentists in Malawi, he added.

The group left Malawi for Swaziland on Feb. 8. Both Malawi and Swaziland are staunch Republic of China diplomatic allies in southern Africa. Currently, the ROC maintains formal diplomatic relations with 26 nations around the world, with most of these scattered in Latin America and Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: 35-45 AGE GROUP MAIN HOME BUYERS IN TAIWAN IN Q4: CEPD SURVEY

TEXT.P: People aged between 35 and 45 were the main home buyers in the fourth quarter of 2004 in Taiwan, accounting for 42.7 percent of the total number of buyers in the domestic real-estate market, according to the results of a recent government survey.

At the same time, the 25-35 age group surpassed the 40 percent mark for the first time to make up 40.4 percent of the total number of home buyers in the final quarter of last year, the results of the poll carried out by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) showed.

The average age for home buyers was 35.9 years, with those with a monthly income of between NT$30,000 and NT$60,000 (US$1,880) making up the largest portion, or 34.1 percent, of the total number of home buyers, according to the poll results.
In the third quarter of 2004, buyers with a monthly income above NT$60,000 were the major driving force in the market, accounting for 59.5 percent of the total number of buyers.

CEPD officials attributed the growth in the number of younger first time home buyers to the government's low interest rate policy, evidenced by the fact that some 54 percent of the home buyers in the fourth quarter were first time buyers, up from 45.9 percent in the third quarter, according to the survey.
Second-hand homes were the most popular in the fourth quarter, making up 46 percent of the total number of homes purchased.
Meanwhile, the average home price was 5.7 times that of the average family income per year, representing a drop from the third quarter level.

Demand for second-hand houses and apartments was stronger than that for newly-built ones in Taipei City and Taipei County, while the demand for newly-built ones was stronger in Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Taichung City and Taichung County, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN LONDON CELEBRATES LUNAR NEW YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Great Britain joined with the London Press Club and the London Foreign Press Club in holding a Taiwan-style Lunar New Year party at the press club's conference hall Thursday.

The festivity, dubbed the Taiwan Day party, brought together more than 150 people, including British media professionals, leading figures of major Taiwanese associations and staff members of the Taipei Representative Office in the U.K., to celebrate the new Year of the Rooster.

Addressing the evening party, Lin Chun-yi, the ROC representative to the U.K., said Taiwanese culture stems from Chinese culture just as American culture stems from English culture. Over the years, Lin said, Taiwanese culture has developed its own unique features in terms of the arts, language and customs.

Lin, who assumed his current post just a month ago, said he is hopeful that members of the British press community can get a better understanding of Taiwan which he said is striving to consolidate its young democracy while being isolated from the international community due to Beijing's diplomatic suppression and military threat.

Lin said all staff members of the ROC representative office will strengthen engagements with members of the London Press Club and the London Foreign Press Club to help them better understand Taiwan's achievements in various areas, including its cultural wonders.

A puppet theater troupe from Taiwan, led by veteran puppeteer Chen Hsi-huang, performed at the evening party, winning much acclaim from the audience. Chou chien-chang, a doctoral student at the London School of Economics and Political Science, demonstrated the art of traditional Chinese calligraphy, while Lin Hsing-hsiang, a Taiwan expatriate in London versed in tea ceremony, introduced six strains of fine-quality Taiwan tea.

Also on display were brochures and souvenirs featuring Taiwan's tourist resources. Lin said he hopes the festivities can help inspire more British people to visit Taiwan to experience the island's natural and cultural wonders.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER RELUCTANT TO ANNOUNCE KMT CHAIRMANSHIP BID

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Friday he supports the proposal that sitting Kuomingtang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan continue to lead the main opposition party.
Wang made the remarks while hosting a Lunar New Year party in honor of his supporters in his hometown of Luchu in the southern county of Kaohsiung.

Wang said 2005 marks the 30th anniversary of his entry into the political world. An emotional Wang said he wanted to take advantage of the occasion to express his gratitude for the long-term support of all the townsfolk. More than 5,000 people, including lawmakers from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union as well as Wang's grassroots supporters, attended the massive-scale lunch party.
During the party, many of Wang's fans urged Wang to announce his bid to run for KMT chairmanship. KMT members are expected to directly elect a new party chairman in May.

However, Wang said he agrees with many party elders' views that Lien should continue to head the KMT because the party still faces many crucial challenges and needs an experienced leader to steer it through the rough tide ahead.

"Our party must address issues regarding a merger with the PFP, disposal of party assets and party restructuring. All these issues are complicated and require Lien's leadership in the process of resolving them," Wang said.
Wang, a 10-term legislator who just won the legislative speakership for a third term, said he will not consider running for the KMT chairmanship until after Lien definitely decides to quit the post.

If Lien insists on stepping down as KMT chairman after his current tenure expires in August, Wang may face competition from popular Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in his bid for the top KMT post. Ma is widely believed to run for the post if Lien insists on retirement.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES FUND TO HELP COSTA RICAN FLOOD VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has donated US$100,000 to help Costa Rican people affected by recent flooding in Limon province.

ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Wu Tzu-dan presented a check for US$100,000 to Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella on behalf of the ROC government in a ceremony held at the Central American country's Presidential Office Wednesday.
Pacheco said he appreciates the ROC's generous donation to help flood victims in Limon province. "I wants to express heartfelt gratitude on behalf of our government and people," Pacheco told Wu.
Many senior Costa Rican officials and journalists were also present at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REITERATES SOVEREIGNTY OVER TIAOYUTAI ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's sovereignty over the Tiaoyutai Islands is undisputed, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.
Lu made the remarks after the Japanese government took ownership a lighthouse on a small islet of the uninhabited Tiaoyutai archipelago Wednesday.

Known as Senkaku by Japanese, the Taioyutais lie in the East China Sea between Taiwan and Japan. Surrounded by rich fishing waters, the island group is a frequent source of friction among the ROC, Japan and mainland China.
Stressing that the ROC's sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais is an undisputed fact, Lu said the ROC government hopes that the three parties can hold peaceful talks to resolve the issue.

Mainland China ceded the Tiaoyutais along with Taiwan to Japan in an 1895 Sino-Japanese war. The United States had jurisdiction over them after World War II until 1972, when they were handed back to Japan. Taiwan and mainland China say their claims to the islands date back centuries.

A Tokyo-based right-wing group built the lighthouse on one of the Tiaoyutai islet in 1988. The ownership of the structure, which had since been transferred to a fishery association in the southern Japanese prefecture of Okinawa, was passed to the Japanese government Wednesday.
Lu said the ROC government will lodge a protest with Japanese authorities after the Lunar New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: After 30 years, Charles puts his affair in order.
The Prince of Wales announced his engagement to Camilla Parker Bowles yesterday after being warned that he had to marry her to avoid a looming constitutional crisis.
The Times has learnt that the Prince was told by his most senior advisers that, effectively, he must choose between marrying or banishing his long-term partner. Mrs Parker Bowles agreed to marriage, but only after being persuaded that the Prince needed to place his personal affairs on a conventional footing before he could become King.
Financial Times: Russsia restricts foreign bids.
Russia will bar foreign-owned companies from bidding for the country's most lucrative natural resources this year in the most explicit and sweeping manifestation of a nationalistic state policy developed under the presidency of Vladimir Putin.
The Ministry for Natural Resources said companies would have to be at least 51 per cent Russian-owned to take part in this year's tenders for strategic oil and metals deposits. The rule may prevent oil companies such as ExxonMobil and ChevronTexaco from developing new Russian oil reserves, and also stymie TNK-BP, a pioneering 50-50 owned Anglo-Russian oil company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STEPS UP NANO TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has stepped up development of nanotechnology and relevant products, industry sources said Friday.
Since the government launched a special program to encourage nanotechnology development in 2002, more than 400 local companies have invested in commercial use of nanotechnology.
By 2008, industry sources said, Taiwan's annual production of nanotechnology-related industries will reach NT$300 billion (US$9.68 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Senate Approves Measure to Curb Big Class Actions
The U.S. Senate overwhelmingly approved a measure on Thursday that would sharply limit the ability of people to file class-action lawsuits against companies. Now the measure is heading to the House of Representatives, where Republican leaders say it will be approved next week and sent to the White House for President Bush's signature. The measure would prohibit state court from hearing many kinds of cases they now consider, transferring them to federal courts. Experts say many cases will wind up not being brought because federal judges have been constrained by a series of legal precedents from considering large class actions that involve varying laws of different states.
Wall Street Journal: In Path of Tsunami, Giant Cement Maker Struggles to Recover Struggles to Recover The Paris-base Lafarge, the world's biggest cement producer lost a third of its employees in Aceh, Indonesia, in the tsunami. Now, amid the urgent need to rebuild roads, hospitals, schools and more than a million homes, the company faces a delicate balance between benevolence and business -- it's working with its traumatized employees who survived, helping with the recovery and defending its 96 percent share of Aceh's market against intruders. The company's struggle, at a time when Aceh's misery is opening up a potential bonanza for suppliers of cement, marks the latest chapter of a global giant's extraordinary odyssey in a region battered by political unrest, economic convulsions, guerrilla warfare -- and now the tsunami.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 12, or the fourth day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the American Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search of gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China when Japanese forces quickly breach Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy in the war between the Ching court and Japan which broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Palau from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan announces that the total membership of the Republic of China National Assembly, under the period of national emergency, shall be 1,576.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the ROC to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: Express trains collide north of Hsinchu, in northern Taiwan, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Chang Kwang-shih, ROC vice minister of economic affairs, returns from Saudi Arabia, where he signed a memorandum of economic coorperation.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1974: Raimundo Guerrero, chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1975: The people of South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1976: Six hundred members of the ROC's National Federation of Industries Association, National Federation of Businesses Association, and the Industrial and Business Association meet and pledge to support government economic policy.
1976: The first Sino-Japanese exhibition of modern painting opens, with more than 52 works by contemporary Japanese artists on display.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The U.S. Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1992: Mongolia's new non-communist constitution takes effect.
1996: Yasser Arafat becomes the first president of Palestine.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the ROC Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policymaking task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
1999: The U.S. Senate votes against removing President Bill Clinton from office in the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
2000: Taiwan doctor Chen Chiu-huang wins the 2000 award of the Foundation de Enterprise Montblanc de la Culture of Britain.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: North Korea Escalates Its Nuclear Threat. North Korea made its boldest claim that it has atomic weapons and said it would not return to six-nation talks to negotiate an end to its nuclear program.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: RP, Indonesia delisted by FATF
The Paris-based Financial Action Task Force (FATF), recognizing the Philippines' progress in its anti-money laundering efforts, has de-listed the country from its list of Non-Cooperative Countries and Territories (NCCT), along with Indonesia.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo: No order for truce
JOLO, Sulu -- US-trained troops equipped with night-vision goggles and bullet-proof body armor joined the fray against Moro insurgents on Jolo yesterday as Malacanang held off any ceasefire order despite Muslim calls for an end to the fighting.
The Philippine Star: RP off money laundering blacklist
After almost three years, the Philippines was finally removed from the anti-money laundering Financial Action Task Force (FATF) list of "non-cooperative countries and territories."
The Manila Times: Rebels hunted down
The military will not let up in its pursuit of Muslim rebels who attacked an Army detachment, triggering fighting in Jolo that has killed more than 60 people, including a battalion commander, in the past five days.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: More back wedding but not an abdication.
A large majority of the British people do not want the Queen to abdicate in favour of the Prince of Wales in the next few years, according to a Populus poll for The Times.
A third of the country thinks that Prince Charles's marriage to Camilla Parker Bowles will weaken the monarchy, with only a tiny minority believing it will strengthen it, the poll, taken after the wedding was announced, indicates.
Financial Times: Blair launches poll pledges.
Tony Blair on Friday set out the ground on which he intends to secure a record third consecutive Labour election victory, amid business disquiet about the potential cost of his commitments.
The prime minister launched a "pledge card" - a familiar Labour election device - after a whistle- stop tour of marginal seats en route to the party's spring conference in Gateshead. He told delegates "not everything has been the way we would want it," but said Britain had made progress since 1997. "And now what we ask people is to help us make the changes necessary to allow our country to move forward."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO ADOPT CARROT AND STICK APPROACH TO CONTAIN BAD PORK PROBLEM

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) will adopt a carrot and stick approach in an effort to prevent pork from pigs that are sick or dead before reaching slaughterhouses from entering the market.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung made the remarks during a visit to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Saturday to inspect the work of quarantine officers and sniffer dogs during the Chinese New Year holiday.

Amid public concern that a large amount of pork from pigs that were sick or dead before reaching abattoirs has been sold by unscrupulous money-hungry criminal farmers in local meat markets, the COA is studying ways to manage the problem at the grassroots level, Lee said.

The measures under study include educating pig raisers on how to handle dead pigs properly and providing incentives to persuade them to send sick or dead pigs to plants for producing organic fertilizer, Lee said.

The COA will also launch a campaign warning pig raisers not to sell their dead or sick pigs to meat markets so as not to undermine the sale of pork in the hope that they will follow government policy.
In addition, the COA is studying measures to confiscate the assets of criminals who make pork products from sick and dead pigs, Lee said.

He also took the opportunity to urge the public not to bring any fresh fruit or meat products into Taiwan, especially since the launch of cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights Jan. 29 for the Chinese New Year holiday.

Noting that many Taiwan people are in the habit of bringing agricultural products into Taiwan from the mainland, he said the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine has since Jan. 29 seized 640 kg of smuggled agricultural and poultry products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP PRESIDENTIAL AIDE TO BEHAVE PRUDENTLY

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that with about three years of experience as premier, he will behave with prudence.
Yu made the remark while hosting a tea party at his official residence for the media.

"While I was the Presidential Office secretary-general for the first time, I felt I did not cope with things in a satisfactory way," he said, adding that "I firmly believe my administrative skills, sharpened during my premiership, will boost my second posting as secretary-general."
Yu's first stint as the president's top aide was in 2000, before he assumed the premiership Feb. 1, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Vows Veto of Any Cutback in Drug Benefit
U.S. President Bush threatened on Friday to veto any bill that scales back Medicare's prescription drug benefit, which becomes available in January 2006 to millions of elderly and disabled people. New estimates showing that the benefit will cost US$724 billion over a decade have touched off a furor in Congress, where lawmakers originally believed that it would cost much less. Many members of Congress say they want to revisit the Medicare law this year, and Conservatives seek cutbacks in benefits and co st controls. Liberals and some cent rists want to require the government to negotiate prices with drug manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST SPEAK OUT AGAINST BEIJING'S PROPOSED ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan people must speak out to let the international community know that they are opposed to a proposed anti-secession law by mainland China, an official of a Taiwan think tank said Friday.

Lai Yi-chung, director of the Department of International Affairs of Taiwan Thinktank, made the remarks in a speech on the threat posed by the mainland on Taiwan at an overseas Chinese cultural and educational center in New York.
The Taiwan people need to make clear that they will never accept Beijing's approach of "defining the status quo and changing the status quo" in the Taiwan Strait.
He noted that the tone of the so-called anti-secession law is based on "Taiwan is an inalienable part of China," which he said is a concept defined by the mainland.

Using the anti-secession law to define the status quo will show that Beijing is now tilting toward adopting a harsher policy toward Taiwan, Lai said, showing that Beijing is on the one hand trying to squeeze democracy in Taiwan and Hong Kong, while on the other hand using the enactment of the law to try to mitigate the political responsibility in making decisions on Taiwan.
Lai cited reports that a court may be set up under the law to prosecute those who support Taiwan or even Tibetan and Xinjiang independence.

For this reason, the proposed law is an "anti-freedom" law that will not only squeeze the freedom that comes with the mainland's economic development but will also affect human rights and democracy in Taiwan.

As the content of the anti-secession law has not yet been made clear, the international community will have to wait until the proposed law is reviewed and approved by the mainland's rubber-stamp National People's Congress in March, Lai said.

The urgent task for the Taiwan people is to let the international community know that the anti-secession law has no market in Taiwan and that they will not accept the way Beijing is trying to unilaterally define the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, he added.

Lei also cited a survey conducted by Taiwan Thinktank late last year on the Taiwan people's perception of the anti-secession law that shows that more than 60 percent of those polled believe the enactment of the proposed law will increase tension in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING TO BE ARRANGED BETWEEN PRESIDENT, OPPOSITION PFP LEADER

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that staff of President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong will officially begin work from next Monday on arranging a meeting between the two.

Reporters have claimed that the president and Soong will meet in an attempt to effect a reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties. However, the date, venue and even the issues to be discussed have not been decided upon.
According to Yu, in order to show goodwill and sincerity, the president has said he will respect the opposition's choice of meeting place and date, as well as the issues on the agenda.
The president said he will also meet with all opposition leaders, Yu said, adding that apart from Soong, Chen also hopes to meet with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to discuss national affairs.

Yu, who made the comments while responding to media questions at his residence, reiterated his gratitude for Soong's goodwill in agreeing to meet with Chen, saying that in order to effect inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, Chen will communicate his ideas and opinions with opposition leaders with sincerity and goodwill.
Saying that Chen respects the PFP's opinion on holding the meeting Yu expressed the hope that Chen and Soong will discuss various issues and then report to the media.
As to whether Chen will meet with Lien, Yu said it is up to both sides to decide.

Meanwhile, a PFP spokesman said that party Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng will discuss the meeting with senior Presidential Office staff and that the PFP will then announce the results of the discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CLARIFIES DONATION FOR GUATEMALA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China donation to Guatemala was to assist a human resource investment project of the Central American ally and was not a political donation, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.
Michel Lu was responding to reports that former Guatemalan President Alfonso Antonio Portillo Cabrera received three checks for a total of US$1.5 million from the Taiwan government.

Lu said that the checks bore Portillo's name because he proposed the project before he assumed the presidency. As the project was ongoing and he continued to preside over it, the three checks were issued in his name, according to Lu.
However, Lu admitted that making out checks to an individual's name to assist an ally's investment project is "inappropriate" and he added that the ministry has adjusted its approach.
Taiwan donated US$1.5 million in 2000, mainly for handbooks for teachers and reference books, he said.

Lu said that Guatemala held an open ceremony at that time to express appreciation for the donation, and the teachers' handbooks and reference books were also printed with words of appreciation for the ROC.
Portillo, who has been living in exile in Mexico since leaving office in January 2004, has been accused of graft and the Guatemalan prosecution authorities are investigating him.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD, DRINKING WATER PROVE UNAFFECTED BY RADIATION

TEXT.P: Radiation contamination tests conducted regularly over the past year on the country's main food, imported food and drinking water prove that they were not affected by radiation, according a report released Saturday by the Radiation Monitoring Center under the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council.

The center, which is responsible for investigating and testing the island's radioactive materials contained in food, regularly collected samples from Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung including rice, flour, vegetables, fruit, meat, eggs and milk to make radioactive contamination tests. It also tested fish, shellfish and algae from Hsinchu, Changhua, Chiayi, and Kaohsiung, all of which were negative.
To test drinking water, the center regularly collected samples from 11 of Taipei City's water supply stations and 23 of the island's water supply stations which also tested negative.

As for imported food, the council said the center regularly tested radioactive contamination tests on frozen meat and milk powder. A total of 132 milk powder samples were tested, all of which were negative.

During the examination period, the center also sent officials to shopping malls and markets to collect a total of 240 samples including seafood, vegetables, dried fruit, dairy products, baby supplies and drinks, all of which were negative for radiation contamination.
Nevertheless, the center officials said they will continue to conduct the tests.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STANCE AGAINST REMOVAL OF ARMS EMBARGO ON CHINA UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Oliver LIn and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department said Thursday that Secretary of State Condoleeza Rice clearly explained during a recent tour of Europe the reasons for the U.S. stance against lifting an arms embargo on mainland China.
The department also said that the United States has not changed its stance and has no intention of accepting the European Union's position of lifting its arms embargo on the mainland.
Both the United States and the European Union implemented a ban on arms sales to the mainland following the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre.

In response to questions raised at a daily briefing regarding whether it is fair to say Washington is ready to accept the European position on the lifting of the embargo after Rice's meeting with European leaders in Brussels, State Department Spokesman Richard Boucher said: "No it's not."

"Secretary Rice made very clear in her discussions that the United States doesn't think this is a good move for two reasons: One, the human rights signal it might send, since political prisoners from Tiananmen are still in jail; and two, the potential security problems that such sales of European technology might entail, " he said.

Noting that the United States wants to keep talking with the E.U. about the matter and will keep working on it with the E.U. to see if both sides can find ways to deal with the issue, Boucher said: "We have not changed our position. I don't think the secretary changed her position during the course of the trip."
Asked whether the U.S. will participate or get involved if European countries draft regulations before they lift the embargo, the spokesman refused to speculate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN VOICE OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Several members of U.S. House of Representatives have voiced their opposition to mainland China's proposed anti-secession law, saying that the law will not only unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait but will also escalate military tension and endanger regional peace and stability.

They said the proposed law will also challenge the U.S. determination to honor its commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and urged Beijing not to enact such a law. They also called for other free nations to jointly oppose the law.
The remarks of the representatives, including Dan Burton, Sherrod Brown, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Peter T. King, Thomas G. Tancredo and Heather Wilson, have been put on the congressional record.

According to Burton, the proposed anti-secession law, together with the publication of a PRC white paper last year titled "China's National Defense in 2004 " that calls Taiwan's independence the "biggest immediate threat to China's sovereignty and territorial integrity, " along with the prospect of a lifting of a European Union arms embargo on the mainland, are alarming and represent a disturbing trend in Beijing's attitude toward the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

"If this anti-secession law is enacted, the response from the Taiwanese will be predictable. Military tension will rise accordingly in the Taiwan Strait and regional peace and stability will be affected, " he said, adding that "this cannot be in the best interests of any country, especially those in the region."

Pointing out that the proposed law is unnecessarily provocative and will escalate tension in the Taiwan Strait as well as challenge Washington's will to stand behind the TRA, Brown said that the mainland is seeking to unilaterally change the status quo in the strait and force its own style of government on the 23 million people of Taiwan. He also said that the mainland has ignored Taiwan's contributions to the mainland's strong economy, as well as Taiwan President Chen Shui-bian's gestures of goodwill.

Saying that the freedom-loving people of Taiwan have reacted to the proposed law with disappointment, Rose-Lehtinen noted that in a recent public opinion poll, 70 percent of Taiwanese people opposed the "anti-secession" law.
"I share the sentiments of the people of Taiwan and stand with them in their zeal for freedom and liberty, " the representative further said.
Condemning the proposed law, Tancredo said that Beijing is feeling out the free world to determine its commitment to the safety and security of Taiwan.

"I hope the family of free nations will condemn the `anti-secession law' with a unified voice, making it clear to China that any resolution of cross-strait tension must be peaceful and above all acceptable to the people of Taiwan," he added.

Expressing his concern that the mainland might use the law to make unilateral decisions to change the status quo of cross-strait relations, Wilson said that the proposed law, if adopted, will not foster an atmosphere favorable to cross-strait goodwill.
King expressed hope that the mainland will not enact an anti-secession law or take any steps that might prompt a confrontation in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT LINE CLOSED BRIEFLY DUE TO INJURY: TRTC

TEXT.P: The Tansui line of Taipei's Mass Rapid Transit system was halted for a few minutes Saturday when a man either jumped or fell on the rails at the Mingde Station and suffered head injuries, according to officials of the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC).
He was immediately rushed to the Taipei Veterans General Hospital by TRTC staff, the officials said.
The incident prompted TRTC staff to cut the power supply for a few minutes, but normal operations were resumed shortly afterward.
TRTC General Manager Tsay Huei-sheng went to the scene of the incident and then visited the hospital to get a better understanding of the situation.

The TRTC is planning to install platform doors at busy stations, including the Taipei Main Station and the Zhongxiao Fuxing Station on the Muzha Line, to prevent people from falling onto the rails during peak hours, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VISITS RELIGIOUS LEADERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh had a busy day Saturday visiting religious leaders in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
Hsieh first visited the Fuokuanshan temple to a warm welcome from many followers who came to pay their respects at the Buddhist temple during Chinese New Year.
Hsieh burned incense and prayed for prosperity for the nation and peace for the people.
With the premier promoting inter-party reconciliation, Master Hsin Yun, head of Fuokuanshan, presented him with a plaque bearing the words "co-existence and propitiousness."
The premier then went to the Kuanteh temple, where he received teaching in Buddhism in 1998 from the temple's head, Master Chinghsin.

Noting that the temple is currently building a nursing home for the elderly, Hsieh also said that his Cabinet will step up care for the elderly in rural areas and will try to persuade youngsters to return to the countryside through education.
He said that more than 10 million out of the island's population of 23 million live in rural areas, while younger people have moved to urban areas, leaving the elderly behind without adequate care.
By 2010, one in five Taiwan people will be elderly, he added.
The premier then called on Cardinal Paul Shan Kuo-hsi and the Catholic leader suggested that he give priority to solving problems related to the general public.
Hsieh said that he benefited a great deal from his meeting with the cardinal, saying that communication and dialogue will definitely help reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU HOPES TO GAIN IN YEAR-END LOCAL CHIEF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will try to strengthen its political base at the grassroots in the hope of expanding its political landscape in year-end local chief elections.

For the sake of the sustainable development of the party and to avoid it disintegrating totally after the its poor performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, the TSU has decided to make every effort in the elections slated for late this year, the TSU officials said.
The initial plan is to communicate with its ally, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and try to field TSU candidates in between three and five cities and counties, the officials said.

The TSU fared worse than expected in the legislative elections, garnering just 12 of the 225 seats, one fewer than in the previous legislative election, prompting a bout of soul-searching in the party.
The TSU's so-called "spiritual leader, " former President Lee Teng-hui, as well as Huang Tsung-yuan, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, discussed the party's direction after the December elections.

Lee has offered to serve as the TSU's adviser, believing that the TSU must strengthen its support base at the grassroots, pool the strengths of its affiliate organizations -- think tank Taiwan Advocates and the Lee Teng-hui School -- and hold regular seminars to solicit more talent to prepare for the year-end elections.

Newly elected TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang also said that the most urgent task is to strengthen the party's support base, saying that as a DPP ally, it will lend support to the government's policies but will keep its own independent identity and will not be absent from the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PASSENGERS BETWEEN KINMEN, XIAMEN TOPS 21,000 DURING HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: The number of passengers shuttling between Taiwan's outlying island of Kinmen and the mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen in Fujian Province topped 21,000 during the weeklong Chinese New Year holiday, Kinmen harbor officials said Saturday.

With the holiday drawing to a close, the number of passengers passing through Kinmen either en route to or upon return from Xiamen reached 1,700 Saturday, making Kinmen's Shuitou Wharf an especially bustling place.
It is estimated that the total number of passengers making use of the direct cross-Taiwan Strait transport link reached 21,707 during the holiday period.
Taiwan opened the direct trade, postal and transport links, or commonly known as the "mini three links," between the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian province in January 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Fewer Gays Being Discharged Since 9/11; 'Don't Ask' Ousters At Lowest Level Yet.
The number of gay and lesbian service members discharged under the military's "don't ask, don't tell" policy has dropped by almost half since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and is at its lowest level since the Defense Department began keeping such figures in 1997, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 13, or the fifth day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1542: Catherine Howard, wife of English King Henry VIII, is beheaded for treason.
1668: Spain recognizes the independence of Portugal under the Treaty of Lisbon.
1692: Under English orders, Robert Campbell of Glen Lyon and his 128 men carry out the Glencoe massacre in Scotland against the MacDonald clan.
1793: Austria, Britain, Holland, Prussia, Spain, and Sardinia form an alliance against France.
1858: Captain John Speke and Sir Richard Burton become the first Europeans to discover Lake Tanganyika in East Africa.
1912: Dr. Sun Yat-sen tenders his resignation to the provisional Senate which was established in Nanking on Jan. 28, 1912. He also agrees to relinquish the provisional presidency of the Republic of China to Yuan Shih-kai, who promises to establish a republican government.
1920: Switzerland is admitted to the League of Nations.
1935: A judge sentences Bruno Hauptmann to die in the electric chair after a New Jersey jury found him guilty of kidnapping and murdering flying ace Charles Lindbergh's infant son three years earlier.
1941: The wonder drug penicillin is used for the first time on a human, a policeman from Oxford, England.
1945: U.S. warplanes bomb Dresden, Germany, killing over 35,000 civilians, while allied forces capture Budapest, Hungary.
1954: Chou Lu, a veteran revolutionary leader of the Kuomintang, dies in Taipei at the age of 70.
1957: The British Defense Ministry announces the production of its first H-bomb.
1958: Taipei area records its lowest temperature (2.6 degrees Celsius) in half a century.
1960: The French test their first atomic bomb in the Sahara Desert in Africa.
1966: The list of winners of the first 10 outstanding ROC female youth awards is announced.
1971: Spiro Agnew, vice president of the United States under President Richard Nixon, hits three spectators with his golf ball during the Bob Hope Desert Classic tournament.
1971: Aided by U.S. aircraft and artillery, South Vietnamese troops enter Laos.
1973: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun of the ROC leaves for Bangkok to attend a meeting of the board of trustees of the Asian Institute of Technology and meet with Thai government officials.
1975: The ROC Cabinet decides to ban activities of the Christian Unification Church on the grounds that it has been violating the customs of the Chinese people.
1975: The Sino-Guatemalan and the Sino-Dominican technical cooperation agreements are approved by the ROC Cabinet.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.
1989: Soviet troops leave Kabul, capital of Afghanistan.
1990: Boxer James Douglas is recognized as the new world heavyweight champion after knocking out Mike Tyson in Tokyo two nights earlier.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Task Force permits performing artists from Taiwan to stage commercial performances in mainland China and to participate in activities sponsored by the Chinese communists.
1991: A U.S. missile hits an air-raid shelter crowded with civilians in Baghdad, killing more than 300 people.
1994: A ferry taking illegal Burmese workers home capsizes off Thailand. More than 150 of them are feared dead.
1998: A special convention votes to make Australia a republic and promises a referendum on replacing the queen as head of state in 1999.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is composed and happy; a fool is always worried and full of distress."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Attacks Kill 24 at Shiite Sites.
Gunmen fired into a bakery complex bedecked with Shiite Muslim political posters at Baghdad while another group of militants car-bombed a Shiite mosque near Baqubah, killing more than 20 people in the two attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 7,000 flee homes in Sulu.
Some 7,000 persons fled their homes and farmlands for fear of being caught in the "final showdown" between government troops and two rebel forces in Sulu even as the Philippine Navy was mobilized yesterday to assist in blocking all the possible exits by the rebels.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Nur's fighters on the run.
Government forces yesterday pounded the escape routes of Moro insurgents on Jolo with rockets and cannon fire but the fleeing guerrillas vowed to "fight to the death."
The Philippine Star: Misuari held incommunicado.
Malacanang has ordered tighter security on detained rebel leader Nur Misuari following reports that the erstwhile chairman of the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) is in close contact with his supporters involved in clashes with government forces in Jolo, Sulu.
The Manila Times: Troops surround Jolo rebels'lair.
The military is preparing to storm a mountain hideout in Jolo where hundreds of Muslim rebels were holed up after five days of clashes that have left more than 60 dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Man kidnapped from hospital and badly beaten due to involving in a fatal traffic accident.
The United Daily News:
Gravel ship missing with 18 crew members on board.
The Liberty Times:
Government mulls expansion of police force for better maintaining social order.
The Taipei Times:
U.S. rejects direct talks with Seoul.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Eyes Iran Via Drones Launched From Iraq.
Bush administration has been secretly monitoring Iranian airspace for nearly a year for signs of nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER STARTS PETITION FOR WANG JIN-PYNG TO RUN FOR KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker announced Sunday that he has begun a signature drive in support of Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to run for the KMT chairmanship.
Lee Chuan-chiao said that the signature drive will continue in spite of a request from Wang to temporarily suspend the campaign.
Lee said his target is to gather signatures from at least two-thirds of KMT lawmakers.

The KMT is scheduled to hold its election for party chairman in May. Both Wang and popular Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou are considered by political observers to be the two best potential candidates if incumbent Chairman Lien Chan does not seek re-election.

Neither Wang nor Ma have publicly thrown their hat into the ring to head Taiwan's largest opposition party, which controls 79 seats in the 225-member legislature, although political observers say that the two have already been sounding out the possibility privately.
Lee said that he will present the signatures if Lien decides not to seek re-election or if Wang gives the go-ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG GRAVEL SHIP MISSING EN ROUTE TO JAPANESE ISLAND

TEXT.P: A ship carrying some 4,500 tons of gravel with 18 crewmen aboard has reportedly gone missing in open seas after it departed Taiwan's eastern harbor of Hualien the night of Feb. 10, shipping industry sources said Sunday.

The Kaohsiung-based gravel ship, the "Jui Tai No. 8, " departed from Hualien Harbor en route to Ishigaki Island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture on the evening of Feb. 10. Of the 18 crewmen, 12 were Taiwanese and six Indonesian and Burmese.

The 5,177-ton "Jui Tai No. 8" was last heard from at 7: 58 p.m. on Feb. 10 when it reported its position -- about 17 nautical miles away from Hualien Airport -- to Kaohsiung's Juipang Shipping Co., which owns the vessel.

Despite the fact that the ship was equipped with VHF radio as well as a satellite telephone, Taiwan-based shipping officials have been unable to raise the ship and no signal has been received, nor has there been anything from the vessel's automatic distress beacon.
Officials speculate that the gravel ship may have encountered a large wave that swamped it without warning.

The Jui Pang Shipping Co. asked the National Search and Rescue Center for help on the morning of Feb. 12, about one day after the agent on Ishigaki Island called the company to say that the "Jui Tai No. 8" had not arrived as scheduled and that the agent had not received any communication from the ship since Feb. 10.

One military search and rescue helicopter and six patrol vessels from Taiwan's Coast Guard Administration scoured the gravel ship's route for one day but found no trace of the ship and no evidence of an oil slick that usually marks the spot where a ship has gone down.

A manager from the Jui Pang Shipping Co. said Sunday that the "Jui Tai No. 8" had just undergone regular maintenance and overall inspections in January and that the amount of gravel on board was within safe carriage allowances.

The manager said that his company is still hoping that the "Jui Tai No. 8" is safe and sound and has just suffered from mechanical failure and is drifting in a position that does not allow for communication.
The mysterious disappearance of the "Jui Tai No. 8" reminded many officials of a similar incident involving another gravel ship, the "Hualien No. 1," that vanished five years ago.

The two ships have a number of aspects in common, including that both were transporting gravel, both departed from Hualien Harbor on a dark February night in inclement weather and both vanished without a trace and without any contact.

On Feb. 28, 2000, the "Hualien No. 1, " carrying 5,300 tons of gravel, departed from Hualien Harbor en route to Taipei Harbor at 5:30 p.m. The ship had 21 crewmen aboard, including 14 Taiwanese and seven Burmese.

Traveling at an estimated speed of 10 knots on a course that kept it three to five nautical miles away from the coast, the ship was scheduled to reach its destination at around 6 a.m. the next day, but failed to arrive.

A team of professors from National Taiwan University's (NTU) Institute of Oceanography claimed to have located the wreckage of the "Hualien No. 1" off the coast of northern Taiwan in September 2003, but subsequent investigations by the Coast Guard Administration have been unable to confirm NTU's findings.

Commenting on the "Jui Tai No. 8, " NTU Professor Sung Kuo-shih, who took part in the effort to located the wreckage of the "Hualien No. 1, " said that the "Jui Tai No. 8" probably met with the same fate as that of the "Hualien No. 1"-- both vessels were hit by a massive and unexpected wave that shifted the gravel in the hold, resulting in a dangerous redistribution of weight which contributed to the vessels' sinking.
Sung believes that the NTU team indeed found the "Hualien No. 1." He said that sunken vessels usually can be spotted using sonar unless they are below 3,000 meters.
The sea route that the "Jui Tai No. 8" was traveling, however, has areas that are between 3,000 and 4,000 meters deep, Sung noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqi Insurgents Step Up Attacks After Elections.
A suicide car bomber killed at least 17 Iraqis at the entrance of a hospital south of Baghdad, and a judge who had investigated crimes in Saddam Hussein's government was gunned down outside his home in Basra by masked men riding a motorcycle, as Iraq's insurgency continued to intensify since elections two weeks ago. From Monday to Saturday, bombers and gunmenhave le ft at least 108 people dead. The attacks have been at or near a Shiite mosque, a hospital, police facilities, a bakery in a Shiite neighborhood and in front of Iraqis' houses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES SERIOUSNESS IN PURSUING POLITICAL RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reiterated Sunday that he is serious in wanting to make peace among the various political parties.

In a meeting with Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charitable organization, located in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Hsieh said that political reconciliation will contribute to social stability and domestic tranquility.

It is for this reason that since he was named premier by President Chen Shui-bian last month he has been advocating that the different parties put aside their differences, Hsieh said, adding that he believes that fence-mending should be initiated by the top officials of the government and that he is willing to take the first step.
There will be no war in the Taiwan Strait if Taiwan maintains its own stability and peace, the premier stressed.
During the meeting, Cheng Yen told the premier that a society should be stable and peaceful and that catastrophes caused by people are worse than natural disasters.

Citing what happened in Aceh, Indonesia as an example, Cheng Yen said that the Dec. 26 tsunami destroyed 600 to 700 schools in the Indonesian province, yet the conflict between the government's armed forces and the rebels has so far destroyed more than 1,000 schools.
She praised Hsieh for his ability, wisdom and tenacity in serving the people, saying that Hsieh should have no problems achieving his aims.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL BOOK EXHIBITION TO OPEN FEB. 15

TEXT.P: The 13th Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE), sponsored by the Government Information Office, is slated to open Feb. 15 at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC).

The annual event will feature a series of exhibitions and discussions that reflect reading activities and trends in the Asia-Pacific region, according to the organizer, the private Taipei Book Fair Foundation.
During the book fair, two major reading trends will be highlighted: "book art" and "digital publishing."

The TIBE 2005 will take place at three different TWTC halls, with Hall I divided into five major sections -- international publishers and their publications; general books; books of special interest; and assorted magazines featuring business, finance, digital content, popular culture and lifestyle.

Hall II will be dedicated to comic books to accommodate domestic and foreign publishers, while Hall III will be devoted to children's books and will include 400 booths displaying works from both Taiwan and abroad, according to the organizer.

Halls I and III will be open only to professional visitors Feb. 15-16, but the public can take part in the activities in Hall II throughout the event and in Halls I and III after the 16th. The show will run until Feb. 20.

Meanwhile, to celebrate the book festival, two major chain bookstore operators in Taiwan-- Eslite and Kingstone -- have already launched "fun reading book fairs" at their 20 branches across the island prior to the TIBE 2005 opening.

Taipei Book Fair Foundation Chairman Rex How said Sunday that the bookstore activities, which began Feb. 1 and will run until Feb. 28, are not only warm-ups for the exhibition but an effort to precis the upcoming TIBE at bookstores around the country.

The effort is aimed at boosting a nationwide reading atmosphere, How said, adding that he hopes those who live in townships and villages outside of Taipei City and not able to visit the TIBE 2005 can still feel the book fair atmosphere and buy books with the same discount that book fair visitors will enjoy.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL NURSING CONGRESS TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI IN MAY

TEXT.P: The 23rd quadrennial congress of the International Council of Nurses (ICN) is scheduled to be held in Taipei May 21-27 this year, ICN sources said in Geneva Saturday.

The 2005 Taipei ICN Congress is expected to be the largest NGO activity ever been held in Taiwan. It will also mark a milestone for Taiwan in its efforts to seek membership in the World Health Organization (WHO) and secure recognition by the international community, Swiss political observers said.

According to Linda Carrier-Walker, a spokesperson for the ICN, so far some 3,000 people from 106 countries have registered to take part in the Taipei ICN Congress. Carrier-Walker said she expects that more than 5,000 people from around the world, including world-renowned nursing professionals, authorities and representatives, will ultimately sign up to go to Taipei for the world conference.

In addition to the Taiwan Nurses Association, which is a major co-sponsor of the congress, the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Health will also pitch in as supporting agencies to make the congress as successful as possible.

The Taipei ICN Congress will be divided into three parts: the ICN conference of national representatives, May 21-23; the ICN general assembly, May 23-27 -- both to be held at the Taipei International Convention Center -- and an ICN exhibition to be held at the nearby Taipei World Trade Center, May 21-27, according to Carrier-Walker.

The ICN was established in Geneva, Switzerland in 1899. There are currently 125 member countries. The ICN is one of the three largest medical organizations in the world besides the World Medical Association and the International Pharmaceutical Federation. Among the three, the ICN has the largest number of members.

These three organizations have been supportive of Taiwan's bid to enter the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision-making body of the WHO, as an observer, said Carrier-Walker, adding that pushing for Taiwan's entry into the WHO is a fixed policy of the ICN.

With the theme of "Nursing on the Move: Knowledge, Innovation and Vitality, " the 2005 Taipei ICN Congress will feature 80 symposiums and seminars, as well as more than 400 meetings. A total of 1,400 out of 2,500 papers submitted to the ICN have been approved and recognized. Of the 1,400 papers, 800 will be displayed at the Taipei World Trade Center during the congress, Carrier-Walker said.

Major topics to be mooted during the congress will include issues regarding AIDS, malaria and pneumonia; nursing manpower, treatment, work environments and mutual recognition agreements; and cutting-edge techniques and facilities.

According to Carrier-Walker, there will be a debate between two representatives from Australia and the United States during the ICN general assembly on the issue of whether there should be legislation on the ratio of the number of nurses to patients in a country. Assembly participants will vote on this issue immediately after the debate, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC EXPECTED TO COMPLETE PRIVATIZATION BY END OF 2005

TEXT.P: The state-operated Kaohsiung-based China Shipbuilding Corporation (CSBC) is expected to finish privatization by the end of 2005, according to a CSBC statement.

The statement said that since the company implemented a "rebirth" project to adjust its enterprise structure and management on Dec. 31, 2001, it has seen operational surpluses. The CSBC's 2004 revenue was NT$16.26 billion (US$512.13 million), with an accumulated surplus of about NT$711 million, surpassing its compulsory target of NT$320 million, the statement said.

Last year, the CSBC had 24 orders for new ships, with a total value of the new contracts amounting to NT$30.89 billion, according to company officials. As of Jan. 31, the total number of contracts the state-run shipbuilder holds is 47, of which 41 are orders for new container ships and six are for freighters.

Thanks to these deals, manufacturing at the two CSBC shipyards in Keelung and Kaohsiung will run through 2009, the officials said, noting that the busy schedule, which was partly caused by a recent boost in the marine transportation market, will help with privatization.

The CSBC has been working on a privatization plan and necessary preparations. As soon as the plan is approved by the Executive Yuan, the government-owned manufacturer will accept tenders, according to CSBC officials.
The CSBC was established in July, 1973 as one of the 10 Major Economic Construction Projects in Taiwan in a governmental effort to promote economic development.
In 1978, the company acquired the Taiwan Shipbuilding Company, becoming the leading shipbuilder on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL CYCLE SHOW TO OPEN MARCH 4

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taipei International Cycle Show, regarded as Asia's largest and the world's third-largest bicycle trade fair, will be held March 4-7 in Taipei.

The event will include exhibitions, seminars and panel discussions at the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) , as well as a high-profile cycling competition -- the Taipei International Elimination Road Race, which is slated to kick off March 6, according to the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) that is organizing Taipei Cycle 2005.

Seventeen cyclists from 16 countries have been invited to take part in the Taipei speed race to compete with 20 cyclists from the Taiwanese national team on the ring road around the TWTC, TAITRA officials said.

According to TAITRA, some 620 manufacturers and traders have been registered to set up 2,027 booths across two exhibition halls of the TWTC. The figures represent growth over last year of 7 percent and 11 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS TO BE CENTERPIECE OF CHEN-SOONG TALKS: PFP

TEXT.P: Talks on cross-Taiwan Strait relations are expected to be the centerpiece of a forthcoming meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, a PFP spokesman said Sunday.

It is hoped that by talking about cross-strait affairs, the government and the opposition PFP will deepen understanding of each other and consequently reach the greatest possible consensus how to resolve their differences, said PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping.

The PFP hopes that Chen and Soong will also exchange views on a cross-strait peace promotion draft law unveiled by the PFP last October, Hsieh said, adding that the PFP remains open to all opinions and arguments about the contents of the draft law, particularly the part regarding the "1992 consensus" and a part that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has criticized as "a move that may result in legislative intervention in administrative operations."

As to the date and venue of the Chen-Soong meeting, Hsieh said, it is expected to be decided after Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun meets with PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng on Monday.
"Anything can be discussed and the PFP has no preconditions to the Chen-Soong meeting," Hsieh added.

Taipei media has reported that Chen will meet with Soong in an attempt to effect a reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties. However, the date, venue and even the issues to be discussed have not been decided upon.

President Chen will also meet with all opposition leaders, according to an earlier statement by Yu, who said that apart from Soong, Chen also hopes to meet with Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to discuss national affairs.

Reports have said that President Chen was irritated about the proposed cross-strait peace promotion draft law, believing that it would seriously infringe upon the rights of the president regarding decision-making on cross-strait issues.

According to the draft law, a cross-strait peace consultation special committee would be established that would have the right to negotiate and consult with mainland authorities without the authorization of the president.

Any cross-strait peace agreement signed by the committee and approved by the Legislative Yuan would become effective if it were approved by the public in a nationwide referendum. The resolutions and suggested laws passed by the committee and approved by the legislature would be binding for government agencies, according to the draft law.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 2,000 PEOPLE TRAVEL KINMEN-XIAMEN ROUTE SUNDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A total of 2,131 people traveled between the Republic of China-held outlying island of Kinmen and the mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen Sunday as the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday draws to an end.
Of the total, 1,191 were Taiwanese business people and their dependents who traveled from Taiwan via Kinmen to Xiamen from where they will return to their jobs or their mainland residences.
Most of the other 940 were Kinmen residents returning from the mainland after sightseeing on the mainland during the holiday.

Since the Kinmen-Xiamen new year holiday exchanges began on Jan. 29, 23,838 people have traveled across the Strait, despite the opening of direct charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China this year.
Most of the Taiwanese business people taking the Kinmen-Xiamen ferries across the Strait said that the Kinmen-Xiamen link is more convenient for them than charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON FLEXIBLE ELECTRONICS TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI FEB. 17

TEXT.P: A seminar on flexible electronics and display technologies will be held in Taipei Feb. 17, an official of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said Sunday.

Chen Liang-gee, director of the ITRI Electronics Research and Service Organization (ERSO), said that government officials, domestic and foreign scholars and experts will deliver keynote speeches and read their papers during the one-day meeting.

Flexible electronics has a great deal of potential to become a mainstream industry, Chen said, adding that the seminar is aimed at helping domestic manufacturers explore business opportunities as early as possible.

The ERSO, the organizer of the event, has been actively conducting research and development of flexible electronic systems by integrating technologies in flat-panel display, nano-electronics, micro-electrical engineering and advanced structural assembly, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIFE BOAT AND BOTTLE RECOVERED AT SEA CAME FROM MISSING SHIP

TEXT.P: Search and rescue operations have discovered artifacts from a missing gravel ship 32 nautical miles east southeast of the port of Suao, northeastern Taiwan, officials of the Coast Guard Administration said Sunday.

The officials said that a CGA ship retrieved a life boat and a steel bottle from the sea after Japanese authorities gave them information on the possible location of the ship. The CGA said the owner of the ship confirmed that the articles retrieved belong to the missing ship, the "Jui Tai No. 8, " which went missing in open seas after it departed Taiwan's eastern harbor of Hualien the night of Feb. 10 with some 4,500 tons of gravel and 18 crewmen aboard.

The Kaohsiung-based gravel ship departed from Hualien Harbor en route to Ishigaki Island in Japan's Okinawa Prefecture on the evening of Feb. 10. Of the 18 crewmen, 12 were Taiwanese and six Indonesian and Burmese.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 14, or the sixth day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Essay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of "discovery," charting and "naming" many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1797: British naval forces under Admiral John Jervis and Captain Horatio Nelson defeat the Spanish fleet off Portugal's Cape St. Vincent.
1859: Oregon becomes the 33rd state of the United States.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by a treaty.
1912: Arizona becomes the 48th state of the United States.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the U.S. industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that later becomes International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1939: The German battleship Bismarck is launched.
1950: The Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1956: Soviet President Nikita Khrushchev denounces the policies of Joseph Stalin at the 20th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
1962: General Hu Chung-nan, strategic adviser to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: The Soviet Union launches its Luna 20 spacecraft to the moon.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on the same basis as Moscow.
1973: Walter Benche Medina, newly-appointed ambassador of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1974: A six-member Jordanian trade mission led by S.A. Matouk, president of the Amman Chamber of Commerce, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1974: Commissioner W. Stanley Cottrill, international secretary of the Salvation Army International Headquarters, leaves Taipei after a three-day visit.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific becomes a territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted Republic of China musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa," or death sentence, against British writer Salman Rushdie for what he deemed to be blasphemy in the author's book "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
1999: Former Nixon White House aide John Ehrlichman dies at the age of 73. He served 18 months in prison for his role in the Watergate cover-up.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of the Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Cor Boonstra, president of Royal Philips Electronics, in recognition of his company's contribution to Taiwan's economic development.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says that he will visit Beijing and invite mainland Chinese leaders to visit Taipei if he wins the March 18 election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR LESS TIGHT-LIPPED ON RUNNING FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said Monday that he would like to "give it a try" when he was asked by reporters whether he intends to run for the KMT chairmanship in May.
Ma was less tight-lipped on the issue following current KMT Chairman Lien Chan's call Monday for party members considering vying for the post to begin their preparations for the May election.

Lien's call indicated that he might not run for re-election, despite the fact that a number of KMT heavyweights, including Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, have urged him to continue leading the main opposition party which controls 79 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.
Ma said that he would like to "give it a try" as part of his commitment to working for reform and unity of the KMT.
Meanwhile, other senior KMT members have begun a signature drive in support of Wang to run for the KMT chairmanship.
Wang and Ma are considered by political observers as the two top candidates to replace Lien Chan as chairman if he decides not to run for re-election.
Neither Wang nor Ma has explicitly stated in public that they want to run for the post, but political observers say that the two have been sounding out the possibility in private.
