Christian and Muslim leaders said yesterday that today's Valentine Day celebration should be utilized to further strengthen unity and cooperation among all sectors of society and spread the gospel of understanding and harmony among the nations.

ZAMBOANGA CITY -- Fighting within screaming distance of each other, Moro guerrillas killed three more soldiers and wounded 13 others in a bid to repel advancing government forces on Jolo Island, officials said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN MINISTER'S CANCELLATION OF SCHEDULED TAIWAN VISIT CRITICIZED
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, feb. 13 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: An influential German newspaper published a commentary Sunday criticizing the German economics minister's cancellation of a planned visit to Taiwan due to mainland China's fierce opposition.

German Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Clement has decided not to visit Taiwan this year after the Chinese ambassador to Germany told German Vice Minister for Economic Affairs Bernd Pfaffenbach last week that Beijing will never tolerate any visit to Taiwan by a German minister.

The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung criticized Clement in the commentary for apparently taking the Beijing envoy's words as an order. The German daily argued that politicians cannot persuade others if they follow orders from totalitarian regimes.
Regardless of the minister's diplomatic reasons for cancelling the scheduled visit to Taiwan, his succumbing to pressure from Beijing is a scandal, the newspaper claimed.
"Since when does Germany need envoys from other countries to meddle in its economic policies?" it added.

While welcoming the benefits to the Chinese people of the country's quick economic development, the newspaper argued that market economies are based on the rule of law and can only really become vigorous after democracy is established. It urged politicians to look for opportunities to promote freedom and democracy.
During ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-Yueh's visit to Germany last December, she extended an invitation to Clement to visit Taiwan this year.
Although Taiwan and Germany have exchanged visits of high-ranking economic officials over the years, the latest visit to Taiwan by a German economics minister was in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO ACTIVELY TAKE PART IN CLEAN DEVELOPMENT MECHANISM

TEXT.P: Taiwan was urged Monday to actively take part in the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) under the Kyoto Protocol on reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the U.N.-initiated Kyoto Protocol, the island will have to face the realities and global demands for greenhouse gas emission reduction, according to professor Lee Ho-ching of Chung Yuan Christian University in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

The CDM is one of the protocol's two project-based flexible mechanisms designed to make it easier and cheaper for industrialized nations to meet greenhouse gas emission reduction targets agreed to under the protocol, and to assist developing countries in achieving sustainable development.

Lee, one of the founders of the Taiwan Climate Protection Coalition, called for the Taiwan government to aggressively seek participation in the less political CDM engagements, which she said will not only help Taiwan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and secure sustainable development, but also help the island to take part in bankable projects in developing countries and gain great earnings expected to be generated from greenhouse gas reduction options.

With the Kyoto Protocol set to enter into force Feb. 16, governments and companies that will have to curb their emissions in compliance with their countries' caps are scrambling to figure out how to do so without killing their bottom lines.

One of the best policies to deal with the issue is to cooperate with developing countries, either by helping them reduce greenhouse gas emissions or by buying their greenhouse gas emission "quotas, " according to National Taiwan University professor Liu Chung-ming.
Liu noted the World Bank has estimated that under the CDM operations, some US$10 billion in funds will flow into developing countries a year.

Of that total, about 70 percent will be directed into mainland China. This will provide Taiwan with a golden opportunity to cash in on the huge market by investing or partaking in bankable CDM projects in China, given Taiwan's cultural, language and geographic advantages, Liu added.

Meanwhile, Tunghai University professor Yenwen Peng, who is also a spokeswoman for the Green Party Taiwan, said that Taiwan may end up facing trade sanctions if it doesn't step up its greenhouse gas reduction efforts.
Peng said that Taiwan releases some 2.39 million tons of carbon dioxide into the air each year, or about 1 percent of the global total, ranking the island 22nd in the world.
If stronger measures are not taken, Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions will rise to some 4.61 million tons a year by 2020, Peng warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND GROUP OF EDUCATION MINISTRY-HIRED ENGLISH TEACHERS TO ARRIVE

TEXT.P: The second group of foreigners that the Ministry of Education invited to come and teach English in Taiwan are expected to arrive today to begin their one-year teaching contracts.

The 14 foreigners, 12 Canadians and two British, will begin a 10-day training course immediately. Foreigners who have been recruited by the ministry will be part of a program to teach English in 14 public-run elementary and junior high schools in 13 cities and counties around Taiwan.
Five Canadians arrived in Taiwan last October, marking the first group of foreigners officially hired by the Ministry of Education to teach in Taiwan.

Ministry of Education officials said that they are also in contact with people in Australia, New Zealand and the United States, hoping that potential English teachers will take advantage of similar opportunities to come to Taiwan to teach for at least one year and at the same time experience the different culture and lifestyle in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraqi Shiites Win, but Margin Is Less Than Projection
A broad Shiite alliance led by two Iran-backed religious parties won a slim majority of seats in the national assembly, final election results showed Sunday. The alliance's victory - in the first fully elected parliament in Iraq's 85-year history as a separate state - was narrower than the alliance had projected and set the stage for protracted maneuvering.
Wall Street Journal: Global Warming; In Climate Debate, The 'Hockey Stick' Leads to a Face-Off
One of the pillars of the case for man-made global warming is a graph nicknamed the hockey stick. It's a reconstruction of temperatures over the past 1,000 years based on records captured in tree rings, corals and other markers. The stick's shaft shows temperatures oscillating slightly over the ages. Then comes the blade: The mercury swings sharply upward in the 20th century. Since it was published four years ago in a United Nations report, hundreds of environmentalists, scientists and policy makers have used the hockey stick in presentations and brochures to make the case that human activity in the industrial era is causing dangerous global warming. But according to a semiretired Toronto minerals consultant Stephen McIntyre, who has spent two years and about US$5,000 of his own money trying to double-check the influential graphic, he says he has found significant oversights and errors. He claims its lead author, climatologist Michael Mann of the University of Virginia, and colleagues used flawed methods that yield meaningless results.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE OFFICIAL TO VISIT GENEVA FOR WTO BILATERAL TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of foreign trade will travel to Geneva, Switzerland soon to attend the World Trade Organization (WTO) Services and Trade Week meeting and engage in bilateral consultations with his counterparts from 14 countries.
Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said that the WTO has begun a series of multilateral meetings on issues promulgated by the WTO Doha Round negotiations.

Huang said that he will take part in activities related to countries that have been targets of dumping accusations, in addition to meeting top trade officials from 14 countries for bilateral consultations on services and trade issues.

According to BOFT officials, Taiwan has been charged by foreign countries of 138 cases of dumping over the past 10 years, ranking the island the fourth in the world. Of the 138 cases, 27 were filed by India, the major accuser. Currently, India is still charging Taiwan in 16 dumping cases, including 11 whose investigations have been completed and five that are still under investigation.
Huang departs for India Monday for talks on seven dumping charges regarding Taiwan's alleged sales at below-normal prices of sodium nitrite, caustic soda, tapes and other products.
From India, Huang will then proceed to Geneva for the WTO Services and Trade Week meeting and other bilateral activities.

Huang said that Taiwan is engaging in bilateral consultations with 14 countries mainly to try to help people from Taiwan enter their job markets in work such as teaching or as principals at Chinese schools in the Chinese communities in those countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened up and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 77.8 points to close at 6,112.4.
The bourse opened at 6,130.32 and fluctuated between 6,148.95 and 6,089.44 during trading. A total of 3.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$92.7 billion (US$2.93 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.9 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, foodstuff issues and paper and pulp issues both at 0.3 percent, textile stocks at 0.2 percent and construction issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 542 to 272, with 170 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained 84 points to close at 6,129, with 22,508 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for March gained 96 points to finish at 6,140, with 12,199 contracts traded, while June futures gained 92 points to close at 6,135, with 20 contracts traded. September futures gained 97 points to close at 6,047, with 37 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,045 for February, 6,044 for March, 6,043 for June, 5,950 for September and 5,974 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
February TE futures moved up 4.3 points to close at 234.25, with 3,454 contracts traded, while March TE futures gained 5.3 points to finish at 234.3, with 2,587 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
February TF futures gained 8.2 points to finish at 1,028, with 4,168 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 7.8 points to finish at 1,028, with 3,443 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' COULD EQUAL 'RED TERROR' FOR TAIWANESE: MAC

TEXT.P: If mainland China enacts its proposed "anti-secession law, " it could signal the beginning of "red terror" for Taiwan citizens working or traveling in mainland China, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said recently.
The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress adopted a draft of the proposed law last December. The draft will be reviewed at the congress' plenary meeting next month.

Facing this situation, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that the government must voice its opposition to the proposed law and this is the reason why the government gave a clear explanation about the matter to the public before the beginning of the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

The MAC said that the proposed law is a mainland Chinese domestic one and that should it pass, it would be a "red terror" for mainland China-based Taiwanese business people, Taiwanese tourists and students, and even multi-national enterprises. Moreover, it would be harmful to normal cross-strait exchanges and activities, the council claimed, adding that peace and stability could be compromised.

It is mainland China's intention, the MAC said, to use "anti-secession" to mean that the current cross-strait status quo should be "unified" rather than "individual, " which is contradictory to the fact that neither side of the Taiwan Strait is subordinate to the other.

It said that Beijing's intention of becoming the dominate force in the Taiwan Strait by enacting the "anti-secession law" totally neglects the international community's understanding of the cross-strait situation.

Noting that under the proposed law, the only option for future cross-strait relations is "unification, " the council said it can also be regarded as a "law for war" and could be interpreted as a justification for military action to solve the "Taiwan issue."

Reiterating that an MAC survey released last December showed that 83 percent of Taiwan people who responded were opposed to mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law, " the council said that peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait are not only the wish of those on Taiwan, but also the wish of the international community.

The council also said that the government will continue to push for the establishment of a "cross-strait peace and stability interaction framework, " as well as further explaining Taiwan's position to the international community to enlist their support so that Beijing stops its attempt to destroy regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: After Bush Leaves Office, His Budget's Costs Balloon.
For President Bush, the budget sent to Congress last week outlines a painful path to meeting his promise to bring down the federal budget deficit by the time he leaves office in 2009. But for the senators and governors already jockeying to succeed him, the numbers released in recent days add up to a budgetary landmine that could blow up just as the next president moves into the Oval Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA THROWS HIS HAT INTO THE RING FOR KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who had been reticent about announcing whether he would run for the chairmanship of the Kuomingtang (KMT), said Monday that he would "give it a try" in the May election.
Asked if he was willing to compete against another possible strong contender, Legislative Yuan Speaker and KMT Vice Chairman, Wang Jin-pyng, for the party's top post, Ma said, "Certainly."

Faced with some within the party who want Lien to stay on for another term and those who support Wang, Ma, who is also a KMT vice chairman, said the election will be held in an open and direct way, and anyone who qualifies will be able to compete.
For Wang's part, he said that he "wished Ma the best" in the election, but stopped short of saying whether he would support Ma's bid.
Wang reaffirmed that "his own intention is clear, " which is to support Lien for another term, if that is his desire.
However, KMT Chairman Lien Chan reiterated Monday in a statement that the party continues to advocate gradually turning over the KMT to the next generation of politicians.
Lien, who is currently traveling overseas, made the remarks in his message to a gathering of KMT members at the end of the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday. Vice KMT Chairman Vincent Siew presided.

Lien urged all aspirants within the party to come forward to solicit nominations, adding that the KMT can use its high-profile members to help bring about progress within the party as well as to aid the development of the nation.
Lien did not say, however, whether he would follow through with his earlier remarks that he would really not seek re-election to the post of chairman.
Wang was asked by reporters if he will run for KMT chairman if Lien has no wish to stay on, to which he replied: "It is better not to talk about the 'if' question."
Regarding Ma's bid, two popular KMT politicians said that they wish the best to come forward through the party's open and democratic election mechanism.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said that aspirants for the party chairman must follow the democratic mechanism within the party, and that the more important thing is the person must be able to bring solidarity and lead the KMT to once again become the ruling party.
"Anyone who can meet these conditions will get my support, " Hu said.
He also expressed the hope that the party chairman election will be a gentlemen's battle, and there will be no pre-designated person for the party's top post.
Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun lauded Ma for being an elite within the party, and dubbed him "the best choice."
Chu also said that he hoped that KMT party members can come in droves to elect their leader in a "just, fair, and open" way.
On bids by other aspirants for the post, Chu said that it will be a good thing if many take part in the election, but he hoped that the election can be conducted in a harmonious atmosphere.
An official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the party will give "best wishes and respect" to any aspirants for KMT chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HAS HIGH EXPECTATIONS OF MEETING WITH PFP CHIEF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he is confident that his upcoming meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will be able to lay a good foundation for inter-party reconciliation and cooperation.
Addressing a Presidential Office lunar new year gathering, Chen said his chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, has contacted PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng to arrange the meeting.

"We all have high expectations for the upcoming meeting, " Chen said, adding that he believes the meeting will be able to help put an end to hostile relations between the ruling and opposition camps and usher in a new era of inter-party reconciliation and cooperation.
Chen further said he hopes the spirit of reconciliation and cooperation can be extended from the domestic arena to relations across the Taiwan Strait.
"Inter-party reconciliation, national unity, cross-strait peace, economic prosperity and social stability are my first wishes for the new year of the rooster," Chen said.
Over the past year, Chen said, hostile political wrangling between the ruling and opposition camps has taken toll on national development.
"Now is the time for us to end all internal rifts and stand united to promote peaceful cross-strait development and domestic economic growth," Chen said.
If political parties cannot reconcile and cooperate, Chen said Taiwan would be unable to engage mainland China and push for a thaw in cross-strait ties.

"I attach great importance to the upcoming meeting with Soong. I hope all people and parties can pool their wisdom and resources to help turn a new page in our nation's political development, " Chen urged.

In the year of the rooster, Chen said he also hopes that Taiwan's democratic reforms can be further deepened and consolidated, particularly in crime-fighting, national health insurance renovation, tax system reform, government restructuring and constitutional re-engineering.

Moreover, Chen said he looks forward to seeing the "Taiwan first" and "Taiwan identity" policy line continue moving forward smoothly and even more swiftly. "This is a common dream of most local people. Let's all weave the dream together, pursue the dream and realize the dream," he added.
Touching on cross-strait affairs, Chen said he doesn't rule out any possibility for inter-party cooperation.

"The most important thing at the moment is that ruling and opposition parties sit down to talk and forge a consensus on measures to resume cross-strait dialogue and boost cross-strait rapprochement. "If necessary, I don't reject the proposal to legislate a law on how to promote cross-strait peace," Chen said.
He was referring to the PFP-proposed cross-strait peace promotion bill that is pending legislative approval.

In his view, Chen said, a cross-party commission should be formed first to work out a package of guidelines for promoting peaceful cross-strait development. "I keenly hope that opposition party leaders can play an active role in the formulation of new cross-strait working guidelines," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER HOPES TO UPGRADE MINISTRY'S IMAGE

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Monday he hopes that the image of the affiliated agencies of the ministry will be upgraded.
Shih made the remarks while attending a gathering of ministry employees after the weeklong Chinese New Year holiday.

He said that all prosecutorial, investigative, correctional and watchdog agencies within the ministry should take on a new mindset and approach to build up the core values of professionalism, enthusiasm and responsibility to give the ministry a fresh look for the public.
Shih also said that he is still pondering possible candidates for the position of vice minister of justice, and solicitations should be completed within one week.
He said that the person who serves as vice minister of justice should be versed in the operations of the ministry, and that several candidates are now under consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: SU CHIN-CHIANG LEADS TSU TO START WORK IN NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: The new chairman of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) expressed his wish Monday for the party to boost its care for the underprivileged and minority groups in Taiwan this year.

Su Chin-chiang reiterated the pro-Taiwan independence party's core values during a party Chinese Lunar New Year gathering Monday: campaigning for a new constitution and rectifying the official designation of the country to " Taiwan" from the Republic of China. He also said that the TSU will definitely not be absent from the elections to be held this year -- those for mayors and magistrates in cities and counties around the island, as well as township representative elections.

Speaking of the recent inter-party activities regarding political reconciliation, the TSU leader said his party is looking forward to forming party-to-party cooperation so long as it is promoted to do the country good, not just political horse-trading.

All executive TSU members and those serving the central and local governments gathered at the party headquarters on the first working day after the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday to greet the year of the rooster. During the festive activity, Su also made a wish that the party will expand.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Charities struggle to spend cash for tsunami.
British charities admitted last night that they would struggle to spend the vast sums of money donated by the public to victims of the Asian tsunami. More than £365 million has been raised in individual donations to tsunami relief in the six weeks since the Boxing Day disaster. More than 85 per cent of British adults have given something. But the British Red Cross has told The Times that it may have difficulty responsibly spending the £60 million raised so far and is considering whether it can divert some money to other causes. At least two other large British charities have privately admitted that they will have difficulty in allocating all the money received. However the charities fear that saying so publicly would result in a belief that they did not need donations in the future.
Financial Times: Blair tries to rebuild relations with public.
Tony Blair confessed on Sunday that he had often appeared arrogant in a candid mea culpa which marked his most concerted attempt to reconnect with the British public after the Iraq war. The prime minister used his keynote speech at Labour's spring conference in Gateshead to acknowledge it was largely his fault that his bond with the public had frayed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST OF TAIWAN'S YOUNG OFFICE WORKERS UNWILLING TO GET MARRIED: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Taiwan's young office workers are unwilling to get married or have babies, according to the results of a poll released Monday.

The poll, conducted by the online human resources service company www.9999.com.tw from Jan. 15 to Feb. 6, shows that 62.27 percent of the respondents aged between 18 and 30 said they are unwilling to get married, against 37.73 percent who said they would like to get married.

The reason most cited by those who do not want to get married is the limitations imposed by marriage on their lives, at 68.86 percent of the respondents, followed by lack of money, unwillingness to have complicated family relations and to "permanently enjoy the feeling of falling in love."
Meanwhile, 74.51 percent of the respondents said they do not want to have children, against 25.49 percent who said they would like to.

Not having sufficient money to raise a child was the reason most cited by those who do not want to have babies, at 61.33 percent of the total, followed by maintaining the quality of life and the idea that "children are no fun."

Yang Ken-cheng, chief operations officer of the online company, ascribed the mentality demonstrated by the so-called F generation toward marriage to the lack of upward adjustment of salaries for young office workers over the past several years.
Also, he added, the F generation office workers pay relatively more attention to the quality of their personal lives, while giving less importance to the continuance of their family lines.
The survey collected a total of 13,707 samples with an error margin of 0.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD FAVORS SETTING UP NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung said Monday that he favors setting up a national communications commission (NCC) in line with the Constitution, with its members appointed by the premier and approved by the legislature.
Lin made the remarks to reporters in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

Lin said he is opposed to a draft bill forwarded by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) in January and called their version unconstitutional in that NCC members would be named by party representatives based on a proportional representation system.

Lin made it clear that he is in favor of establishing an NCC as soon as possible, but pointed out that the KMT-PFP bill is not congruent with the public mandate that political parties and the military should quit the media.

According to the GIO chief, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should do its best to conduct inter-party negotiations and push for the early passage of a bill that is in line with constitutional requirements.
If the two opposition parties try to press for the passage of their unconstitutional bill in the Legislative Yuan, it would bring a follow-on effect in the form of "numerous boycotts," he warned.
The governing DPP controls the largest number of 89 seats in the 225-member legislature, followed by the KMT with 79 and the PFP with 34 seats.

However, as the "pan-green alliance" of the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, failed to secure an overall majority in last year's Dec. 11 legislative elections, it is still finding it difficult to push its bills through the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS TO MEET TO ARRANGE MEETING BETWEEN PRESIDENT, PFP HEAD

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff will meet with opposition People First Party (PFP) Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng Friday to set the stage for a meeting between Chen and PFP Chairman James Soong, party sources said Monday.
PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, telephoned Chin earlier in the day to discuss preparatory work for the much-anticipated Chen-Soong meeting.

Yu and Chin agreed to meet Friday at the Taipei Guest House, a government-owned estate near the Presidential Office, to work out technical details for the meeting, including the date, venue, format and agenda, Hsieh said.
According to Hsieh, neither side has any prerequisites or preset stances on the Chen-Soong meeting.

"Our party hopes the upcoming high-level inter-party rendezvous will address a PFP-proposed bill on promotion of peaceful development across the Taiwan Strait. The bill is pending legislative approval. Our primary goal is to create a mechanism for peaceful cross-strait interaction based on the core values agreed by both the ruling and opposition parties, " Hsieh explained, adding that the PFP has no intention of usurping the president's power in dealing with cross-strait engagements.

Meanwhile, Soong said at a PFP Lunar New Year party that he is willing to meet with Chen mainly because the PFP wants to assist the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration in seeking a breakthrough to the deadlocked cross-strait relations.

"Cross-strait issues are closely related to domestic political, economic and social developments. We cannot afford to ignore them. As an opposition party, the PFP can do little in pushing for cross-strait peaceful development. Therefore, we hope to cooperate with the DPP administration to realize our ambitious goal of ensuring permanent cross-strait peace," Soong said.
Nevertheless, Soong went on, the PFP will never compromise on its stance against Taiwan independence simply in order to cooperate with the pro-independence DPP.

"Taiwan independence is never a PFP option. We believe that pursuing independence will bring infinite disaster to Taiwan. Independence is no solution to the cross-strait issue. The PFP insists that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must use peaceful, non-violent, non-military means to resolve their disputes. Pro-independence rhetoric and action are counterproductive to cross-strait ties," Soong said.

Noting that rancorous political wrangling between the ruling and opposition camps over the past few years has undermined Taiwan's development, Soong said the PFP is willing to work for inter-party reconciliation and cooperation for the sake of national interests and the people's well-being.
He further stressed that the PFP will not seek horse-trading with the DPP.
"We will not seek any posts. What we really care about is assisting the DPP in promoting ethnic harmony, political transparency, inter-party cooperation and cross-strait peace," Soong said.

Previous media reports said Chen might name Soong to serve as chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which is authorized to handle cross-strait engagements in the absence of official ties. However, PFP sources said Soong is not interested in taking over the post that has been left vacant since the death of former SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu early this year.

Unless the DPP drops its pro-independence party platform, the sources said, Beijing is unlikely to engage the DPP administration. Under such circumstances, the sources said, accepting Chen's offer to be SEF chairman would only hinder Soong from playing a more active and constructive role in promoting cross-strait rapprochement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO UPGRADE ENERGY EFFICIENCY IN VIEW OF KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will help domestic industries upgrade their energy efficiency while also studying the feasibility of international cooperation to cut greenhouse gas emissions, IDB officials said Monday.
The officials made the remarks in view of the Kyoto Protocol, which will come into force Wednesday, putting limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

The officials said that Taiwan will work in line with the international trend of environmental protection as a citizen of the global community, but will also take into consideration the needs of its industrial development with the official start of the Kyoto Protocol.

The officials said they will work on a multi-prong approach to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The government will lead industry in structural adjustments and step up the promotion of new sectors that rely less on energy consumption, such as the information service and cultural and creativity industries, by providing them with tax and financial incentives.

The bureau will also help manufacturers cut their greenhouse gas emissions in an economically viable way. Major investment projects in volving large amounts of greenhouse gas emissions will undergo streng thened energy efficiency screening, they said.

The IDB also will help manufacturers examine greenhouse gas emissions and will establish an emission databank. On the other hand, the bureau will also help high energy-consuming industries to implement "clean production," they added.

The IDB will also provide economic incentives to encourage industries to introduce or develop technology or equipment that can cut greenhouse gas emissions, and adopt production procedures that will cut energy use and greenhouse gas emissions.
The bureau will also study ways to introduce recycling of carbon dioxide and will explore the possibility of international cooperation to cut the emissions of carbon dioxide.

In addition, the bureau will launch a campaign to promote the importance of the Kyoto Protocol among domestic manufacturers, and to let the international community understand Taiwan's efforts in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: STSPAB SETS ITS TARGET REVENUE FOR THE YEAR AT NT$300 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration Bureau (STSPAB) has set its target revenue for the year at NT$300 billion (US$9.47 billion) , STSPAB Director Tai Chein said Monday.
Tai made the remark at a news conference to announce the Southern Taiwan Science Park's (STSP's) operational achievements for last year and its operational targets for the coming year.
A total of 20 new manufacturers will begin operations in the science park this year, two of which are world famous companies. They are expected to create 45,000 jobs, Tai said.
The STSP consists of two parks -- the Tainan Science Park (TSP) and the Kaohsiung Science Park (KSP), Tai said.
Currently, there are a total of 127 and 30 manufacturers, respectively, in the TSP and the KSP, with 69 manufacturers in operation. Only one manufacturer is actually operating in the KSP, he said.

Of the six major industries, the optoelectronics industry and the semiconductor sector play the leading roles, accounting for 97 percent of the total production value of the STSP, with the optoelectronics industry representing 65 percent and the semiconductor sector accounting for 32 percent, Tai said.

The STSPAB will do its utmost to promote the TSP's biotechnology development and will set up a special 14-hectare area for manufacturing biotechnological equipment for medical purposes. As for the short-term goals, The STSPAB intends to persuade at least five manufacturers to operate in the special area and hopes to make the area the world's largest research, development and manufacturing center.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN-ELECT TO BE SWORN IN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman-elect Su Tseng-chang will be sworn in Tuesday at a ceremony at the party's headquarters, a DPP official said Monday.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said that President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, former President Lee Teng-hui, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang and representatives of other opposition parties and lawmakers will witness the oath-taking ceremony.
Chen, Lu, Hsieh, Wang and acting DPP Chairman Ker Chien-ming will be invited to give speeches, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY DISCUSSION SHOULD COME BEFORE NAMING KMT VICE PREMIER: KMT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should discuss key policies with the party before talking about inviting a KMT vice chairman to serve as vice premier.

Chang Jung-kung, a KMT spokesman, made the remarks in response to an invitation from Premier Frank Hsieh to P.K. Chiang to serve his deputy. Hsieh has expressed the hope that the KMT will give a goodwill response on the matter by Thursday.
Chang noted that before Hsieh assumed office Feb. 1, he said he would talk about policy first before filling his Cabinet posts.
If Hsieh wants to invite Chiang and make good use of his rich experience, especially in the economic field, then both sides should talk about policy first, said Chang.

The KMT is willing to talk with the DPP about major issues, such as the orientation of the nation, cross-Taiwan Strait direct trade, postal and transportation links, and the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, he said.

Chang said that all major issues should be sorted out so that they will not be manipulated later to undermine the trust between the ruling and the opposition parties, further affecting national stability.

Chiang earlier this month turned down Hsieh's offer, saying that any such appointment should have been arranged through party-to-party negotiations before the new Cabinet was formed and that it would be meaningless for him to enter the Cabinet as an individual who enjoys no support or endorsement from his party.

Chiang stressed that if the DPP intends to recruit any opposition members to join the Cabinet, it must negotiate with the concerned party for a party-to-party agreement, which he said would be a symbol of ruling and opposition cooperation.

Otherwise, Chiang said, the same old story will be repeated. Former Premier Tang Fei, who accepted President Chen Shui-bian's appointment in 2000 without the KMT's blessing, was forced to step down just a few months later over a disagreement with the DPP about the fourth nuclear power plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SETS `4-NO-INCREASES PRINCIPLE' FOR HEALTH INSURANCE REFORM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has set a "four-no-increases principle" for a transitional reformation of the national health insurance program aimed at preventing the debt-ridden system from bankruptcy, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Monday.
According to Cho, Hsieh issued the directive during a meeting with Department of Health (DOH) Minister Wang Hsiu-hung, DOH Vice Minister Hou Sheng-mao and Minister-without-Portfolio Fu Li-yeh.
It was decided during the meeting that future health insurance reforms will be carried out in the form of "dynamic adjustments," Cho said.

With a view to winning more public support for a proposed transitional reformation of the cash-strapped national health insurance program, Cho said, the premier outlined his principle, which means no increase in the basic insurance premiums; no increase in the self-payment rate for patients whose monthly salary falls below NT$87,600; no increase in the self-payment rate for patients with serious diseases; and no increase in the self-payment rate for chronic disease patients.

In a bid to plug the health insurance program's gaping deficits, the DOH has floated plans to add a new bracket to the current system that determines an individual's contribution to the program in terms of his or her monthly salary. At present, the top bracket is capped at NT$87,600 per month. Under the DOH-proposed plan, the new top bracket will be capped at NT$130,000 per month by the end of February. Should this proposal be adopted, it is expected to generate additional revenue of NT$1.3 billion per year.

Cho said the Cabinet will make a final decision at its regular weekly meeting Feb. 23 on whether this short-term or transitional reform measure will be adopted, as well as on how to curb the wasteful use of medical resources and which laws or regulations should be revised to improve the national health insurance program.

During Monday's meeting, Cho said Hsieh also announced five measures to avoid waste of medical resources: using smart IC health insurance card information to check on those who frequently visit hospitals; avoiding repeated physical checkups; tightly monitoring pharmaceutical prices to narrow price gaps; stepping up investigations into violations of health insurance rules by hospitals and clinics; intensifying publicity campaigns to instill in local people the knowledge of correct medication and when to visit hospitals.
Cho said Hsieh will also make an inspection tour of major medical facilities to see for himself the health insurance system in practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE INCREASES SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade increased sharply in January, with double-digit growth in both imports and exports, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Finance.
Exports amounted to US$15.3 billion in January, up 29.7 percent on the same month of last year, while imports increased by 46.7 percent to US$15.5 billion, the tallies show.
Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$200 million in January.
Hong Kong and mainland China were Taiwan's largest overseas markets, absorbing a combined US$5.79 billion-worth of Taiwan goods, or 37.8 percent of the country's total exports.
Japan was the country's largest supplier, selling goods worth US$3.95 billion to Taiwan, accounting for 25.5 percent of its total imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC RECONCILIATION WOULD PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT PEACE COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 14 (CAN) An atmosphere of reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties would be favorable to the promotion of a cross-Taiwan Strait peaceful development committee, Taiwan's top mainland China policy charter said Monday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks as arrangements were being made on a series of meetings between the ruling and opposition party leaders.

The meetings will be conducive to reconciliation between the ruling and the opposition parties, Wu said, claiming that this in turn will help promote a peaceful and stable exchange framework between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and the establishment of a cross-strait peaceful development committee.
Wu noted that the committee's establishment is a key policy promoted by President Chen Shui-bian after winning his re-election bid last year.

Looking ahead, Wu said that although cross-strait relations seemed to ease at the end of last year, a proposed "anti-secession law" by mainland China that will be put to review and approval in the rubber-stamp National People's Congress in March, still cast a long shadow over cross-strait relations.
If it is enacted into law, it will definitely impact the government's promotion of a more eased cross-strait policy, Wu said.
He expressed the hope that "China will forego the legislation of the anti-secession law in consideration of the response of the international community and the views of the Taiwan people. "
On whether the government will step up the promotion of cross-strait cargo charter flights, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that it is still too early to talk about the matter.

He noted that the cross-strait Chinese New Year charter flights for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland are still underway and said the MAC will have to wait for related government agencies to give their reports after the services end Feb. 20 before it can assess when to promote cross-strait cargo charter flights.
Chiu said the promotion of cross-strait cargo charter flights will require the willingness of both sides and that even if there is willingness, they cannot be promoted immediately.
"The more important thing is the cross-strait atmosphere. When the atmosphere is right, both sides will promote the matter, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW COUNTERPRODUCTIVE TO CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Both the United States and the European Union think mainland China's planned anti-secession legislation is counterproductive to peace across the Taiwan Strait, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Monday.
Chen made the remarks after presiding over a Lunar New Year gathering at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) auditorium.

He said the government sent six delegations to the United States, Japan and EU countries last year to brief officials, academics and opinion leaders on the adverse impact on cross-strait relations of Beijing's planned anti-secession law, which targets Taiwan.
The MOFA has also instructed embassies and representative offices abroad to express to their host governments Taiwan's opposition to the proposed legislation, Chen said.

The mainland's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- is scheduled to screen the so-called anti-secession law in March. Chen said such a move could draw a backlash and protests from the people of Taiwan and could hinder cross-strait rapprochement.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Feb. 15:

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES CHEN-SOONG MEETING CAN PAVE WAY FOR PASSAGE OF MAJOR BILLS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) looks forward to seeing the upcoming meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong can contribute to the passage of major bills related to people's livelihoods, a party whip said Monday.

Legislator Lai Ching-teh, who concurrently serves as secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, made the remarks after the Presidential Office announced that Chen's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, will meet with PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng Friday to set the stage for the much-anticipated Chen-Soong meeting.

In addition to addressing issues related to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Lai said he hopes the Chen-Soong meeting will pave the way for the passage of major bills in the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to facilitate sweeping domestic reforms.

"Many critical bills have been pending legislative approval for a long time. We hope the Chen-Soong meeting can contribute to a speedy passage of those bills, including those related to judicial reform and reformation of the national health insurance system," Lai said.

Through a telephone conversation, Yu and Chin agreed to meet Friday at the Taipei Guest House, a government-owned estate near the Presidential Office, to work out technical details for the Chen-Soong meeting, including the date, venue, format and agenda, the Presidential Office said Monday evening. There will be no limits on the topics to be discussed during the Yu-Chin meeting, a spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP MAY FACE SHOWDOWN IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Although the opposition "pan-blue alliance" secured a majority in the legislature after last December's elections, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) are very likely to face a showdown in the magistrate and mayor elections slated for the end of this year.

Analysts said that the two allied parties are very likely to be competing with each other in the elections, including those for Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors and magistrates, should they fail to agree to a joint election strategy as they did in last year's legislative polls.

If the PFP refuses to cooperate with the KMT in the coming elections, such a development would drive both into a very difficult situation in the face of strong competition from the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, they said.

Given that the voter ratio for the "pan-blue alliance" and the "pan-green camp" is about 55 percent to 45 percent, they said that a split between the KMT and PFP will make it extremely hard for both to perform well in the year-end magistrate and mayor elections.

Whether or not the two parties will continue to cooperate or seek backing from other forces will be a test of wisdom for their leaders and mutual trust will be indispensable in any coming two-way cooperation, they said, noting the PFP's attitude will be the key due to its crucial importance as the third largest party in the Legislative Yuan.
The PFP controls 34 seats in the 225-member legislature, lagging behind the ruling DPP's 89 seats and the main opposition KMT's 79 seats in the sixth Legislative Yuan, which opened Feb. 1.

But the chances of KMT-PFP cooperation in the coming elections appear to be very slim, as PFP Chairman James Soong has repeatedly said in recent months that the party will "walk its own way" for the welfare and benefit of the Taiwan people. The meaning of the PFP's existence is now to help the DPP adopt a middle road and push the KMT to step up reform, Soong has said.

Meanwhile, the PFP seems to have kicked off efforts to cement its power base at the grassroots level, evident in that it has already started preparations for the magistrate and mayor elections in various administrative areas where it stands a good chance, including Taipei County, Keelung City and Changhua County, regardless of the KMT, observers said.

For the time being, the PFP plans to field hopefuls to run in five or six cities and counties. Once the candidates are decided, the PFP will hold on to the end and will never yield to outside pressure from the KMT, party officials said, adding that Soong hopes to foster greater affinity for the PFP among the rank and file through the year-end elections for the party's long-term development.

To serve that end, the party will name candidates with strong popular backing to run, such as Legislator Chou Hsi-wei for Taipei County magistrate, legislative caucus whip Liu Wen-hsiung for Keelung mayor and former lawmaker Hsieh Chang-chieh for Changhua magistrate, party officials said.

They stressed that PFP candidates will not be absent for a second time in the magistrate and mayor elections in the various key areas and claimed that they are confident of winning the race despite competition from the KMT.

According to the PFP officials, it is good for party lawmakers to take part in popular elections, as most of them have no administrative experience. It will also be a good thing for the party, which they said is keely hoping to foster younger generations.

At the same time, the KMT is scheduled to put forth a candidate list in May or June before conducting negotiations with the PFP. By August at the latest, the KMT will have decided upon all its candidates in every electoral area.

At present, incumbent KMT magistrates and mayors, including Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Zhen-zhe, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Taichung County Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng, Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei and Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan have shown keen interest in running for re-election.
But a fresh KMT-PFP cooperation seems unlikely in view of the PFP's reluctance, observers said, adding that sharp competition between the two parties will be hard to avoid.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO PROMOTE ENERGY SAVING POLICIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will pull out all the stops to promote energy saving policies in line with the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol, Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.
Taiwan will adhere to terms of the Kyoto Protocol, even though it is not a signatory of the international agreement, Ho said.
Taiwan is not allowed to sign the international accord as it is not a member of the United Nations.
A national energy conference slated for June 20-21 will mainly discuss the country's energy consumption structure, greenhouse gas emissions and upgrading energy efficiency, the minister revealed.

According to a draft plan, the MOEA has set mid-term and long-term energy saving targets of upgrading energy efficiency by 1.2 percent year-on-year by 2010 and by a further 1 percent by 2020, she added.
However, she said, the government's policy of making Taiwan nuclear-free will not be changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD ARRIVES IN ROME FOR PRIVATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his wife arrived in Rome Monday for a three-day private visit.
Upon his arrival at the airport in the Italian capital, Lien politely refused to take reporters' questions, saying that his visit was private in nature.
According to Lien's entourage, the KMT head and his wife are scheduled to leave for Paris Feb. 17 for a three-day visit before returning to Taiwan.
Lien was greeted at the airport by ROC Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng and ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 15, or the seventh day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1564: Galileo Galilei, the Italian astronomer and physicist who was the first to use a telescope to study the stars, is born.
1748: Jeremy Bentham, English philosopher, is born. He was a pioneer of utilitarianism, an ethical doctrine which holds that the best action is one that will result in the greatest happiness and least pain for the greatest number of people.
1898: The U.S. battleship Maine, which was sent to Cuba to protect American citizens during the Cuban rebellion against Spanish rule, explodes and sinks in Havana Harbor as 260 lose their lives.
1912: Yuan Shih-kai is elected provisional president by the provisional Senate.
1922: The Permanent Court of International Justice, established by the League of Nations, holds its first session in The Hague, capital of the Netherlands.
1928: After some 70 years of efforts, the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
1933: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt escapes an assassination attempt in Miami by Italian-born anarchist Giuseppe Zangara.
1936: China's first international long-distance telephone service between Shanghai and Tokyo begins operation.
1942: Thousands of British troops in Singapore surrender to Japanese forces in World War II.
1944: The Allies begin to bomb the German-held strategic position of Monte Cassino in Italy as some 1,000 British bombers pound Berlin, Germany. Meanwhile U.S. troops recapture the Solomon Islands in the Pacific in World War II.
1945: British forces reach the River Rhine in their advance toward Berlin during World War II.
1946: The world's first computer is born at a university in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania.
1952: Greece and Turkey formally join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1965: Canada adopts a new national flag with red and white colors as its base and a maple leaf at the center.
1965: Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Chen Yi says in Beijing that peaceful coexistence with the United States is out of the question.
1966: South Korean President Park Chung Hee arrives in Taipei for a four-day state visit.
1970: A Dominican Airlines DC-9 crashes into the sea, killing all 102 aboard.
1973: Henry A. Kissinger, the United States' national security adviser under President Richard M. Nixon, visits the Chinese mainland.
1973: The Republic of China and Paraguay sign an agreement on technical cooperation at Asuncion.
1974: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation signs an oil exploration agreement with two Philippine corporations.
1974: Arthur Pothuije, director of the new U.S. Trade Center in Taipei, arrives with his wife.
1974: Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of state for finance and national economy, arrives in Taipei for talks on economic cooperation.
1975: Kuo Chie-hsiung of the Republic of China fires a record 6-under-par 66 for an eight-stroke victory in the Philippines Open Golf Championship.
1976: Clement C. Conger, curator of the U.S. White House and the diplomatic reception room of the U.S. State Department, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1989: The Soviet Union withdraws its remaining soldiers from Afghanistan, ending nine years of military intervention.
1994: Pyongyang agrees to open part of its nuclear program to international inspection.
1995: A fire at a restaurant in Taichung City claims 64 lives in one of Taiwan's worst fire disasters in recent years.
1999: Henry Kendall, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, dies at the age of 72. He is considered a pioneer of the environmental movement among scientists.
2000: The two new naval patrol boats, the Chinchiang and the Hsianchiang, are formally commissioned by the ROC Navy.
2001: The sixth Japanese-Taiwan academic symposium, sponsored by the Asia-Pacific Forum of Japan, is held in Tokyo, attended by about 50 scholars and experts from the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, sentiment is called out by the study of poetry; judgment is formed by the study of the arts; and education of the character is completed by the study of music."
