DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Shiite and Kurdish Slates Win 75% of Votes in Iraq. A popular Shiite Muslim slate and a Kurdish bloc captured almost 75% of the vote in Iraq's landmark election, a momentous power shift in the heart of the Middle East,according to provisional results released. The tally also confirmed minimal participation in the poll by Iraq's long-dominant Sunni Arabs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Valentine's Day blast kill 12
Bomb explosions in Makati City, General Santos City, and Davao City killed at least 12 people last night, turning the celebration of Valentine's Day into a nightmare. The Philippine National Police (PNP) said the first explosion rocked General Santos City followed by another in Davao City shortly before 7 p.m. Then at 8 p.m., a bus exploded near the Metro Rail Transit (MRT) 2 Ayala Station in Makati City.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 7 killed in Abu bombings
AT LEAST seven people were killed and nearly 100 wounded when attackers claiming to be Abu Sayyaf last night bombed buses and crowded places in the cities of Makati, General Santos and Davao.
The Philippine Star: Valentine bombing spree
Three bomb explosions in a span of one hour jolted a nation celebrating Valentine's Day last night, killing at least seven people and wounding over a hundred others, military and police officials said.
The Manila Times: Bloody Valentine
THREE bombs jolted the country on Valentine's Day, killing 11 persons and injuring 80 others, police said. Bombs exploded simultaneously in the cities of General Santos, Davao and Makati Monday afternoon hours after government troops launched a full-scale offensive on Muslim rebels' lairs in Jolo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC TO RESPECT IPR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday urged the public to respect intellectual property rights while addressing the opening ceremony of the 2005 Taipei International Book Exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center.

Jointly presiding over the opening ceremony with Lin Chia-lung, director-general of the Government Information Office, Chen said that reading can not only increase the sum of one's knowledge, but can also help expand a person's "field of vision" to deal with matters. Only those people or nations that have a wide field of vision can move forward steadily and not be eliminated by the times or circumstances, he added.
The president also expressed the hope that students will respect intellectual property rights by not engaging in such activities as photocopying textbooks.

Meanwhile, Lin said the exhibition is a model of cooperation between the government and private sectors. He added that the government will not only help publishers to hold exhibitions, but will also help them to participate in leading international book fairs overseas. He said that by doing so, it is hoped that Taiwan's publishing sector can serve as a center for cultural exchanges.

On display at the exhibition, whose theme is "New Reading Trends in Asia, " are paper and digital publications from around the world. Various seminars and forums will also be held during the fair to give the public a better understanding of the reading trends in other countries in Asia and the West.
A total of 877 publishing companies from 40 countries are participating in the fair which is set to run through Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA CONFIDENT ABOUT DOING JOB OF TAIPEI MAYOR AND KMT CHAIRMAN WELL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that he is confident about being able to do both the job of mayor and of chairman of the opposition Kuomintang well.

Ma, who a day earlier openly expressed his intention to run for the post of party chairman in the election scheduled for this May, made the remarks at a gathering of KMT members at the party's Taipei branch to celebrate the Chinese New Year.

Ma, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, said Monday that for the sake of reform and solidarity of the KMT and the integration of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, People First Party and New Party, he would "give it a try" regarding running for the post of chairman. Ma's term as Taipei mayor is set to expire in December next year.

Ma said Tuesday that he will travel around the island to explain his views in running for the party's top post and his views on various party affairs in meetings with rank and file KMT members in the hopes of arousing their concern for party affairs and their support for the party's policies.

Meanwhile, another possible contender for the KMT chairmanship, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, said that he would give running for the post "serious consideration" if incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan decided not to run for re-election.
The politically savvy Wang, who is also a KMT vice chairman, said Monday that he supports Lien's continued leadership of the party.

On the view expressed by Legislator Ker Chien-ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party that a legislative speaker should not concurrently serve as a party chairman, Wang said this is only Ker's own personal opinion.

Chi Kuo-tung, the KMT's caucus whip in the legislature, noted that even President Chen Shui-bian concurrently served as party chairman before, adding there is no reason why a legislative speaker cannot do so. He also noted that Lien Chan has called for all qualified candidates within the party to come forward to run for the chairmanship.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA'S ACCOUNT FOR TSUNAMI DISASTER DONATIONS TO CLOSE AT END OF MONTH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has so far received a total of NT$230.61 million (US$7.21 million) in cash for relief aid to people affected by last December's devastating tsunami tragedy in South and Southeast Asia, a ministry official said Tuesday.
Chiang Kuo-chiang, vice chairman of the MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, said the ministry's special account for receiving the tsunami-related donations will close at the end of this month.

Meanwhile, Chiang said, the ministry will form a special task force to weigh how to use the donations to help tsunami-affected people in South and Southeast Asian nations, including Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and India.

According to Chiang, the MOFA has also collected a large amount of relief goods which have been delivered to various disaster zones either by air or sea. Both commercial and military planes have been used to transport the relief supplies, he added.
The MOFA has arranged for the delivery of 155 tons of Taiwan-donated relief supplies to Indonesia, 88 tons to Sri Lanka and 11 tons to India, Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Tokyo, Feb.15 ( CNA) The Japan Times: Shiites win Iraqi election; Long-oppressed majority seizes mantle from Sunnis.
A Shiites Islamis't bloc won Iraqis first election since the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein, sealing the political resurgence of the long-oppressed majority but leaving the restive Sunni Arab minority in the cold.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS BARE ALL IN THE NAME OF CLEAN AIR

TEXT.P: Six university students bared all Tuesday in Taipei to bring attention to Taiwan's failure to address the reduction of the emission of greenhouse gases as specified in the Kyoto Protocol, which will come into force tomorrow.

The students from Taichung and Yunlin, under the auspice of Taiwan Environmental Protection Union Secretary-General He Tsung-hsun and Yunlin County Wild Bird Society Acting President Chang Tzu-chien, stripped in front of the Executive Yuan despite pleas from police that they could be cited for indecent exposure. In the end, the students -- all men -- were left with fig-leaf signs covering their private parts admonishing Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
The Taiwan Academy of Ecology also took part in the protest.

Under the Kyoto Protocol, to which Taiwan is not a signatory, 30 industrialized countries have agreed to reduce emissions of six major greenhouse gases between 2008 and 2012 to 5.2 percent below 1990 levels.
EPA figures show that Taiwan's total greenhouse gas emissions rose by 70 percent between 1990 and 2000.

The environmentalists pointed out that the government has acted against international trends and has continued to promote an investment project by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) to build the island's eighth naphtha cracker and a large steel refinery, which they said consume large amounts of energy and give off a great deal of greenhouse gases.
The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said earlier this month that the FPG's steel refinery in Yunlin will begin construction in June at the latest.
The project is now only waiting for environmental impact assessments and related operations are proceeding smoothly, IDB officials said.

When the Executive Yuan officials got wind of what was going on outside, they asked the protesters to come inside and discuss the issue; however, the students preferred to carry on with their publicity stunt.
The event ended with the environmentalists shouting slogans of "love the earth" and "protect the climate."
A student surnamed Wu said that this was the first time that he had ever done something like this, adding that he and the others had decided to strip without being cajoled.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GIVES ULTIMATUM FOR VICE PREMIER POST TO OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that if he fails to find a candidate from one of the opposition parties to become vice premier, he will announce his own candidate after Feb. 17.
The premier made the comments while attending the inauguration of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) new chairman, Su Tseng-chang.

Pointing out that although he already has his own candidate for the post in mind, Hsieh said that to establish political harmony and respond to the people's expectations, the Executive Yuan still hopes to find a candidate from one of the opposition camps.

Nevertheless, the premier said that since administrative work should not be interrupted and the legislature will soon start its new session, he will announce his own candidate for the post if the opposition continues to give him the cold shoulder.
The premier has invited P.K. Chiang, a former deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan and a vice chairman of the Kuomintang, to serve as vice premier, but Chiang has not been receptive to the idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 9.99 points to close at 6,122.39.
The bourse opened at 6,121.97 and fluctuated between 6,142.44 and 6,106.5 during trading. A total of 3.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$71.98 billion (US$2.28 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent.

Five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.5 percent, textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 0.3 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 482 to 316, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Iraq Rebels Elude Intensified U.S. Raids; Military Shifts to More Selective Targeting.
Intensified military raids in Iraq over the past few months have significantly battered the ranks of mid-level insurgents but have scored few gains against the 30 or so most wanted rebels, according to senior U.S. military officers here.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February lost six points to close at 6,123, with 11,655 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost eight points to finish at 6,132, with 9,400 contracts traded, while June futures lost 15 points to close at 6,120, with 23 contracts traded.
September futures remained unchanged at 6,054, with 17 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 10 points to end at 6,048, with two contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,129 for February, 6,140 for March, 6,135 for June, 6,054 for September and 6,058 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

February TE futures moved down 0.6 points to close at 233.65, with 2,740 contracts traded, while March TE futures lost 0.5 points to finish at 233.8, with 2,736 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 0.4 points to finish at 233, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.
February TF futures lost 1.8 points to finish at 1,026.2, with 2,645 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved down 3.6 points to finish at 1024.4, with 2,992 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.006 to close at NT$31.590.
A total of US$711 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.702 and hit a low of NT$31.530.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO LURE TAIWANESE EXPATRIATES TO RETURN TO START OWN BUSINESSES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) has launched a project to provide loans to lure Taiwanese expatriates to return to Taiwan to start their own businesses.

The OCAC's service center in Los Angles said that the "salmon returning home" project stands for a call from the government for overseas Taiwanese to return, hoping that they settle in Taiwan and then reach back out to the world.
Any Taiwan expatriates who are certified by the OCAC, and have valid Republic of China passports, or have a legally registered business can apply for loans to start their own businesses.

The project will provide individuals up to NT$4 million (US$126,980) in loans, with NT$1 million being collateral free, to start their businesses, while a single business can get up to NT$12 million in loans, with NT$3 million being collateral free.
Anyone interested can contact the service center at 626-443-9999 for more details about obtaining the loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Aids & TB tests for all immigrants in Tory plan.
Michael Howard, the Conservative leader, has defended controversial plans to force economic immigrants to undergo tests for contagious diseases before arriving in Britain. The Conservative leader said that the proposal was a "common sense" approach to protecting public health and the NHS. The Tories plan to demand that people travelling to live and work in Britain for more than 12 months undergo the health checks for conditions including HIV/Aids, hepatitis and tuberculosis (TB) , paid for by themselves before departing their home country. Those with TB would automatically be precluded from entry.
Financial Times: Buy-to-let lending cools down.
New mortgage lending to buy-to-let investors has fallen for the first time, data showed on Monday, suggesting an end to a boom that has shored up the UK property market. The findings signal support is crumbling at the lower end of the housing market, where buy-to-let investors have been replacing potential first-time buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN TRADE IN JANUARY POSES DOUBLE-DIGIT GROWTH: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports in January reached US$30.82 billion, a growth of 37.7 percent over the same month last year, officials of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Tuesday.

Taiwan suffered a deficit in January of US$200 million, the second deficit in a row. Despite that, the island has still maintained double-digit growth in terms of foreign trade, the officials said. According to customs tallies, Taiwan's exports in January saw a 29.7 percent increase over the previous year's level to US$15.31 billion, while imports surged 46.7 percent to US$15.51 billion.

With an expected sluggishness in global economic development due to factors including the recent fluctuation of the U.S. dollar against the yen and the euro, the possible raising of U.S. interest rates, as well as mainland Chinese authorities' economic controls, the scale of global trade is expected to shrink this year, a situation that is believed will slow Taiwan's economic expansion, BOFT officials said.

Meanwhile, in January, Taiwan's combined exports to Hong Kong and mainland China saw a growth of 38.3 percent over the same month last year, with exports accounted for 37.8 percent of the island's total exports, according to the BOFT.

In order not to be over-dependent on the mainland Chinese market, the bureau has chosen Vietnam, India, Bangladesh, Japan, South Korea, Brazil, Russia and Argentina to serve as goal markets in its efforts to help Taiwanese business diversify their overseas markets, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD CONSIDER HOW TO SHAKE OFF THREAT FROM CHINA: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must consider how to shake off the threat from communist mainland China.
Lu made the remarks when she attended the inauguration of Su Tseng-chang as the new DPP chairman.

Lu noted that the Eurasia Group recently ranked President Chen Shui-bian as the 27th major national leader in the world, while in another ranking by the U.S. magazine Parade, a weekend supplement to 340 U.S. newspapers, Chinese President Hu Jintao was called the fourth of the world's top-10 dictators.
The sharp contrast is a great encouragement to the DPP, Lu said.
The vice president used the comparison to highlight the fate of the Taiwan people, saying that Taiwan bears two historical crosses.

Firstly, Lu was referring to the authoritarian regime of the Kuomintang administration, a situation that began to be addressed first during the infamous "Kaohsiung Incident" in 1979, a rally organized by the opposition to celebrate International Human Rights Day that turned violent. The incident is generally considered to have sewn the seeds for the growth of the DPP.
Secondly, Taiwan faces an unprecedented threat from mainland China, which seeks hegemony by absorbing Taiwan, something that the people of Taiwan must counter, Lu said.

The DPP has to see clearly its historic responsibility and understand the historical challenges it has faced, Lu said, adding that instead of concentrating on relations with mainland China, the focus must also be on Taiwan's relations with the world.
Lu said that President Chen stands for the Taiwan people, whose influence and moral courage have won recognition from the international community.
The DPP needs to recreate this beautiful island, she said, adding that the party's goal is to build Taiwan into a "normal, great, beautiful and complete country," Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DPP CHAIRMAN TAKES PARTY HELM

TEXT.P: New ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Tuesday he will dedicate himself to leading the party in winning the hearts and minds of the public.
Su made the pledge in his inaugural speech, titled "Action, Interaction, Touch the People."
Saying that the DPP belongs to the people, Su said the party is willing to take firm action to realize its noble ideals and will move the people through "action and interaction."

"As the ruling party, the DPP must always be modest, humble, accountable and responsive to popular demand. The DPP must also take the lead in offering initiatives toward formulating mainstream public opinion," Su said.

Su, a lawyer-turned-politician, said he will serve as a role model for all DPP party workers by "embracing the land and the grassroots people, interacting with rank-and-file party members and engaging all social quarters."

He said he will also direct all departments at the DPP headquarters to engage the major political parties and direct DPP local chapters to forge extensive and familiar ties with various segments of society.
"We'll turn attentive ears to different voices and reflect popular opinion. We'll be a sincere party and win the hearts and minds of the people with passion, sincerity and humility," Su said.
Stressing that the DPP has accomplished many historic missions with courage, diligence and perseverance, Su said the party must continue working hard because many even tougher challenges lie ahead.

Su took the DPP's helm in a ceremony attended by many prominent political figures from both the ruling and opposition camps, including President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, former President Lee Teng-hui, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang, People First Party Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung and Cheng Feng-shih, deputy director of the Kuomintang's policy coordination department. However, three former DPP Chairmen -- Hsu Hsin-liang, Shih Ming-teh and Lin Yi-hsiung -- did not attend.

As Su used to be rugby player, a rugby ball was used in the handover ceremony to symbolize the transition of the party's helm. President Chen, who stepped down as DPP chairman last December to assume responsibility for the party's worse-than-expected performance in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, passed the rugby ball to acting Chairman Ker Chien-ming, who then transferred the ball to Su, completing the handover ceremony.

Su entered politics after serving as a defense lawyer in the trial of pro-democracy activists involved in the 1979 Kaohsiung Incident during Taiwan's martial-law era. He also previously served as a provincial assemblyman, as well as the magistrate of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung and the most populous county of Taipei in northern Taiwan. He resigned as President Chen's chief of staff last December to run for the DPP chairmanship. He invariably ranks top of a shortlist of DPP candidates for the 2008 presidential race.
Addressing the handover ceremony, Chen said success has always belonged to those who have worked hardest at every stage of life.
Premier Hsieh, who also once served as DPP chairman, said Su has outpaced him in terms of personal image, intelligence, courage and popularity.

"I have a feeling of ease in seeing Su taking the party's helm. Under his leadership, the DPP will become even stronger and more popular. I keenly hope the DPP will serve as the Cabinet's backup in delivering on the party's promise to bring good fortune, prosperity and security to the nation and the people," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS WIRE TAIWAN SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH CNA

TEXT.P: Business Wire Taiwan (BWT) and the Central News Agency (CNA) have entered into an agreement that provides BWT with access to all of Taiwan's media outlets, Internet service providers and mobile phone operators, BWT President Hector Boteo announced Tuesday.

Under the agreement, Boteo said, news from BWT will also reach government agencies, academic institutions and private industries, as well as more than 100 newspapers that subscribe to CNA and cater to overseas Chinese communities all over the world.

"Over the past few months, BWT has been developing a series of agreements with government organizations and news agencies throughout the Asia-Pacific region to expand our news distribution network in China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, " Boteo said, adding that "the realization of this initiative with CNA represents a milestone for our news penetration in these markets."
The New York-based Business Wire President Cathy Baron-Tamraz expressed satisfaction with the agreement and described CNA as a trusted news source.

"We are truly excited about this partnership with the Central News Agency, an organization that for more than 80 years has been a trusted news source of media outlets in Taiwan and around the world," she said.

"We look forward to becoming a strategic partner in editorial content for CNA subscribers, providing the latest full-text news and information from leading companies and organizations from around the world," she added.

Business Wire, a leading global business and financial news provider, disseminates electronically some 1,000 full-text news releases daily to the media, the Internet, online services and databases, and the global investment community in 150 countries in 45 languages.
It also provides real-time, simultaneous access to key audiences -- the news media, trade publications, institutional and individual investors, business-to-business decision makers and consumers.
It has a multi-channel delivery network, with access to some 60 international and national news agencies, financial information providers and Web-based news service around the world.

Founded in Guangzhou, southern China April 1, 1924 and headquartered in Taiwan since 1949, CNA provides about 1,500 items of objective, fast and comprehensive local and international news in Chinese, English and Spanish every day to the media.

CNA's coverage spans the globe, with correspondents in every city and county in Taiwan and in 35 cities overseas. In addition to articles, it offers radio, television, in-flight services and mobile phone operators with news content and images from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOCUS OF BATTLE AGAINST PIRACY TO BE CONCENTRATED ON BOOKS

TEXT.P: The Intellectual Property Office (TIPO) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will concentrate on cracking down on pirated books, a TIPO official said Tuesday.

Lu Wen-hsiang, vice director of the TIPO, told a news conference while unveiling an anti-piracy advertisement that book piracy has not aroused the same public awareness as piracy of software, music and movies, because, he claimed, it "prevails only among university students" who prefer to download digital books from the Internet or steal the work of authors by buying pirated books rather than buying authentic copies.
"Therefore we will try to instill into them the respect for intellectual property through an advertising campaign using film and posters that should appeal to youth," Lu said.

In order to get the maximum publicity, Lu said, the advertising campaign was timed to launch to coincide with the beginning of the new semester and the beginning of the Taipei International Book Exhibition 2005, which opened that day.
Lu said he hopes the ads will also impress foreign publishers who visit Taiwan for the book exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ANNOUNCE NOMINEES IN MID-JUNE FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: In preparation for the magistrate and mayoral elections set for the end of this year, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will announce its nomination list in mid-June, a party official said Tuesday.

According to DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang, who spoke after a Central Standing Committee meeting, the party approved a nomination process schedule for the December election and its Central Executive Committee will make public the list June 14.

It was also decided that candidates will be produced according to the results of a vote within the party on May 22 and the results of a public opinion poll from May 25 to June 10, Lee said, adding that prospective DPP hopefuls must apply for registration forms during the March 28-April 1 period.
Prior to this, the Central Executive Committee will announce on March 22 on how many candidates the party will field in the race, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Seems Sure of the Hand of Syria, Hinting at Penalties.
The Bush administration, condemning the assassination of the former prime minister, Rafik Hariri, in Lebanon, suggested Monday that Syria was to blame and moved to get a new condemnation of Syria's domination of Lebanon at the United Nations Security Council. American and European officials als o said the Bush administration was studying the possibility of tougher sanctions on Syria, effectively tightening penalties imposed in May, when Washington said the Syrian government had failed to act against militant groups in Israel and against a supply line from Syria to the insurgents in Iraq.
Wall Street Journal: In Qatar, Oil Firms Make Huge Bet On Alternative Fuel.
Qatar in the Persian Gulf is undertaking a gas-to-liquids, or GTL, project by establishing plants to turn natural gas into an ultraclean automotive fuel. These plants will produce a clear liquid that operators say will have the high efficiency of diesel fuel, but virtually none of the sooty pollutants. Millions of diesel cars and trucks around the world could run on this fuel. These plants are part of a big bet by a small nation to reshape global energy markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS CALL FOR URGENT NEED TO CUT GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan might face serious heatwaves and power and water shortages in 30 years if the country fails to cut its greenhouse gas emissions, experts and researchers have warned.

According to a mock forecast by the Global Changes Research Center under National Taiwan University, there will be more than 60 days with temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius each summer three decades from now should average temperatures continue to rise. The number could surge to 90 days six decades from now, according to the research. The present average is 40 days.

Center Director Liu Chung-ming said that continued high temperatures would first trigger dry spells, affecting agriculture and that subsequent water shortages would deal a heavy below to the country's economy and threaten people's lives, especially children and the elderly.
However, in a total contradiction, Liu Shaw-chen, director of the Research Center for Environmental Changes at Academia Sinica, expressed grave concern over flooding rather than drought.

As a result of rising temperatures, floods caused by precipitation due to sharply increased evaporation would become much more frequent in Taiwan, Liu explained, pointing out that Taiwan's average temperature is rising at a pace double that of the world average.

Taiwan's average temperature has increased by 1.1 C over the past century, compared to the world's average increase of 0.6 C degrees, according to Liu, who ascribed the worsening to the country's rapid urbanization, the "heat island" effect and pollution.
He claimed that per-capita carbon dioxide emissions in Taiwan are double the levels of developed countries such as Germany and Britain but is still less than levels in the United States and Canada.

Given that Taiwan's gross domestic product has not in turn grown markedly, it is an indication that energy has been seriously wasted, he said, urging the government to review its energy policies and tighten restrictions on vehicles and energy-consuming industries.

At the same time, the government should draw up a comprehensive policy to deal with the country's long-term demand, he went on. He also called for an in-depth examination and practical adjustments of the ruling party's anti-nuclear power stance.

In view of the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol Wednesday, Taiwan is very likely to be sanctioned by the international community if it fails to cut its greenhouse gas emissions effectively, local environmentalists have warned.

Citing statistics released by the Environmental Protection Administration, Taiwan is the world's 22nd-largest polluter in terms of carbon dioxide emissions -- 2.39 million metric tons per year, or nearly 1 percent of the globe's total, they said, adding that the amount will have climbed to 4.61 million metric tons in 2020 at its current pace of an annual 7.9 percent growth rate.
Should Taiwan be punished, exports of its cement, petrochemical and steel industries, as well as the hi-tech semiconductor and panel display sectors will be tremendously hurt, they pointed out.
The issue is not just about the economy but also about a tainted national image, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MOVE ADOPTED TO PREVENT MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS FROM ABSCONDING

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau took over the responsibility Tuesday of handling the reception of tour groups from mainland China to prevent them from absconding en masse once they arrive in Taiwan.

Several cases involving mainland tour groups disappearing en masse upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- were reported last July. To prevent a recurrence of similar incidents, the Aviation Police Bureau then sent staff members to receive mainland tour groups, assisting them in customs clearance and luggage claim before transferring them to tour guides employed by local travel agencies.
As the Aviation Police Bureau faces a manpower shortage, relevant government agencies decided to authorize the Tourism Bureau's travel service center at CKS Airport to take over the job from Feb. 15.

Hereafter, the CKS travel service center will issue provisional passcards to licensed tour guides from local tourist agencies so that they can enter the airport's controlled areas to receive incoming mainland tour groups.

In preparation for taking over the new mission, the Tourism Bureau has organized training programs to help qualified local tour guides familiarize themselves with the procedures of receiving mainland tour groups. About 300 local tour guides have attended the training courses and passed examinations to qualify them for provisional passcards.

Lin Chung-ching became the first local tour guide to legally enter the airport's controlled areas with a temporary passcard issued by the Tourism Bureau Tuesday to receive eight incoming mainland tourists.
With a view to revving up the local tourist industry, the government now allows mainland citizens to make group tours of Taiwan as long as they arrive and leave via a third area.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MAKES NEW APPOINTMENTS

TEXT.P: A former director of the Department of Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) System under the Kaohsiung city government will be the new vice minister of transportation and communications, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Tuesday.

Cho said Premier Frank Hsieh, who was previously mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, has endorsed Chou Li-liang's replacement of Tsai Duei as vice minister of transportation and communications.
Tsai will now serve as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Public Construction Commission, Cho said.

Chou resigned as the Kaohsiung MRT department chief last year in the wake of a spate of landslides and other accidents at MRT construction sites and his new appointment is expected to receive criticism, but Cho claimed that the landslide accidents were mainly related to the region's topography and had "nothing to do" with faulty or slipshod engineering.

As the island's first high-speed railway is slated to become operational later this year, Cho said Chou was recruited to oversee relevant affairs. Chou's professional expertise has long received high recognition in engineering circles, according to Cho.
Meanwhile, Cho said the premier has also approved the appointment of Tang Chin-chuan, a former legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), as vice minister of justice.
Noting that Tang has been a noted labor and human rights lawyer, Cho said Tang is very suitable for the new post.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 16 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, Feb. 16:
09: 00, The weekly Cabinet meeting will be held at the Executive Yuan.
09: 30, The Green Party will present petitions to the Executive Yuan.
10:00, The Taiwan Climate Protection Federation will hold a news conference on the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall.
10: 30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a rally of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China at the Mandarina Crown Hotel in Taipei.
12:00, The Council for Cultural Affairs will issue a new book on local fine arts development in Taiwan at the council's headquarters.
12:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a luncheon party of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China at the Mandarina Crown Hotel in Taipei.
12: 30, Environmental Protection groups will stage a protest at the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office.
15: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will receive members of the Taiwan delegation to the 2005 Melbourne Deaflympic Games at the Presidential Office.

14: 00, The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will hold a news conference at the EPA headquarters to announce measures to be taken by the government to adhere to the terms of the Kyoto Protocol.
16: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
16: 20, The Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IC INDUSTRY YIELDS NEW HIGH IN OUTPUT VALUE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's IC industry recorded a production value of US$33.3 billion in 2004, the first time that the country's hi-tech business surpassed the NT$1 trillion mark, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Tuesday.
The figure represents a 1.5-fold increase over the 1999 level and ranks Taiwan in the world's fourth place in terms of output value, according to DGBAS tallies.

However, it is worth noting that the chip foundry sector of the domestic industry is the world's No. 1, setting a production value of US$12 billion last year, the same statistics show. In terms of good items, chips made up the bulk of the domestic industry, accounting for more than 80 percent of the total.
At the same time, the domestic IC design sector also ranks in second spot globally, with an output value of US$7.8 billion, the tallies indicate.
DGBAS officials attributed the brilliant performance to the industry's excellent research and development abilities, outstanding manufacturing processes and unique labor division strategy.

They also ascribed the global industry's growth to strong demand for opto-electronic goods such as digital cameras and video cameras, and for daily use products such as cell phones and personal computers.

The increase marked a turnabout for a sluggish world semiconductor industry over the past few years. The international market scale of the semiconductor industry peaked in 2000 at US$204.4 billion, but started to dwindle in 2001 due to a global economic recession.
In terms of region, the United States was the world leader in the IC industry prior to 2000, enjoying a market share of more than 30 percent.

However, Asian countries such as Taiwan and South Korea have increasingly replaced the United States in recent years, DGBAS officials said. Countries in the Asia-Pacific region have outpaced the United States since 2001 to become the world's largest manufacturing base, with a combined production value of US$88.7 billion and a 40 percent stake in the global market.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN BACKS PARTY'S STANCE ON HIS POSSIBLE CABINET JOB

TEXT.P: opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who has been tapped by Premier Frank Hsieh as his favorite candidate for vice premier, said Tuesday that he backs the KMT's stance on the idea of his serving in the Cabinet and was relieved to learn that Hsieh has already found someone else.
In a written statement issued through the KMT, Chiang affirmed the premier's efforts to cooperate with the KMT for the sake of political stability and his pragmatic approach to political issues.
"There is no single panacea for the economic issues, " Chiang said, adding that the economy will not be easily turned around simply by appointing him vice premier.

As a loyal party member, Chiang said, he respects the KMT's insistence that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should have sought KMT approval before trying to recruit him, claiming that this would have brought about reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties.

Noting that he recommended to President Chen Shui-bian four years ago that he cooperate with the opposition in order to stabilize the political situation, seek harmony with mainland China for the interest of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, strengthen the ruling team and boost morale in the civil service, Chiang said these recommendations were also the KMT's demands for the DPP in exchange for it's approval of Chiang's appointment.
"The KMT's requests are necessary for the Taiwan people to have a better future, for me to have a free hand in the Cabinet and for the people to improve their wellbeing," Chiang claimed.

Chiang said he hopes Chen and Hsieh are not disappointed because of the failure of their negotiations with the KMT, predicting that there will be more opportunities for cooperation between the two parties on other issues.
Chiang left for the United States for a private visit earlier in the day after learning that Hsieh had given up trying to recruit him.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL WARNS BEIJING AGAINST PUSHING TAIWAN TO REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Mainland China is pushing Taiwan to decide through a referendum whether to "separate from the mainland" if it makes the "one country, two systems" or "one China" principle a part of its proposed anti-secession law, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Speaking with a group of pro-Taiwan independence activists, Wu said Taiwan will have no choice other than to ask its people to decide in a referendum whether to unite with the mainland on Beijing's terms of "one country, two systems" or whether to accept the "one China" principle if Beijing enshrines either of them in its proposed law.
He warned Beijing that the enactment of the so-called "anti-secession law" is a provocation and an attempt to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, which Taiwan will not tolerate.
The pro-independence activists called on the government to respond strongly to Beijing's proposal to enact an anti-secession law designed to frighten Taiwan into giving up moves toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PRAISES STUDENTS' PERFORMANCES IN SCIENCE OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu praised Taiwan students' performances in the 2004 International Junior Science Olympiad (IJSO) Tuesday but encouraged them to give equal devotion to both science and the humanities.

Receiving members of the Taiwan delegation to the IJSO 2004 and their parents at the Presidential Office, Lu said that Taiwan students' performances in international scientific contests are evidence of the success of the country's science education.
However, she encouraged the students to pay equal importance to study of the humanities, even though their main interest is in scientific research.

The vice president also suggested that the Ministry of Education should pay more attention to girls in terms science education after observing that there was only one girl in the six-member Taiwan delegation to the 2004 IJSO.
Taiwan and Indonesia tied in first place in the 2004 IJSO held in Jakarta, each winning five gold medals and one silver in the first international science contest for students under 15 years old.
A total of 31 delegations participated in the competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WILL NOT HELP WITH SEARCH FOR VICE PREMIER: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) wants nothing to do with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) search for a new vice premier, a spokesman for the opposition party said Tuesday.

Asked by reporters whether Premier Frank Hsieh had approached the PFP for help, Hsieh Kung-ping said his party will not name any PFP member or any member of any other political party to serve in the Cabinet.
"It is the premier's business to form the administration, " Hsieh said.
The premier has said he is trying to name a vice premier from an opposition party, but has already been rebuffed in his first choice of opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR CONTINUES TO GROW

TEXT.P: The operating volume of Kaohsiung Harbor continued to grow in January, with the loading and unloading volume of containers expanding by 3.7 percent over the same period of last year, according to statistics released Tuesday by the harbor authorities.
The statistics show that a total of 772,000 containers were handled in the southern Taiwan port.

The tallies also indicate that 3,250 vessels entered or left the harbor in last month, with a total displacement of 58.59 million tons, which is 5.1 percent more than the corresponding period of the previous year.
A total of 38.19 million tons of cargo was loaded and unloaded during the same period, representing an annual growth of 3.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 16, or the eighth day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer, is born. He advanced the theory that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun, discrediting the Ptolemaic model of the universe.
1659: A new way of paying money without using either coinage or a letter of credit is first used in England when Mr. Nicholas Vanacker signs a "cheque" to a creditor.
1884: Robert J. Flaherty, U.S. explorer and filmmaker, is born. His works, including "Nanook of the North," were the world's first major documentaries.
1906: British labor representatives meet in London to establish the Labour Party.
1918: Lithuania, which is located in Northern Europe, proclaims its independence from Russia.
1931: The Control Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1937: The synthetic material nylon, which was developed by the U.S. chemist Wallace Carothers, is patented.
1942: Kim Jong Il, North Korean leader, is born.
1944: Allied aircraft bomb a Japanese naval base at Truk in the Caroline Islands, destroying some 200 planes.
1945: The United States starts massive air raids on Tokyo as U.S. forces capture Bataan in the Philippines during World War II.
1959: Fidel Castro becomes the leader of Cuba at the age of 32.
1960: The USS Triton begins an underwater voyage around the world, becoming the first nuclear submarine to undertake such a journey.
1968: A China Air Transportation plane flying from Hong Kong to Taipei crashes in Linkuo, killing 21 and injuring 43.
1970: The Directorate General of Posts starts nighttime business operations.
1973: Robert E. Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The Republic of China revalues the New Taiwan dollar upward by 5 percent against the U.S. dollar. The new exchange rate is NT$38 to US$1.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander in chief, returns to Taipei after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1983: The Dutch airline Martinair inaugurates flight services to Taiwan, marking the first air link between the Netherlands and the Republic of China.
1986: A China Airlines Boeing 737 plane crashes near Makung, in Taiwan's Penghu Islands, killing all 13 aboard.
1992: OPEC member countries agree to cut oil output by 1 million barrels a day.
1994: An earthquake claims 134 lives and injures at least 550 in southern Sumatra in Indonesia.
1994: The Helenic Republic (Greece) declares an embargo on the Macedonian Republic in a conflict over the use of the name Macedonia. The two countries later reached an agreement on the use of the formal name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" for the latter's entry into the United Nations.
1998: A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane returning from Bali crashes near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing all 116 aboard and six people on the ground.
2000: Two destroyers of the Republic of China, the Loyang and Suiyang, are decommissioned after more than two decades of active service.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang formally files a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, accusing him of embezzling party funds.
2004: Taiwan's Government Information Office and National Geographic Channel International announce a cooperative project on documentary production aimed at introducing Taiwan's natural beauty and cultural legacy to the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The common people should be educated in what they ought to do; not to ask why they should do it."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WELL AWARE OF U.S. VIEWS ON ANTI-SECESSION LAW: STATE DEP'T
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 15 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Tuesday that Beijing is acutely aware of Washington's views concerning it's proposed anti-secession law.

The spokesman made the remarks in response to reporters' questions after Robert B. Zoellick, nominee for the post of deputy secretary of state, commented on China's anti-secession law in his confirmation hearing by saying that Washington certainly discourages Beijing from enacting such a law.
"We encourage a dialogue, and we certainly discourage actions like that that move in the other direction," Zoellick said during the hearing held by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations.

Asked how the United States has tried to discourage China from enacting the anti-secession law, Boucher responded by saying that the U.S. government has made it clear that neither side " should take unilateral steps that try to define the situation further or push it in one direction or another."
Boucher noted that the United States has made its position on the proposed anti-secession law clear right from the start.
Pointing out that Secretary of State Colin Powell and the U.S. embassy in China have raised the issue with Beijing, Boucher said that "the Chinese know clearly what our views are."

Meanwhile, in response to questions raised by Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Ala.) , Zoellick said during the hearing that the goal of the United States is for China and Taiwan to work out their differences peacefully and in a way that is acceptable to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Zoellick also said that the U.S. administration maintains its policy based on the one-China principle and the three communiques and that U.S. President George W. Bush remains committed to the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP ECONOMIST TIGHT-LIPPED ON POSSIBLE APPOINTMENT AS VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) President Wu Rong-i declined to respond to news reports Wednesday that he is going to be appointed by Premier Frank Hsieh as vice premier.
Wu said that he has no idea about the appointment, which he described as "an appointment made by the media."
He also declined to confirm whether he has been sounded out by Hsieh about such an appointment.

Premier Hsieh disclosed Tuesday that he already has a suitable candidate for the vice premiership who "is able to handle the overall economic situation, capable of dealing with international affairs and who is not a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party."
Wu is widely believed to be the person described by Hsieh.

Hsieh extended an invitation to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Jiang in January to serve as his deputy and later said he would not contact any other potential candidates ahead of the Feb. 17 deadline that he set for a response from the KMT on the appointment of Jiang. The KMT has set six preconditions which Hsieh said go beyond his authority to meet.
Hsieh, formerly Kaohsiung mayor, was sworn in as premier Feb. 1, inaugurating a new Cabinet which Hsieh said will make consultations and coexistence its cornerstone.

All the members of the previous Cabinet under former Premier Yu Shyi-kun were retained, with the exception of Executive Yuan Secretary-General Arthur Iap, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan and Central Personnel Administration Director-General Lee Yi-yang.
The post of vice premier, however, has remained vacant.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG SERVING AS KMT HEAD WOULD AFFECT HIS NEUTRALITY AS SPEAKER: DPP

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that if Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng assumes the post of KMT chairman, this will affect his neutrality as the head of the legislature.

Lai Ching-teh, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, made the remarks as reports circulated that Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who openly expressed Monday his intention to run for the top KMT post, could face a possible challenge from Wang.

Wang has said that he supports KMT Chairman Lien Chan's continued leadership of the party and that he would only give "serious consideration" to running in the May election if Lien decided not to stay on in his post.

Lai said that the KMT chairman election is an internal matter of the KMT and that the DPP will not interfere. He added however that the DPP's position is that the legislative speaker should be neutral.
As the speaker, Wang represents the legislature, Lai noted, adding that if he were to assume the KMT chairmanship, then he might ignore the views of other parties when speaking for the legislature.

Meanwhile, four DPP legislators said Wednesday that Wang must make a choice between the legislative speakership and the KMT chairmanship, adding that if he decides to run for KMT chairman, he should first step down as speaker.
DPP Legislators Huang Wei-tse, Hsieh Hsin-ni, Chen Ying and Cheng Yun-peng made the call in a press conference held at the legislature.
Huang said that it is "inappropriate" for others to stick their noses into the KMT's internal affairs, but he added that Wang must maintain his strict neutrality as legislative speaker.

If Wang serves concurrently as the KMT chairman, this will undermine his neutrality in presiding over the legislature, thus affecting the harmony between the ruling and the opposition parties as well as the legislature's efficiency, Huang claimed. He added that Wang might be inclined to put party considerations first, thus undermining the dignity of the legislature as well as seriously affecting its operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF REPORTED DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CASES ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: A total of 53,054 domestic violence cases were reported in 2004, double the level of 2000, the National Police Agency (NPA) announced Wednesday.

The number of habeas corpus applications from victims of domestic violence also increased over the past five years, which shows that the public is becoming more and more aware of its rights, NPA officials said.

While reported cases of continuing domestic violence after the issuance of a habeas corpus writ rose from 501 in 2000 to 961 in 2004, the number of people arrested red-handed jumped from 432 in 2000 to 717 in 2004, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIWAN STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 21.10 points to close at 6,143.49.
The bourse opened at 6,134.53 and fluctuated between 6,158.80 and 6,086.30 during trading. A total of 3.70 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$85.23 billion (US$2.69 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 2.2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.8 percent and plastics and chemicals stocks at 0.1 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.7 percent, construction shares at 0.5 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent. Textile shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 555 to 241, with 187 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS SHOULD NOT BE LINKED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that those who want to take part in the election of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman should not link the election with the next presidential election.
Wang made the remarks amid reports that he and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou could face off in the KMT chairman election in May.

Noting that the next presidential election will not be held until 2008, Wang said that changes could be dramatic during the ensuing period and that those who want to take part in the party chairmanship election should not link the outcome with jockeying for the presidential election.

With media surveys showing that Ma is far more favored than Wang for either the KMT chairmanship or the presidential election, Wang claimed that the survey is only "for reference" and that there will be changes in the actual elections.
Wang also said he will maintain party solidarity and harmony.

"Whether I run in the party chairman election or not, I'll respect Ma, " Wang said, adding that he will "protect him to a substantial degree, " as Ma is a major asset of the party and should be cherished.

On the issue of some legislators promoting a meeting between him and Ma, Wang said there is no need for such a meeting, as Ma has already made known his intention to run, while Wang said he is still undecided.

But he said the KMT has been pushing for years without success for reforms by making the legislative caucus, instead of the party's central committee, decide on the KMT's policies. "If I have the chance to serve as the legislative speaker and concurrently the party chairman, I would be better able to push for such reforms," he said.

On claims from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party that it is not appropriate for him to serve concurrently as party chairman and legislative speaker, Wang noted that the constitutional systems of each country vary and that there are different stipulations on the role, function and power of the legislative speaker.
There are no regulations in the legislature that say the speaker, in addition to presiding over the legislature, has no political room or cannot take part in policy making, he pointed out.

According to Wang, the neutrality of the speaker and his role outside the legislature should not be relevant. In addition, he went on, the majority leader in the House of Representatives of the United States also concurrently serves as the speaker of the House.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ENERGY CONFAB SLATED FOR JUNE IN RESPONSE TO KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: A national energy conference is scheduled to be held in June to allow the country to work out measures to cope with Wednesday's implementation of the Kyoto Protocol on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, according to officials from the Bureau of Energy.

More than 200 people, including government officials, lawmakers, labor representatives, academics and activists from environmental protection groups, will be invited to take part in the conference, which is aimed at soliciting experts' opinions and reaching consensus on Taiwan's energy policies in the post-Kyoto Protocol era, the officials said.

The Kyoto Protocol, negotiated in Japan's ancient capital of Kyoto in 1997 and ratified by 140 nations, calls on 35 industrialized countries to rein in their release of carbon dioxide and five other gases produced by burning oil and coal, as well as by various other processes.

Although Taiwan is not a United Nations member nor a signatory to the U.N.-initiated Kyoto Protocol, the island is obliged to bear its responsibilities as a member of the global village, a Bureau of Energy spokesman said.

Taiwan might end up becoming a target of concern or even trade sanctions if it does not step up its greenhouse gas reduction efforts, given that Taiwan releases some 2.39 million tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere each year, or about 1 percent of the global total, ranking the island 22nd in the world in this regard.
If stronger measures are not taken, Taiwan's greenhouse gas emissions are expected to rise to some 4.61 million tons per year by 2020, the official warned.
Meanwhile, Liu Ming-lung, one of the founders of the Taiwan Climate Protection Coalition, said that Taiwan cannot sit idly by any longer in the face of global actions to curb emissions.
Liu called on the government to ratify the Kyoto Protocol, even though Taiwan is not a signatory, and then move to deal with industries and companies that are the country's major polluters.

In addition, Liu said, the administration should aggressively push for the enactment of a greenhouse gas emissions control law to legally require that greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan be cut to the 2005 levels by 2015.

Liu said the administration should also conduct an overall review of the country's energy policies regarding nuclear, thermal and recycled power, and try to secure for the country a low-pollution power source that requires low energy to produce.
In light of the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol, Taiwan is also urged to take part in the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) under the Kyoto Protocol.

The CDM is one of the protocol's two project-based flexible mechanisms designed to make it easier and cheaper for industrialized nations to meet greenhouse gas emission reduction targets agreed to under the protocol, and to assist developing countries in achieving sustainable development.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, it will have to face reality and the global demand for greenhouse gas emission reduction, according to Professor Lee Ho-ching of Chung Yuan Christian University in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

Lee, another founder of the Taiwan Climate Protection Coalition, called on the government to seek participation in the less politically high-profile CDM engagements, which she said would not only help Taiwan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and secure sustainable development, but would also help the island to take part in bankable projects in developing countries and gain a share of the great earnings expected to be generated from greenhouse gas reduction options.

With the Kyoto Protocol entering into force, governments and companies that will have to curb their emissions in compliance with their countries' caps are scrambling to figure out how to do so without killing their bottom lines.

One of the best policies for dealing with the issue is to cooperate with developing countries, either by helping them reduce greenhouse gas emissions or by buying their greenhouse gas emission "quotas, " according to National Taiwan University Professor Liu Chung-ming. Those that emit less gas are allowed to sell the "credit" to other countries or companies who emit too much.
Liu noted that the World Bank has estimated that under the CDM operations, some US$10 billion in funds will flow into developing countries every year.

Of that total, about 70 percent will be directed into mainland China. This will provide Taiwan with a golden opportunity to cash in on the huge market by investing in or taking part in bankable CDM projects on the mainland, given Taiwan's cultural, language and geographic advantages, Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for February gained five points to close at 6,128, with 14,578 contracts changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET DECIDES TO IMPOSE INCOME TAX ON SERVICEMEN, SCHOOL TEACHERS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Wednesday to impose income tax on military servicemen and primary and junior high school teachers.
The draft of the amended income tax law will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for screening.
Executive Yuan officials said the move is a major short-term measure for financial reforms promoted by the Ministry of Finance.
The officials estimated that if income tax for military servicemen and school teachers is collected, it will add around NT$13 billion (US$412.69 million) in tax revenues to the national coffers.
The government scrapped income tax for military servicemen and primary and junior high school teachers in 1955, mainly as an incentive, because their salaries were generally low at the time.
However, former Premier Yu Shyi-kun decided to reimpose the income taxes to establish a just and reasonable tax system.

The ministries of national defense, education and finance reached a consensus on the reimposition of income tax in 2002 but the previous legislative Yuan that ended in January this year failed to screen the amended income tax law.

Ken Livingstone was under intense pressure last night to apologise for an allegedly anti-Semitic remark which is overshadowing the most crucial week for London's 2012 Olympic bid. Supporters of the bid now fear that the Mayor of London's refusal to apologise for his remarks is distracting attention from the four-day visit which climaxes with a dinner hosted by the Queen at Buckingham Palace.
Financial Times: France fuels China arms row.
Michele Alliot-Marie, the French defence minister, has argued that sales of weapons technologies to China could slow Beijing's push to develop its own capabilities, which was part of the reason why her country backed lifting a European Union arms embargo on China.
