DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO PUSH FOR REVIVAL OF SCHOOL SUBSIDIES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will push for the revival of subsidies for Taiwanese schools based in mainland China, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.

Hsieh said that although subsidies for 2005 were axed by the Legislative Yuan in its last session, the Cabinet will seek to plan for extra budget in this area so that educational subsidies for mainland-based Taiwanese schools can be sustained.

The premier made the remarks in an address to an annual Spring Festival party in honor of mainland-based Taiwanese businessmen. The party was co-sponsored by the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Straits Exchange Foundation and the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries.
Nearly 500 Taiwanese businessmen, including 50 chairmen and 20 presidents of various Taiwanese trade associations based on the mainland, attended the luncheon party.
It marked the first time Hsieh had attended an event with members of the mainland-based Taiwanese business community since he assumed the premiership Feb. 1.
He played a tune on a ceramic flute to entertain the participants, who responded with a big round of applause.
Addressing the opening of the luncheon, Hsieh touted for support for the establishment and operation of a cross-Taiwan Strait peace and development committee initiated by President Chen Shui-bian.

Hsieh, who vowed in his inaugural speech Feb. 1 that his new Cabinet will make consultations and coexistence its cornerstone, said that consultations and coexistence can also be motto for the development of cross-strait relations.

Hsieh also voiced his staunch support for a statement made by Chen earlier in the day that he will push for the launch of direct cargo charter flights across the Taiwan Strait based on the successful Chinese Lunar New Year two-way, non-stop cross-strait passenger charter flights.

He said direct cross-strait cargo charter flights will not only help bolster business and trade development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, they will also benefit Taiwan in its development of free trade ports.
As to whether he will accept an invitation from Taiwan business groups to visit the mainland, Hsieh said his tight schedule will not allow him at present to make such a trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON EXPECTED TO VISIT TAIWAN LATER THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed news reports Wednesday that former U.S. President Bill Clinton is expected to visit Taiwan before the end of this month as part of a tour of Asia.

MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said the Foreign Ministry invited Clinton to visit Taiwan in a move to show Taiwan's admiration for Clinton's contributions to maintaining stability in the Asia-Pacific area during his tenure.
Inviting retired U.S. presidents, as well as heads of state from countries that are friendly toward Taiwan, have always been the set policy of the Foreign Ministry, Lu added.
Delivering a speech in Taipei and meeting with President Chen Shui-bian are expected to be part of his one-day itinerary, the details of which have yet to be fleshed out, according to MOFA officials.
Although Clinton is no longer president, he is expected to be accorded treatment befitting a head of state during his visit, according to MOFA officials.
Clinton has remained an internationally important figure since his retirement and now acts as an unofficial representative of the United States.

During his upcoming Asian tour, Clinton is expected to visit South Asian and Southeast Asian countries that were battered by the devastating tsunami of Dec. 26 last year. He is also expected to visit several Northeast Asian countries, including Japan, South Korea and mainland China.
"It is hoped that Clinton will be able to squeeze in one day to visit Taiwan during the tour, " MOFA officials said.
With eight years in the White House, Clinton is very familiar with the delicate triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations.

The former U.S. president originally planned to come to Taiwan in November 2003 but was forced to cancel the visit due to a tight schedule. He was also scheduled to visit Taiwan Sept. 12, 2001, but failed to make it due to the 911 terrorist attacks.
Clinton visited Taiwan four times during his tenure as governor of Arkansas before being elected U.S. president in November 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO NEGOTIATE WITH MAINLAND CHINA ON CARGO CHARTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is ready to negotiate with mainland China on the launch of cross-Taiwan Strait cargo charter flights, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

According to a plan unveiled by the government in 2003 but never implemented, the cargo charter service will be operated by Taiwanese air carriers and planes will be required to stop in Hong Kong or Macau en route, Wu said.
However, other arrangements such as allowing mainland carriers to offer the service and making the charter flights non-stop will have to be made through negotiations between both sides, Wu said.

Wu made the remarks after President Chen Shui-bian said earlier in the day that he hopes cross-strait cargo charter flights could be started soon following the launch of special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights this year.
Wu said the negotiation format of the passenger charter flights, in which government representatives were allowed to participate, should also apply to the negotiations on the cargo charter flights.
Meanwhile, Wu urged Beijing to drop its plan to enact an "anti-secession law, " legislation that will damage what he described as "the friendly atmosphere across the strait."

If the law is to dictate "one country, two systems" as the only option for the future development of cross-strait relations or make Beijing's "one China" principle the precondition of cross-strait negotiations, it will be tantamount to forcing the Taiwanese people to call a referendum to express their opinions on the issues, Wu said.
He said Taiwan and the mainland need to promote different policies to enhance mutual trust.

In addition to the Lunar New Year charter flights, the government is working to facilitate the launch of cargo charter flights, enhance tourism across the strait and step up cross-strait crime-fighting cooperation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO ANNOUNCE HIS DEPUTY SOON

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he will announce his deputy within the next few days.

Hsieh made the remarks following media speculation that possible candidates for the vice premier post are Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) President Wu Rong-i or Taiwan's permanent representative to the World Trade Organization Yen Ching-chang.
Hsieh, a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was sworn in as premier Feb. 1.
Describing speculation as "impolite" and making unnecessary trouble for those named, Hsieh said he will announce the appointment within the next few days.
However, he joked that the candidates named by the media are not bad and maybe he will start to think about them.

The choosing of the vice premier has been through many twists and turns after Hsieh had originally invited P.K. Chiang, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and a former deputy speaker of the legislature, to take the post but received the cold shoulder from the KMT.
Hsieh's invitation of a KMT member to serve as his deputy was considered by the DPP to be a gesture of goodwill toward the opposition, whose "pan-blue alliance" holds the majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO PUSH FOR CROSS-STRAIT CARGO CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian offered talks with mainland China Wednesday on the opening of direct cargo charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, but warned that Beijing's proposed anti-secession law could further strain bilateral relations.

Addressing a Spring Festival gathering of Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China -- commonly known as "taishang" -- in Taipei, Chen said he looks forward to an early launch of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights based on the successful Chinese Lunar New Year two-way, non-stop cross-strait passenger charter flights.

"The success of the passenger charter flights shows that if there is sincerity, nothing is impossible. If the mainland wants to sit down and talk, there is nothing that cannot be discussed," Chen said.

The president further said he hopes the mainland will work to ease misunderstandings and hostility toward Taiwan and stop any actions that would only drive the two sides farther apart, such as its unilateral suspension of institutionalized cross-strait dialogue and its planned anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Chen said the so-called anti-secession law could spoil the positive mood created by the Lunar New Year passenger charter flights. The law, slated to be discussed by the mainland's rubber-stamp National People's Congress in March, is viewed as part of Beijing's campaign to pressure democratic Taiwan into uniting with the communist mainland.

More than 480 members from 67 Taiwanese trade associations on the mainland, including many senior executives of those organizations, attended the party, which was jointly organized by the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Straits Exchange Foundation and the National Federation of Industries.
Chen said the Year of the Rooster has come with new opportunities for both domestic political development and cross-strait affairs.

"My appeal for opening a new era of consultations and dialogue has won the support of a majority of local people and various political parties, " Chen said, adding that he believes his upcoming meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will help put an end to protracted hostile political wrangling between the ruling and opposition camps and re-mould national unity.

Turning to cross-strait affairs, Chen said the smooth launch of direct cross-strait charter flights for home-bound "taishang" for Lunar New Year celebrations has not only benefited the "taishang" but has also served as a good omen for the opening of the long-talked-about cross-strait charter cargo flights.

Over the past more-than four years, Chen said, he has on numerous occasions held out olive branches to the mainland and has demonstrated the maximum degree of flexibility in dealing with cross-strait affairs, including his "five noes" guarantee, his willingness to discuss the "future one China" issue, the opening of the "mini three links, " and the adjustment of the "no haste, be patient" policy toward mainland-bound investment.

Moreover, Chen went on, he even came up with the initiative in his New Year's Day message that the two sides could resume dialogue on the basis of their 1992 Hong Kong talks. Chen said he has never wavered on his "pragmatic forward-looking" cross-strait policy since he assumed the presidency May 20, 2000.

Chen said he hopes to invite opposition political leaders and representatives from various social quarters to discuss the formation of a cross-strait peaceful development commission in the near future to draft concrete working guidelines for a solid foundation for long-term peaceful cross-strait development.

A 56-year-old ban on direct cross-strait air links has been temporarily lifted for this year's Lunar New Year holiday, also known as the Spring Festival. Under a landmark cross-strait deal, six mainland Chinese airlines and six Taiwanese airlines have been allowed to operate 48 passenger charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OPPOSES UNILATERAL CHANGE OF CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States' policy on the Taiwan Strait is unequivocal, which is to oppose either side of the Taiwan Strait changing the status quo unilaterally, Adm. William J. Fallon, commander of the U.S. Atlantic Fleet, said Tuesday.
Fallon, nominated to head the U.S. Pacific Command, made the remarks at a confirmation hearing at the Senate.

Asked about his views on cross-strait relations, Fallon admitted that they are worrisome and stressed that to protect the interests of the United States, Washington must play the role of stable deterrent with credible strength so as to prevent any possible miscalculation by either side.
Fallon also said that faced with the mainland's military expansion, the United States must keep abreast of Beijing's intentions toward Taiwan as well as its military strategy in Asia and the Pacific.

U.S. President George W. Bush nominated Fallon Jan. 27 to replace Thomas B. Fargo, who is slated to retire. Fallon has also been concurrently the head of the Norfolk-based Fleet Forces Command since October 2000.

The Pacific Command, based in Honolulu, is responsible for American forces -- air, land and sea -- from the west coast of the United States to South Asia. It is the largest of nine combat commands in the U.S. military.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO SPEED UP ENACTMENT OF GREENHOUSE GAS CONTROL LAW

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will speed up the enactment of a greenhouse gas control law in reaction to the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, EPA head Chang Juu-en said Wednesday.
Chang said he hopes the draft of the law will be finalized in June and passed by the legislature by the end of this year.
Although Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, the country will contribute its part in controlling greenhouse gas emissions to comply with international standards, Chang said.
According to the EPA, the carbon dioxide released by Taiwan is expected to increase to 460 million tons in 2020, which will be quadruple the volume of 1990.
The law targets a reduction of carbon dioxide emissions by 35.6 million tons a year by 2020.

Chang said the EPA has surveyed six major greenhouse gases released by the electricity, petrochemical, steel, paper, cement and optoelectronic semiconductor industries in order to control their total emission volume.
Also, Chang said, he will not rule out the possibility of recommending that the government impose a "carbon tax" to push pollution-prone industries to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases.
In the future, greenhouse gas emissions will be one of the criteria for environmental impact assessments for major development projects by the industrial sector, he went on.
This measure can be put into force in six months at the earliest, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSFER OF TWO CHIANGS' DIARIES TO U.S. HURTS TAIWAN'S FEELINGS:DPP

TEXT.P: The transfer of two late Republic of China presidents' personal diaries to the United States has hurt Taiwan people's feelings, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.

Legislator Lai ching-the, who will soon serve as the DPP legislative whip, was referring to the transfer of the late President Chiang Kai-shek's and his son and successor Chiang Ching-kuo's personal diaries to the Hoover Institute of Stanford University.
"Although the Chiang family's move was not illegal, it has hurt Taiwan people's feelings," Lai said.

In his view, Lai said, the two late presidents' personal effects are Taiwan's assets. Academia Sinica, Taiwan's foremost academic body, has expressed a keen interest to keep the two Chiangs' diaries, but failed to obtain the Chiang family's consent.

The two Chiangs ruled Taiwan many years. Lai said that although some local people have ill feelings about them, many other people recognized their contributions to Taiwan. "It is regrettable that the Chiang family has sent the two late presidents' diaries abroad, " he added.

Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese mainland to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. He died in 1975 and his remains were embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan, awaiting a proper burial on the mainland.

Chiang Kai-shek ruled Taiwan with an iron fist, using martial law to suppress democracy. However, some view him as a hero for keeping the island out of reach of the Chinese communists and claim that it was he who fostered Taiwan's freewheeling market economy.

Chiang Ching-kuo is respected for ending martial law in 1987, shortly before his death, thus unleashing the democratic forces that broke his family's vice-grip on power and eventually ended the Kuomintang's half-century of rule over Taiwan.

Chiang Ching-kuo died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan. His Russian-born wife died Dec. 15, 2004 and her cremated ashes, which are being kept at Chiang's mausoleum, will be buried along with her husband.
The two Chiangs' personal diaries were brought to the United States earlier this year by Chiang Ching-kuo's daughter-in-law Fang Chih-yi.
Fang said in San Francisco Tuesday that the contents of the two Chiangs' personal diaries were closely related with modern Chinese history.

"Therefore, the Chiang family would not retain them in private. We instead hope to present them to internationally recognized experts for preservation and study in an open, just and impartial manner. Many research institutes have expressed hopes to own them. But we think that the Hoover Institute, which has a rich collection of modern Chinese archives, is the most appropriate organization to hold them. We have decided to have the Hoover Institute store them for 50 years," Fang said.

Kuo Tai-chun, a Hoover Institute researcher who plays a key role for the institute's decision to form the Modern Chinese Archives, said the institute has used what she called the safest way to preserve the two Chiangs' diaries.
Modern Chinese history experts at the Hoover Institute and the Chiang family will form a special task force to screen the two Chiangs' diaries before deciding which parts will be publicized.
The Hoover Institute will hold a ceremony Wednesday (U.S. time) to mark the establishment of its Modern Chinese Archives.

Kuo said the archives contain many historically significant documents regarding the three most powerful families in modern China -- the Chiang, Soong and Kung families -- as well as the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Chinese Women's League founded by Madame Chiang Kai-shek.

Moreover, Kuo said, many living KMT party elders, including former ROC Premiers Hau Pei-tsun and Tang Fei and former Control Yuan President Wang Tso-jung, have also presented their personal documents and effects to the Hoover Institute for preservation. According to Kuo, all those documents are extremely readable and of great historical significance.
KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang already arrived in San Francisco to attend the Modern Chinese Archives' inaugural ceremony at the Hoover Institute.
Meanwhile, the embalmed bodies of the two Chiangs are scheduled to be interred at a military cemetery in Taipei County this July.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO INCREASE IN NUCLEAR POWER TO HELP CUT GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS

TEXT.P: The government will not increase the use of existing nuclear power plants or build new ones to reduce Taiwan's emissions of greenhouse gases, an official of the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Yeh Jiunn-rong, the executive officer of the Executive Yuan's task force on the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Kyoto Protocol, stressed that the government's goal of promoting a "nuclear-free homeland" remains unchanged.

The government will step up the development of clean and renewable energy, and will never resort to increasing the number of generators in nuclear power plants or build new nuclear power plants to help resolve the greenhouse gas emissions problem.
Yeh made the remarks as the Kyoto Protocol came into effect the same day.
The Kyoto Protocol has 84 signatories of which 30 are industrialized nations. Taiwan is not a signatory.

However, Yeh continued, since Taiwan is highly reliant on international trade, if domestic enterprises cannot fall into line with international trends of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, then it will lose its international competitive edge.
For Taiwan to substantially reduce its greenhouse gas emissions will involve many complex factors, Yeh said, adding long-term planning is required.
Taking a cue from industrialized countries, Yeh said that it will take at least 10 to 15 years to see marked changes.

Amid reports that the government will impose some form of "ecology tax" or a "carbon dioxide tax," Yeh said that the government will definitely establish tax incentives, such as encouraging enterprises to build new factories or renew equipment and phase out dilapidated facilities or outdated production procedures to upgrade energy efficiency and cut greenhouse gas emissions.
"But there is no plan to cope with the problem simply with taxes," Yeh stressed.

Speaking of environmentalists who recently protested against the government's approval of Formosa Plastics Group's project to build a a large steel mill in Yunlin County, Yeh said that cutting carbon dioxide emissions does not mean that companies will not be able to build new facilities.
On the contrary, he said, if the construction of new, cleaner plants eliminates out-of-date polluting ones, the practice will be encouraged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO INTRODUCE BILLS TO MEET KYOTO PROTOCOL GUIDELINES

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will introduce legislation to cut greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday as the Kyoto Protocol went into effect.

To reduce greenhouse gases in the country, mainly carbon dioxide and other carbon by-products produced as the result of burning oil, gas and coal, Hsieh said the Executive Yuan will work out measures to improve energy efficiency, develop renewable energy and review the country's energy management and industrial policies to meet the requirements of the Kyoto Protocol.

As a member of the global village, Taiwan cannot exempt itself from the obligation to cut emissions of greenhouse gases to below the 1990 level by 2012 as provided for by the Kyoto Protocol, although the country is not a signatory, Hsieh said.
The premier made the comments after being briefed by Yeh Jiunn-rong, head of a panel under the Executive Yuan formed to prepare the country for the requirements called for by the Kyoto Protocol.

The premier also asked the Environmental Protection Administration to draw up rules to regulate greenhouse gas emissions, and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to formulate new industry and energy management policies to bring the country within the limits of the protocol.
The premier said the Executive Yuan has already submitted to the Legislative Yuan a draft bill designed to encourage the development of renewable energy.
Hsieh asked related government agencies to focus on attracting investments from environmentally friendly industries to avoid damage to ecosystems.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: F.D.A. to Create Advisory Board on Drug Safety.
Responding to widespread criticism of the government's handling of drug safety problems, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration announced Tuesday that it was creating a board to advise it on drug complications and to warn patients about unsafe drugs. The agency will soon tap into large databases, including those at the Medicare agency, to uncover dangerous side effects in drugs already on the market. The announcement comes as Congressional committees are investigating the agency's ability to discover drug dangers.
Wall Street Journal: New Factor in Iraq: Irregular Brigades Fill Security Void.
In the battle against insurgents in Iraq, two kinds of Iraqi military forces are emerging: the planned units and the pop-ups. The planned units of the Iraq Army, about 57,000 soldiers strong, are the result of careful preparation this summer between the U.S. and Iraqi commanders. The pop-ups started to emerge last fall out of nowhere, catching the American military by surprise. These dozen disconnected units totaling as many as 15,000 soldiers are fast becoming one of the most significant developments in the new Iraq security situation. Frequently, U.S. officials don't find out about the irregulars until they stumble across them. Some Americans consider them a welcome addition to the fight against the insurgency -- though others worry about the risks.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENHOUSE GAS REDUCTION REQUIRED OF NEW INVESTMENT PROJECTS: MOEA

TEXT.P: The two new investment projects by the Formosa Plastics Corp. (FPC) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will be required to minimize their carbon dioxide emissions to conform to international efforts in controlling the release of greenhouse gases, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Wednesday.

Chen Chao-yi, director of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, made the remarks after local environmental protection groups had asked that the two projects -- one for a steel plant and another for a petrochemical plant -- be scrapped.
The projects were approved by the ministry ahead of Wednesday's implementation of the Kyoto Protocol, an international agreement to cut back on the emission of greenhouse gases.
Chen said the ministry is very concerned about the problem of greenhouse gas emissions and held serious discussions before approving the projects.

It was determined during the National Energy Conference in 1998 that the hi-tech sector will be the backbone of Taiwan's industries and that basic industries such as steel and petrochemical industries will be mainly for domestic demand, Chen pointed out.
The Environmental Protection Administration will require the FPC and CPC to minimize their carbon dioxide emissions while conducting environmental impact assessments for the two projects, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SUPPORTS TAIPEI 2009 DEAFLYMPIC GAMES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The government will support wholeheartedly the Taipei 2009 Deaflympic Games, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday.

Receiving members of the Taiwan delegation to the Melbourne 2005 Deaflympic Games at the Presidential Office, Chen said that he instructed the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports to extend necessary assistances to the organizing committee of the event.
The government's support, financially and administratively, will definitely satisfy all concerned bodies, he pledged.

Chen praised Taiwan's deaf athletes for their outstanding performances in the Melbourne Games by winning nine gold, four silver and three bronze medals and upgrading the country's global ranking to fifth from 24th recorded in the previous Games.
The deaf athletes' performances have not only upgraded Taiwan's status in the international community but also contributed to the promotion of the country's international exchanges, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANUFACTURERS MUST CUT GREENHOUSE GASES: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Domestic manufacturers should adopt new production procedures that emit less greenhouse gases, a move geared to respond to the spirit of the Kyoto Protocol, which came into force Wednesday, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Wednesday.

Ho made the remarks after environmentalists voiced concern that Taiwan's recently approved petrochemical investment projects may produce large amounts of carbon dioxide, a kind of greenhouse gas believed to cause global warming.

The minister noted that before approving the large investment projects presented by Formosa Plastics Group and state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. to construct a naphtha cracker plant, a steel refinery and a petrochemical complex, the ministry reached agreement with the companies for them to adopt the finest production procedures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
In addition, the ministry also asked them to present energy-saving projects, Ho added.
Noting that the production of steel necessarily produces carbon dioxide, Ho stressed that Taiwan will do what it can to reduce this output to its lowest level possible.
The process of adopting new production procedures and eliminating those factories with low energy efficiency will have a positive impact on the reduction of global greenhouse gas emissions, Ho said.

As to the opinions of environmentalists, Ho said, "We can have more communication with them, but investors ought to be given the chance to fully explain their projects given that no other country prohibits new investment projects simply because of the Kyoto Protocol."
The U.N.-initiated Kyoto Protocol, of which Taiwan is not a signatory, requires industrialized countries to reduce greenhouse gases on average to 5.2 percent below 1990 levels by 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS IMMEDIATE STEPS TO CURB CRIME

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh directed relevant government agencies Wednesday to work out more effective crime-fighting measures within a week.
Hsieh gave the directive at his first formal Cabinet meeting since assuming office Feb. 1.
The premier said the Ministry of the Interior, which oversees the National Police Administration, and all city and county governments must work together to increase the number of police officers.
According to the government's 2005 budget, Hsieh said, the nation should have 72,423 police officers.
"But at the moment, we have only slightly more than 68,500. The interior ministry and local governments should immediately recruit more police officers to reduce the crime rate," Hsieh said.

With a view to enhancing police authorities' criminal investigative and preventive capabilities, Hsieh said the ratio of detectives in the forces should be raised from the current 10 percent to 12 percent.
Moreover, Hsieh said equipment should be upgraded where possible and the police presence in residential communities should also be increased.
Relevant government agencies should also study the feasibility of adjusting police ranks to boost police officers' morale and dignity, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOU SHENG-MAO TO BE NEW HEALTH MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh approved Hou Sheng-mao's appointment Wednesday as minister of the Department of Health (DOH), Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said.
Cho noted that Hou, a former DOH deputy minister, obtained Hsieh's approval due to his excellent views on the problems of the country's national health insurance.
According to Cho, Hou will be sworn in together with other vice ministers Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTALISTS PROTEST U.S. FOR NOT SIGNING KYOTO PROTOCOL

TEXT.P: Several environmental groups protested in front of American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT) Taipei office Wednesday because of the Bush administration's refusal to sign the Kyoto Protocol, which requires most signatory nations to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
The groups, including the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union (TEPU), presented ironic dramas describing Bush as being "responsible for global warming."
TEPU Chairwoman Chen Shu-hua noted that the United States' carbon dioxide emissions account for 36 percent of the world's total, No. 1 in the world.
However, she added, even though it is responsible for the escalation of global warming, the Bush administration refused to sign the Kyoto Protocol for the sake of the country's economic interests.
Chen urged the U.S. to assume its duty as world leader and implement the regulations of the protocol.

She also urged the Taiwan government not to follow the incorrect path taken by the United States and continue developing industries that pollute. Taiwan must also not import poorly designed nuclear power generating equipment from the U.S.
Judging from the current increase of Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions, the output of this greenhouse gas from the island in 2010 will be four times that of the 1990 level, Chen added.
The U.N.-initiated Kyoto Protocol requires industrialized countries to reduce greenhouse gases to an average of 5.2 percent below 1990 levels by 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA WAIVER BY JAPAN FOR TAIWANESE LAUDED BY FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs welcomes Japan's decision to waive the visas requirement for Taiwan tourists, and hopes the temporary measure will become permanent.

An ministry official said the measures approved by the Japanese House of Councilors, or the upper house of the Diet, on Feb. 8 will boost exchanges between the two countries and will benefit both sides.

Under this measure, Taiwan tourists will be allowed into Japan without a visa for a maximum of 90 days between March 25 and Sept. 30, which is timed to coincide with the Aichi World Expo to be held in Aichi Prefecture in central Japan from March 25 to Sept. 25.

Since Taiwan has been offering Japanese tourists visa-free entry for the past three years, the official said the ministry hope Japan will reciprocate Taiwan's goodwill by making this temporary measure a permanent one after Sept. 25. (Maubo Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR GIANT UMC SEARCHED BY PROSECUTORS

TEXT.P: More than 80 investigators led by two prosecutors from the Hsinchu District Court searched the semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp.'s (UMC) Hsinchu headquarters and its Taipei office Tuesday amid allegations that the company has invested in a wafer foundry in Suzhou, eastern China.
Also searched Tuesday were four venture capital companies and a public accountant's office.
The investigators seized a number of documents and account books for further investigation.
A former UMC senior executive, Hsu Chien-hua, who is now chairman of the Hejian Technology in Suzhou after resigned from the UMC, was also called in by prosecutors for questioning Tuesday.
UMC had no comment on investigations Wednesday.
A spokesman for the company answered journalists' questions by saying that Hsu is no longer a UMC employee and the company is in no position to make any comment.

As the second-largest semiconductor manufacturer in Taiwan, UMC has long been reported to be investing in Hejian without the authorities' approval, and the fact that 24 former UMC senior executives were recruited by Hechien en masse gave the speculations some substance but UMC has denied any direct investment in Hejian.
Taiwan authorities have warned UMC that it would be punished severely if it jumps the gun and invests in the mainland without the approval of the government.
Investigators are said to be mulling the necessity to question UMC Chairman Robert Tsao.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS POLICE TO FILL IN VACANCIES IMMEDIATELY

TEXT.P: The police force, which has been under strength, should fill in all vacancies immediately, according to a directive from Premier Frank Hsieh Wednesday.

After learning that the police force is 3,800 persons under its designated strength, the premier told the country's police chief in a Cabinet meeting that the shortage in forces should be eliminated as soon as possible.
The launch of the five-day workweek bears part of blame for the shortage as the average working hours of police have been decreased by one-sixth.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 17, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:

1989: Leaders of Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, Lybia and Mauritania sign a treaty to form the North African Common Market.
1992: The Republic of China Ministry of National Defense publishes its first white paper on national defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S MILITARY BUILDUP COULD TILT CROSS-STRAIT BALANCE: CIA HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's continuous military buildup and modernization could tilt the strategic balance across the Taiwan Strait and also threaten U.S. forces in Asia, CIA Director Porter Goss warned Wednesday.
Goss made the remarks at a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing to assess the main security threats to the United States.
The CIA chief said that Beijing has significantly increased the number of its missiles aimed at Taiwan and has commissioned several brand new submarines over the last year.
In addition to beefing up its conventional military capability, Beijing has stepping up efforts to develop "robust, survivable nuclear armed missiles," he pointed out.
Goss also noted that Taiwan has continued to strengthen its own national identity in various ways, including pushing for constitutional reform, which Beijing has seen as moves toward independence.
"If Beijing decides that Taiwan is taking steps towards permanent separation that exceeds Beijing's tolerance, we assess China is prepared to respond with varying levels of force," he added.

"China is increasingly confident and active on the international stage, " Goss said, adding that Beijing is "trying to ensure that it has a voice on international issues and secures access to natural resources and to counter what it sees as Untied States' efforts to contain or encircle it."

Muslim members of the House of Representatives remained hopeful yesterday about the chances of a ceasefire in Sulu despite the series of city bombings that were allegedly staged by the Abu Sayyaf Group.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: 11,000 jobs to fill at March fair.
Singapore's biggest job fair next month will showcase 11,000 openings, reflecting how last year's robust economic growth rate has translated into good news for the 71,000 or so people in the market for work.
While the posts available range from bartenders to fund managers, the majority of the openings are for engineers.
The number of positions offered at the coming Career 2005 fair is 10 per cent higher than what was available last year, said Ms Dilys Yong, the chief of the event's organiser, HQ Link.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Singapore, Indonesia sign Investment Guarantee Agreement.
Singapore and Indonesia signed Investment Guarantee Agreement (IGA) yesterday, paving the way for business to invest with legal protection.
The IGA including Most Favored Nation, free to transfer fund, land levying, and compensation issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE REPS CALL FOR RESTORATION OF DIPLOMATIC TIES WITH ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A resolution was introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives Wednesday calling for the Bush administration to scrap its "one China" policy and resume formal diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

In presenting the bill, Rep. Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.) , leading author of the bipartisan resolution, said that the "one China" policy, in which Washington recognizes Beijing's stance that Taiwan is a part of China, is fiction.
"Taiwan is a free, sovereign and independent country that elects its own leaders. It is not, nor has it ever been a local government of communist China -- and everyone knows that," Tancredo said.
He asserted that the time has come "to scrap this intellectually dishonest and antiquated policy in favor of a little consistency and honesty."

"There is absolutely no good reason that the United States cannot maintain the same kind of normal relationship with the democratically elected government in Taiwan that it maintains with the autocratic regime in Beijing," Tancredo continued.

He stressed that when then U.S. President Jimmy Carter decided to sever formal ties with Taiwan and shift U.S. recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979, Carter did not consult with Congress in advance, let alone seek its approval.
Tancredo noted that despite Carter's unilateral decision to cut diplomatic relations with Taiwan, the island has remained a staunch and reliable ally of the United States.
The bipartisan resolution was jointly introduced by Tancredo and four other lawmakers, including Rep. Ileana Rose-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) , chairman of the House International Relations Subcommittee.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT TAIPEI CHIEF PAYS COURTESY CALL ON NEW DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), paid a visit to new ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang Thursday and exchanged views on a variety of issues.
It marked the de facto U.S. ambassador's first visit to DPP headquarters since Su took over the ruling party's helm earlier this week.

Su said after their hour-long, closed-door meeting that he had spoken with Paal on a range of topics, including his plan to visit the United States, Taiwan's arms procurement and Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law."
Saying that the United States is Taiwan's best friend, Su said the DPP attaches great importance to Taiwan-U.S. relations.
"We keenly hope to forge extensive ties with various U.S. social quarters and maintain smooth bilateral communications channels, " Su said.

During their talk, Su mentioned that the DPP has come up with a comprehensive plan to promote party-to-party diplomacy. "Paal welcomed our plan, " Su said, adding that senior DPP officials, including himself, will travel abroad to foster friendship and cooperative programs with major foreign political parties.
Asked whether Paal had any message from U.S. authorities, Su said only that they discussed matters of mutual concern and had common views.
Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim, who concurrently heads the DPP's international affairs department, said DPP chairmen have traditionally been welcomed to visit the United States.

With two important elections to be held this year -- elections for mission-oriented National Assembly members in May and elections for city mayors and county magistrates in November or December, Hsiao said it is unclear when Su might travel to the U.S., but that it was likely to be in the second half of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAISING WATER, ELECTRICITY RATES STILL ON BACK BURNER: MOEA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh tried Thursday to explain remarks made a day earlier by the premier regarding hikes in water and electricity rates by saying that any move in that direction would depend on various factors.

Premier Frank Hsieh had said that electricity and water rates should not be increased if bank interest rates are lower than inflation levels. Ho said that as far as she knows, Hsieh did not mean that key utility rates would never be raised, only that talks on the issue have been postponed.
As to how long such talks should be delayed, Ho said, "It all depends on the overall economic situation at home as well as how well the utility suppliers are doing financially."
It would not be acceptable to allow the Taiwan Power Company to go bankrupt because it could not raise rates, she added.

Ho has in the past made clear her intention to raise rates. She said on Dec. 29 that electricity rates will be raised by no more than NT$0.5 per unit, or one kilowatt/hour, given that Taiwan's electricity costs NT$2.07 per unit on average, which is far less than Japan's NT$4.8, Hong Kong's NT$3.74 and even the Philippines' NT$3.56.

For the same reason, she said, the price of water should also be raised, arguing that Taiwan's water rates, now NT$10.77 per ton, are unreasonably cheap compared to NT$62.7 per ton in Germany, NT$56.7 per ton in Denmark, NT$17.5 per ton in the United States, NT$14.4 per ton in Canada, and between NT$17 to NT$44 per ton in Hong Kong.
Besides, Ho argued, Taiwan's water rates have remained unchanged for 10 years. A rate hike would also discourage users from wasting water, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP AIDES WILL MEET TO WORK OUT DETAILS FOR CHEN-SOONG MEETING

TEXT.P: Top aides of President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong are scheduled to meet Friday to finalize technical matters pertaining to the much-anticipated Chen-Soong meeting.

President Chen's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, will meet with PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng at the Taipei Guest House, a government-owned estate located near the Presidential Office, to flesh out details, including the date, venue and format as well as agenda of the meeting.
Yu and Chin are expected to give a news conference after their meeting.

Lai Ching-teh, a party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said recently that the DPP looks forward to seeing the upcoming Chen-Soong meeting contribute to the passage of major bills related to people's livelihoods by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, in addition to addressing issues related to cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Meanwhile, Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the PFP will be resolutely firm during the Chen-Soong meeting on the issue that the Republic of China's status as well as position should not be changed under any circumstances.
In addition, Liu noted, all topics, including cross-starit affairs, should be open to discussion during the Chen-Soong meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIWAN STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange dropped Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 71.33 points to close at 6,072.16.
The bourse opened at 6,118.62 and fluctuated between 6,139.65 and 6,072.16 during trading. A total of 3.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$85.28 billion (US$2.69 billion).

All but one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.5 percent; cement issues down 1.4 percent; construction issues down 1.1 percent; both plastics/chemicals stocks and paper issues down 1 percent; and financial stocks down 0.9 percent. Only textile shares posted a 0.1 percent gain.
Losers outnumbered gainers 619 to 223, with 141 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMOTING UNITY IS PURPOSE OF RUNNING FOR KMT CHAIRMAN: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday the purpose of his running for the party's chairmanship is to promote party unity.
Ma said he will quit the race if his decision to run causes a split in the party.
Public concerns have been voiced that the competition between Ma and Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, another KMT vice chairman, for the chairmanship may cause the party to fracture.
Ma said it is the common expectations of all KMT members to see reforms take place within the party and that he hopes whoever is chairman will work towards this goal to save the party.

He urged anyone running for the chairmanship to present their respective philosophies to provide party members information on which to base their decision when it comes time to choose their future leader.
Ma said he believes this competition will make the KMT more united than before.
Agreeing with Ma, Wang said every KMT member has a responsibility to unite the "pan-blue alliance" of the People First Party and the KMT to boost the KMT's development.

Wang would not speculate as to whether KMT Chairman Lien Chan plans to run for re-election, and he said issues concerning the chairmanship election were not mentioned during his conversation with Lien over the phone on Wednesday.
Lien, who is currently on a trip in Europe, has not specified if he will seek re-election. Ma had previously said that Lien has no intention of continuing at the post.
Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao, who is a supporter of Wang, confirmed that Ma had called him to explain why he was running for the KMT chairmanship.
However, Lee said he does not think Ma is a suitable candidate for the position.

Lee said Ma and Wang should play different roles within the party and complement each other, and he suggested that the two meet in private to exchange their views on the future development of the KMT.
Disagreeing with Lee, pro-Ma KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng said no one is in a position to judge who is suitable and who is not to become the party leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: FO GUANG SHAN FOUNDATION SIGNS PACT WITH HK UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Buddhist Master Hsing Yun, founder of the Fo Guang Shan Foundation for Buddhist Culture and Education, signed a cooperation agreement Thursday with Daniel P.L. Law, dean of the Faculty of Arts at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, at Fo Guang Shan Temple, Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.
Under the pact, the foundation will help the Hong Kong university to set up a Buddhism research center.
The cooperation will start from March 2005 and run to February 2010, with the foundation sponsoring HK$1.2 million each year to help the university promote the study of Buddhism.

Master Hsing Yun noted that the establishment of a Buddhism research center in the Chinese University of Hong Kong represents a big step forward in world cultural exchanges and a milestone in the study of Buddhism.

Chuo Chun-ying, deputy director of the Public Affairs Department at the Presidential Office, who is also an alumna of the Hong Kong university, said it would be good if the Fo Guang Shan Foundation set up more Buddhism research centers in other prominent schools around the world as a way to promote international cultural exchanges.
Present at the signing ceremony were academics and cultural leaders from Hong Kong and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN CANADA CELEBRATES LUNAR NEW YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 16 (CNA) (By Wu Hsien-kuang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada and the National Press Club of Canada jointly held a Taiwan theme night in Ottawa on Tuesday to celebrate Chinese Lunar New Year.
The annual event, which was held at the press club in past years, took place for the first time this year in a banquet hall on Parliament Hill.
It was attended by more than 200 people including Republic of China representative to Canada Thomas Tung-pi Chen, Canadian parliamentarians and diplomats.
In addition to a one-man drama presented by a Taiwanese graduate student in Toronto, there were also musical performances by Taiwanese expatriates in Canada.

University of Ottawa associate professor Scott Simon and senior Canadian strategic analyst Robert Henderson were invited to give speeches on the political situation after Taiwan's legislative elections and international relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-GUATEMALA TIES REMAIN SECURE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Guatemala are unchanged and steadfast, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.
Lu was responding to reports that Guatemalan Minister of Economic Affairs Marcio Cuevas will head a delegation to visit mainland China in March.

Quoting a report from the ROC Embassy in Guatemala, Lu said Cuevas faces pressure from the Guatemalan business community to resolve the country's huge trade deficit with mainland China. As a result, Lu said, Cuevas decided to head a delegation of business and industry executives to visit the mainland.
Lu said Cuevas has assured the ROC government that he will visit the mainland in a private capacity and focus talks with mainland officials on trade issues.

"Cuevas has assured us that his mainland visit will absolutely not affect Guatemalan relations with Taiwan, " Lu said, adding that Cuevas has promised to brief the ROC Embassy in Guatemala City on his mainland visit after his return.

Lu said the ROC government has consistently attached great importance to interaction with the nation's diplomatic allies in Latin America, including Guatemala. In addition to carrying out various cooperative projects, Lu said, senior government officials have made regular visits to those countries. Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to make an official visit to Guatemala in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING OPPORTUNITY FOR NATIONAL UNITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday his upcoming meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will create a fresh opportunity for national unity, reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties.
Chen made the remarks during a Chinese Lunar New Year gathering with members of six local industrial and commercial organizations.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng is scheduled to meet Friday to discuss details of the Chen-Soong meeting, such as its date, venue, format and agenda.
On the choice for vice premier, Chen said Premier Frank Hsieh is targeting a candidate with an international perspective who is good at communication, coordination and economics.
Meanwhile, Chen said the fall of the stock market is only a temporary phenomenon and does not represent any problem with the economy.
The weighted index slipped 71.33 points to close at 6,072.16 on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March lost 50 points to close at 6,078, with 31,930 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved down 87 points to finish at 6,071, with 116 contracts traded, while June futures lost 69 points to finish at 6,056, with 12 contracts traded.
September futures lost 66 points to finish at 6,001, with 17 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 27 points to close at 6,000, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,128 for March, 6,158 for April, 6,125 for June, 6,067 for September and 5,973 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

March TE futures moved down 3.15 points to close at 231.65, with 5,859 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 4.4 points to finish at 232, with 42 contract transactions. September TE futures lost 2.75 points to close at 230.25, with one contract traded, while December TE futures moved down 13.8 points to finish at 223.5, with one contract transaction.

March TF futures lost 6.4 points to finish at 1,011.4, with 4,775 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 10.2 points to end at 1,011.8, with 34 contracts traded. June TF futures lost seven points to finish at 1,008, with one contract changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 1.6 points to close at 1,011, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, giving up NT$0.006 to close at NT$31.563.
US$454 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.602 and slid to a low of NT31.530 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Greenspan Backs Idea of Accounts for Retirement
Alan Greenspan, the U.S. Federal Reserve chairman, gave his blessing on Wednesday to the creation of individual investment accounts in Social Security but expressed unease that the change could lead to trillions of dollars in additional government borrowing in the next few decades.
Wall Street Journal: Tsunami Lending in Sri Lanka, Loans Take On Key Role In Disaster Relief
Though the world has pledged more than a US$1 billion to help Sri Lanka care for its tsunami victims, but the relief cash has been too slow to reach those who need them to rebuild their lives. Many survivors are going into debt as much of the roughly US$1.1 billion pledged internationally for Sri Lanka still hasn't arrived, and of what has, only a small portion has made it to victims so far, according to local aid officials. The reasons include bureaucratic snafus and political wrangling. Aid workers note that government officials are even impounding some donated supplies for fear they could be delivered to insurgents such as the Tamil Tigers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Nuclear audit says Sellafield has 'lost' 30kg of plutonium.
Sellafield, Britain's major nuclear site, has"lost"30 kilograms of plutonium, according to figures due to be published today. The annual audit of nuclear material at all of Britain's civil nuclear installations is expected to reveal that the plutonium -- enough for seven or eight nuclear bombs -- was classified as"material unaccounted for"last year. Financial Times: Birt joins call to share BBC cash.
Plans for the future funding of the BBC were mired in controversy on Wednesday night after Lord Birt, the prime minister's "blue skies thinker", backed a proposal to give rival broadcasters a claim on some of its licence-fee cash.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: War Helps Recruit Terrorists, Hill Told; Intelligence Officials Talk Of Growing Insurgency.
The insurgency in Iraq continues to baffle the U.S. military and intelligence communities, and the U.S. occupation has become a potent recruiting tool for al Qaeda and other terrorist groups, top U.S. national security officials told Congress yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA GRATEFUL FOR U.S. LAWMAKERS' PROPOSAL FOR TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official expressed gratitude Thursday for a motion presented by several U.S. congressmen calling for the restoration of diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Victor J. Chin, director of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, made the remarks after several members from the U.S. House of Representatives presented a proposal a day earlier urging the Bush administration to abandon its "one China" policy and resume official ties with Taiwan.

Rep. Tom Tancreado (R-Colo.) , who led the bipartisan proposal, said he sees "no reason" why the U.S. government cannot normalize its ties with Taiwan while maintaining diplomatic relations with Beijing.

Chin noted that the proposal has been made before in the U.S. Congress and expressed hope that Taiwan will gain the joint support of both the executive and legislative branches in the United States to carry out the plan.

In addition, Chin added that the ministry has also noticed the concern expressed by several U.S. congressmen regarding Beijing's proposed so-called "anti-secession law, " which could provide the legal groundwork for military action against Taiwan.
Chin said the congressmen are worried that the law might have a negative impact on the stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO HOLD SEMINAR ON CHINA'S 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will hold a seminar on Friday to discuss mainland China's plan to enact an "anti-secession law."

During the seminar, former president and TSU spiritual leader Lee Teng-hui is expected to call for unity by all Taiwanese people against the legislation and push the government to work out countermeasures.

According to TSU officials, although the legislation is only a domestic law of the mainland, Beijing may pressure its diplomatic allies to support the law to step up its diplomatic suppression of Taiwan.

Under these circumstances, overseas Taiwanese who support the cause of changing the country's official name and rewriting the Constitution may face the risk of being extradited to the mainland for trial, they said.
The TSU is planning to push for a piece of legislation to counteract the "anti-secession law" during this legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DIPLOMATS TO ATTEND SKY LANTERN FESTIVAL: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will invite foreign ambassadors and envoys stationed in Taipei to pray for world peace in a traditional Taiwan folk activity Saturday, a spokesman said Thursday.

According to the MOFA official, foreign ambassadors and representatives, including those from various countries that were hit by the Dec. 26 earthquake and ensuing tsunami, will be invited to participate in the "sky lantern lighting" activity to be held Saturday night in Pingshi township, Taipei County, to pray for world peace.

Attending foreign diplomats will sign their names with calligraphy brushes on five huge lanterns that will be lit and allowed to rise into the sky, hot air balloon-style, in a gesture to appeal for world peace, the official said.

The activity should help them gain a better understanding of Taiwan's traditions and lifestyles and offer them an opportunity to spread love, care and compassion to the rest of the world jointly with the Taiwan people, he said.
The activity is also meant to thank the many anonymous donors who contributed to the tsunami refugees in Southeast Asia and South Asia, he added.
The Taiwan government and private sector contributed more than NT$2 billion (US$63.5 million) and 3.55 million tons of relief materials to various affected countries in the region, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO NAME ECONOMIST AS VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh is set to name Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, as his vice premier Friday in light of the fact that his attempt to recruit opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang was rebuffed.
Anonymous sources close to the premier said Hsieh has promised to wait for Chiang's decision until Friday, but Chiang made his intentions clear when he left for the United States Tuesday.
The sources said Hsieh decided to ask Wu to join his Cabinet as vice premier Tuesday evening and was greeted with a positive response.

The premier told journalists that his choice for the post of vice premier should be a person with training in finance and economics, familiar with international affairs, capable of managing the country's overall economic aspects, good at coordinating the work of various government units and preferably not a member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
As a U.S.-educated economist, Wu meets all the requirements and has long been an important economic advisor to the administration of President Chen Shui-bian.

Wu scrapped a plan to go on an overseas trip at the last minute Thursday, apparently for the purpose of attending a Friday morning news conference at which the premier is expected to announce Wu's appointment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARINES TO JOIN CAPITAL DEFENSES: MND

TEXT.P: A brigade of marines will be posted in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei from March as part of the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) plan to reinforce defenses in the greater Taipei area to counter any possible "decapitation" strategy adopted by mainland China against Taiwan, MND sources said Thursday.

Decapitation strategies short-circuit command and control systems, wipe out nationwide nerve centers and leave the opponent hopelessly lost. Many military observers say the mainland is very likely to use this strategy to invade Taiwan by seizing the island's center of power, the capital and its top leaders.

Against this backdrop, MND sources said, defenses in the greater Taipei area will be greatly beefed up. The marines to be stationed in Linkou from March will be armed with portable air-defense missiles, minesweeping helicopters and other rapid response weapons.

In addition, military police forces in Taipei's suburban Tachih district will also be augmented in April by adding an artillery regiment and an armored brigade that will be equipped with 120 mm mortars, anti-tank rockets and Avenger air-defense missiles. In the future, the military police unit will also purchase locally developed "Clouded Leopard" eight-wheeled armored vehicles.

Meanwhile, the sources said, the army division stationed in the Kuantu-Tamsui area on the outskirts of metropolitan Taipei will also be reinforced. Once the MND's three massive arms procurement projects clear the legislature, the missile command in Taipei County's Taishan township will be equipped with advanced Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries.

The navy is also planning to deploy fast warships at the newly built Taipei Port, the sources said, adding that once the military's current troops restructuring project is completed, defenses in the greater Taipei area will be heavily fortified.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK SETS NEW HIGH IN OUTPUT VALUE FOR 2004

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park set a new high in output value of NT$1.859 trillion (US$59 billion) for 2004, up by 27 percent over the previous year's level, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration reported Thursday.

Despite the fact that many economic forecasting agencies have predicted that the world economy is set to slow this year, administration officials are optimistic that the figure will further go up by more than 10 percent for 2005.

The semiconductor, computer and peripherals, telecommunications, opto-electronics, precision machinery and bio-tech industries were the major driving force behind the park's all-time high productivity, with the semiconductor sector contributing the largest portion of its total production value of NT$744.1 billion, or 69 percent.

In terms of the ratio of output value, the semiconductor industry was followed by the computer and peripherals sector with 12.7 percent, the opto-electronics industry with 12.1 percent, the telecommunications industry with 5.6 percent and the precision machinery industry and biotechnology industry with 0.9 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively.

In terms of revenue growth rate, the precision machinery industry increased the most by 60 percent over the 2003 level to NT$9.2 billion, followed by 39 percent for the opto-electronics and the biotech industries, with output values of NT$131.3 billion and NT$2.5 billion, respectively. The telecom and computer industries expanded by 10 percent and 3 percent, respectively, to hit NT$60.5 billion and NT$138.2 billion.

Meanwhile, mainland China, replacing Hong Kong, became for the first time the park's No. 1 export outlet last year, accounting for about 20 percent of outbound shipments and registering a growth rate of 52 percent year on year.
Hong Kong, Japan, the United States and South Korea came after in that order, while Japan, the United States, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea were the leading five import sources for the park.
As of the end of last year, a total of 115,477 workers were employed by 384 companies operating in the park, up by 13 percent and 4 percent, respectively, compared to the level of a year ago.

It marks an average per-capita production value of NT$9.4 million for the park in 2004, with each worker in the semiconductor sector posting the highest level of NT$111.9 million, ahead of NT$96.9 million in the computer and peripherals industry, NT$83.4 million in the telecom industry, NT$60.5 million in the precision machinery industry, NT$52.6 million in the opto-electronics industry and NT$24.8 million in the biotech sector.

The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan, set up in 1979, is the country's oldest and the most representative of its kind in Taiwan. Its success serves as a text book model for many countries keen to build similar compounds to house high-tech businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS PLAY DOWN IMPACT FROM INVESTIGATION OF UMC

TEXT.P: Several business leaders in Taiwan said Thursday that they believe an investigation into a local semiconductor giant's alleged ilegal investments in mainland China will not affect Taiwanese businessmen's willingness to invest there.

Leaders of major Taiwan business groups, including the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises of the Republic of China, made the remarks one day after law enforcement agencies started to investigate alleged illegal transactions as well as capital and technology transfers between United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) and HeJian Technology in Suzhou, mainland China, a wafer foundry believed to have received investment from UMC without the approval of the Taiwan government.

Day Sheng-tung, chairman of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, said the issue is not expected to affect Taiwanese investments there and that the investigation should be considered an economic affair rather than a political one.

He said the government's regulations regarding Taiwan companies' direct investment in the mainland China or Hong Kong are quite relaxed and that local businessmen already consider Taiwan, the mainland and Hong Kong as investment targets rather than political entities.

Meanwhile, Huang Mao-hsiung, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, expressed hope that the investigation will not cause any negative impact on Taiwanese investment in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE TOURISTS VISIT KINMEN; MINI LINKS URGED TO BE OPENED WIDER

TEXT.P: A group of Japanese tourists arrived Thursday on the outlying island of Kinmen for a two-day visit, part of a four-day Taipei-Kinmen tour organized by a travel agency based in Osaka.

The Japanese tourists, mainly middle-aged women, were met warmly by the Kinmen tourism authorities and local people. Kinmen County Tourism Bureau chief Lin Chen-chia gave a gift bag to each of the Japanese visitors.

Although most of the Japanese visitors said they did not know much about the Taiwan-controlled island, they said they most wanted view nearby mainland China's Xiamen from Kinmen and drink the special Kinmen kaoliang liquor after learning something of the island's history.
The Kinmen County Tourism Bureau and the council organized a delegation that visited Tokyo, Osaka and Fukuoka last August as part of efforts to attract foreign visitors.

Saying that the Kinmen county authorities have been trying hard to push the island on to the world stage, Lin called on the central government in Taipei to open wider the existing "mini three links, "-- direct trade and transport services maintained between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and the mainland ports of Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian Province -- to help serve that end.

According to Lin, Kinmen county is hoping to lure some of the 200,000 foreign visitors that visit Xiamen each year to travel to Kinmen via the mini links. Should foreign tourists visiting Kinmen be further allowed to proceed to Taiwan proper on sightseeing trips, it would also help the government meet its target of doubling the number of tourist arrivals by 2008.

The "mini three links" kicked off in January 2001 to offset the absence of full links between Taiwan proper and the mainland. Direct trade, transport and postal services across the Taiwan Strait have been banned since 1949 after the two sides split in the wake of acivil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC DENIES LINKS WITH HOJIAN TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , a major chip maker in Taiwan, issued a statement Thursday denying any direct or indirect investment in HoJian Technology, located in Suzhou, in mainland China's Jiangsu Province.

The statement was issued one day after law enforcement authorities began to investigate UMC's alleged ilegal transactions as well as capital and technology transfers with HoJian Technology, a chip maker believed to have received investment from UMC without the approval of the Taiwan government.
The UMC statement denied any personnel exchanges with HoJian, and said that no UMC executives have ever, directly or indirectly, invested in the mainland company.
The statement said UMC and companies associated with the group are all enterprises with independent operations. They have never assigned anyone in the group to work in HoJian.
However, the statement added that the company has no idea whether any former UMC employee has worked for HoJian.

UMC said in the statement that the company has not sold any machinery to HoJian, not has it transferred technology to HoJian, and said it would bring a lawsuit against any semiconductor firm that violates UMC patent rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON TO BE ACCORDED RED-CARPET WELCOME: MOFA

TEXT.P: The government will accord former U.S. President Bill Clinton a red-carpet welcome when he visits Taiwan later this month, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Victor J. Chin, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, told a news conference that in recognition of Clinton's contributions to the promotion of substantive Taiwan-U.S. relations during his presidency, particularly his decision to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to patrol waters near Taiwan during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, the government will accord Clinton courteous treatment "near the level" offered to a sitting head of state.

"We'll offer him the maximum grade of security protection. The only difference from his treatment to that of a sitting head of state will be the absence of military honors and a 21-gun salute because the United States does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, " Chin explained.
Asked whether Clinton will meet with senior Taiwan officials and opposition leaders, Chin said Clinton's itinerary has yet to be finalized.
Out of respect for Taiwan, Chin said, Clinton is expected to meet with President Chen Shui-bian during his brief visit.

Since Clinton ended his eight-year tenure, he has traveled around the globe delivering speeches for staggering fees. Chin acknowledged that a local private organization will pay the bill for Clinton's speech in Taiwan.

According to Chin, the fee will be "reasonable" and will not surprise or impress anybody. As for the exact amount, Chin said the MOFA is not in a position to divulge such information out of regard for general international practice and a tacit understanding with Clinton.

According to MOFA officials, Clinton is scheduled to deliver a speech on Asian democracy on the evening of Feb. 27 to be sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy and a youth association. Clinton's exact arrival time and details of his local itinerary have not yet been fully fleshed out, the officials said.
"We have been keeping in close contact with Clinton's office and we hope his itinerary can be finalized soon so that we can publicize it," said a MOFA official.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER EXECUTIVE OF TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR GIANT RELEASED ON BAIL

TEXT.P: A former executive of semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) who is at the center of a scandal involving UMC's alleged illegal investment in mainland China, was released on bail of NT$10 million (US$317,088) Thursday.
The prosecutors who asked the court to take Hsu Chien-hua into custody the previous day have yet to decide whether to appeal against the court's decision.

Hsu, who has been working as chairman of HeJian Technology Co. in the mainland city of Suzhou immediately after leaving his job as a senior technician at UMC in 2001, is suspected of being the UMC's representative to HeJian and prosecutors said they have circumstantial evidence of UMC's investment in the mainland chip maker.
Hsu was questioned by prosecutors one day before he was slated to return to Suzhou after spending the Chinese New Year holiday in his home in Taiwan.
The Taiwan authorities restrict hi-tech firms from investing in the mainland without approval.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said the regulations for investment in the mainland are very clear. Local firms may invest there if they follow the regulations, which she claimed do not impose unreasonable restrictions on would-be investors.
However, she then said her office will review the regulations if businessmen feel they are unreasonable.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 18, or the 10th day of first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral, dies in Rome at the age of 89.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, a US astronomer, is the first to see Pluto, realizing it is the Sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" (Manchuria) proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the US House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1960: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay agree to establish the Latin American Free Trade Association.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1972: The Supreme Court of California abolishes the death penalty.
1974: Jorge Cervantes-Pinzon, outgoing charge d'affaires from Colombia, leaves Taipei for home.
1976: C.C. Yang, ROC economic affairs vice minister, and S.M. Osman, secretary-general of the Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organization, sign an agreement on technical cooperation.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1991: The US assault ship Tripoli and the guided missile cruiser Princeton are damaged by mines in the Persian Gulf during the Gulf War.
1992: A delegation from the US President's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote bilateral trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
1998: Mya Than Tint, one of Burma's most renowned and admired writers, dies at the age of 69.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (the Chinese equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if he is proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of his mind."
