DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO PUSH FOR CONSISTENCY IN ECONOMIC POLICY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that there should be consistency in the country's overall economic policy in order to help the administration forge ahead with various development projects with the private sector coping with it smoothly.

Addressing a breakfast meeting with leaders from six major industrial and business groups, Hsieh noted that he will see to it that major economic and development projects that were implemented or planned during Yu Shyi-kun's term as premier will be continued.
On the prospects of Taiwan's economic development in the future, Hsieh said that he thinks "political variables" could be major factors that may interrupt normal development.

Hsieh, who just appointed an economist to be his deputy to reflect his determination in reforming and propping up Taiwan's economic and industrial progress, also said that he will push for a more dynamic tax regime requiring all individuals and businesses to pay at least some tax.

Noting that minimum taxation levels may be worked out in the near future, Hsieh, who took office Feb. 1, explained that this is an attempt to broaden the base for the government to levy taxes and increase revenues.

Meanwhile, reiterating his administration's "healthy Taiwan" motto, Hsieh called for support from the business and industrial sectors for the government's plans to raise the top bracket of the national health insurance premiums based on a person's monthly salary, from the current NT$87,600 to NT$130,000, in an attempt to avoid increasing premiums for those in the lower brackets while saving the debt-ridden system from bankruptcy.

Noting that he himself will be affected by the higher-bracket initiative, Hsieh appealed to the industrial and business leaders to support the plan based on a sense of social justice, saying that individuals with higher incomes should pay more to help sustain the cash-trapped national health insurance program.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ADMINISTRATION URGED TO STRONGLY OPPOSE ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Several members of the U.S. House of Representatives introduced a motion Thursday calling for the Bush administration to voice strong opposition to China's proposed anti-secession law.

The motion came one day after a bipartisan resolution was introduced into the House by five legislators, including Rep. Tom Tancredo (R.-Colo.) and Rep. Ileana Rose-Lehtinen (R-Fla.), demanding that the Bush administration scrap its "one China policy" and resume diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

The motion, which was introduced with Rep. Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), co-chairman of the pro-Taiwan U.S. congressional Taiwan Caucus, as the lead author, said that the Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress agreed Dec. 29 last year to place the anti-secession bill on the agenda for the congress' plenary meeting set to open March 5 this year.

Claiming that enacting the law will unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, which goes against the United States' longstanding cross-strait policy, the motion called for the U.S. administration to express fierce opposition to the proposed law.

President Chen Shui-bian reiterated in his inauguration speech for a second term and his Double Tenth National Day speech last year Taiwan's determination to maintain peace, stability and the current cross-strait status quo, the motion also said.

The motion added that the agreement reached by representatives from the two sides of the strait Jan. 15 on direct cross-strait charter flights during the Lunar New Year holidays ought to establish a foundation for the development of normalization of relations and the resumption of dialogue between the two sides of the strait.

Noting that the United States' Taiwan Relations Act, which was enacted in 1979, is an efficient instrument for maintaining peace, security and stability in the Taiwan Strait, the motion said that according to the act, any actions to decide Taiwan's future that are not peaceful and do not have the consent of the Taiwan people would cause serious concern for the United States.
The motion also requested that the U.S. government continue to encourage Taipei and Beijing to engage in a dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OPEN TO CROSS-STRAIT 'TWO-WAY, NON-STOP' CARGO FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) does not exclude the possibility of opening "two-way, non-stop, multi-spot" cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-shan said Friday.

Speaking at a hearing at the Legislative Yuan sponsored by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hung Chi-chang calling for a pragmatic policy to accelerate steps toward realization of cross-strait cargo flights, Chiu said that so long as the carriers and the mainland-based Taiwanese businesspeople submit concrete data indicating their needs, the government will spare no efforts to facilitate implementation of related programs.

Chiu's remarks were a follow-up to President Chen Shui-bian's statement two days earlier saying that he hopes that cross-strait cargo charter flights could be started soon following the success of the special cross-strait Lunar New Year passenger charter flights this year.

Hailing the special Lunar New Year charter flights as a success, Chiu stressed that so long as the private sector can agree on terms with the administration, and the governments of the two sides of the strait can turn "ideas into action, " then progress in the promotion of "two-way, non-stop, multi-spot" cross-strait cargo charter flights can be made easily.

According to a plan unveiled by the MAC in 2003 but never implemented, the cargo charter service would be operated only by Taiwanese carriers, and planes would be required to stop in Hong Kong or Macau en route. However, other arrangements, such as allowing mainland carriers to offer the service and making the charter flights non-stop will have to be made through negotiations between the two sides.

Chiu added that opening cargo charter flights should be a less difficult issue than the opening of passenger charter flights and that the MAC will remain open to talks as well as plans regarding the implementation of cross-strait cargo charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER NAMES DEPUTY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced Friday that Wu Rong-I, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, is his vice premier.
Hsieh, accompanied by Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, and Cho Jung-tai, spokesman for the premier, made the announcement at a press conference in front of the Executive Yuan.

Introducing the newly appointed vice premier, Hsieh said that Wu, who has an economic and finance background, is well aware of the government's policies and administrative work, adding that his new deputy has also been an economic advisor to President Chen Shui-bian and various governmental institutions and agencies.
The premier also said that the new vice premier, who he described as "a man of international vision, " is also a man with coordinating and advisory abilities.
Hsieh had originally sought to appoint P.K. Chiang, a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, but his overtures were rebuffed.

Saying that he will rely on Wu to integrate and coordinate the nation's economic and financial policies, the premier added that Wu, who has good relations with the industrial and business sectors, will have his full support in putting the government's policies into practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW VICE PREMIER URGED TO HELP MAKE TAIWAN A BETTER PLACE

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Vice Premier Wu Rong-i was urged Friday to help improve the quality of life in Taiwan and make the nation a better place in which to live.
Wu, a Belgium-trained economist who has been president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research for several years, was formally appointed by Premier Frank Hsieh as his deputy that day.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank, who has been a close friend of Wu for 20 years, urged Wu to help forge ahead with the existing administrative policies, to help hammer out detailed plans to facilitate implementation of the Ten New National Development Projects, and to help upgrade Taiwan's quality of life.

Chen, who has also served as chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said he hopes the new Cabinet under Hsieh's leadership will not see frequent policy turnarounds.
The Ten New National Development Projects, which Chen described as goals the government must achieve, needs more elaborate planning before they can be implemented, Chen said.

Noting that both Hsieh and Wu have made great contributions to efforts aimed at improving the environment around Taiwan, Chen called for Wu to help make further efforts to raise the quality of life as a top priority of the new administrative team.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING TO DISCUSS CROSS-STRAIT, SECURITY, ETHNIC ISSUES

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait peace, defense and security, as well as ethnic amity, will be the main issues on the agenda of a long-awaited meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, officials said Friday.
The agenda was agreed upon by Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng, who were in charge of arranging the technical details of the meeting.
The meeting will take place at the Taipei Guest House but the date of the meeting has yet to be set, according to Yu and Chin.
During the meeting, Chen and Soong will seek consensus on the three issues, on which opinion between the two sides is divided, Yu said.

In the same way that the last Chen-Soong meeting, held four years ago, made possible the economic development conference, the upcoming meeting will create a fresh opportunity for political stability in Taiwan, Yu said.
Yu said both Chen and Soong are determined and sincere about meeting each other and that he will maintain close contact with Chin to hammer out a date for the meeting.

A local daily reported Friday that the PFP would prefer to postpone the meeting until after Feb. 28 in the wake of massive raids launched by prosecutors on United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) over the semiconductor giant's alleged unlicensed investments in mainland China.

While UMC Chairman Robert H.C. Tsao is known to be a close friend of Soong and a supporter of the PFP, there has been speculation that the raids were ordered by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government because of Tsao's affiliation with the PFP.

Chin admitted that some PFP members have demanded that the Chen-Soong meeting be postponed because of the UMC incident, which he said is more destructive than the DPP's decision to scrap the fourth nuclear power plant more than four years ago.

PFP legislative caucus convener Liu Wen-hsiung, who is one of the politicians supporting a postponement of the meeting, said the UMC incident has made the political atmosphere completely improper for such a meeting.
For this reason, Liu said, the caucus canceled a meeting set for later Friday with Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan.

In response, DPP Policy Committee chief Ker Chien-ming urged the PFP not to politicize the case, saying efforts to reconcile the ruling and opposition parties should not be affected by an isolated incident.
Ker said the UMC incident is a judicial case that should be taken care of by the judiciary.

After a prolonged search in which several rebuffed the White House for the job, President Bush turned to Negroponte, a career foreign service officer who has served as delegate to the United Nations and ambassadorh to Iraq. Negroponte was confirmed by the Senate for the earlier jobs in 2001 and 2004 by large margins.
Wall Street Journal: Harvard Clash Pits Entrenched Faculty vs. Brusque Leader Vs. Brusque Leader.
Harvard University's secretive seven-member governing board issued an unusual statement yesterday to stand behind the school's president, Lawrence H. Summers, who has been criticized for a talk he gave at a recent conference on work-force diversification. The board's one-page letter to "the Harvard community" sets the stage for a possible showdown between Summers and his prominent faculty critics, who are moving toward a referendum on his leadership. Hired more than three years ago to retool Harvard for the 21st century, the former treasury secretary has found the hierarchical management style common in corporations and cabinet agencies to be a tough fit for a storied university accustomed to decision making that is decentralized and collegial. The confrontation comes as more and more universities, pressed financially on several fronts, have turned to leaders with experience outside academia to reinvigorate their institutions -- and have in turn often met resistance from faculty.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN, BOEING SEAL DEAL ON PLANE MODIFICATIONS

TEXT.P: The Evergreen Aviation Technologies Corp. (EGAT) signed a contract Friday in Taipei with Boeing for plane modifications, according to EGAT officials.
Under the contract, EGAT will help Boeing modify three B747 passenger planes into Large Cargo Freighters that will be used to transport large components of B787 aircraft, the officials said.
The modified freighters will have a volume of 65,000 cubic feet, which is three times larger than a 747-400F cargo freighter, they said.
The modification project will start in mid-2005 and is scheduled for completion in two years, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 43.27 points to close at 6,115.43.
The bourse opened at 6,072.45 and fluctuated between 6,128.64 and 6,062.96 during trading. A total of 3.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.4 billion (US$2.73 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENCE PARK ASSOCIATION CALLS FOR POLICY LIBERALIZATION

TEXT.P: The Allied Association for Science Park Industries in Taiwan urged the government Friday to accelerate the overhaul or liberalization of regulations that are either outdated or insufficient.

Tung Chao-chin, chairman of the association, called for the government to pay heed to the trends of industrial developments at home and abroad and readjust laws and regulations to meet the actual needs.

Taking the recent incident involving semiconductor manufacturing giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) as an example, Tong said it is a worldwide trend to allow mature high technology to be transferred overseas when costs of production at home are prohibitively high while demand for such production remains brisk in the world markets.

Tung said that only by allowing these mature high technologies to be transferred overseas, where production costs are much lower, will Taiwan's hi-tech industries be able to maintain their international competitiveness.
This is a trend that has been practiced for years in industrially advanced countries such as Japan and the United States, Tung argued.

UMC was charged with illegal investing in a mainland China-based firm and the Hsinchu prosecutors' office has stepped up a probe into UMC after the chief of the mainland-based firm He Jian Technology, who is aformer executive of UMC, was released on bail of NT$10 million (US$317,088) Thursday. UMC released a statement later that day denying any wrongdoing.

Tung said that the incident is adversely affecting UMC's competitiveness and it is also shaking Taiwan hi-tech firms' confidence in the government's resolve to help the private sector, a development Tung said runs counter to the principle of "Taiwan First" that the government has espoused for years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL POSTS 5.6% PROFIT FROM CROSS-STRAIT NEW YEAR FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, has posted a 5.6 percent profit from the four round-trip passenger charter flights it provided across the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, a CAL executive said Friday.

Speaking at a public hearing on cross-strait transportation issues organized by a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators, CAL Chairman Chiang Yao-chung said that even though the unprecedented two-way, non-stop cross-strait passenger charter flights were launched hastily and the occupancy rate fell short of expectations, his company still managed to turn a profit.

"This means that cross-strait flight services could be profitable," Chiang said, adding that the average passenger occupancy rate for the CAL's four round-trip Lunar New Year cross-strait charter flights was 60 percent.

Under a landmark cross-strait deal, six mainland Chinese airlines and six Taiwanese carriers have been allowed to operate a total of 48 round-trip passenger charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 for homebound Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China -- commonly known as "taishang" -- for Lunar New Year celebrations.
While recognizing the significance of the flights, Chiang also presented his views on the opening of the much-anticipated cross-strait cargo charter flights.

Chiang said mainland China's three commercial airline groups have only 13 all-cargo planes, while CAL alone has 17 all-cargo aircraft and ranks seventh in the world in terms of annual cargo transportation volume.

"We are confident of offering the best cargo transport services should the ban on direct cross-strait cargo charter flights be lifted, " Chiang said, adding that CAL has long been prepared to launch such services and can begin operations soon after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait come to terms on the issue.

As to the formula for the proposed cross-strait cargo charter flights, Chiang said he hopes the flights can be direct and non-stop. In the initial stage, Chiang said, the destinations can include Taipei on the Taiwan side and Shanghai, Beijing and Guangzhou on the mainland side. In the second stage, the mainland's Xiamen, Kunming, Chengdu, Hangzhou and Nanjing can be included and carriers can be allowed to extend cross-strait charter flights to major European destinations.

In the first stage, Chiang said, cross-strait charter flights can focus on transporting products produced by "taishang, " but he said that products manufactured in the United States and European countries should also be included in the second stage to maximize the economic effects of the operations.

Direct cross-strait air and shipping links have been banned since 1949 when the Chinese communists took control of the mainland. President Chen Shui-bian said earlier this week he hopes the two sides can discuss the opening of cross-strait cargo charter flights based on the successful Lunar New Year passenger charter flights.

Speaking at Friday's public hearing, a spokesman for EVA Airways, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, said that if direct cross-strait cargo charter flights do not open soon, local carriers will lose opportunities to enter the vast mainland airborne cargo market.
The spokesman said EVA plans to cooperate with Shanghai Airlines in setting up a joint-venture air cargo company but he would not elaborate.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TOP OFFICIALS INTERFERING INVESTIGATION INTO UMC CASE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan secretary-general claimed Friday that no top government officials have ever interfered in a judicial investigation into an alleged scandal involving semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC).

Lee Ying-yuan made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan while answering questions from reporters regarding the high-profile case. He said the government will manage the case concerning UMC's alleged illegal investment in a mainland Chinese wafer foundry, the HeJiang Technology Co., under the law and will allow law-enforcement units make an independent investigation.
The Taiwan authorities restrict high-tech companies from investing in the mainland without approval.

Hsu Chien-hua, a former UMC executive who was taken into custody after being suspected of being the chipmaker's representative to HeJian, was released Thursday on bail of NT$10 million (US$317,100). Hsu has been working as chairman of the Suzhou-based company since leaving his job as a senior technician at UMC in 2001.
Hsu was questioned by prosecutors one day before he was slated to return to Suzhou after spending the Lunar New Year holiday at his home in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT EYEING SERVICE SECTOR TO EASE KYOTO PROTOCOL IMPACT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is poised to promote the service sector as part of the government's efforts to minimize the impact of the Kyoto Protocol on Taiwan industry, a CEPD spokesman said Friday.

The CEPD, Taiwan's highest economic policy making agency, will swing into full gear soon to promote that goal in the coming four years and it expects to lift the service sector's output value to NT$8.99 trillion (US$285.4 billion) to account for 71.4 percent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) by that time -- an increase from the current level of 67.8 percent, the official said.

Of the NT$8.99 trillion production value, about NT$4.78 trillion will be generated by knowledge-intensive businesses -- some 31.9 percent of the country's GDP -- the official said, adding that around 61.39 million workers will be employed in the sector.
He stressed that the government will advocate energy-saving service businesses in the future by stepping up industrial upgrading and added value productivity.
The Kyoto Protocol, designed to cut greenhouse gas emissions, became effective Wednesday in more than 140 countries around the world.

Although Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations or a signatory to the protocol, local environmentalists have urged the government to adhere to the pact as a constructive member of the global village.

In response to their calls, the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has made it clear that the government, in line with a conclusion reached in a 1998 national energy conference, will still encourage hi-tech industries rather than traditional ones, production of which will be limited to satisfying local demand in the future.

Meanwhile, various technical assistance task forces set up under the MOEA kicked off operations that same day to help promote energy effective measures to 2,900 large consumers in both the private and government sectors in the coming four years, an official of the Bureau of Energy said.

Private sector companies in the steel and electronics industries, hypermarkets, department stores, hospitals and thermal power plants, as well as public agencies, state-run enterprises and schools, will be targeted by the task forces, which will provide on-the-spot energy-saving technical assistance focusing on recycling, pollution prevention and reuse of industrial waste water.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC MULLS RELAXING PASSENGER RESTRICTIONS FOR CROSS-STRAIT CHARTERS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday that the government might relax passenger restrictions for cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights in the future so that they can serve more people besides mainland China-based Taiwanese businessmen and their dependents.
Chiu said this year's special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights, which started Jan. 29 and are set to run through Feb. 20, have been successful despite some minor shortcomings.
A total of 45 flights have been made so far, serving 9,887 passengers, Chiu pointed out.
Chiu said the government will conduct a comprehensive review and evaluation of the charter service after it is completed and try to seek improvements.
The government will not rule out the possibility of relaxing passenger restrictions in the future if the problems involved can be overcome, Chiu said.

Although the charter flights are designed to serve Taiwanese businessmen, some unqualified passengers, such as foreign maids, journalists and students, reportedly were found to have been allowed to take the flights this year.

Unlike the previous Lunar New Year charter flight services in 2003, which were operated solely by Taiwanese airlines between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau, this year's service is being jointly operated by a total of 12 carriers from Taiwan and the mainland, with flights between Beijing/Shanghai/Guangzhou and Taipei/Kaohsiung.
The flights are not required to land in a third location en route this time around, although they still need to detour through Hong Kong air space.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ASKS JAPAN FOR VISA-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Japan Friday to brush aside pressure from Beijing and grant permanent visa-free treatment to visitors from Taiwan.
Chen made the call while receiving a group of Japanese visitors composed of members of the Sino-Japanese Cultural and Economic Association.

Chen thanked Japan for its decision to extend visa-free privileges to Taiwan tourists during the 2005 World Exposition to be held in Aichi from March 25 to Sept. 25, but he expressed the hope that the Japanese government and parliament will make the measure permanent despite pressure from Beijing.

Pointing out that Japan ignored Beijing's pressure to vote in May last year in favor of Taiwan's participation as an observer in the World Health Assembly, he said he strongly believes that permanent visa-free status would not be a problem should the Japanese government fully exercise its leverage.
He also called for support from his visitors for the signing of a free trade agreement between Taiwan and Japan, describing it as an urgent matter to prevent mainland China's economic expansion.

The president also boasted of his success in strengthening Taiwan identity since he assumed the presidency for the first time in May 2000. The reasons behind his decision to step down last year from the chairmanship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party were to carry out Taiwan-centric reform and to make Taiwan a sound, progressive, beautiful and great nation, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SHOULD TAKE BACK STOWAWAYS ON SCHEDULE: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China should quickly take back its nationals detained in Taiwan for illegal entry, Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.
Taiwan presently holds around 2,400 detainees in Hsinchu, Ilan and Matsu waiting to be shipped back to the mainland, Chiu said, adding that if Beijing cares about them, it should take them back.

Under the terms of an existing bilateral agreement, Beijing is supposed to take detained stowaways back in batches three times every two months, but the number repatriated last year is only half of the scheduled target, Chiu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC CHAIRMAN CLARIFIES CONNECTION WITH HE JIAN TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) Chairman Robert H.C. Tsao denied allegations Friday that the company has unlawfully transferred capital, technology and human resources to mainland China-based He Jian Technology.

Tsao made the clarification in ad space that he purchased in two major dailies in the wake of raids by prosecutors over the past two days on UMC over the company's alleged unlawful investments in He Jian.
Tsao claimed that UMC only helped He Jian to begin operations but did not make any substantial investment and thus did not violate the government's policy on investments in the mainland.
Tsao said he made the decisions in matters regarding the case and will take full responsibility.

According to Tsao, UMC Vice Chairman Hsuan Ming-chih helped He Jian in its start-up to maintain cordial business relations and the opportunity for a merger should the government on Taiwan decide in the future to relax its restrictions on mainland investments.
Tsao denied allegations that UMC has transferred some of its orders to He Jian, although he admitted that UMC did try to assist He Jian in winning orders from clients.
Tsao called the raids by prosecutors a kind of "corporate white terror" and asked prosecutors to stop immediately.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR PRAGMATIC REVIEW OF CROSS-STRAIT INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: The nation's policy toward commercial exchanges with mainland China should be reviewed pragmatically in line with the changing global economic climate and general market trends, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Hsieh made the remarks amid growing concern about the government's policy direction regarding high-tech companies' investments in mainland China after prosecutors raided Hsinchu-based United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , the world's second-largest contract chipmaker, earlier this week in search of evidence of the company's allegedly illegal mainland investment activities. Under current regulations, chipmakers are required to apply for permission before investing in mainland China.
Hsieh said the government has a clear-cut policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait trade and investment, which he said has not been completely implemented.
In his view, Hsieh said, all existing laws and regulations must be followed and enforced for the sake of defending the government's credibility and maintaining fair play in business.
"Poor law enforcement will not only undermine the government's credibility but will also hurt the interests and rights of those who faithfully obey the rules," Hsieh said.

Nevertheless, Hsieh went on, business activities are mainly regulated by economic rules rather than by laws. "Therefore, a specific commercial law or rule should be pragmatically and prudently reviewed whenever the ratio of law breakers exceeds that of law abiders," Hsieh said.

To the best of his understanding, Hsieh said, law enforcement authorities have received more than 800 reports about local companies violating the existing laws in launching investment projects on the mainland. The UMC case is one of the relatively more serious violations, Hsieh said.

Stressing that he didn't receive any information before prosecutors launched the raid on nine UMC offices and the residence of one of its senior executives, Hsieh said he will not give any directives on any specific judicial case.

However, Hsieh said, he will discuss with the Ministry of Justice general principles for handling similar cases, including suspects' human rights and protection of rights of investors or shareholders in the process of investigations of any suspicious cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO LAUNCH ACTIVITIES AGAINST BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will launch a series of activities this month against Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law," TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang said Friday.
Speaking at a seminar on policies to be promoted by the TSU, Su said that his party will initiate a signature drive on Feb. 28 to express Taiwan people's opposition to the proposed bill.

The TSU will organize a large demonstration in early March in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, for the same purpose, Su added. Former President Lee Teng-hui, who is considered the TSU's spiritual leader, will also take part in the rally.
Addressing the meeting, Lee said that Taiwan is a sovereign and independent nation and that it cannot accept Beijing's proposed law, which he said obviously targets Taiwan.
As a countermeasure, Taiwan should enact a "China relations act" or a bill in opposition to mainland China's desire to swallow Taiwan, Lee suggested.
The 23 million people of Taiwan should make it clear to the Beijing authorities that they will defend Taiwan's democracy, freedom and sovereignty, he went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO JOIN EUROPEAN GROUP AS AN OBSERVER: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday he hopes Taiwan can be admitted to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE) as an observer.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with David Atkinson, a member of the House of Commons of the United Kingdom and chairman of the PACE's Liberal Party caucus, who is currently on a visit in Taipei.

While all Council of Europe members are European countries, Chen said Taiwan looks forward to joining the PACE -- the 46-member Council of Europe's legislative arm -- as an observer like Canada, Mexico and several other non-European states.

Noting that Taiwan has made remarkable achievements in promoting democracy, the rule of law and the protection of human rights, Chen said Taiwan hopes to work together with all PACE member states in spreading those universal values around the globe.
Chen said he hopes the PACE will organize a delegation to visit Taiwan to get a better understanding of Taiwan's efforts to promote democracy and human rights.
The president also thanked Atkinson for his long-term support for Taiwan's cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLIDARITY UNION EARMARKS 12 BILLS IT URGENTLY WANTS PASSED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) vowed Friday to introduce 12 urgent bills in this legislative session.

Lawmaker Lo Chih-ming, convener of the TSU caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said his party has not been active enough in initiating and acting on bills relating to the public's livelihood in the past and will be more aggressive in the new session.
The TSU only holds 12 seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.
Notable among the bills is a "China relations act, " which is designed to make clear Taiwan's designation as a state and crystallize its opposition to mainland China's desire to annex Taiwan.
Another bill is an "allegiance to the country act, " crafted to ensure government employees are loyal to Taiwan.

Lo said his party wants to introduce a revision to the Referendum Law that would transfer the legislature's power to initiate a referendum to the Executive Yuan, with the caveat that any referendum proposed by the Executive Yuan would need the approval of the legislature.

Other legislation that the TSU would like to see passed into law is a sunshine bill to address allegations of ill-gotten gains by political parties -- specifically targeting the Kuomintang -- and a law governing the activities of political parties.
The party will also push for legislation regarding agriculture and fishery issues, religion and a basic law for women's welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES NAVY TO PLAY MORE ACTIVE STRATEGIC ROLE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the nation's naval force Friday to play a more active strategic role in the Taiwan Strait area and strengthen cooperation with their U.S. and Japanese counterparts.
Chen made the remarks while attending a Chinese Lunar New Year celebration party at the Tsoying naval base near the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

The president took advantage of the occasion to express his gratitude for naval officers and enlisted men for their braving bad weather to defend national security on sea during the Lunar New Year holiday.

"Because of Beijing's refusal to renounce the option of using force against Taiwan, our soldiers have to keep alert during the Lunar New Year holiday," Chen said. With its fast economic growth in recent years, Chen said, mainland China has largely increased its military budget. In addition to purchasing and developing advanced weapons, Chen said, the mainland navy has also adjusted its overall development strategy from coastal defense to building up a deep-sea naval force. Moreover, its submarines have been very active in the Taiwan Strait and Asia Pacific.
In the face of ever mounting mainland military threat, Chen said the navy must beef up its defense capabilities.

"I hope local people can support the government's plan to procure eight diesel-electric submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States to beef up naval defense capabilities, " Chen said, adding that the navy should also adjust its development strategy and play a more active strategic role in the region and deepen cooperation with U.S. and Japanese naval forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC CASE INDIVIDUAL, LEGAL INVESTMENT SECURE: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The court case of United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) is an individual case and Taiwan companies will not have any problem with their mainland-bound investments as long as they conform to the government's regulations, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-jueh said Friday.

UMC, the world's second-largest chip foundry after the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) , has been charged with illegally passing on capital and technology to mainland-based He Jian Technology Co. in Suzhou. UMC headquarters and factories in Taipei and Hsinchu were searched by prosecutors on Tuesday.
The Taiwan government bans private individuals or companies from investing in wafer plants in mainland China without government permission.

Stressing that local companies will not be punished by the government if their investments in mainland China fully fall in line with the required legal process, Ho said she hopes that the prosecution authorities will complete their investigation into the case and find the facts as soon as possible.
Ho said that her ministry will deal with UMC in compliance with the law should prosecutors discover hard evidence that implicates UMC in any illegal activities with He Jian.
Meanwhile, He Jian issued a statement on its Web site denying any links to UMC, emphasizing that it is an independent, foreign-owned company that has nothing to do with the Taiwan company.
James Lee, director of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, called on Taiwan businesses to strictly follow government rules in launching investment plans in mainland China.

Lee further said that the government should heed Taiwan companies' needs and that it should help local enterprises break into foreign markets amid fierce competition. But he reiterated that local companies should abide by the law when carrying out investments overseas, in particular mainland China, due to its sensitive relations with Taiwan.
According to Lee, UMC applied to open an office in Shanghai a few years ago to study and explore neighboring markets. But he added that no unusual changes to the company's business have been found.

The administration has showed grave concern over the UMC case, as the semiconductor industry is the major engine at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan -- the country's oldest and most representative facilities to accommodate hi-tech industries.

The park racked up a record revenue of NT$1.859 trillion (US$59 billion) for the whole of 2004, some 69 percent of which was contributed by the semiconductor sector. TSMC and UMC generated nearly 30 percent of the industry's total output value.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'HANDS ACROSS TAIWAN' ORGANIZERS TO TAKE AIM AT ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: A number of local pro-independence groups are organizing a global protest to be held on Feb. 28 -- the country's Peace Day -- against Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law."

These groups, including Taiwan Societies from the four corners of the nation, the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association and the Taiwan Association of University Professors held a news conference Friday to announce their plan.

After successfully staging a "hand in hand across Taiwan" event to promote a "Taiwan first" campaign last year, these same pro-independence groups said the purpose of this year's campaign, called the "228 Universal Campaign for a Free Taiwan, " is to oppose mainland China's attempt to annex Taiwan, and all political leaders, regardless of their political affiliation, are invited to join the event.
The protest will be held simultaneously in 18 counties and cities in Taiwan as well as in a dozen overseas cities on the afternoon of Feb. 28.
In the evening, protesters in various cities and counties will hold a candlelight vigil and read a "Free Taiwan Declaration."
In the lead-up to Feb. 28, a series of seminars will be organized, beginning from Feb. 20, to promote Taiwan's statehood, according to organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND DIPPED SLIGHTLY IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: A total of 92 mainland Chinese investment projects were approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in January with a combined capital of US$495 million, which is 1.33 percent less than the corresponding time of the previous year, according to statistics prepared by the ministry's Investment Commission.
Most of the investments went to Jiangsu province, eastern China, accounting for 51.59 percent, followed by Guangdong province, southern China, accounting for 26.59 percent.

By industry, electronics and electrical appliance manufacturing made up the lion's share of 44.94 percent, followed by chemical manufacturing at 11.81 percent, and precision equipment manufacturing at 8.74 percent.

During the same time, the commission approved 74 foreign direct investment projects in Taiwan, with a combined capital of US$237 million, which represents a 68.18 percent increase in the number of projects and a 24.37 percent increase in capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SETS UP TASK FORCE TO PROMOTE SAVING ENERGY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) set up a task force Friday to provide government agencies and the business sector with information on how they can better save energy.

MOEA officials said that the task force, formed by officials and experts from the Bureau of Energy, Chinese Petroleum Corp., China Steel Corp. and Taiwan Power Co., will make a tour across the nation to teach government agencies, large energy-consuming enterprises and shopping malls how to save energy.

Taiwan will save energy equivalent to the consumption of 295,000 kiloliters of oil and will reduce the emission of 810,000 tons of carbon dioxide a year if the energy-saving measures to be promoted by the task force are implemented, they noted.

Steel mills, petrochemical plants, manufacturers of cement, paper, textiles and electronics, power plants, government offices, schools, hospitals, department stores, hotels, convenience stores, shopping malls and theaters are the main targets of the task force, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER VOWS TO PLAY THE ROLE OF COORDINATOR

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i pledged Friday to be a good coordinator in the Executive Yuan in hopes that this will promote the country's economic growth and help businessmen to earn more profits.
In his first full day as vice premier, Wu told CNA his only goal is to enhance economic growth and help businessmen make money.
However, the economist-turned-vice premier said Taiwan's economic growth forecast to be 4.67 percent this year, couldn't be raised by any single person; rather, it can only be boosted by teamwork.
He promised to coordinate the efforts of different government branches and various sectors to achieve this goal.

As to the priority of the Executive Yuan's economic and financial policy, Wu said it should be set by the premier and executed by various ministries and related government agencies. What he will do, Wu said, is to help with the exchange of views among different ministries.

In regard to the policy concerning economic exchanges with mainland China, the former chief of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research said the "no haste, be patient" policy employed by the government under former President Lee Teng-hui was a bit on the conservative side, and has been replaced by the policy of "active opening, effective management."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 19, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Chinese communist warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1973: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ing Afredo Obiols Gomez leaves for home after a weeklong tour of Taiwan.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1976: Four Beijing opera stars leave Taipei for Hong Kong to participate in the Hong Kong Festival of Arts.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
2003: Adm. Ni Yue-si, a strategy adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 90.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found."

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT SECURITY COUNTS ON U.S. ADHERENCE AND ALLIES' SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Friday that the cross-Taiwan Strait issue is one of concern and that U.S. policy toward the region remains unchanged.
Rice also said that neither side of the strait should try to unilaterally change the status quo and that U.S. efforts to maintain stability in the region depend very much upon itself and its allies.

Her comments came while responding to media questions regarding a Washington Post report that the United States and Japan will declare after a meeting they will hold in Washington, D.C. Saturday on bilateral security matters that Taiwan is a mutual security concern.

Pointing out that the United States and Japan have "very deep and broad relations" to try and help bring and maintain peace and stability in the Asia Pacific region, Rice said that Japan has also more recently taken on a broader role in its humanitarian efforts in Iraq and also in the cooperation to help victims of the Dec. 26 tsunami. "So in fact this is already a broad and deep relationship that addresses most of the issues of concern, " she continued.

Rice also said that with the recognition of a one-China policy on the basis of the three communiques and Washington's responsibility under the Taiwan Relations Act, the policy of the United States is very clear.

"We have cautioned all parties that there should be no attempt to change the status quo unilaterally. That means no attempt by China to change the status quo unilaterally, no attempt by Taiwan to change the status quo unilaterally. And our efforts to maintain stability in the region count very much on an American adherence and that of our allies, of which Japan is certainly an ally, that the cross-strait problems will be resolved peacefully, " she said

Touching on the upcoming meeting she and U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld will have with Japanese Foreign Minister Nobutaka Machimura and Defense Minister Yoshinori Ohno, Rice said they look forward to discussing at the meeting ways to promote peace and security in the Asia Pacific region.
