DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Iraq Envoy to Be Chief of Intelligence. President Bush nominated the U.S. ambassador to Iraq, John D. Negroponte, to serve as the nation's first director of national intelligence , selecting a veteran diploma to oversee a historic restructuring of the U.S. intelligence community after a string of catastrophic failures.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Joker, Kiko oppose ID system
Two administration senators yesterday rejected proposals for a national identification (ID) system and congressional approval of an anti-terrorism bill, saying these could intrude into the private lives of Filipino citizens and open the door to possible human rights abuses.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 3 blast suspects known
POLICE yesterday claimed they were closing in on three people suspected to be behind the Makati bus explosion, as the death toll from the Valentine's Day blast in the city rose to four.
The Philippine Star: GMA backs national ID system
President Arroyo called on Congress yesterday to set up a national identification system and asked cities and towns to issue ID cards for their residents until the new ID law can be passed.
The Manila Times: 45% of RP families poor
NEARLY half of all Filipino families lived in poverty and did not have $1 a person a day in 2000, according to the estimates made by the Asian Development Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Budget with something for everyone.
The young, the old, and the 'sandwich generation' in between, businessmen and the needy - there was something for just about everyone in the Budget unveiled yesterday.
In his Budget speech yesterday - his first as Prime Minister and fourth as Finance Minister - Mr Lee Hsien Loong said: 'This will benefit all Singaporeans. It will provide $1.3 billion of help to groups which need and deserve help, especially those who are finding it hard to keep up with the structural changes.'
The Lianhe Zaobao: Budget with care and pardon.
Singapore Prime Minster and Finance Minister lee Hsien Loong presented the 2005 Budget statement in Parliament yesterday and make everyone satisfy.
The Budget presented by PM Lee gives help to Singaporeans they need take care, and makes Singapore become a society with care and pardon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOLD TRADE FACILITATION SEMINAR: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is set to hold a trade facilitation seminar next month to share its experience of automation in dealing with customs operations with other countries, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced Saturday.
The BOFT said the island has engaged in talks on trade facilitation issues raised by the World Trade Organization (WTO) and put on the agenda of the multilateral Doha Round of trade negotiations.
It also said that trade facilitation is aimed at promoting international trade by simplifying import and export procedures, particularly customs clearance procedures, of WTO members.

Despite the fact that the issues have been included on the agenda of the new round of multilateral trade talks, the BOFT said, however, that the developing and least developed countries are worried that they will not be capable of carrying out future decisions of the talks.

Saying that the government has worked on the elimination of trade obstacles and that the relevant suggestions it has raised at the Doha talks have been welcomed by other WTO members, the BOFT said that it will invite the developing and least developed countries to attend the forthcoming seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-JAPAN SECURITY PACT CHANGES TO HINDER CHINESE INVASION OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday that expected revisions to the U.S.-Japan Security Alliance will make a mainland Chinese invasion of Taiwan difficult to achieve.

According to a Washington Post report, the United States and Japan are expected to release a joint agreement in Washington Saturday to identify security in the Taiwan Strait as their "common strategic objective."

While giving a lecture to trainees at the Lee Teng-hui School, Lee said that Beijing has used military force to try to intimidate the Taiwanese people into voting for candidates it favored in three presidential elections since 1996.

Disappointed at its failure to achieve the desired results, Beijing has given up hope on unification through peaceful means and is determined to achieve unification through military force, according to Lee.

He said the mainland's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" has received negative responses from the United States and Taiwan because, he said, Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China is totally unconvincing.
He urged Beijing to review its nationalist policy and to bring about peace in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLIND PEOPLE SOLICIT SUPPORT FOR GUIDE DOG SCHOOL

TEXT.P: Several visually impaired people pleaded for support from the public Saturday for the establishment of a guide dog school in Taiwan.

Yang Huan-hsieh noted that he is one of only eight blind people in Taiwan to have obtained a licensed guide dog from the American group "Leader Dog." With the help of the dog, his mobility and quality of life has significantly improved, he said.

As there are still many blind people who need this kind of help, Yang urged the public to donate money for the establishment of a guide dog training school. Their target is to raise NT$60 million (US$1.9 million).
Those interested in donating can do so through the more than 1,700 7-11 convenience stores around the nation, Yang added.
Chen Chang-ching, secretary-general of the Taiwan Guide Dog Association, said there are some 50,000 blind people around the country, but only 11 guide dogs in service.
Chen said his association hopes to set up a guide dog school within three years to serve the blind, with support from both the government and the private sector.
He explained that it costs some NT$1.2 million to train a guide dog and that the association assigns guide dogs to the visually impaired for free.
In addition, a guide dog school should have kennels, a playground, a hospital and a dormitory for the visually impaired, as well as training and administration offices.
According to Chen, the association has matched eight blind people with dogs and has sent three people to receive guide dog training in Europe and United States.
The training procedure for a guide dog is quite difficult but interesting, Chen said.
While urging the public to extend their support for the training of guide dogs, he advised people not to feed, touch or shout at the dogs, as doing so could distract them from their work.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLIND ASSOCIATION IN MOSCOW RECEIVES DONATIONS FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to Russia transferred Friday a donation from former ROC Legislator Chen Shei-saint to a branch of the Russian Blind Association in Moscow.

Chen Jung-chie, representative of the Taipei-Moscow Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, said it was the seventh time that the former legislator had extended his help to the various branches of a blind association in Moscow.
The donation, worth US$1,000, is expected to benefit some 50 of the more than 700 visually impaired people at the association's Lomonosov branch, Chen added.

The director of the Lomonosov branch also attended the donation ceremony and expressed gratitude for the money from the former legislator and for the help from the ROC representative office over the years.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGES IN U.S.-JAPAN SECURITY PACT SEND WARNING TO BEIJING: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A plan by the United States and Japan to revise their security pact to make Taiwan a mutual security concern will send a clear warning to mainland China, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker said Saturday.

According to the Washington Post, the United States and Japan are expected to release revisions to the U.S.-Japan Security Alliance in Washington Saturday to identify security in the Taiwan Strait as a "common strategic objective."

Lee Wen-chung, who is a co-convener of the legislature's National Defense Committee, said that although the content is not new, the fact that the United States and Japan are confirming this point in their security alliance indicates that they have recognized the precarious situation across the Taiwan Strait.

Lee pointed out that Washington and Tokyo in 1998 included in their alliance the phrase "areas surrounding Japan that have an important influence on Japan's peace and security, " and that then-Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto also specified that the Taiwan Strait was considered part of "areas surrounding Japan."
In other words, Lee claimed, the United States and Japan would consider a war across the Taiwan Strait as an attack on Japan and would take joint military action to defend security in the region.

According to Lee, the United States and Japan see the mainland as a potential strategic opponent and the economic lifelines of Japan will be severely impacted in the event of a war across the Taiwan Strait.
He said the U.S.-Japan security alliance will thus provide protection for Taiwan's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR TO RUN FOR NANTOU COUNTY CHIEF POSITION

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Tsai Huang-liang announced Saturday that he will participate in a party primary for the nomination to run for the post of Nantou magistrate in the year-end magistrate and mayoral elections.
Tsai, a legislator-at-large born in Nantou, urged incumbent Nantou Magistrate Lin Tzung-nan, also a DPP member, to compete with him in the party primary to be held later this year.

Tsai noted that there is increasing dissatisfaction about the county's development according to several surveys among residents of Nantou County and said he decided to run for the post not only for the sake of Nantou but also for the sustainable development of the party.

Saying that the year-end magistrate and mayoral elections are considered a prelude to the 2008 presidential election, Tsai said the DPP must win the local elections to ensure its administrative leadership.
He also issued a declaration guaranteeing not to make personal attacks or disseminate false information about other candidates.

For his part, Lin expressed doubt about the provenance of the "various surveys" mentioned by Tsai, claiming that it is "natural" for a low approval rate to occur in the first term of a political figure, citing the example of Premier Frank Hsieh, who was formerly Kaohsiung mayor. Lin said Hsieh's approval rating was low in the first few years of his first term as mayor, but that the rate surged sharply in his second term.

Lin, who assumed his post three years ago, said that many construction projects have got underway in his current term and that these projects cannot be interrupted. He added that eight years will be sufficient for him to realize his promises to voters.
Describing the competition in the party's preliminary vote as no less fierce than that in the official elections, Lin said he respects Tsai's decision to seek the candidacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINE EXECUTIVES TO VISIT BEIJING NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The Beijing-based Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) has invited senior Taiwan airline executives to visit mainland China next week, aviation sources said Saturday.

Michael Lo, president of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) , who concurrently serves as Mandarin Airlines president, said the CAAC invitation is mainly aimed at celebrating the Spring Festival or the Chinese New Year.
According to Lo, this is not the first time the CAAC has invited Taiwan airline executives to Beijing for Spring Festival celebrations.

"Taiwan's airline companies have all set up representative offices in mainland China and are familiar with the CAAC officials. We have maintained frequent exchanges. Similar Spring Festival gatherings between the two sides have taken place in the past, " Lo said.

In his capacity as TAA president, Lo and Pu Zhaozhou, director of the CAAC's Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, signed a landmark deal in Macau Jan. 15 to allow six carriers on each side of the Taiwan Strait to operate a total of 48 round-trip special cross-strait charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families home for the Lunar New Year celebrations.

Lo's upcoming Beijing visit has drawn attention, as media reports have speculated that he might take advantage of the trip to discuss the opening of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights with the mainland authorities.
Lo said the speculation is unfounded because he will visit Beijing in his capacity as Mandarin Airlines president, not the TAA president.

"My upcoming Beijing visit has nothing to do with cross-strait cargo charter flight negotiations. The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has not authorized the TAA to negotiate cargo charter flight issues," Lo said.
As Beijing refuses to engage Taiwan's government, the MAC has had to commission the private TAA to negotiate Lunar New Year charter flights and aviation pacts with Hong Kong and Macau in the past.

During his visit, Lo said, he might exchange views with CAAC officials on the operations of the unprecedented two-way, non-stop cross-strait passenger charter flights during the just-concluded Lunar New Year holiday and the long-talked-about cargo charter flights.
"But the talks will be private in nature, not formal consultations," he stressed.

The media reports had claimed that Lo and senior executives of other Taiwan carriers, such as China Airlines, UNI Airways and TransAsia Airways, will travel to Beijing Feb. 22 to meet with CAAC officials, including Pu, on the cargo charter flight issues. The reports also quoted mainland sources as saying that Beijing will not oppose a proposal that the cargo charter flight negotiations follow the model set in January's holiday charter flight talks that took place in Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING PENDING DPP'S CROSS-STRAIT INVESTMENT POLICY: PFP

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong might meet President Chen Shui-bian next week if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government responds positively to a call to relax restrictions on investment in mainland China, PFP officials said Saturday.
Top aides of Chen and Soong met Friday to discuss the technical details of the Chen-Soong meeting but failed to set a date for it.

PFP politicians claimed that the atmosphere was improper at present for such a meeting in the wake of raids launched by prosecutors on semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) over alleged unlawful investments made by the company in the mainland.
UMC Chairman Robert H.C. Tsao is known to be a close friend of Soong and a supporter of the PFP.

According to the PFP officials, the UMC case indicates that the government's policy toward the mainland is already out of date and that it is necessary for the opposition to push the government to address the problems faced by local industry and to seek to relax its policy.
The Chen-Soong meeting will only be meaningful if the DPP government is willing to change its cross-Taiwan Strait policy, the officials said.

Liu Wen-hsiung, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said the UMC case has sent a shockwave across the hi-tech sector and has cast doubt on the DPP's sincerity in seeking political stability through the Chen-Soong meeting.

Chen Wen-tzung, a spokesman for the Presidential Office, said the opinions of the PFP have been heard and that the president's aides will keep in contact with the PFP to try to hammer out a date for the meeting.

Presidential Office officials claimed the president has always been sincere about meeting Soong, but they said the UMC incident is a judicial case in which the president is in no position to interfere.
Meanwhile, DPP Policy Committee head Ker Chien-ming urged the PFP not to delay the meeting any longer, saying that it should not be linked to the UMC case.
Ker proposed that Chen and Soong seize the opportunity of the meeting to exchange their views on problems concerning local industry.
Lo Chih-ming, convener of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus, said his party is opposed to the PFP's attempt to use the Chen-Soong meeting as a bargaining chip.
Until related laws are amended, any investments in the mainland without the government's approval are illegal, Lo pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS OF YOUNG PEOPLE VISIT 13TH TIBE

TEXT.P: Thousands of children and teenagers braved the cold Saturday to visit the Taipei World Trade Center, venue of the 13th Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) to browse displays of comic books from domestic and foreign publishers.
With long queues building up before the opening of the exhibition , the comic books hall became jam-packed by the afternoon, according the private Taipei Book Fair Foundation.

The annual event spotlights a series of exhibitions and discussions that mirror reading activities and trends in the Asia-Pacific region, with this year's show focusing on "book art" and "digital publishing." The exhibition will run through Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLARS TALK ABOUT CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: An American scholar said Saturday that discussions between the United States and Japan about security in the Taiwan Strait should not surprise anyone, as apart from China and Taiwan, these are the only two countries that are likely to become militarily involved in case of a conflict across the Taiwan Strait.

Bonnie Glaser, a senior researcher at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, made the remarks following reports that the United States and Japan are expected to revise their security agreement to make Taiwan a security concern for both countries.

Glaser said that concerns about a growing mainland military buildup are rising in Japan and there are also worries about the possible use of force against Taiwan, as well as the presence of Chinese submarines in Japanese waters.
As allies, both the United States and Japan share interest in preserving peace and stability in the region, Glaser said.

Meanwhile, professor Edward Friedman from the University of Wisconsin, noted that Taiwan's real security lies in the respect of the mainland to Taiwan's identity, as Russia does with Finland and Britain does with Ireland.

It does not serve the long-term interests of the Taiwanese people that cross-strait relations are in a dilemma where each side feels it is responding defensively to the other side and does not respect the interest of the other side or understand the "ratcheting-up" consequences of its own actions, Friedman said.

Noting that a military buildup and tension will not serve the interests of peace and prosperity in the region, Friedman claimed that the mainland is not aware of the long-term impact of its decision to target Taiwan with missiles in an attempt to threaten the island into submitting to its demand that Taiwan accept status under which Hong Kong is ruled by Beijing.

"What is needed now is a way and a forum for both sides of the strait to talk and understand each other and back away from any further increase of tensions, " Friedman said, adding that the mainland's President Hu Jintao and Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian should cooperate, with the mainland taking the first step away from its military threat in order to eliminate the tension, which will be in the interest of all the people in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., JAPAN CONCERNED AT MILITARY BUILDUP BY MAINLAND CHINA: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: The rapid military buildup by mainland China is making the United States and Japan worried that it might tilt the military balance across the Taiwan Strait, analysts said Saturday.

Commenting on a plan by Washington and Tokyo to release a joint agreement to identify security in the Taiwan Strait as a "common strategic objective, " National Sun Yat-sen University Professor Andrew Yang said the move indicates that the mainland's military activities in the Western Pacific are making them nervous.
Yang said the cross-strait military balance is altering and that the United States and Japan must be prepared for all possible contingencies.
Meanwhile, national policy adviser Luan Ming said that by making the declaration, the United States and Japan are trying to warn Beijing against waging a war in the region.

According to Luan, Japan used to avoid touching on the Taiwan Strait issue, but the security threat posed by the mainland's military buildup in the Asia-Pacific region has forced Japan to take a position.

Luan said the United States does not wish to see Beijing or Taiwan try to change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally and is very unhappy with Beijing's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" providing legal means to deal with the Taiwan issue through non-peaceful means.
He said the United States and Japan are sending a message to Beijing that they will not sit idly by in the event of a war across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MOBILE INTERNET USAGE RATE LESS THAN THOSE OF NEIGHBORS

TEXT.P: The results of a recent global survey show that Taiwan's mobile Internet usage rate in 2004 reached 43 percent, lagging behind Japan's 64 percent, South Korea's 51 percent and Hong Kong's 55 percent.

Taiwan's authoritative Web site, the Focus on Internet News and Data (www.find.org.tw) , organized and operated by the Advanced e-Commerce Institute and the Institute for Information Industry, along with similar facilities in other countries and areas including Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, Finland and Greece, conducted the "Worldwide Mobile Internet Survey" simultaneously in October and November in an effort to study mobile Internet developments and trends.

According to survey results, Taiwanese users spent an average of 21.3 minutes on mobile Internet services in the most recent month that the poll was carried out, compared with 22.1 minutes in South Korea, 29.1 minutes in Hong Kong and 33.5 minutes in Japan.
The figures reflect the fact that there is ample room in the Taiwan market for mobile network service providers to expand their business, according to a report by the Web site.

In terms of the monthly amount of money that online users paid for their mobile Internet services in 2004, Taiwan also saw the smallest average figure of NT$168.6 (US$5.36) among its neighbors, while Japanese users spent NT$671.9 on average, followed by NT$301.6 in South Korea and NT$204.1 in Hong Kong.

The results also show that in Japan, the most popular mobile Internet service was the E-mail service, with the most recent usage rate recorded at 85 percent. In the case of other mobile online services, those for downloading pictures and telephone ring tones were also frequently used in the countries conducting the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SINGLES OUT FIVE PRIORITY BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has singled out five legislative bills that he hopes can clear the legislative floor soon after the new legislative session opens Feb. 25, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Saturday.

The five bills involve measures to bolster the tottering national health insurance program, the restructuring of the Executive Yuan, the special statute regarding three massive arms procurement projects, revisions to the rules of operation of the mission-oriented National Assembly and the special statute concerning a planned world exposition in 2008, Cho said.

According to Cho, Hsieh called during a working lunch with legislative whips of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and several government officials for quick legislative passage fo the five urgent bills.

Those present at the lunch at Hsieh's official residence included Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, Cabinet Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, Legislator Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently heads the DPP's policy coordination commission, two new DPP whips in the legislature -- Chao Yung-ching and Chen Ching-chun -- and Cho himself.

During the meeting, Cho said the premier also promised to assign more aides to strengthen engagements and consultations with the Legislative Yuan in order to win the legislature's support for the administration's policy initiatives and reform programs.

In the past five years, the hostile opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has stonewalled the passage of many critical bills and has boycotted the implementation of a number of reform programs at nearly every turn.

Since Hsieh assumed the premiership, he has made inter-party reconciliation and cooperation one of his priorities. Dubbing his team a "Cabinet of consultations, " Cho said Hsieh has assured DPP legislative whips that he will deliver on his promise to strengthen communications and consultations with the legislature before floating any major policy initiatives or bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BID FOR HOSTING 20TH WORLD ORCHID CONFERENCE IN 2011

TEXT.P: Taiwan will make a bid for the right to host the 20th World Orchid Conference and Exhibition scheduled for 2011, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

Noting that the World Orchid Conference is the highest-level global meeting on orchid cultivation and development, COA officials said that hosting such an event will help further upgrade the worldwide competitiveness of Taiwan's orchid industry.

"Taiwan has long been lauded as a kingdom of orchids and accounts for more than 70 percent of the world's total orchid exports. We are qualified to sponsor the world orchid congress and exhibition, " said a senior COA official.

According to COA tallies, Taiwan's orchid gardens cover more than 500 hectares of land and its annual orchid production amounted to US$74 million. Taiwan plays an influential role in the world orchid market, the official said.
The 18th World Orchid Conference and Exhibition will be held in Dijon, France March 11-20, 2005.
"We'll organize a delegation to take part in the upcoming world orchid conference and show and to lobby the support for our bid to host the 2011 event," the official said.

Singapore and South Africa reportedly are also interested in hosting the 2011 world orchid congress, the official said, adding that Taiwan will step up efforts to seek other countries' support for its bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN SEIZED FOR INTENDING TO SMUGGLE FAKE COINS INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A man was arrested at an airport on the frontline island of Kinmen Saturday for allegedly intending to smuggle bogus NT$50-denominated coins into Taiwan from mainland China, aviation police said.

Tsou Wen-feng, 56, was originally scheduled to take a Mandarin airlines flight from Kinmen to the central Taiwan city of Taichung after arriving on the nation's offshore defense outpost via the direct "mini three links" route from Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian province.

Tsou was intercepted after security officers at Kinmen's Shangyi Airport detected "suspicious articles" in his carry-on baggage by X-ray. Aviation police later uncovered 1,377 NT$50-denominated fake coins in the baggage.
It marked the first time that a Taiwan businessman operating on mainland China has ever tried to smuggle counterfeit coins into Taiwan via the "mini three links" route.
Tsou, who has previous criminal records of burglary and fraud, claimed that he bought the fake coins in an antique shop in Beijing for 1,300 yuan or renminbi (about NT$5,200).
Aviation police have transferred the case to the Kinmen Prosecutor's Office for further investigations, including his motivation and the possible flow of the fake coins.
Police said they will also look into why Tsou had managed to pass security checks at Xiamen and Kinmen ports.

"The mini three links" refer to direct trade, postal and shipping links between Taiwan's two outlying defense outposts of Kinmen/Matsu and Fujian's Xiamen/Mawei. Only Kinmen/Matsu residents and Taiwan businessmen operating in Fujian area and other selected groups of Taiwan people are eligible to use the direct "mini three links" shipping services.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR OF THE ROOSTER FULL OF PROMISE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian attended the light-up ceremony for the 2004 Taipei Lantern Festival Saturday at the Taipei City Hall plaza.
Chen joined Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in lighting up a theme lantern to mark the start of a series of festive activities in cerebration of Lantern Festival which falls on Feb. 23 this year.

It marked the first time that Chen attended the light-up ceremony for the Taipei Lantern Festival in his capacity as president. The annual event was launched during Chen's tenure as Taipei mayor from 1994 to 1998.

Chen said he took great pleasure in attending the ceremony, saying he was impressed by the "lantern tunnel" along the tree-dotted Jen Ai Road that links the Presidential Office to the Taipei City Hall. The road, decorated with numerous lanterns and small light bulbs, now looks like a "lantern tunnel."

Noting that Lantern Festival, which falls on the 15th day of the first month on the lunar calendar, has traditionally marked the end of Lunar New Year celebrations, Chen said he hopes all local people will start hard work after the festival.

"Our country endured man crises and difficulties in the past year. The new Year of the Rooster is like a 'blank' paper which is full of promise. Let's work even harder from now on to create even brighter future for our country," Chen said.
In related news, Premier Frank Hsieh attended the Pinghsi Sky Lantern Festival light-up ceremony in Pinghsi on the outskirts of Taipei.
Hsieh wrote eight Chinese characters on a big sky lantern to pray for reconciliation, co-existence and progress in the new year.
"I keenly hopes the sky lantern will bring good fortune, peace and prosperity to Taiwan and all mankind around the world, " Hsieh said.

The activity was organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and attended by more than 40 foreign ambassadors and representatives stationed in Taipei as well as tens of thousands local people to pray for world peace and security.
Foreign diplomats signed their names with calligraphy brushes on five huge lanterns that were lit and allowed to rise into the sky, hot air balloon-style, in a gesture to appeal for world peace.

The activity was designed to help foreign envoys gain a better understanding of Taiwan's traditions and lifestyles and offer them an opportunity to spread love, care and compassion to the rest of the world jointly with the Taiwan people, MOFA officials said.

The activity was also meant to thank the many anonymous donors who contributed to the tsunami refugees in Southeast Asia and South Asia, the officials said, adding that the ROC government and private sector contributed more than NT$2 billion (US$63.5 million) and 3.55 million tons of relief materials to various tsunami-affected countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: F.D.A. Is Advised to Let Pain Pills Stay on Market
A panel of experts voted unanimously on Friday to advise the Food and Drug Administration that three leading painkillers - Celebrex, Bextra and Vioxx - can cause worrisome heart problems. But it also advised against banning the drugs, though by narrow margins in the cases of Bextra and Vioxx. Most of the advisory panel's members said that the agency should do the following: place warnings on the drugs' labels detailing their heart risks; ban consumer advertising for the drugs; and require each prescription to include a guide outlining the risks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
FDA Panel Opens Door For Return Of Vioxx; Many Advisers Urge New Restrictions on Painkillers
A Food and Drug Administration expert advisory panel narrowly voted yesterday in favor of allowing the arthritis painkiller Vioxx back on the market under strict conditions. The committee also voted in favor of allowing Celebrex and other drugs in the COX-2 class to remain available.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 20 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Feb. 20:
10: 00, The Taiwan North Society will sponsor a seminar on strategies to cope with China's so-called anti-secession law in Taipei.
10:45, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun will attend activities at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
17:00, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng will preside over the light-up ceremony for a lantern exhibition at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
18:30, Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai will preside over a light-up ceremony rehearsal for the 2005 Kaoshiugn Lantern Festival at the bank of Love River.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 20, or the 12th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1437: James I, King of Scotland, is assassinated by a group of nobles seeking to place a rival on the throne. He was 42.
1694: Voltaire, French philosopher, writer and moralist who waged a lifelong campaign against intolerance and injustice, is born.
1707: Aurangzeb, the sixth and perhaps last of the great Mogul emperors of India, dies at the age of 88. He seized the throne at Agra from his father, Shah Jahan, 49 years earlier, killing two of his brothers and jailing the third to secure his succession.
1811: Austria declares itself bankrupt.
1904: Alexei Kosygin, Soviet prime minister from 1964 to 1980, is born.
1915: The Panama-Pacific Exhibition, in celebration of the opening of the Panama Canal between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, opens in San Francisco.
1916: The Battle of Verdun begins after Chief of the German General Staff Falkenhayn chooses to attack the French city of Verdun, despite his belief that France will defend it to the last man.
1919: Afghan head of state Habibullah Khan is assassinated. He was succeeded by one of his sons, Amanullah Khan.
1922: Hong Kong police fire on striking workers, killing two and severely injuring seven.
1933: The U.S. House of Representatives passes an act to abolish the law prohibiting the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1938: British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of appeasement of Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini and German's Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
1942: Portugal protests to Japan after Japanese troops invade Portuguese Timor.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China declares the Yalta Secret Agreement not binding in the case of China.
1952: A meeting on the Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is held in Taipei.
1960: The third plenary session of the first ROC National Assembly opens in Taipei.
1962: Astronaut John Glenn circles the Earth three times in less than five hours, becoming the first U.S. citizen to orbit the planet.
1966: Chester William Nimitz, admiral of the U.S. Pacific Fleet during World War II, who halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers, dies at the age of 81.
1967: President Sukarno surrenders all executive power to General Suharto, keeping only the title of president of Indonesia.
1971: Major-General Idi Amin Dada heads the new government of Uganda as president after the Uganda Army overthrows Apollo Milton Obote.
1972: Radio telephone service between Taipei and Madrid is inaugurated.
1974: A six-member South Korean Parliamentary Mission led by Oh Joon Suk arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1976: International Monetary Fund experts and representatives of the ROC Ministry of Finance begin their annual meeting with ROC Vice Minister Wang Shao-yu and the IMF Asia Department's consultant Andreas Abadjis as co-chairs.
1976: Gen. Wego Chiang, president of the Armed Forces University, and 30 foreign cadets studying war techniques in the ROC visit the offshore island of Kinmen.
1979: Mount Sinira erupts in Indonesia, claiming 175 lives.
1988: Torrential flooding in Rio de Janeiro leaves 500 dead and 10,000 homeless.
1997: Washington refuses to recognize the World Trade Organization's authority in its dispute with the European Union over trade with Cuba.
2000: ROC opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian stresses that only political party rotation can maintain Taiwan's administrative neutrality and achieve independence of the government's judicial branch.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is not in office in the government of a country, should never give advice as to its policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: Thermometer plunges by 20 degrees Celsius, eight died from cold.
The United Daily News: U.S., Japan calls jointly for peace talks between Taiwan and mainland China.
The Liberty Times: U.S. and Japan set goal of easing tension across Taiwan Straits.
The Taiwan Daily: President Chen Shui-bian and Taipei City Mayor lighten lantern together.
The Central Daily News: U.S. reiterates its opposition to unilateral change of situation across Taiwan Straits.
The China Post: Premier singles out priority bills for legislative session.
The Taiwan News: Lu welcomes U.S., Japan concern.
The Taipei Times: China joins the diplomatic fray in North Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA, Enrile back ID system
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo stood firm yesterday in pushing for the establishment of a national identification (ID) card system, initially on the local level and soon on a national scale, saying it is a vital component of government's anti-terror efforts.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 'Terror threat still high'
THE US State Department urged Americans in the Philippines to remain on high alert, warning there might be future bombings targeting airports, passenger ships and seaports.
The Philippine Star: Local gov'ts may enact own nat'l ID ordinances
The controversy surrounding the proposal to implement a national identification (ID) system can be avoided through local legislation, Malacanang said yesterday.
The Manila Times: New Jolo clashes kill 9
Fresh fighting erupted Saturday in Jolo where government troops captured a Muslim rebel camp just days earlier, leaving at least four soldiers dead and one wounded.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Audit Faults U.S. for Its Spending on Port Defense
The Department of Homeland Security has allocated hundreds of millions of dollars to protect ports since Sept. 11 without sufficiently focusing on those that are most vulnerable, a policy that could compromise the United States' ability to better defend against terrorist attacks, the department's inspector general has concluded. The audit found that hndreds of thousands of dollars has been invested in redundant lighting systems and unnecessary technical equipment, but "the program has not yet achieved its intended results in the form of actual improvement in port security." The audit report indicated that lless than a quarter of the US$517million that the department distributed in grants between June 2002 and December 2003 had been spent as of September 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP SAYS PFP MUST NOT DERAIL PLANNED CHEN-SOONG MEETING

TEXT.P: Postponing a planned meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong would cast a shadow over the credibility of the PFP and disappoint the public, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) whip Lai Ching-the said Sunday.

The meeting was to have been sometime before the start of the new legislative session on Feb. 25, but the PFP has cooled on the idea since an investigation into possible illegal investments in mainland China by semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) was undertaken. The chairman of the company, Robert Tsao, is a PFP supporter.
Lai said the Chen-Soong meeting should not be linked with the possible case against UMC as it is a judicial probe that has nothing to do with politics.
UMC is alleged to have invested without the permission of the Taiwan government in a Suzhou, southern China-based chipmaker, He Jian Technology. Tsao has denied the allegations.

It is inappropriate for the PFP to postpone the proposed Chen-Soong meeting to try and gain leverage over the outcome of the UMC investigation, Lai said, adding that the image of the judicial branch of government would be sullied if it were less than impartial, as Soong seems to be implying.
Moreover, the image of the PFP would be tarnished if it actually believes that the president could meddle in judicial affairs.

The Chen-Soong meeting is aimed at creating an atmosphere for reconciliation among competing parties and thereby lay the groundwork for some form of cooperation between the DPP and the PFP, Lai said. It is not an exercise in political horse-trading, which would benefit no one and prompt a backlash from the general public, Lai went on.
Noting that preparations for the Chen-Soong meeting have already begun, Lai urged Soong not to disappoint the public by pulling the plug at the eleventh hour.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: FDA Advisors OK Disputed Pain Relievers.
A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel voted to let doctors prescribe Cox-2 painkillers, including Celebrex and Vioxx, but recommended stronger warnings about the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES INCLUSION OF TAIWAN IN U.S.-JAPAN SECURITY STATEMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs Sunday welcomed the new U.S.-Japan joint security statement, in which cross-Taiwan Strait issues are included for the first time.
The United States' security alliance with Japan forms the backbone of U.S foreign policy in Asia.

The joint security statement, announced upon the conclusion of the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee in Washington, D.C. Saturday, indicated that both Japan and the United States will develop a cooperative relationship with China, welcoming it to play a responsible and regionally and globally constructive role.
The statement also indicated that Japan and the United States encourage the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue.

Saying that he was pleased that cross-strait issues were included in the security statement as common strategic objectives of Japan and the United States, foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu said that Taiwan attaches great importance to maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait, and that Taiwan is committed to securing peace, stability and sustainable development in the Asia-Pacific region.

The text of the official statement, however, was not identical to what was reported earlier in the Washington Post that said that "the United States and Japan will declare Saturday for the first time in a joint agreement that Taiwan is a mutual security concern." Commenting on this, Lu said that " although the official statement differs from the media report, their spirits are perceptibly the same."

On what roles the United States and Japan are expected to play in matters concerning cross-strait security in the future, Lu said that it is still too early to speculate on any "concrete moves," although the statement is believed to be conducive to peaceful development across the Taiwan Strait in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Talk With Putin Will Test Bush's Inaugural Pledges.
The last time they sat down, President Bush politely asked President Vladimir Putin about Russia's retreat from democracy. Putin, according to U.S. officials, responded with a testy tirade on Russian history, filibustering for so long that Bush, left with an extended list of other issues to cover in a short private lunch, let the matter go without challenging the former KGB colonel. (By Jorge Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' URGED TO OPPOSE CHINA'S 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: Scholars urged political leaders from the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party (PFP) and New Party Sunday to come forward and oppose mainland China's attempt to enact an "anti-secession law."

At a seminar organized by several pro-independence groups to discuss Taiwan's options to counter Beijing's attempts to bring Taiwan into its fold, Hsu Young-ming, a researcher at Academia Sinica, recommended that the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is the leading organizer of a Feb. 28 protest against mainland China's proposed legislation, ask leaders of the "pan-blue alliance" to side with them on this issue.

Noting that KMT Vice Chairman and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is expected to run for president in 2008, Hsu said Ma is likely to be amenable to joining the protest to fend off Beijing's attempt to enact a law purporting to prevent Taiwan from seeking independence.
Once Ma joins the protest, Hsu said, KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong are almost certain to follow suit, Hsu optimistically predicted.

Wu Shu-ming, chairman of the Northern Taiwan Society, told the seminar that the joint statement issued the previous day in Washington by the United States and Japan that encourages the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait is an unveiled warning to mainland China against its military threat to Taiwan. This statement is beneficial for Taiwan, he added.

Taiwan should make good use of this opportunity to air its opposition to Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law," and drive home to the international community the danger posed by such a law to Taiwan, Wu said.

He urged the government to respond in a high-profile manner to the proposed bill, preferably in conjunction with the international community, since the world will not even notice what Beijing is doing if Taiwan remains silent.

Also at the seminar was Lin Hsiang-kei, a professor from National Taiwan University. He questioned Taiwan's policy of dealing with matters of politics and economics differently regarding the mainland when China treats them the same when it comes to Taiwan.

The economist said international rating firms considered Taiwan's business environment excellent in 2000 when the Democratic Progressive Party took power; however, foreign investors got cold feet afterward because of the island's decision to allow domestic manufacturers to relocate their operation to the mainland. If local businessmen are scrambling into the mainland market, how can the government convince foreigners to invest in the island deserted by its own businessmen?

The island is nursing a viper by funnelling so many investment projects to the mainland, Lin warned, adding that this will give Beijing an easy weapon to control the island through Taiwan's heavy economic interdependence on China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WELCOMES INTERNATIONAL ATTENTION TO TAIWAN ISSUE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said he welcomes the international community's concern about peace across the Taiwan Strait after the U.S. and Japan listed the peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues as one of their joint strategic objectives in the region.

Noting that peace resolution of issues between Taiwan and the mainland would serve the interests of both sides of the Strait, the premier said he would like to see more attention paid to the issue by the international community.

As to the review conducted by Washington and Tokyo about the geographical scope covered by their joint defense pact, Hsieh said his administration will monitor the situation, but he cautioned his fellow countrymen not to expect too much from it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO CUT BACK ON 'OVER-PACKAGING' OF PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is preparing to notify other members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) about a draft bill concerning efforts to limit excessive product packaging, authorities from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Sunday.

The draft bill, still in the pipeline at the EPA, is meant to notify WTO members about Taiwan's regulations and standards on product packaging in an attempt to minimize the negative impact on the environmental and to ensure that regulations, standards, testing and certification procedures do not create unnecessary obstacles or technical barriers to international trade, EPA officials said.

The contents of the draft bill are expected to be posted on the WTO Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT) Web site beginning later this month to allow interested parties from other WTO members to become acquainted with Taiwan's regulations on future product packaging, EPA officials noted.

Since consistent international standards do not exist, EPA officials said, the EPA is drafting Taiwan's own statute to limit excessive packaging of products, while taking into consideration that the impact of the statute must not cause problems regarding trade with other WTO members.
The early notification is being done so that amendments can still be introduced and comments taken into account, EPA officials said.
Technical regulations and product standards vary from country to country. Having many different regulations and standards makes life difficult for producers and exporters, EPA officials noted.

According to the EPA-drafted "over-packaging control draft bill," the outer package of a product must not exceed 25 percent of the product's volume or size, and no outer wrapping should exceed three layers.

The bill, which will contribute to reducing the waste of materials and resources, as well as reducing the labor needed in waste handling, is expected to be enacted and publicized next May and take effect next July at the earliest, EPA officials said.

It is expected that after the "over-packaging control law" takes effect, Taiwan's packaging designs will move toward a "material-saving, easy-to-recycle direction, " the officials said, adding that the volume of packaging materials is expected to be reduced by 6,900 tons a year, about one-third of the volume that is used islandwide currently.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S 'CHINA PHOBIA' CHANGING: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Japan's anxiety over Communist China has gradually eased, underlined by its willingness to explicitly agree in a joint U.S.-Japan security statement that Japan and the United States encourage the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said Sunday.

Tang Bi-a, the Tainan-based DPP legislator who maintains close connections with Japanese politicians, said that although Japan and the United States were not specific on protecting Taiwan's security in the new U.S.-Japan joint security statement, it is historically significant that the two governments included cross-Taiwan Strait issues as one of their common strategic objectives for the future.

Tang added that Japan and the United States did not explicitly indicate in the joint statement that "Taiwan is a mutual security concern" as the Washington Post predicted earlier to save face for Beijing and to avoid irritating Chinese at the same time.
The United States' security alliance with Japan forms the backbone of U.S foreign policy in Asia.

The joint security statement, announced upon the conclusion of the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee in Washington, D.C. Saturday, indicated that both Japan and the United States will develop a cooperative relationship with China, welcoming it to play a responsible and regionally and globally constructive role.
The statement also indicated that Japan and the United States encourage the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue.

The text of the official statement, however, was not identical to what was reported Friday in the Washington Post that said that "the United States and Japan will declare Saturday for the first time in a joint agreement that Taiwan is a mutual security concern."

Tang commented that it has been difficult for the Japanese government to make major changes in its policy on mainland China, although Japan's stance on Beijing has been changing gradually as a result of Beijing's bullying attitude toward Japan and other countries.
Tang said she will trying harder in the future in efforts to push for the Japanese government to take a harder attitude toward Beijing to reflect the facts.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-JAPAN STATEMENT REAFFIRMATION OF ASIAN ROLE: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The newly released joint United States-Japan statement that included a reference to desiring peace in the Taiwan Strait was not made to contain mainland China; rather, it emphasized the maturing alliance between Japan and the U.S. in the Asia-Pacific region, a political analyst from a Taiwan think tank said Sunday.

Lai I-chung, director for the Department of International Affairs at Taiwan ThinkTank, said although the U.S.-Japan joint statement said the two countries "encourage the peaceful resolutions of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue" rather than list "Taiwan security" as their joint concern as reports had forecast, it doesn't means the reports are false.
"Officials from the Japanese foreign ministry indicated that 'the security of the Taiwan Strait' would be listed among the joint strategic objectives of Japan and the United States," Lai said.
The statement showed that Japan has joined hands with the United States in assuming a role as the manager of international order in the area in line with its increasing strength and globalization.

In case of a military conflict between Taiwan and China, Lai predicted that Washington would not sit idly by and Tokyo would give logistic support to whatever military action is taken by the United States, but would stop short of participating in the conflict itself.
He recommended that Taipei authorities reach out to this new accord through exchanges with Japan and the United States in the fields of economics, the military and anti-submarine warfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO AWARD PRIZES TO FARMERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will honor 34 farmers by awarding them "Shen-nung" or "farming god" prizes Monday, an official from the Council of Agriculture which sponsors the event said Sunday.
Among the 34 winners chosen for their distinguished contribution to the country's agriculture sector, 12 are women, the official said.
The president will also honor 18 model farmers.
There have been 765 winners since the awards were established in 1983.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF JOINT U.S.-JAPAN SECURITY COMMITTEE STATEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun & Jorge Liu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China and North Korea were main concerns of a meeting of the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee held Saturday in Washington, D.C.

A joint statement, issued by the committee after U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld, Japan's Minister for Foreign Affairs Nobutaka Machimura and Minister of State for Defense and Director-General of the Defense Agency Yoshinori Ohno concluding the one-day meeting, indicated that new threats are also emerging in the Asia-Pacific region and that modernization of military capabilities in the region requires attention.

To encourage China to improve transparency of its military affairs and to encourage the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue were listed in the statement as part of U.S.-Japan common strategic objectives in the region.

The ministers also strongly urged North Korea to return to the six-party talks expeditiously and without preconditions, and to commit itself to complete dismantlement of all its nuclear programs in a transparent manner subject to verification.
The full text of the joint statement is as follows:
1. United States Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and
Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld hosted Japan's Minister
for Foreign Affairs Nobutaka Machimura and Minister of State
for Defense and Director-General of the Defense Agency
Yoshinori Ohno in a meeting of the Security Consultative
Committee (SCC) in Washington, DC, on February 19, 2005. They
addressed security and alliance issues facing the United
States and Japan, as well as other aspects of the
relationship. Working Together on Challenges Facing the World
Today
2. The Ministers noted the excellent state of cooperative
relations between the United States and Japan on a broad array
of security, political, and economic issues. They looked to
expand that cooperation, recognizing that the U.S.-Japan
Alliance, with the U.S.-Japan security arrangements at its
core, continues to play a vital role in ensuring the security
and prosperity of both the United States and Japan, as well as
in enhancing regional and global peace and stability.
3. The Ministers underscored the importance of U.S. and Japanese
leadership in providing international assistance to
Afghanistan, Iraq, and the broader Middle East -- efforts that
are already producing results. The Ministers lauded the
successful cooperation between the United States and Japan
with other countries in extending wide-ranging assistance to
those who suffered from the earthquake and the subsequent
tsunami disaster in the Indian Ocean.
4. The Ministers recognized that cooperation and consultation
between the United States and Japan have been pivotal in
promoting non-proliferation, particularly through the
Proliferation Security Initiative. They welcomed the success
of multinational interdiction exercises hosted by the United
States and Japan and by others.
5. The Ministers expressed their confidence that ballistic
missile defense (BMD) enhances our ability to defend against
and deter ballistic missile attacks and dissuade other parties
from investing in ballistic missiles. Taking note of
achievements in missile defense cooperation, such as Japan's
decision to introduce ballistic missile defense systems and
its recent announcement on its Three Principles on Arms
Export, the Ministers reaffirmed their commitment to close
cooperation on policy and operational matters and to advancing
U.S.-Japan cooperative research in BMD systems, with a view to
possible cooperative development.
Common Strategic Objectives
6. The Ministers discussed the new security environment in which
new and emerging threats, such as international terrorism and
proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) and their
means of delivery, have surfaced as common challenges. They
recognized that deepening interdependence among nations in a
global community means that such threats can affect the
security of nations worldwide, including the United States and
Japan.
7. While noting that these threats are also emerging in the
Asia-Pacific region, the Ministers also emphasized that
persistent challenges continue to create unpredictability and
uncertainty. Moreover, they noted that modernization of
military capabilities in the region also requires attention.
9. Based on this understanding of the international security
environment, the Ministers concurred that both Governments
need to work closely together to pursue common strategic
objectives through their respective efforts, implementation of
the U.S.-Japan security arrangements, and other joint efforts
based on the alliance. Both sides decided to hold regular
consultations to coordinate policies in accordance with these
common strategic objectives and to update these objectives as
the security environment requires.
10. In the region, common strategic objectives include:
* Ensure the security of Japan, strengthen peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, and maintain the capability to address contingencies affecting the United States and Japan.
* Support peaceful unification of the Korean Peninsula.

* Seek peaceful resolution of issues related to North Korea, including its nuclear programs, ballistic missile activities, illicit activities, and humanitarian issues such as the abduction of Japanese nationals by North Korea.
* Develop a cooperative relationship with China, welcoming the country to play a responsible and constructive role regionally as well as globally.
* Encourage the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue.
* Encourage China to improve transparency of its military affairs.
* Encourage Russia's constructive engagement in the Asia-Pacific region.
* Fully normalize Japan-Russia relations through the resolution of the Northern Territories issue.
* Promote a peaceful, stable, and vibrant Southeast Asia.
* Welcome the development of various forms of regional cooperation, while stressing the importance of open, inclusive, and transparent regional mechanisms.
* Discourage destabilizing sales and transfers of arms and
military technology.
* Maintain the security of maritime traffic.
11. Global common strategic objectives include:
* Promote fundamental values such as basic human rights, democracy, and the rule of law in the international community.
* Further consolidate U.S.-Japan partnership in international peace cooperation activities and development assistance to promote peace, stability, and prosperity worldwide.

* Promote the reduction and non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) and their means of delivery, including through improved reliability and effectiveness of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, the International Atomic Energy Agency, and other regimes, and initiatives such as the Proliferation Security Initiative.
* Prevent and eradicate terrorism.
* Coordinate efforts to improve the effectiveness of the United Nations Security Council by making the best use of the current momentum to realize Japan's aspiration to become a permanent member.
* Maintain and enhance the stability of the global energy supply. Strengthening of U.S.-Japan Security and Defense Cooperation.
12. The Ministers expressed their support and appreciation for
each other's efforts to develop their respective security and
defense policies. Japan's new National Defense Program
Guidelines (NDPG) emphasize Japan's capability to respond
effectively to new threats and diverse contingencies, Japan's
active engagement to improve the international security
environment, and the importance of the Japan-U.S. Alliance.
As a central component of its broad defense transformation
effort, the United States is reorienting and strengthening
its global defense posture to provide it with appropriate,
strategy-driven capabilities in an uncertain security
environment. The Ministers confirmed that these efforts will
ensure and strengthen effective security and defense
cooperation as both countries pursue common strategic
objectives.
13. In this context, the Ministers underscored the need to
continue examining the roles, missions, and capabilities of
Japan's Self Defense Forces and the U.S. Armed Forces
required to respond effectively to diverse challenges in a
well-coordinated manner. This examination will take into
account recent achievements and developments such as Japan's
NDPG and new legislation to deal with contingencies, as well
as the expanded agreement on mutual logistical support and
progress in BMD cooperation. The Ministers also emphasized
the importance of enhancing interoperability between U.S. and
Japanese forces.
14. The Ministers concurred that this examination should
contribute to these consultations on realignment of U.S.
force structure in Japan. They decided to intensify these
consultations in a comprehensive effort to strengthen the
alliance as the bedrock of Japan's security and the anchor of
regional stability. In this context, both sides confirmed
their commitment to maintaining deterrence and capabilities
of U.S. forces in Japan while reducing the burden on local
communities, including those in Okinawa. The Ministers
directed their staffs to report expeditiously on the results
of these consultations.
15. The Ministers also stressed the importance of continued
efforts to enhance positive relations between local
communities and U.S. forces. They emphasized that improved
implementation of the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) ,
including due attention to the environment, and steady
implementation of the Special Action Committee on Okinawa
(SACO) Final Report are important to the stable presence of
U.S. forces in Japan.
16. The Ministers, noting that the current Special Measures
Agreement (SMA) will expire in March 2006, decided to start
consultations on future arrangements to provide appropriate
levels of host nation support, bearing in mind the
significant role of the SMA in supporting the presence of
U.S. forces in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DATE FOR CHEN-SOONG MEETING YET TO BE IRONED OUT: PFP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Aides to President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will meet in the next few days to set a date for a much-anticipated meeting between the two, a PFP official said Sunday.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's policy-making center, told the Central New Agency that PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng is expected to contact Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun to talk about the detail of the meeting, and added that he himself will soon meet Presidential Vice Secretary-General James Huang to set a date and concrete discussion topics for the meeting.

Local media has reported that the Chen-Soong meeting is very likely to be held between Feb. 25, when the sixth Legislative Yuan will hold its first meeting, and Feb. 27, when former U.S. President Bill Clinton is slated to visit Taiwan.

Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the legislature, said that the two parties should do everything they can to make the much-awaited meeting happen as soon as possible amid high public expectations.

A Chen-Soong meeting has been much anticipated by the public since the president called for compromise and rapport between the ruling and opposition parties in the wake of the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Despite the fact that Chen narrowly won the March 20, 2004 presidential election for a second term, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the PFP and the New Party retained its majority in the 225-member Legislative Yuan after the general polls, controlling a total of 114 seats.

In an effort to put an end to bitter political conflicts, the DPP, which won 89 seats in the legislature, has tried hard to entice the PFP, which seized 34 seats, to form a majority to push through bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Blair's pension offer to mothers.
Tony Blair is planning to woo stay-at-home mothers in the forthcoming general election by pledging a big increase in their basic state pension if Labour is re-elected. The proposed manifesto pledge, worth at least 3 billion pounds, would mean that women would be entitled to full state pensions regardless of how many years they had worked.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER VOWS TO HELP ECONOMY, WARNS OF MAINLAND INVESTMENT RISKS

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i has vowed to help Premier Frank Hsieh improve Taiwan's economy and help domestic companies effectively explore the mainland market by offering them advice to avoid investment risks there.

Wu made the remarks Saturday at a news conference held at a Russian-style restaurant run by the Taiwan Russia Association (TRA) in response to concerns over investigations into United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC).

The Taiwan-based semiconductor giant -- the world's second-largest chip maker on a contract basis -- was charged by prosecutors with illegally investing in a mainland-based wafer plant -- He Jian Technology in Suzhou -- which triggered concerns from the public and the political spectrum.

Claiming that the UMC case is by no means a politically motivated matter, Wu urged the public not to overreact to the case and said that the government does not prevent Taiwan businesses from making money in mainland China; on the contrary, it provides them with advice to ward off risks in the highly volatile market.

Wu urged domestic enterprises to be extremely cautious in their mainland investment plans and said that the government is in a position to remind them of possible risks, despite the fact that their investments are not prohibited by law.
The vice premier also encouraged Taiwan companies to diversify their investments by considering breaking into the Russian market.
Citing remarks by TRA Vice Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung, he said that a TRA delegation visited Russia last year and did business worth US$250 million.

The establishment of the TRA was also designed to boost economic and cultural exchanges between the two countries, he said, pointing out that the former communist country has transformed to a market-driven economy.

George Zinoviev, deputy director of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission in Taipei, voiced his hope that the TRA will help open a new window of opportunities and exchanges for the people of the two countries.
Wu served as chairman of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research before becoming Hsieh's deputy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTERCARD ADVISOR POSITIVE ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY, JOB MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy and the job market will continue to improve this year on the back of a resilient real estate market, according to the leading economic advisor with MasterCard International.

Yuwa Hedrick-Wong, the leading economic advisor in charge of Asia-Pacific markets at the international credit card organization, made the forecast Saturday while publishing a report on the new global economy.

According to Hedrick-Wong, the Taiwan economy is currently in an upward spiral, with its property market expected to further move up this year after a recession of more than nine years. Housing prices in Taiwan surged by 12 percent on average for 2004.

As banks are likely to continue a loose loan policy for home buyers this year, a low interest rate will further stimulant the real estate market and benefit other sectors, helping pushing up incomes of salaried people and increase consumers' spending, Wang said.

Wang predicted that Taiwan's jobless rate will fall from 4.1 percent in 2004 to 3.7 percent in 2005, and that consumer spending will rise by 4.5 percent this year as compared to last year's 3.6 percent. Consumer product prices are assessed to increase by around 3 percent, he added.

He also forecast that the Taiwan economy will expand by 5.5 percent this year, slower than the previous year's 6 percent, but pointed out that employees' salaries will not grow at a fast pace on the grounds that companies would rather spend money to hire more workers.

Commenting on future challenges facing Taiwan's businesses, he said that large enterprises should step up their research and design efforts to build up their own brand names to grab a larger slice in the world market, including mainland China.
In the small- and medium-sized sector, companies may encounter a shortage of skilled workers as a result of a long-term lack of industrial upgrading and innovation, he estimated.

Taiwan will be able to create and seize a larger market only when its trade and economic exchanges with mainland China are fully free from restrictions and included in the vast trade bloc formed by the mainland and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON INVITED TO TAKE PART IN CAMPAIGN FOR FREE TAIWAN ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: The organizers of a universal campaign for a "free Taiwan" have invited former United States President Bill Clinton to take part in activities they will organize in Taiwan, an official of the organizing committee said Sunday.

Wu Shu-min, president of the Northern Taiwan Society, said that Clinton will be invited make a wish Feb. 28 at a "wishing tree" to be erected in front of the Red Theater in Taipei City and bear witness to Taiwan people's strong willingness for a free Taiwan.
Premier Frank Hsieh will also be invited to take part in the activities.
According to media reports, Clinton is expected to arrive in Taiwan Feb. 27 for a visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
MOFA officials said, however, that Clinton's itinerary has yet to be finalized.
The Northern Taiwan Society together with a number of local pro-independence groups are organizing a global campaign for a free Taiwan on Feb. 28 -- Taiwan's Peace Memorial Day.
A lighting-up rally will be held simultaneously in 16 counties and cities in Taiwan as well as in a dozen overseas cities on the evening of Feb. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MULLS INCREASE OF CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: The government will evaluate the possibility of increasing cross-Taiwan Strait charter flight services, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Sunday.
Chiu made the remarks after this year's special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flight services came to an end that day.

The government will conduct a comprehensive review and evaluation of the charter flight services and will weigh the possibility of allowing the operation of charter flights for the Dragon Boat Festival and Mid Autumn Festival holidays or on weekends, he said.
This year's cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights, which started Jan. 29, were successful and were believed to have paved the way for improvement in the cross-strait ties, Chiu stressed.
A total of 48 flights were jointly operated by 12 carriers from the two sides of the strait, serving more than 10,000 passengers, aviation industry sources said.

Unlike the previous Lunar New Year charter flight services in 2003, which were operated solely by Taiwanese airlines between Shanghai and Taipei/Kaohsiung via Hong Kong/Macau, this year's charter flights were not required to land in a third location en route, although they still need to detour through Hong Kong air space.

Meanwhile, more than 35,000 people used the ferry service between Kinmen and Xiamen with a total of 250 trips operated by ships from the two sides during the period between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20, according to tallies made public Sunday by Kinmen authorities.

The Kinmen-Xiamen shipping links form part of the so-called "three mini links" -- along with direct trade and transport links -- between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports. The links were established on Jan. 1, 2001 to help promote economic development on the two frontline islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 21, or the 13th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1673: Jean Baptiste Poquelin Moliere, the French playwright whose sophisticated comedies include "Tartuffe" and "The Misanthrope," is buried in secret in a Paris cemetery.
1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLANS TO HOLD JOINT MILITARY EXERCISES WITH U.S., JAPAN: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) categorically denied news reports Monday that Taiwan's military is preparing to conduct joint military exercises with the United States and Japan when it holds its annual "Hankuang" military exercises later this year.

Noting that the "Hankuang" exercises are a regular part of the Republic of China military's training, MND spokesman Liu Chih-chien said there are currently no plans to hold joint exercises with any other countries.

Commenting on another newspaper report that an ROC Naval fleet is planning to conduct its first-ever around-the-globe friendship tour to cement ties with seven diplomatic allies, Liu said that the plans are in the works with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and that no formal announcement will be made concerning the tour until the two ministries have worked out all the relevant details.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONWIDE ABORIGINAL GAMES TO OPEN LATE MARCH IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The nationwide aboriginal games are slated to be held March 25-28 in Kaohsiung County, with more than 3,000 aborigine athletes from 24 cities and counties taking part, the games' preparatory committee announced Monday.

A total of 3,078 men and women athletes are expected to compete in 14 events during the four-day games to be held at 10 venues around Kaohsiung County, said Su Hui-yueh, preparatory committee executive director.

The torch run marking the opening of the biennial games is scheduled to start from the Maolin National Park March 16. President Chen Shui-bian is expected to grace the games with his presence at the opening ceremony to be held at the Kaohsiung County Stadium March 25, Su said.

The 14 sporting events to be featured at the games are: track and field, relay racing, road running, tug of war, weigtlifing, table tennis, volleyball, judo, traditional archery, aboriginal weightlifing, aboriginal wrestling, aboriginal dance and worship rituals, softball, and croquet, according to Su.
