DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-JAPAN JOINT STATEMENT A 'POSITIVE STEP' SAYS U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. scholar on Sunday affirmed Japan's endorsement of the need for a peaceful solution of the Taiwan Strait issue in a joint statement released after the U.S.-Japan Security Consultation Committee meeting, saying that "it is a positive step."

The meeting was held in Washington, D.C. last Saturday by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, Japanese Foreign Minister Nobutaka Machimura and Defense Minister Yoshinori Ohno to discuss various issues including a peaceful resolution of cross-strait problems.

Concluding the meeting, the United States and Japan officials listed "encouraging the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue" in the statement as part of their common strategic objectives in the Asia-Pacific region.

Commenting on the statement, June Teufel Dreyer, a political science professor at the University of Miami, said: "This is less than we were led to believe would be contained in the joint statement. But it is still a positive step, since to the best of my knowledge, it is the first time that Japan has expressed itself officially endorsing the need for a peaceful solution of the Taiwan Strait issue."

It is reckoned that the United States and Japan talked more about the issue in private than in public, the professor said, adding that if China adopts its proposed anti-secession law, this will further stimulate Japan.

However, the scholar said she's worried about Washington's recent description of its one-China policy, saying that what worries her "is the way recent references to the one-China policy have seemed to accept Beijing's view of what 'one China' is, as opposed to the original Shanghai Communique statement that the U.S. merely acknowledges that 'Chinese on both sides of the strait' believe there is but one China."

In the statement, the United States and Japan's common strategic objectives also include ensuring Japan's security, strengthening peace and stability in the Asian and Asian-Pacific regions, developing cooperation relations with China, and welcoming China to play a responsible and constructive role in the region and in the world.

Expressing their serious concern over the statement, a spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Sunday that the Chinese government and people are fiercely opposed to the United States and Japan including Taiwan issues related to China's national sovereignty, territorial integrity and national security in the joint statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER CARGO FLIGHTS NEED OFFICIAL NEGOTIATIONS: MOTC

TEXT.P: The opening of direct charter cargo flights across the Taiwan Strait needs to be negotiated by representatives commissioned by the governments of the two sides, a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) official said Monday.

Lin Chih-ming, director of the MOTC's Department of Navigation and Aviation, said that he does not think it appropriate that senior executives from six Taiwan airlines talk about the issue with mainland Chinese authorities when the Taiwan executives attend a Spring Festival party in Beijing Tuesday. The event is being hosted by the mainland's Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC).

Although the unprecedented two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter passenger flights went off without a hitch during the recent Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, creating a favorable atmosphere for carriers from the two sides to consider direct cross-strait charter cargo flights, Lin stressed that official negotiations are a must before direct cross-strait charter cargo flights can be opened.

Taiwan negotiators, whether officials from the private Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) or airline representatives themselves, will have to be authorized by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to engage in cross-strait negotiations before direct charter cargo flights are operated on a regular basis, Lin noted.

He added that since Beijing refuses to engage Taiwan's government, the MAC had to commission an official from the TAA to negotiate the Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights and other aviation pacts with Hong Kong and Macau in the past.

Chang Kuo-cheng, director-general of the MOTC Civil Aeronautics Administration, in his capacity as an adviser to the private TAA, took part in talks with mainland Chinese negotiators for the opening of the landmark Chinese Lunar New Year charter passenger flights.
Chang said that so far he has no idea whether he will be assigned again as one of the Taiwan negotiators for talks with Beijing on direct cross-strait charter cargo flights.

All 12 senior executives from Taiwan's six carriers who are traveling to Beijing for Tuesday's Spring Festival party have kept a low profile and have said nothing about speculation that direct cross-strait charter cargo flights will be brought up during the party.

Purely coincidental or not, the MAC hosted a similar party Monday in honor of the representatives from the six Taiwan carriers and officials from the TAA as well as the transportation and communications ministry.

According to Michael Lo, president of the TAA, who concurrently serves as president of Mandarin Airlines, this is not the first time the CAAC has invited Taiwan airline executives to Beijing for Spring Festival celebrations.

"Taiwan's airline companies have all set up representative offices in mainland China and are familiar with CAAC officials. We have frequent exchanges. Similar Spring Festival gatherings between the two sides have taken place in the past," Lo said.
Lo said the rumors of the trip being used to discuss the direct flights are unfounded because he will visit Beijing in his capacity as Mandarin Airlines president, not as president of the TAA.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR STILL AWAITING RESPONSE FROM PFP CHAIRMAN ON MEETING

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that he is still awaiting a response from opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong regarding his suggestion that they come together for a meeting.
According to Ma, who is also one of the Kuomintang's vice chairmen, Soong promised to meet him during or after the Lunar New Year holidays.

While responding to media questions before listening to a briefing on the "Taipei Travel Network" project at the Taipei Municipal Hall, Ma said that he doesn't mind waiting until a later date if the PFP chairman is too busy to hold such a meeting at the current time.

In response to a reporter's question, Ma said that a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and James Soong would not affect the "pan-blue alliance's" process of further consolidating their cooperation.

"Pan-blue alliance" supporters have requested that the Kuomintang and the PFP further consolidate their cooperation or even move toward a merger, the mayor said, adding that the Kuomintang will not abandon these goals even though it will take a lot of effort to achieve.

On Sunday, New Party Chairman Yok Mou-min was critical of the PFP chairman, saying that a Chen-Soong meeting could undermine the "pan-blue alliance" power to take the initiative in dealing with the nation's policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NAVAL FLEET DIPLOMACY' EFFECTIVE WAY TO BOOST TIES WITH ALLIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Monday that sending a naval fleet abroad is an effective way to engage diplomatic allies.

Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu was responding to media reports that the navy's "Friendship Fleet " will embark on an around-the-globe training voyage across the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans between March and June, during which time the fleet will make port calls at seven of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies.

Lu said the voyage is a regular part of naval training. Cadets at the Chinese Naval Academy are required to receive training aboard the "Friendship Fleet" before graduation. Lu said the foreign ministry has consistently offered necessary assistance to the fleet for its annual overseas training voyage, including negotiating port calls with diplomatic allies and arranging logistic supplies and administrative services.
Lu said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will make a formal announcement after this year's "Friendship Fleet" itinerary is fleshed out.
MND spokesman Naval Captain Liu Chih-chien said earlier in the day that the "Friendship Fleet" is now undergoing coastal navigation training.

In recent years, the "Friendship Fleet" has sailed to Latin America, the ROC's diplomatic stronghold. During the voyage, naval academy cadets are given the chance to practice combat skills, tactics and navigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING TO TAKE PLACE AT TAIPEI GUEST HOUSE FEB. 24

TEXT.P: The much-anticipated meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is scheduled to take place at the Taipei Guest House Feb. 24, top aides of Chen and Soong announced Monday after finally ironing out the details.

President Chen's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, consulted with PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng Monday morning in an attempt to hammer out the date, venue and format as well as agenda of the meeting, as early as possible.

In a written statement, the Presidential Office announced in the afternoon that based on beliefs that the interests of the nation as well as the people should be given top priority, both Yu and Chin agreed that the Chen-Soong meeting should be held without further delay.

The two top aides and their respective negotiating teams decided that President Chen will meet with PFP Chairman Soong at the Taipei Guest House, a government-own estate located near the Presidential Office, this Thursday.

At the beginning of this year, President Chen said that he would like to meet with Soong as well as other political party leaders for talks on issues pertaining to cross-strait relations, economic affairs and the legislation of major bills related to the people's livelihood.

The PFP warned last week that Soong would meet President Chen only if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government responds positively to a call to relax restrictions on investment in mainland China.

PFP politicians claimed last Friday that "the atmosphere was improper at present for such a meeting in the wake of raids launched by prosecutors on semiconductor giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) over alleged unlawful investments made by the company in the mainland." UMC Chairman Robert Tsao is known to be a close friend of Soong and a supporter of the PFP.

According to the PFP officials, the UMC case indicates that the government's policy toward the mainland is already out of date and that it is necessary for the opposition to push the government to address the problems faced by local industry and to seek to relax its policy.
The Chen-Soong meeting will only be meaningful if the DPP government is willing to change its cross-Taiwan Strait policy, the officials said.

Presidential Office officials said that the opinions of the PFP have been heard and they said that the president has always been sincere about meeting Soong, but they said the UMC incident is a judicial case in which the president is in no position to interfere.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WANTS DIALOGUE WITH OPPOSITION TO CONFIRM CONTROL YUAN NOMINEES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) wants to discuss with the various parties involved how to resolve the impasse regarding opposition lawmakers' refusal to confirm the president's Control Yuan nominees immediately after the new Legislative Yuan opens on Feb. 25.

Ker Chien-ming, executive director of the DPP's central policy committee, made the remarks after the previous legislature, which ended last month, failed to confirm the members nominated by President Chen Shui-bian.

The nominations were shelved by the legislature owing to objections from the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party (PFP). The move left the watchdog body in limbo as its members should have been sworn in on Feb. 1.

Ker said the ROC Constitution stipulates that there will be 29 members in the Control Yuan serving six-year terms. They are to be nominated by the president and confirmed by the Legislative Yuan. The Constitution also says that the committee will first review the nominated Control Yuan members and then the matter will be taken to the floor of the legislature for a vote.

Noting that any proposed bills or budgets that failed to pass one legislature must start from scratch in the next, Ker said the Constitution stipulates that the members of the Control Yuan must be confirmed, and any laws or regulations that contradict the Constitution are invalid.

Ker also said that it is the responsibility for the legislature to do their duty and confirm the choices of the president. Only if the nominees are not confirmed by the legislature can they be chosen again and only by the president if he so decides, he said. The request for new nominees is not provided for in the Constitution or any law, he added.
Meanwhile, a PFP legislator said that Ker should not interpret the Constitution on his own.
Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP whip in the legislature, said that whether to confirm the nominees or not is the prerogative of the new legislature.

Since the public is generally not satisfied with the individuals nominated by President Chen, Liu claimed, the legislature not confirming the picks follows the consensus of the people, and if the ruling party has a different view, it should sort out the problem through consultations with the opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS IN PHILIPPINES DONATES 50 WHEELCHAIRS TO PASAY NEEDY
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association, Inc. in the Philippines donated 50 wheelchairs to the city government of Pasay Monday to help physically challenged citizens.

The donation was presented by John Lu, chairman of the group of Taiwanese business people operating in the Philippines, to Mayor Peewee Trinidad at a ceremony at Pasay City Hall, in which Taiwan's Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-Hsing, as well as more than 300 city officials and police officers took part.
Pasay is one of 17 satellite cities in the Great Manila region. With a population of 500,000 and active economic activities, the city is known for its entertainment and convention centers.

The Taiwan Association has regularly supported charitable activities in the Philippines since its founding 23 years ago to promote friendly and cooperative relations between the Taiwanese and Philippine people, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE REPORT BRILLIANT RESULTS IN SAFETY ENHANCEMENT OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Police reported good result after a 40-day safety enhancement program which they said was the most successful in three years.

Police kicked off the "spring safety" program, a regular operation that takes place around Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, which included strengthening order and security, ensuring traffic safety, as well as providing various services during the period between Jan. 11 and Feb. 19.
Police also cited various statistics to show that the performance this year was especially good.
There were 3,776 fewer cases of thefts and burglaries compared with the same period last year and 7,014 fewer cases than the tallies recorded in 2003.
On the crackdown on drugs, there were 8,700 cases during the period, and 9,481 suspects were nabbed, up 3,644 cases from the previous year, and by 4,245 cases from 2003.

On the prevention of major traffic accidents, the statistics showed that police handled 203 major traffic accidents with 218 fatalities during the period, a drop of 55 cases from 2004 and 85 from 2003.

On the crackdown on driving under the influence of alcohol, 11,700 such cases were reported, 3,577 cases more than the previous year, and 2,469 cases more than 2003, showing that police pullout stops were working.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Strong Europe essential for world peace, declares Bush.
President Bush will today call on Europe to join the United States in a "new era of transatlantic unity" to bring peace and prosperity to the Middle East and Africa. Mr. Bush will use the keynote speech of a groundbreaking European visit to rally America's historic allies to "a moment of consequence and opportunity". He will acknowledge the bitter pre-war differences on Iraq without offering apology or apportioning blame. But he will present the splits as a drop in the ocean in the wider context of transatlantic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRACKDOWN ON BURGLARY, FRAUD TO BE TOP PRIORITY: INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: From March 1, the police authorities will give priority to a crackdown on burglary and fraud as part of their efforts to create a safer and more secure living environment, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyun said Monday.

"In the coming six months from March, an intensified crackdown on burglary and fraud will be the top priority for all the police forces, " Su said after presiding over a meeting of police chiefs from cities and counties around the nation at the headquarters of the National Police Administration (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
Su called the meeting after Premier Frank Hsieh directed relevant government agencies last Wednesday to work out more effective crime-fighting measures within a week.
During the meeting, Su said senior NPA officials and local police chiefs reached consensus on giving priority to intensifying the fight against burglary and fraud.

Quoting NPA tallies, Su said burglary and car theft account for 65 percent of the criminal cases reported in Taiwan. Against this backdrop, he went on, police authorities will focus on cracking down on burglary and car theft in the coming six months.
From April, Su said, the NPA will post police officers at motorized vehicle inspection and license bureaus in various cities and counties to prevent stolen cars from being licensed.
In August, he said, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will issue new automobile license plates with new devices to prevent counterfeiting.

In addition, Su said, MOI officials will discuss with Ministry of Justice officials the possibility of enhancing the ratio of repeat or habitual burglars taken into custody and the possibility of imposing heavier punishments on repeat offenders.

In view of telephone fraud becoming increasingly rampant, Su continued, police authorities will also give equal priority to this form of crime in the first stage of the intensified crime-fighting drive.

Su said the government will tighten the supervision of cell phone subscription applications and stipulate that only cell phone companies' own branches can handle such applications. The new measures are aimed at preventing criminal rings from using cell phones to commit fraud, Su said.

Moreover, he said, police will step up community patrols and hold seminars to brief local people on how to prevent burglary. Community patrol squads will be awarded cash prizes if they can achieve satisfactory results in reducing crime in their precincts, Su said.

All local police chiefs attending Monday's meeting signed a joint declaration on making concerted efforts to beef up police forces and upgrade their crime-fighting capabilities, as well as to crack down on burglary and fraud, upgrade police service quality and promote cooperation with the public to prevent criminal activities, Su said.
The minister further said the MOI will call a meeting of city and county government chiefs in Taitung Friday to further discuss measures to fight crime and improve public order.
"The public and private sectors must pool their wisdom and resources to prevent crime and violence from polluting or eroding our hard-won economic prosperity and democratic lifestyle," Su said.
Speaking at his first formal Cabinet meeting last Wednesday, Hsieh directed the NPA and all city and county governments to work together to increase the number of police officers.
According to the government's 2005 budget, Hsieh said, the nation should have 72,423 police officers.
"But at the moment, we have only slightly more than 68,500. The Interior Ministry and local governments should immediately recruit more police officers to reduce the crime rate," Hsieh said.

With a view to enhancing police authorities' criminal investigative and preventive capabilities, Hsieh said the ratio of detectives in the forces should be raised from the current 10 percent to 12 percent.
Moreover, Hsieh said, equipment should be upgraded where possible and the police presence in residential communities should also be increased.
Relevant government agencies should also study the feasibility of adjusting police ranks to boost police officers' morale and dignity, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINE AIRLINES ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT TO MEET IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Chou Huei-ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nine airlines executives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will gather in Beijing for a post Chinese New Year party Tuesday.

The "spring festival party" is being held at the invitation of the Office of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs under Beijing's Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) and comes at a time when cross-strait charter flights for China-based Taiwan businessmen during Chinese New year holiday has just concluded and the topic of cross-strait charter cargo services is on everyone's lips.

It is understood that Michael Lo, president of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA), who consulted with Pu Zhaozhou, director of CAAC's Office of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Affairs, in early January on cross-strait charter flights, will attend the party in his capacity of the president of the Taiwan-based Mandarin Airlines.

Lo denied that the party has to do with the discussion of cross-strait charter cargo flights, although he said that it is possible to exchange views on the just-concluded cross-strait charter flights and possible charter cargo flights.
"There will by no means be formal consultations," Lo said.

Nearly every Taiwan airline has set up offices in the mainland. Taiwan airline operators said that CAAC officials have invited Taiwan operators individually for the "spring festival party" in recent years, but it will be the first time that the two sides gather together.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PETROLEUM UNIVERSITY' OPENS IN CHIAYI CITY

TEXT.P: A training program described as a "Petroleum University" affiliated to the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) opened in the southern city of Chiayi Monday.

The opening ceremony was presided over by CPC Chairman C.T. Kuo and CPC General-Manager Chen Pao-lang, with Chiayi Mayor Chen Li-jen, Chiayi Council Speaker Tsai Kui-si, National Chiayi University President Lee Ming-jen and Taiwan Petroleum Union President Chuang Chueh-an also present.
Kuo said the CPC program was set up to cultivate the staff's professional skills and welcome the era of globalization.

The program comprises four petroleum industry-related departments including petroleum refining, oil extraction, petroleum marketing and petroleum engineering. It includes CPC directors-general and academic experts and scholars who will offer hands-on knowledge relating to the petroleum industry, according to Chen Pao-lang, who doubles as program's president.

Each department is divided into four professional programs, with each program classified into three levels. The 120 students come from various sectors, including those who intend to change their careers and those who aspire to cultivating their professional skills, Chen added.
The program will be a cradle for the CPC to cultivate staff, who will in turn exercise what they learn to make the CPC play a leading role in the petroleum industry, Chuang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HONORS FARMERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian honored 34 farmers with "Shen Nung" or "farming god" prizes, as well as naming 18 "model farmers" Monday in recognition of their contributions to agriculture.

Speaking at the prize awarding ceremony, which was sponsored by the Council of Agriculture, the president expressed hope that the awards will persuade more people, especially the younger generation, to enter the agricultural sector.
There have been 765 winners since the awards were established in 1983.
The president noted that small farmers are the mainstay of Taiwan's agriculture but that they are relatively uncompetitive in terms of operation costs.

Faced with the impact of market opening after Taiwan joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) Jan. 1, 2002, Chen said the government has unveiled a series of measures related to the adjustment and transformation of agriculture, better use of farmland, the upgrading of the labor force in the agriculture sector, assistance to farmers to transfer to other sectors and the care of aged farmers.

He said the government's measures are aimed at stabilizing the domestic agricultural product market in the short term, and developing export-oriented and high value-added agriculture that will be competitive in the long term.

The president said that Taiwan's agriculture must work toward quality and branding through research and development as well as international marketing, so as to ensure the sustainable development of Taiwan's agriculture, while on the other hand increasing the income of farmers and fishermen.

On agricultural issues in the new round of WTO Doha Round of talks, the president also said the government has always wanted to protect the interests of farmers and advocates a reasonable grace period be given to each WTO member considering the unique nature of agricultural development.
The government will also forge allegiances with countries whose stances are close to Taiwan's in the hope of effectively safeguarding the nation's interests and the rights and interests of farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WHIP RULES OUT PARTY CHIEF'S ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT UNITS

TEXT.P: A People First Party (PFP) lawmaker demanded Monday that the ruling party and the Presidential Office stop defaming PFP Chairman James Soong by spreading rumors that he will be offered a post in exchange for inter-party cooperation.

Liu Wen-hsiung, a PFP whip at the Legislative Yuan, made the comments in an effort to dismiss rampant rumors that the government might offer Soong a post related to cross-Taiwan Strait affairs in a trade for his party's cooperation with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the legislature.
Describing the rumors as a gross insult to both the PFP and Soong, Liu urged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Presidential Office to stop spreading them.

"Soong will never accept an offer to take over the chairmanship of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation or that of the Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development under the Presidential Office, " Liu said, claiming that "it is totally out of the question in the future, nor has it even been considered by Soong."
Meanwhile, DPP legislative whip Lai Ching-teh appealed for continued efforts to forge rapport between the two parties despite outside or inside pressure.
Lai's remarks came after an announcement from the PFP headquarters that a planned meeting between Soong and President Chen Shui-bian will take place Friday. Lai welcomed the PFP's statement.

In view of the fragile cross strait situation, Chen has repeatedly sought cooperation with the PFP since last December's legislative elections. The PFP won 34 seats in the polls, becoming the third-largest party in the sixth Legislative Yuan, lagging behind the DPP with 89 seats and the main opposition Kuomintang with 79 seats.

The DPP has been trying hard to entice the PFP to form a stable majority with it to secure political stability during Chen's second term, despite sharp differences over the two parties' stances on Taiwan's future course with regard to independence or unification with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMPLE ROOM FOR TAIWAN-MAINLAND CHINA CHARTER FLIGHTS TO IMPROVE

TEXT.P: This year's Lunar New Year charter flights should serve as a reference for improvements to future similar operations and the service should be enhanced to provide carriers with greater incentives, aviation industry sources said Monday.

The key point for the government to consider is whether the service should be expanded in the future in order to stimulate the willingness of aviation companies to operate the flights, the sources said.

According to a Far East Air Transport Corp. spokesman, the passenger load averaged about 90 percent on the round-trip Taipei-Shanghai route, but the rate on its Taipei-Guangzhou route was only about 50 percent. The Taipei-Shanghai route should be marginally profitable if relevant promotion and advertisement costs are written off, he noted.
Mandarin Airlines estimated that it should also have chalked up a slim profit from the Lunar New Year charter flights -- offered by six carriers from either side during the January 29-Feb. 20 period.

Although this year's holiday charter flights won a better response from mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families thanks to low ticket prices and the historic non-stop service, industry sources suggested that the practice be applied to other major holidays such as the Dragon Boat Festival, the Mid-Autumn Festival or even weekends.
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications estimated that average passenger load on the special charter flights should be more than 50 percent.

Compared to the first Taiwan-mainland charter flights in 2003, this year's service saw some improvements, Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) President Michael Lo said. Lo is also Mandarin's general manager.

Lo revealed that executives from the Taiwan aviation industry will travel to Beijing Tuesday to take part in a Spring Festival gathering hosted by the Civil Aviation Administration of China. But he was reserved about the possibility of whether the two sides will touch on issues regarding the long proposed cross-Taiwan Strait cargo services.
The TAA chairman was one of the Taiwan representatives that reached a final agreement on the just-concluded charter flights in the middle of last month with mainland counterparts in Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPOND TO CALL FOR TALKS ON CARGO CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu urged mainland China Monday to respond positively to Taiwan's call for talks on the opening of direct cargo charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.

Wu made the appeal during a lunch with senior executives of six local airline companies to review the operations of the just-concluded special cross-strait strait charter flights for home-bound Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland for Lunar New Year celebrations. The lunch party was jointly organized by the MAC and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
Wu said the smooth conclusion of the unprecedented two-way, non-stop cross-strait passenger charter flights has laid a good foundation for the launch of the long-talked-about cargo charter flights.

Taiwan has been well prepared for talks with Beijing about the opening of direct cross-strait cargo charter flights, Wu said, adding that back in 2003, the MAC unveiled a package of principles for cross-strait cargo flights.
"We are willing to negotiate with Beijing on the cargo flight service on the basis of those guidelines and on the formula set forth in the Lunar New Year passenger charter flights," Wu said.

As cargo charter flights would be operated on a regular basis, Wu said the scope of negotiations will be even wider. Therefore, he said, Taiwan hopes the mainland will respond as soon as possible to its call for negotiations of technical details regarding the flights.

"Cross-strait cargo charter flights are even more important than the Lunar New Year passenger charter flights and involve more issues that require bilateral talks to settle. We keenly hope that negotiations can get underway as early as possible, " Wu said, adding that he is hopeful Beijing will not set any prerequisites for opening talks.

Under a landmark cross-strait deal struck in Macau Jan. 15, six carriers on each side of the Taiwan Strait were allowed to operate a total of 48 round-trip special charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families home for the New Year celebrations.

Senior executives of all six Taiwan airlines -- China Airlines, Mandarin Airlines, EVA Airways, UNI Airways, Far East Air Transport Corp. and TransAsia Airways -- were invited to the lunch party to review the charter flight operations and offer opinions for improvements.
Wu expressed his gratitude for all MAC and MOTC staff members as well as the six airlines for their concerted efforts to make the cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights a reality.

The lunch came a day before senior executives of the six Taiwan airlines were to leave for Beijing to attend a similar gathering to be hosted by the Civil Aviation Administration of China. In addition to reviewing the just-concluded passenger charter flights, they are also expected to exchange views with their mainland counterparts on the launch of cargo charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HONG KONG, JAPAN WORK TO BUST MULTI-NATIONAL DRUG OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been working with Japan and Hong Kong to bust a multi-national drug smuggling operation, officials of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) said Monday.
The officials made the remarks as police in Tokyo announced that they had broken up a smuggling operation involving Taiwan, Japan, mainland China and Hong Kong.

Tokyo police also seized 75 kg of liquid methamphetamine and more than 286,000 ecstasy pills, estimated to worth more than 6 billion yen (around US$57.14 million) in market value, and arrested four Japanese suspects.

The officials said that MJIB Taichung agents first took notice of the case and began worked with the National Police Administration to monitor the exchanges between drug rings in Hong Kong and Taiwan.
The agents learned in early 2004 that drug rings in mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan wanted to collaborate to smuggle the raw materials for making amphetamine to Japan.

The agents then provided related information to Japan and Hong Kong police in May 2004, and began a long-term surveillance operation. Tokyo police recently began a series of raids on the hangouts of four of the suspects.

Tokyo has attached great importance to the information provided by Taiwan, twice sent officials to Taiwan to get information and has expressed appreciation for the help in solving the case, the agents added.
They said that the MJIB will continue to work with drug enforcement agencies of other countries to crack down on drug crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE ISSUES TO BE TABLED IN PRESIDENT'S MEETING WITH PFP HEAD: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's Thursday meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong will center on peace across the Taiwan Strait, national security and harmony among the different ethnic groups, an aide to the president said Monday.

Huang Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said economic ties with mainland China might also be raised, adding that since these issues cannot be covered in a single meeting, the president would like to have follow-up meetings with Soong after Thursday.
Sub-issues of their discussion are still being worked on by the two leaders' aides, who might exchange views in the leadup to Thursday's meeting, Huang said.

As to the PFP's insistence that the president should change his administration's policy on economic exchanges with the mainland before any meeting with Soong can take place, Huang said, the president is keeping an open mind about which issues should be discussed and will not rule out economic policy with regard to the mainland.

Answering journalists' questions, Huang confirmed that the president will discuss with Soong his idea for a commission on promoting peace across the strait, but "only its framework and general principles."
The press has rumored that Chen will offer Soong the job as head of the proposed commission in exchange for PFP support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the legislature.
Huang emphasized that the president would like to exchange views with Soong even though he understands it is impossible to expect Soong to see eye-to-eye with him on all of the issues.

The meeting is part of Chen's efforts to reconcile with his political rivals, namely Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Soong, who challenge the legitimacy of the president and have asked the courts to deny Chen the presidency in two failed lawsuits that are under appeal.
Asked whether the president would like to meet with Lien too, Huang said his office would not rule this out.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPILATION OF MEMORIES OF AUTHORITARIAN RULE VICTIMS SOUGHT

TEXT.P: A researcher at Academia Sinica recommended Monday that the government borrow a lesson from Guatemala and compile a report on the memories of the victims of Taiwan's period of authoritarian rule.

In a speech to government leaders in a monthly meeting at the Presidential Office, Academia Sinica Researcher Wu Nei-teh said turning the political legacy of past authoritarian rulers into a democratic asset is a difficult challenge facing many newly developed democracies around the world.

Among them, there are about 20 that have followed the example of South Africa in setting up a commission to get a true picture of past terror and to pardon those who admit their past crimes in contributing to such reigns of terror, Wu said.
Studies have shown that the stories pried out by South Africa's Truth Commission have only aggravated the wrath of the people and widened the rift between different racial groups, Wu went on.
Although truth might not bring about reconciliation, the absence of truth will only make reconciliation even more difficult, Wu warned.

On the other hand, he went on, Guatemala has set up a historical clarification commission to collect the testimonies of more than 20,000 victims who suffered at the hands of that country's past military dictators and compile them into a book titled "Memories of Silence."
Instead of naming the victims' offenders, the book published by the government refers to them as "the ruling authorities" to avoid reopening wounds or giving rise to further conflict.
Rather than venting the victims' vengeance on the offenders, the report is trying to sooth the victims' grief and shed light on the past of the country by giving a fair report.

Given that Taiwan is plagued by the different ethnic groups' different perceptions of the past government, Wu suggested that the government follow the Guatemalan model in dealing with the political legacy of the country's past authoritarian rulers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Cabinet in Israel Ratifies Pullout From Gaza Strip.
Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon won cabinet approval on Sunday for two sweeping plans intended to reshape Israel's relations with the Palestinians: the withdrawal of Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip, and a revamped route for the separation barrier in the West Bank. The cabinet approved the Gaza pullout by a strong but expected margin, 17 to 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PLANS TO VISIT 3 SOUTH PACIFIC ALLIES IN MAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will visit three of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific in May, an official of the Presidential Office said Monday.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, made the remarks following media speculation that Chen will visit the allies in May and could possibly stay aboard the navy's "Friendship Fleet."

The reports said the fleet will embark on an around-the-globe training voyage across the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans between March and June, during which time the fleet will make port calls at seven of the ROC's diplomatic allies.
Huang clarified that Chen plans to visit the Marshall Islands, Tuvalu and Kiribati, but said his visit will not include stay with the fleet, as this would disrespect to the allies.
In addition, the fleet's itinerary is different to that of Chen's state visits, he added.
Chen visited two other ROC South Pacific allies -- Palau and the Solomon Islands -- in late January. He said at that time that he would visit other allies later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR VOWS TO BOOST 'CITY DIPLOMACY'

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai said Monday he will do his utmost to promote "city diplomacy, " including expanding engagements with Kaohsiung's sister cities.

Chen made the remarks while hosting a luncheon in honor of delegations from three of Kaohsiung's sister cities -- Portland and Seattle, in Oregon and Washington states, respectively, and South Korea's Busan.
The delegations have been invited to attend the 2005 Kaohsiung Lantern Festival.
Chen told his guests that Kaohsiung is a beautiful port city with a special strategic location and rich historical and cultural legacies.

Chen said his administration will continue various infrastructure and cultural development projects launched by former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, who is now premier, to further boost the city's economic prosperity. In addition, Chen said he will devote more efforts to promoting city-to-city diplomacy, enhancing engagements and cooperation with sister cities and forging friendships with other foreign cities.

Tom Crowder, president of the Portland Sister Cities Commission, who heads the Portland delegation, said Kaohsiung is welcome to organize a delegation to attend the city's annual Rose Festival in June.
Nicholos Licata, a Seattle city councilor and leader of the Seattle delegation, said he was impressed by Kaohsiung's beauty and its people's hospitality.

You Kyung Jo, head of the Busan delegation, said Taiwan and South Korea have maintained close relations and expressed hope that Kaohsiung and Busan can further boost exchanges and cooperation in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT HAITI, DOMINICA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will leave Taipei Tuesday for visits to two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean -- Haiti and the Dominican Republic -- officials said Monday.
According to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Tan will make transit stops in Tokyo and New York on his way to the two Caribbean countries.
His visit will last for about a week, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC TO OPEN OFFICES IN NEW YORK, LONDON: FSC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) will open offices in New York and London in July and December this year, FSC Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng announced Monday.

Kong made the announcement during classes on Taiwan's financial management, investment and challenges at National Taiwan University and National Chengchi University -- the first of their kind in a series planned by the FSC in colleges and universities across the country.
According to Kong, the FSC will step up its pace to push the domestic financial market to go international and make Taiwan into a world fund-raising and capital management center.
First of all, Kong said, the FSC will speed up mergers in the domestic banking sector in the hope of creating a major and prominent bank for the country.

Pointing out that Taiwan lacks a representative and efficient bank to compete against banks of other countries, he said that the leading five banks in Taiwan only enjoy a combined 37 percent stake in their home market, even lagging well behind the 73 percent boasted by the leading bank of Indonesia and the 68 percent of Thailand's most prominent bank.

The urgent need to merge and consolidate Taiwan's banks is far beyond the public's imagination, he noted, adding that the FSC will provide sound banks with greater incentives in the second half of this year to help them move swiftly in that direction. The FSC will also increase pressure on those with inadequate performance to do the same, he said.

According to the FSC chief, the lack of globalization is another major shortcoming of Taiwan's banks. He said that domestic banks are unable to make more lucrative profits due to their inability to market innovative financial products and services.

Taiwan has a large amount of capital lingering outside of the country -- as much as NT$400 billion (US$12.7 billion) from the banking sector, some NT$100 billion from the securities companies and over NT$60 billion from the mutual fund companies, he added.

Commenting on the relatively lackluster stock market in recent months, he expressed confidence that the domestic bourse will gradually regain momentum in the near future. As the Taiwan Stock Exchange is one of those approved by the American Stock Exchange as appointed overseas markets, its operations are comparable to those of any developed countries, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARES U.S., JAPAN CONCERNS OVER REGIONAL PEACE

TEXT.P: American and Japanese concern with peace across the Taiwan Strait corresponds with Taiwan's concern, an aide to the president said Monday in a response to a joint statement issued by the two countries in Washington Saturday.
However, Huang Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said the government will not stress too much the significance of the statement and will not comment on it.

He confirmed a news report that the U.S.-Japan joint statement was brought up in a meeting of the National Security Council (NSC) earlier in the day, but rebutted a press rumor that the meeting was called by the president in response to the statement, saying it was a routine meeting presided over by NSC Secretary-General Chiou I-jen without the participation of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL INCREASE SELF-DEFENSE CAPABILITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the government will increase Taiwan's self-defense capability to safeguard the peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.

Addressing a dinner party hosted by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen to entertain members of the diplomatic corps in celebration of the Lunar New Year, Chen said it is part of his government's efforts for this year to increase Taiwan's self-defense capability to avoid the peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait status quo from being changed unilaterally.
Beijing's increasing military buildup has not only posed a threat to the peace and stability of the region but also has broken the regional balance, Chen pointed out.

Also, he criticized Beijing's attempt to enact a proposed anti-secession law as casting a shadow on the development of cross-strait ties, which he said has just showed signs of improvement following the smooth operation of cross-strait charter flights during the Lunar New Year holiday.

It is a serious promise he made to the 23 million people of Taiwan and to the international community to create a new and stable environment for consultation and dialogue, the president said, adding that it also serves as his basic position in pursuing peaceful and stable interactions between the two sides of the strait.

Chen said he will continue to promote the establishment of a framework of peaceful and stable interactions between the two sides by setting up a committee for cross-strait peace and development to seek a domestic consensus on the issue.

Chen also called on the international community to join efforts to safeguard the peace and security of the Taiwan Strait. The normalization of cross-strait relations needs not only the goodwill demonstrated by and concrete actions taken by the two sides but also promotion by the international community, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ECHOES CALLS FOR REVIEW OF ECONOMIC REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh supports calls for a review of economic regulations, especially those that restrict local hi-tech companies's investment in mainland China and the tax-free privileges extended to the semiconductor industry, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Rong-tai said Monday.
The spokesman quoted the premier as saying that he prefers to enforce thoroughly more relaxed rules rather than have stringent rules that are too harsh to be applied.

As to which technology should be considered as advanced skills and whether they should enjoy tax-free privilege, the premier was cited as saying that the related government agencies should redefine and update regulations on their own without having to be asked by their superiors.

The spokesman made the comment after local businessmen complained that some "hi-technology" prohibited by the government from being transferred to the mainland is no longer considered high-tech and should not be protected by the regulations.

They complained in the wake of prosecutors' search of the United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) in connection with its alleged illegal investment in the mainland that the out-dated regulations have only cost the companies that command these skills the chance to venture into the mainland market.

Meanwhile, a lawmaker complained that the UMC, as well as another giant chipmaker, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, have not paid any tax in the last eight years because of the tax-free status provided for the hi-technology companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 22, or the 14th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian navigator and "discoverer" of the South American coast, dies at the age of 58. America was named in his honor.
1732: George Washington, the first U.S. president, is born.
1784: The Empress of China, the first trading ship sent to China from the United States, sets sail from New York.
1788: Arthur Schopenhauer, German philosopher who saw the ideal state of man as one of contemplative freedom achieved through art, is born.
1810: Frederick Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born. His music was noted chiefly for its expressiveness.
1857: Robert Baden-Powell, British hero of the siege of Mafeking in the Boer War and founder of the Boy Scouts, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1879: U.S. storekeeper Frank W. Woolworth, thinking centralized purchasing will help keep prices down and profits up, opens the new F.W. Woolworth Co. Five-and-Ten Cent Store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
1924: Calvin Coolidge becomes the first U.S. president to broadcast from the White House.
1932: Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1934: Nicaraguan guerrilla leader General Augusto Sandino is executed by his rival, General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1946: Dr. Selman Abrahams announces he has discovered streptomycin, an antibiotic which can be used to treat tuberculosis and bacterial infections.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secret Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1967: U.S. forces and South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1973: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company of New York, arrives to open a Taipei branch.
1974: Minister of Finance K.T. Li, Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of finance and national economy, issue a joint communique on financial and economic cooperation.
1979: The Caribbean island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1990: The last statue of Joseph Stalin topples in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia.
1991: U.S. President George Bush gives Saddam Hussein 24 hours to quit Kuwait or face an all-out ground war against allied forces.
1993: The Taiwanese film "The Wedding Banquet" wins a Golden Bear Award for Best Picture at the 43rd Berlin International Film Festival.
1996: Russia and the International Monetary Fund reach a deal on a loan of more than US$10 billion.
1996: The French government announces the abolition of conscription and the adoption of a voluntary system for military service.
2000: Chien Wen-hui successfully receives a piece of his wife's liver in an operation performed at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, marking the first wife-to-husband live-donor liver transplant ever conducted in Taiwan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian is accused of taking bribes from a Malaysian business tycoon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Life sciences top choice for students seeking poly entry.
When it comes to polytechnic courses, life sciences have pushed engineering into the shade.
Over the past five years, since the Government declared its intention in 2000 to develop the lucrative biomedical industries sector, interest in the field has boomed.
In 2002, out of the 15,505 applicants to polytechnics, 22.9 per cent chose a chemical and life sciences course as their first choice. Only 21.2 per cent chose engineering.
By last year, the gap had widened even further, with 26.6 per cent choosing life sciences and just 17.5 per cent opting for engineering.
The Lianhe Zaobao: CPF Board will implement new rules to prevent the cashback when people buy the flat.

According to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Tan will make transit stops in Tokyo and New York during his trip.
His visit will last for about a week, the officials said.

The United States government is highly committed in providing the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) the much-needed training on counter-terrorism as a joint effort by the Philippine and American governments in combating the global menace with the holding of the 2005 RP-US Balikatan joint military exercises in the country.

POLICE are hunting a supposed girlfriend of former Representative Dennis Roldan after he pointed to her as one of the alleged masterminds of the kidnapping of a 3-year-old boy, a top intelligence officer said yesterday.

Government prosecutors recommended yesterday that no bail be set for former Quezon City congressman Dennis Roldan and six other people allegedly involved in the kidnapping of a three-year-old Filipino-Chinese boy last Feb. 9.
