THIS time the actor Dennis Roldan did not know how to act and project himself as he appeared uneasy before the flashing cameras.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER, PFP AGREE TO COOPERATE TO ENACT MAJOR BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reached a three-point agreement, including cooperation in the legislation of major bills, with the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) Tuesday.

With the new legislature set to open Friday, the premier has been busy calling on the legislative caucuses of various parties, including the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Kuomintang, over the past two days.

Hsieh called on the PFP caucus for a closed-door breakfast meeting Tuesday and then called on the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union to exchange views with them on which bills should take top priority in the new legislature and to promote exchanges between the legislative and the executive branches.

Hsieh noted that the next three years presents a good opportunity for reform as there are no national elections scheduled for the period. He added that the two sides agreed at the meeting to cooperate to promote the legislation of major bills over the next two years.

He also said that the Executive Yuan will not float any politically controversial bills without prior consultations with opposition parties during his tenure, noting that in the past, many such bills failed to clear the legislature because of the absence of prior communications with the opposition and because the ruling party had not controlled a majority in the 225-seat legislature.
In addition, Hsieh and the PFP expressed the hope of passing legislation floated by the PFP related to promoting cross-strait peace.
Liu Wen-hsiung, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that the party will promote the bill based on respect of the right of President Chen Shui-bian to set cross-strait policy.

Hsieh stressed that President Chen has proposed the establishment of a cross-strait peace and stability exchange framework, adding that he is sure that when President Chen and PFP Chairman James Soong meet Thursday, the two sides can discuss the matter and reach a consensus on promoting cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50,000-PLUS PEOPLE MOVED TO TAIWAN IN 2004: MOI

TEXT.P: A total of 50,776 people moved to Taiwan last year, marking an increase of 13,471 from the figure for 2003, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Tuesday.
Meanwhile, 47,185 local residents moved abroad last year, down 2,375 from the year-earlier level, giving Taiwan a net population inflow of 3,591 for 2004.

The MOI tallies also showed that 12,804 people moved out of Taipei City last year, marking the highest figure for any administrative district in Taiwan. Changhua County and Yunlin County placed second and third on the list, respectively.

At the same time, a total of 20,210 people moved into Taoyuan County, placing the northern Taiwan county at the top of that list. Taipei County and Taichung City placed second and third, respectively.

Over the past five years, MOI officials said, Taipei County, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu County, Hsinchu City, Taichung City, Tainan City and the frontline island of Kinmen have all seen increases in net population inflows.

A total of 12 cities and counties -- Taipei City, Ilan County, Miaoli County, Changhua County, Nantou County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, Tainan County, Kaohsiung County, Pingtung County, Taitung County and Hualien County -- have experienced net population outflows during the same period, with Taipei City topping the list.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AGAIN IN AN ATTEMPT TO BLOCK TAIWAN'S IHR INCLUSION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and C.H. Lu)

TEXT.P: Beijing's permanent representative to the United Nations Office in Geneva insisted Monday that any revisions to the International Health Regulations (IHR) must uphold the principles of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of WHO member states.

Although Sha Zukang did not directly refer to Taiwan in his remarks at the WHO meeting in Geneva on the IHR, his remarks have been widely interpreted as an attempt to block Taiwan's inclusion in the IHR after it is revised.
The meeting, the second of its kind since last November, was held with the goal of bringing the IHR up to date and increasing controls on the international spread of infectious disease.

The WHO member states that engaged in the two-week session of inter-governmental working group meetings held last November failed to reach agreement on certain contents of the regulations, including Article 65 of the current IHR rules related to the inclusion of states that are not WHO members.
During Monday's meeting, Sha said that Beijing can only accept the IHR if the basic principles of WHO members' sovereignty and territorial integrity are respected.

Although it had been decided that the revisions of some IHR articles, including Article 65, would be discussed at a meeting set for Feb. 25, Sha requested that the agenda be changed to discuss the articles in advance. As such, a consultation meeting was scheduled for Tuesday to discuss the request.
Taiwan's diplomatic allies have said that they will oppose such a request.

Nicaragua has proposed revising Article 65 of the current IHR rules relating to the participation of non-members, saying that the article should include those territories that have the ability to add to the knowledge pool in health-related matters and that can take on IHR affairs in the same manner as WHO members.
If the Nicaraguan proposal is adopted, Taiwan is expected to be included in the IHR.

However, China and its backers have strongly opposed the proposal, claiming that the territories do not have the proper legal status to join the IHR since the WHO is an inter-governmental organization and the IHR is a convention among nations.
It has been learned that some WHO members have also suggested that the IHR add the text of "universal application" in Article 2 of the regulations, which Beijing would most likely oppose fiercely.
Sources close to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Geneva said the office has been trying to drum up strong support among friendly nations for its IHR bid.
Although admitting that there is still a long way to go for Taiwan to gain inclusion in the IHR, the sources said that the island's efforts have generally been welcomed by several WHO members.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE WORKERS STAND TO LOSE IN CROSS-STRAIT CONFLICT
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By S.J. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Hostilities between mainland China and Taiwan would adversely affect the lives of thousands of Philippine workers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, a Philippine university professor said Monday.

Professor Dagdag of the University of the Philippines was commenting on mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law." The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress agreed Dec. 29 last year to place the "anti-secession bill" on the agenda of the congress's plenary session set to open March 5 this year. The details of the proposed law have yet to be made public.
According to the government on Taiwan, the law could become a "war law" that might lead China's military, police and militia to use force to solve cross-strait problems.
The professor also said the Philippines hopes to maintain friendly relations with both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Pointing out that some 100,000 Philippine workers are in Taiwan and many Filipinos are also working in China and Hong Kong, the professor said that an conflict between Taipei and Beijing would certainly affect the lives of the Philippine workers.
He also said that cross-strait problems should be resolved peacefully and that the Philippines does not want to see war between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Bush to Talk Security, Not Scold.
U.S. President George W. Bush will probably keep a promise to prod President Vladimir Putin over concerns that Russia is backsliding on democracy when the two meet in Slovakia on Thursday. However, while seeking explanations, Bush is unlikely to tie his administration's Russia policy to Putin's record on democracy because Moscow remains too valuable as a partner in security and oil and would become too troublesome as a spoiler if antagonized.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Says Russia Must Make Good on Democracy.
U.S. President Bush Monday warned Russia that it "must renew a commitment to democracy and the rule of law, " but said he believed that the nation's future lay "within the family of Europe and the trans-Atlantic community." Speaking at the the grand setting of Concert Noble in Brussels, Bush declared that in a "new era of trans-Atlantc unity" the United States and Europe must work together to rebuild Iraq, seek peace between the Israelis and Palestinians, insist that Iran not develop nuclear weapons and demand that Syria end its occupation of Lebanon.
Wall Street Journal: Bush Urges EU to Press Moscow on Democracy.
U.S. President Bush pushed for a tougher line toward Moscow Monday in Brussels, urging the European Union to "place democratic reform at the heart" of every conversation with Russia, while continuing to advocate changes to the Middle East's political landscape.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE CHURCH URGES PARTIES TO UPHOLD TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Presbyterian Church in Taiwan called on both the ruling and opposition parties Tuesday to uphold the sovereignty of Taiwan while conducting inter-party consultations and cooperation.
The call was made in a "declaration of justice and peace" released by the church ahead of President Chen Shui-bian's planned meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.
Officials of the church said the declaration was issued out of concern for the country's future, especially since mainland China is planning to enact an "anti-secession law."
In the declaration, the church insists that the independence of Taiwan's sovereignty is the foundation of inter-party cooperation.

It says the pursuit of justice and peace is a shared responsibility of the international community and that the long-time isolation of Taiwan by the international community is against the universal principles of justice and peace.

Calling for the establishment of a new relationship between Taiwan and China, the church said the two sides should seek mutual recognition and respect based on the principles of equality, reciprocity and peaceful coexistence.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER'S TRANSIT STOPS IN JAPAN, U.S. DRAW ATTENTION

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen left Taipei Tuesday for visits to two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the Caribbean -- Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
This will be Chen's first-ever visits to the two Caribbean allies since he assumed the top diplomatic post last April.

Chen is scheduled to make transit stops in Tokyo and New York en route to the Caribbean, which has led observers to wonder if will take advantage of the stopovers to exchange views with Japanese and U.S. authorities on Taiwan Strait issues after a Japanese official announced over the weekend that the security of the Taiwan Strait will be subsumed in the U.S.-Japan joint security pact.
Chen said his itinerary has long been set and that meetings with Japanese or U.S. officials were not on his agenda for the current trip.

Nevertheless, Chen said that as Taiwan's minister of foreign affairs, he always welcomes opportunities to talk with foreign officials, including those from countries with which the Republic of China doesn't have diplomatic ties.

Touching on the latest joint U.S.-Japan security statement that called for a peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes through dialogue, Chen said the ROC government welcomes the international community's increasing concern about Taiwan Strait security and stability.

"We also hope that China can pay heed to this growing international trend and cooperate with Taiwan in maintaining regional peace and stability, which is not only in Taiwan's interests but also in China's," Chen said.

Stressing that peace is Taiwan's top cross-strait policy goal, Chen said he keenly hopes that the just-concluded Chinese Lunar New Year cross-strait charter passenger flights can serve as a foundation for bilateral constructive engagements in the future.
Chen's two-leg Caribbean visit will last about a week, diplomatic officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LOBBYING GROUPS TO VISIT EUROPE TO LOBBY ON TAIWAN'S BEHALF

TEXT.P: The government will soon send three delegations to Scandinavia, the Baltic and other European countries to lobby on Taiwan's behalf, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

Yang Maysing, chairwoman of the foreign ministry's Research and Planning Committee, said that in view of mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law" against Taiwan and the European Union leaning toward lifting an arms embargo against mainland China, the delegations hopes to help the international community learn more about the threat faced by Taiwan.
Yang said that the groups will explain that the proposed "anti-secession law" will seriously hurt peace in the Taiwan Strait and human rights in Taiwan.
Hopefully, the international community, after being briefed on the precarious situation Taiwan faces, will do what it can to block the "anti-secession law" from going into force, she said.

Wu Shu-ming, the head of the Northern Taiwan Society, an academic group, will lead the group to Scandinavian countries. A doctor surnamed Teng will lead the second group to Baltic countries, and the third group will be headed by Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng and herself to visit the Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia and Italy, Yang said.
Scandinavian countries have been concerned about issues related to the human rights situation in mainland China and peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, she explained.

The Baltic countries should be more able to empathize with Taiwan's situation given its experience of being under the threat of Russia in the past. The third group will visit European countries that the foreign ministry has not frequented before, hoping that the visit will give them more understanding of the will of the Taiwan people and their government's position.

She said that the government's lobbying against the proposed "anti-secession law" through private communication and media publicity "has borne fruit, while Beijing's move has caused concern from the Untied States, Japan and East Asian countries."
She said that at present, the government will devote itself to the prevention of the legislation of the "anti-secession law."

On the EU's intention of lifting an arms embargo against mainland China, Yang observed that Europe is concerned about the human rights situation there but rarely touches on the delicate situation in the Taiwan Strait.
The EU does not seem worried that the lifting of the arms embargo would tilt the military balance in the Taiwan Strait, which she said would seriously damage Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.184 to close at NT$31.332.
A total of US$1.3 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.516 and hit a low of NT$31.320.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 35.61 points to close at 6,107.17.
The bourse opened at 6,155.54 and fluctuated between 6,161 and 6,106.19 during trading. A total of 3.14 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.93 billion (US$2.26 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up at 0.1 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, construction issues and machinery and electronics shares both at 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues and cement stocks both at 0.8 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 686 to 140, with 159 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULES FOR HI-TECH INVESTMENT IN CHINA NEED REVAMPING: CONSULTANT

TEXT.P: The government should overhaul its rules restricting Taiwan hi-tech companies' investment in mainland China, as there is a big gap between business demand and the existing law, according to an investment consultant.

Hsieh Chie-liang, a manager at Polaris Securities Co., Ltd. suggested that the government revise its current regulations and work out a phased opening to heed the hi-tech sector's need to explore the mainland market.
According to Hsieh, only by doing so will Taiwan hi-tech industry maintain their competitive edge across the world amid aggressive foreign competition.

Despite a government law banning private individuals and companies from investing in mainland-based hi-tech businesses without official permission, he said that it is hard to control outflows of capital and personnel.

In view of the fact that the global semiconductor industry has prominently clustered in the mainland, Taiwan's competitive chip foundries will suffer huge losses if they are still not permitted to "go west," he said.
Against such a backdrop, the government should allow investment by domestic chipmakers in certain mature and low-profit manufacturing processes in the mainland, he said.

At the same time, it is necessary for the government to strictly define the role of Taiwan in domestic corporations' market deployment strategies as a business operations center or a research and development hub, requiring them to retain their key expertise and capital at home, he added.

Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said Monday that the government will further discuss a wider opening of its policy with hi-tech industry insiders and scholars.

In response to a continued cry for a full opening by some companies, Yeh said that the government reviews its policy periodically, but he added that a go-ahead for some leading technologies requires detailed assessments in advance.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO PHILIPPINES SPEAKS IN MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Reacting to the recent U.S.-Japan statement that included a reference to cross-strait peace and stability, a Republic of China diplomat said Monday that Taiwan acts in accordance with its best interests and needs.

ROC representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing was referring to a U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee meeting held in Washington, D.C. Saturday in which officials from both sides discussed various issues including the peaceful resolution of cross-strait problems via dialogue.
Wu was speaking at a university seminar in Manila on the significance of Taiwan's democratization on surrounding countries.

Wu said that the U.S. and Japan formulate their East Asian policies based on their own interests, and that the statement indicated that the two countries are concerned about and have taken heed of the subtle changes of the strategic environment in East Asia and the entire Asia-Pacific region.

He said the subtle changes have come from the so-called "peaceful emergence" of mainland China, North Korea's claim to be in possession of nuclear weapons and the subtle changes in cross-strait relations.
On the reaction of Taiwan to the U.S.-Japan joint statement, Wu said that Taiwan will basically handle the situation based on its own interests and needs.

Taiwan knows what is best for its people, Wu maintained. In addition to positive exchanges with the U.S. and Japan, Taiwan also needs to work to ensure peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Food cancer scandal grows as shops clear more shelves.
Serious flaws in the regulation of Britain's food industry allowed millions of products containing a cancer-causing dye to reach supermarket shelves without proper safety checks, it emerged last night. Chilli power containing the illegal food dye was traded between more than six different companies on being imported into the UK, allowing it to spread rapidly with little chance for regulators to monitor its safety, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March lost 47 points to close at 6,097, with 23,003 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for April moved down 49 points to finish at 6,096, with 97 contracts traded, while June futures lost 44 points to finish at 6,100, with 12 contracts traded. September futures lost 30 points to finish at 6,035, with seven contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,144 for March, 6,145 for April, 6,144 for June, 6,065 for September and 6,077 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

March TE futures moved down one point to close at 233, with 3,673 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 1.85 points to finish at 233.15, with 12 contract transactions. September TE futures lost 0.1 points to close at 233, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

March TF futures lost four points to finish at 1,013, with 2,828 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 4.2 points to end at 1,012.6, with 16 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REGRETS CHINA'S ATTEMPT TO BLOCK TAIWAN'S IHR INCLUSION

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials expressed regret Tuesday over mainland China's latest attempt to block Taiwan's inclusion in the International Health Regulations (IHR).

During a World Health Organization (WHO) meeting on the IHR held Monday in Geneva, Beijing's permanent representative to the United Nations Office in Geneva, Sha Zukang, insisted that any revisions to the IHR must uphold the principles of sovereignty and territorial integrity of WHO member states.
Sha's remarks were apparently an attempt to block Taiwan's inclusion in the IHR due to the fact that Taiwan is not a WHO member.

Foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu said the IHR revisions can provide an opportunity for Taiwan to take part in the WHO and that nothing should deprive the 23 million Taiwanese people of their right to medical care and health information.

In a statement, the ministry called on the international community to help Taiwan participate in the WHO framework for IHR revisions and urged mainland China to stop its blockade against Taiwan to enhance the attachment between people from both sides of the Taiwan Strait and promote cross-strait cooperation.

It said that Beijing had invited officials of Taiwan's Center for Disease Control (CDC) to attend the IHR meeting set for Feb. 21-26 as members of the Chinese delegation, when it was well aware of the fact that Taiwan would never agree to attend the meeting as a Chinese delegate.

In a similar attempt to make the international community believe that Taiwan is controlled by mainland China and has a representative place in the Chinese delegation, Beijing invited CDC officials to attend a IHR conference between mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan in October last year, according to the statement.
The ministry asserted that Taiwan and China are two independent entities and that it is impossible for Taiwan to join the Chinese delegation.

The ministry urged the WHO to respond to Taiwan's request to send its own representatives to participate in the inter-governmental working group meetings in the name of human rights and humanitarianism.

In addition to securing the assistance of its diplomatic allies, the government is lobbying for the support of the United States and European nations for IHR revisions in favor of Taiwan, foreign ministry officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAPA LAUNCHES DRIVE TO OPPOSE PROPOSED 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' BY CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 21 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A pro-Taiwan independence group based in the United States has launched a "one-person, one-call" drive to lobby U.S. congressmen to oppose to a proposed "anti-secession law" by mainland China.

The Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) gathered in a Presbyterian Falls Church in North Virginia Monday, with He Cheng-shan, head of the FAPA's Washington, D.C. branch and reverend Chen Chin-fang spearheading the movement.

Chen noted China's full National People's Congress will meet in Beijing in March to discuss the draft "anti-secession law, " and urged all Taiwan compatriots to act in unison to urge U.S. congressmen to oppose the proposed law.
If Taiwan expatriates can get the support of 100 U.S. congressmen, the voices opposing the "anti-secession law" will get wider attention, he said.
The FAPA, established in 1982 in Los Angeles to promote the establishment of an independent and democratic Taiwan, also plans to protest in front of the Chinese Embassy Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES FOR THAW IN CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian likened the onset of spring with a thaw in cross-strait relations when he attended a Spring Festival gathering of literary and artistic figures Tuesday.
The president said that with the concerted efforts of all people, political reconciliation and the easing of cross-strait tensions can be achieved.
"Spring is coming," the president said, referring to cross-strait peace and democratic development in Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks during his meeting with hundreds of literary and artistic figures at the party, which was sponsored by the National Cultural Association (NCA).
The president also presented each participant a "red envelope, " or lucky money, to wish them a happy and prosperous new year.
Chen said that he has always admired the lives of the literati and artists, saying that the power of culture and arts is unlimited.

With no pressure to seek another term, Chen said he hopes to do his best to deliver on the promise he made when he headed the NCA in August 2000 to establish a country based on culture so that Taiwan can become steeped in rich cultural ambience.

Chen also took the opportunity to introduce Tchen Yu-chiou, the NCA's secretary-general, saying that she served as the chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs before, and hoped that she will continue to contribute to the literary and artistic development of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEANING OF 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' GETTING ATTENTION ABROAD: MOFA

TEXT.P: The international community is beginning to understand the serious ramifications of Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law, " thanks to the foreign ministry's efforts to get the message across, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Tuesday.

Meeting with a group of pro-independence activists at his office, Kau explained that the international community is starting to understand that Beijing is trying to translate its threat against Taiwan in general into pressure on Taiwan people and businessmen through the proposed law.

Citing information gathered by his ministry, Kau said it is possible that Taiwan people and businessmen would be subject to criminal punishment when they are outside of Taiwan because of the "schism" of their domicile as provided for in the Beijing law, which is an infringement on their human rights, he added.

The foreign ministry has sent teams around the world to explain what Beijing is up to, although there are still some countries that believe that the law won't disturb the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
This issue is put on the back burner by some countries because they already have their hands full with the crises in Iraq, Afghanistan, Africa and North Korea, Kau said.
Kau said his ministry is sparing no effort to make the world understand that if they coddle China on this issue, it will only encourage military adventurism in solving its disputes with Taiwan.

Activists, mainly members of the four Taiwan Societies in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan, and the Association of Lee Teng-hui's Friends, have urged the ministry to respond strongly to Beijing's "anti-secession law, " and to push vigorously for the country's entry into the United Nations or organize a referendum to decide the country's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOPES CHINA WILL PUT OFF 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW': AIT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The United States hopes mainland China will put off its plan to enact an "anti-secession law" to help temper the tension across the Taiwan Strait, an American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) official said Tuesday.

Raymond F. Greene, chief of the political section at the AIT's Taipei office, made the remarks during a visit to the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), according to Lai Ching-teh, one of the caucus leaders.
Greene expressed concern about the DPP's attitude toward the "anti-secession law" and whether it will promote a law to counteract it, Lai said.
He also expressed worry that cross-strait tension will escalate as a result of the enactment of the law and any move by Taiwan to retaliate, Lai said.

Lai told Greene that the DPP has repeatedly displayed goodwill to Beijing to try to improve cross-strait relations but it has to show its resolve to defend Taiwan's sovereignty in the face of the mainland's plan to introduce the "anti-secession law."

While the DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, will organize a demonstration for this purpose Feb. 28, they are likely to cooperate to propose a piece of counteracting legislation after the "anti-secession law" is passed, Lai said.

Asked whether the "anti-secession law" is the reason behind the United States' and Japan's recent decision to list "encouraging the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue" part of their common strategic objectives in the region, Greene said Washington has a long-standing concern over peace in the Asia-Pacific region and that this concern will not change because of the "anti-secession law," according to Lai.

Also during the visit, Greene expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will pass the budget for a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States within this session.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CARGO LINKS MAY TAKE PLACE BEFORE PASSENGER SERVICE: MAC

TEXT.P: Direct cargo links between Taiwan and mainland China might take place ahead of passenger services due to their importance to Taiwan's economic development, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday.

Wu made the remarks while paying a visit to outlying Kinmen Island, where he thanked the Kinmen authorities for their hard work in operating the "mini three links" -- direct trade and transport links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian Province -- during the Chinese New Year holidays.

A record high of more than 35,000 passengers, mainly mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families, returned home for the Feb. 9 holiday via the mini links despite direct charter flights between Taiwan proper and the mainland during the January 29 - Feb. 20 period.

Turning to the direct charter flight services, Wu said that the MAC, Taiwan's top mainland policy planning agency, will use this year's experience to improve similar operations in the future. But he pointed out that the MAC has no plans for the time being to expand the service to other major holidays.
According to the MAC chief, the decision was made on the grounds that demand for Taiwan-mainland charter flights on other holidays or weekends is not strong.

However, he revealed that the council will try its best to push for direct cargo services between Taiwan and the mainland, as the issue has long been hoped for by the two sides. He added that the scope of the links is expected to be broad and may run during the whole of year.
Compared to passenger services, direct cargo transportation carries a greater significance to Taiwan's economic development, he explained.
Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and MAC officials were also present during the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF PROMISES TO EXPAND 'MINI THREE LINKS' IN GRADUAL MANNER

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday that the government will further expand the direct "mini three links" in a gradual manner to help boost the development of Taiwan's two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu.

Wu made the remarks during an inspection tour of Kinmen to review the "mini three links" operations. Also, for the first time, Wu invited journalists posted in Taipei by three mainland Chinese news organizations -- Xinhua News Agency, China News Service and the People's Daily -- to accompany him on the Kinmen tour to show his determination to improve relations across the Taiwan Strait.

The "mini three links" refers to direct trade, postal and shipping links between Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/Mawei in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian. With the launch of two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter flights during the just-concluded Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, some people were worried that the prospects for the "mini three links" might dim after the holiday.
However, Wu said the "mini three links'" function cannot be easily replaced even when direct cross-strait shipping links become a reality.

"For Taiwan businessmen in the Fujian area, it's very convenient to travel via the 'mini three links' routes, " Wu said, adding that the government will conduct regular reviews of the "mini three links" operations and continue to expand them in terms of practical demand.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng echoed Wu's views, saying that Kinmen, which lies closer to Fujian than it does to Taiwan, will not be marginalized even after direct links between Taiwan proper and the mainland are opened.

"If the decades-old ban on direct cross-strait links can truly be lifted, it would symbolize substantial progress in cross-strait relations. By then, residents in all mainland provinces will be allowed to make sightseeing trips to Kinmen to help boost its tourist industry and overall economic development."

The mainland authorities began allowing Fujian residents to make leisure trips to Kinmen late last year. Because of poor publicity, only 400-plus Fujian residents have visited so far, but Lee said they have shown amazing purchasing power.
"I hope the cross-strait policy can become ever more open to allow residents in other major mainland cities, such as Shanghai and Beijing, to travel to Kinmen via direct air links," Lee said.

In response, Wu said that so long as the mainland is willing to negotiate with Taiwan, the two sides will be able to flesh out feasible packages for more convenient passenger and cargo transport services across the Taiwan Strait.

Under a landmark cross-strait deal struck in Macau Jan. 15, six carriers on each side of the Taiwan Strait were allowed to operate a total of 48 round-trip special charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families home for the New Year celebrations.

If mainland China is willing to negotiate without setting any prerequisites, Wu said he believes direct cross-strait cargo charter flights can take off on a regular basis in the not-too-distant future.

DOC.HEADLINE: NKFUST FORGES SISTERHOOD TIES WITH JAPANESE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: The National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology (NKFUST) forged sisterhood ties with the Baiko Gakuin University (BGU) of Japan Tuesday, according to NKFUST President Chou I-chang.

The signing ceremony was held at the NKFUST, in which Chou and BGU President Nakano Shinji signed a five-year bilateral agreement on exchanges of personnel, professors, students, academic reports and journals. They also agreed to co-organize academic symposia in various fields, Chou said.
To further promote academic research exchanges, both sides agreed to exchange a professor and two students for a one-year research and study program, Chou went on.

They also plan to set up "dual degree programs" in graduate schools, where graduate students can pursue studies for the first year in one school and the second year in the other. In the third year, the students' theses will be assessed by both universities' professors, Chou added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER MAKES TRANSIT STOP IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen made a three-hour transit stop at Narita Airport outside Tokyo Tuesday on his way to Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

He was greeted at the airport by Taiwan's representative to Japan Koh Se-kai and officials from the Interchange Association of Japan, which was formed to deal with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties. He was then escorted to a VIP lounge that was off-limits to the press.

Chen's arrival was considered by the Taiwan authorities to be politically significant, not only because he is the first ROC foreign minister to set foot in Japan since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1972 but also because Japan has just aligned itself with the United States in calling for the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue.
Reporters speculated that Chen might have exchanged views with Japanese officials on issues of mutual concern during his brief stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY NO LONGER OPPOSED TO DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT LINKS

TEXT.P: With the unprecedented two-way, non-stop Lunar New Year charter flights across the Taiwan Strait concluding smoothly, the military's attitude toward direct cross-strait transport links has changed, a senior official said Tuesday.
Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said during a Spring Festival lunch with local journalists that the military will not be a "stumbling-block" to the implementation of government policies.
According to Lee, the just-concluded Lunar New Year charter flights have proved that the the military is capable of fully monitoring mainland China's commercial flights.
"Therefore, if the government makes a policy decision on opening cross-strait air links on a regular basis, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will not oppose such a policy," Lee said.

Under a landmark cross-strait deal struck in Macau Jan. 15, six carriers on each side of the Taiwan Strait were allowed to operate a total of 48 round-trip special charter flights between Jan. 29 and Feb. 20 to carry mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families home for the Lunar New Year celebrations. Following their smooth conclusion, the government is now mulling a further easing of cross-strait economic exchanges and promoting regular cross-strait cargo charter flights.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chief of the General Staff Lee Tien-yu echoed the defense minister's views, saying that so long as the government comes to a decision, the military will coordinate with the government to facilitate the launch of cross-strait cargo charter flights.

"During the Lunar New Year period, the military's radar system was capable of monitoring each mainland charter flight from its takeoff from a mainland airport, its detour through Hong Kong airspace, to its arrival in Taiwan," he said.

With progress in warfare strategy and weaponry systems, Lee Tien-yu said, the ancient "Trojan Horse" formula is no longer applicable in modern warfare. Moreover, he went on, the military is fully prepared to cope with any contingencies.

Military sources said the military has reinforced combat preparedness at military bases surrounding the two airports used for the Lunar New Year cross-strait charter flights -- Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan and Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung. Rapid response forces equipped with air-defense and anti-terrorist weaponry systems have been stationed at all those bases to deal with contingencies at the two airports, the sources said.

The sources further said the military is still opposed to opening military-cum-commercial airports for cross-strait charter flights out of security concerns. The military also opposes allowing cross-strait night flights for similar reasons. As military-cum-commercial airports are used for domestic air routes, the sources said, cross-strait flights could be "downgraded" to domestic flights if they use those airports.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINI LINKS TO BE GRADUALLY ENHANCED: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday that the "mini three links" might be gradually enhanced due to their indispensable role in the absence of full links between Taiwan and mainland China.

Wu made the remarks during an inspection trip to the frontline island of Kinmen. The MAC chief was briefed by Kinmen county officials about the mini links operations during the recent Lunar New Year holiday and he thanked relevant personnel for their hard work during the peak period.

Claiming that the government is poised to further upgrade and open the mini links in a piecemeal fashion, Wu said that the practice is of great significance owing to their indispensable convenience for passengers traveling between Taiwan proper and the mainland in the absence of direct transport services between the two sides.

The mini links are in particular important for Taiwan businessmen and their families based in Fujian Province, he said, adding that the convenience is extremely important, even if direct air links are set up across the Taiwan Strait.
Kinmen lies closer to Fujian Province than it does to Taiwan proper.
A record high number of more than 35,000 passengers -- principally mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and their families -- returned home for the Feb. 9 Chinese New Year holiday via the mini links.

Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said he is not worried that Kinmen would be marginalized should cross-strait air travel be permitted. If air links were established between Taiwan and the mainland, he said, it might help bring in a larger number of mainland visitors, boosting the economy for the outlying island.

Lee, however, pointed out that the government should further step up its promotion campaign to lure tourists from Fujian, as the Fujian authorities began permitting residents late last year to travel to Kinmen on sight-seeing trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LOOKS FORWARD TO MILITARY EXCHANGES WITH JAPAN: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The military has on many occasions expressed interest in setting up exchanges with its Japanese counterpart, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Tuesday.

Lee made the remarks at a Spring Festival lunch with local journalists where he was asked about his views on an earlier media claim that the military will conduct a joint computerized war game with U.S. and Japanese forces during the Han Kuang 21 Exercise to be held later this year.
Lee just said the military's computerized war game system can be linked up with the U.S. forces but he refrained from mentioning whether the system can also be linked up with Japanese forces.
Asked about the possibility of triangular Taiwan-U.S.-Japan military cooperation, Lee said the military has consistently maintained cooperative ties with its U.S. counterpart.

As for Japan, Lee went on, the exchanges have so far been confined to reservist generals. "We have repeatedly expressed our intention to conduct exchanges with the Japanese military and we are well prepared to forge cooperative ties with Japanese forces, " he added.

According to media claims, the Presidential Office was upset by the premature media exposure of the planned joint computerized war game with the U.S. and Japanese forces and thus canceled a military meeting a day earlier.

However, Lee denied that the Presidential Office had any plans to hold a military meeting that day but he confirmed that the military is investigating how the information about the Han Kuang exercise was leaked to the media.
Lee said details of the Han Kuang exercise have not yet even been fleshed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC BANKS' OVERDUE LOAN RATIO STABLE IN JANUARY: FSC

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 22 (CNA ) Taiwan's banks posted an average overdue loan ratio of 2.78 percent in January, a similar level to the rate registered at the end of December last year, a spokesman for the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) reported Tuesday.

The 2.78 percent ratio is equal to a combined overdue loan worth NT$432.8 billion (US$13.7 billion) , the FSC official said, adding that it is worth noting that the amount of normal bank loans continued to drop to NT$155.1 billion.
Taiwan's banks have succeeded in slashing their overdue loan ratios in recent years. The average overdue loan rate still stood at above 5 percent at the end of June 2003.
As of late January this year, some 87.5 percent of the domestic banks had managed to register an overdue loan ratio lower than 5 percent, with 50 percent of them recording a rate below 2.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SETS KEYNOTE FOR SNAP PARTY CONGRESS

TEXT.P: The Central Executive Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) set the keynote Tuesday for its March 12 extraordinary party congress.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said after a meeting of the committee that the keynote will be "persist in reform and defend Taiwan," while the logo of the congress will be a shield with a heart formed by two hands, according to Lee.
The shield represents the party's determination to defend Taiwan and the heart means the party's passion for the island.

The purpose of the snap congress is to approve regulations for nominating the party's candidates for members of the National Assembly that will be responsible for amending the Constitution later this year.

Noting that the DPP has promised to update the country's Constitution by cutting the size of the legislature and redrawing the constituencies from which lawmakers are elected, Lee said his party is determined to carry out its campaign promises thoroughly.

But since Beijing's National People's Congress is set to enact a so-called "anti-secession law" in an attempt to prevent Taiwan from seeking independence, the DPP Congress will also speak out against Beijing loudly during the congress, Lee said.

Calling Beijing's "anti-secession law" an attempt to justify an eventual attack against Taiwan and thereby posing a serious threat to regional security, Lee said the DPP was founded to defend Taiwan's sovereignty and it will do whatever it can to ensure the country's survival.
During the snap congress, Lee said, the DPP will lambaste Beijing's attitude toward Taiwan and will reiterate its determination to defend the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICIANS THROW COLD WATER ON IDEA OF AGREEMENT WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: Politicians across the political spectrum threw cold water Tuesday on a U.S. China affairs expert's idea of locking in the status quo across Taiwan Straits with a U.S.-brokered agreement of 20-to-30 years between China and Taiwan.

Su Chi, a lawmaker of the opposition Kuomintang and a former chief of the Mainland Affairs Council pointed out that the suggestion of Kenneth Lieberthal, a former senior director for Asian affairs of the National Security Council in the United States, is unfeasible because China, which considers the Taiwan issue to be an internal affair, would never accept the mediation of any third country, particularly the United States, which China blames for encouraging Taiwan independence.
Furthermore, Su said, Taiwan has difficulty even building a consensus among its own politician on negotiations with China.

Lawmaker Sun Ta-chian of the opposition People First Party also took a dim view of the idea, saying that the possibility of an agreement such as that suggested by Lieberthal is slim in light of Beijing's hostility toward Taiwan's leaders.
Tung Li-wen, director of the Department for Chinese Affairs under the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said his party will not accept any negotiation on the sovereignty of Taiwan.
Lai Hsing-yuan, a lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, said it would not pay to compromise Taiwan's sovereignty for only 20 or 30 years of peace with China.
Lieberthal said in an article published in the March-April issue of Foreign Affairs that there are two approaches to eliminate the possibility of war across the Taiwan Strait.

The first approach, according to Lieberthal, is for Beijing to adopt an international definition of Taiwanese independence, under which a country is independent only if other countries recognize it as such.

Citing former Secretary of State Colin Powell as declaring in Beijing late last year that "Taiwan is not independent", Lieberthal said Beijing had already succeeded in preventing Taiwan's independence by this standard.

However, Lieberthal said Beijing is highly unlikely to adopt this simple resolution, therefore there are the second approach which is to lock in the status quo by having Beijing and Taipei negotiate a 20-to-30-year "agreed framework" for stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Such an agreement would eliminate the possibility of Beijing's attack against Taiwan, and the possibility of Taiwan's crossing the independence red line, Lieberthal said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 23, or the 15th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at
Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of
the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United
States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading
proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse, " which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of
his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United
States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great
Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign
the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa
Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1
million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty
Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating
cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist
Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets
up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's
Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in
exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting
and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested
after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4
of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang
adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER ARRIVES IN NEW YORK FOR TRANSIT STOP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By C.Y. Tseng and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Chen Tan-sun arrived in New York Tuesday for an one-day transit stop en route to Haiti and the Dominican Republic -- two ROC diplomatic allies in the Caribbean.
According to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, the minister has no plans to meet with U.S. officials or local Taiwanese expatriates during his short stay in the city.

Chen's three-hour transit stop at Narita Airport near Tokyo earlier the same day has received significant media attention as Japan recently held a security consultation meeting with the United States after which the two countries emphasized in a joint statement that maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait is part of their common strategic objectives.

The New York Times recently quoted Chen as saying that the joint statement has made Taiwan more confident in it's security but that he would not like to see the statement as a challenge to China and only wants to emphasize the importance of resolving cross-strait problems peacefully.
Chen's trip to Haiti and the Dominican Republic will be his first to ROC diplomatic allies in the Caribbean since he became the nation's top diplomatic official last year.
