DOC.HEADLINE: MORE PYGMY WHALES FOUND BEACHED ON TAINAN COUNTY COAST
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Nearly 20 pygmy killer whales were found beached Wednesday morning on a beach in Tainan County, southwest Taiwan, one day after eight others were found on the same beach, coast guard authorities reported.
Veterinarians, coast guard officers and experts from the Taiwan Cetacean Society rushed to the scene to try to help the pygmy killer whales back into the sea.

The experts are still trying to determine why so many pygmy killer whales have beached themselves over the last two days. Further adding to the mystery is the fact that the pygmy killer whale, which is actually a species of dolphin, is usually seen in waters off Taiwan's east coast and rarely off the island's western shores.

Of the eight beached pygmy killer whales discovered on the sandbank in Tainan County's Chiangchun rural township Tuesday, three have died, three have been returned to the sea in good health, while the remaining two have been sent to the Sitsao Reservation District of Tainan City for treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY COUNCILORS VISIT VERSAILLES TO CONSOLIDATE FRIENDSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Versailles, France, Feb. 22 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A ten-member delegation from the Taipei City Council, headed by Wu Bi-chu, speaker of the council, visited the Versailles city government Tuesday with the aim of consolidating friendly relations between the two sister cities.

Welcoming the delegation, S. Buffetaut, Versailles deputy mayor responsible for international affairs, said that the city, which played an important role in French history to the end the imperial era in the country, is a symbol of freedom. He also said that Taipei is well known as a democratic and free city.

In response, Wu said that Versailles is a world famous city of culture and that Taipei has a lot to learn from the French city, expressing the hope that the two cities will strengthen their cultural, educational, economic and trade exchanges in the future.
Chen Yu-mei, a member of the Taipei City Council delegation, also said that Taipei can learn a lot from France as Taipei is currently working on promoting its cultural tourism industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR BEIJING TO ABANDON MOVES HARMFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A ranking official from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) called for the Beijing leadership Wednesday to abandon moves and gestures that are potentially harmful to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Commenting on Beijing's proposed anti-secession law, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Ta-san said that it is undesirable and meaningless for China to take actions that will consequently hamper cross-strait exchanges, infringe on the rights of the Taiwan people, and destabilize the situation in East Asia.
China's National People's Congress (NPC) Standing Committee late last year placed the anti-secession bill on the agenda for the annual session of the NPC set for this March.
Chiu noted that the Beijing authorities have yet to make public the contents of the proposed bill, presumably because they are still watching how nations concerned are reacting to it.

President Chen Shui-bian in his New Year's message called for the nation to seriously face Beijing's proposed anti-secession law which he said would undermine stability across the Taiwan Strait if enacted.

Chen said that Beijing has been actively engaging in "psychological, legal and media warfare" in pushing to enact the anti-secession law, which he said is aimed at establishing a legal justification for a military invasion of Taiwan.

In related news, Chiu welcomed Minister of National Defense Lee Jye's remarks a day earlier that the defense ministry will not oppose the opening of cross-strait air links on a regular basis if the government makes such a policy decision.

It is a welcome message from Lee that the military is capable of defending Taiwan and is fully capable of monitoring mainland China's commercial flights, a reassurance that further strengthens the confidence of the people, Chiu added.

Lee said Tuesday that with the unprecedented two-way, non-stop Lunar New Year charter flights across the Taiwan Strait concluding smoothly, the military's attitude toward direct cross-strait transport links has changed.
He noted that the military will not be a "stumbling-block" to the implementation of government policies.
Lee said that the just-concluded Lunar New Year charter flights have proved that the military is capable of fully monitoring mainland China's commercial flights.
"Therefore, if the government makes a policy decision on opening cross-strait air links on a regular basis, the Ministry of National Defense will not oppose such a policy," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUAO FISHING BOAT DETAINED BY JAPANESE FISHERIES FORCES
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, Eastern Taiwan, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Forces from Japan's Fisheries Agency detained Tuesday a Suao-based fishing boat, the Chin Fu Yu No. 66, for allegedly trespassing into Japan's economic zone, sources from the Ilan Fishery Association said Wednesday.

Lin Yue-ying, executive director of the Ilan Fishery Association, quoted a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) source in Fukuoka as saying that the vessel, along with its three Taiwanese and seven mainland Chinese crew, was seized by the Japanese fisheries forces in the East China Sea, which is an overlapping area between Taiwan's and Japan's 200-km economic zones.
The vessel was towed to a fishing port in the Japanese Five Islands chain, while the crew was transported to Fukuoka for questioning, according to the MOFA source.
The Japanese fisheries authorities are said to have demanded some 4.3 million yen as a guarantee payment for the crew's release.

The families of the three Taiwanese crewmen called the Suao Fishermen's Radio Tuesday night for help, Lin said, adding that the Suao Fishery Association is currently making emergency arrangements to bail the crew out as quickly as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Says Europe Should Not Lift Its China Arms Embargo
A simmering dispute with Europe came to the fore front on Tuesday when U.S. President Bush said there was "deep concern" in the United States that lifting the European Union's arms embargo against China would change the balance of relations between China and Taiwan. The issue has been one of the few disagreements to spill into the open during Bush's trip to repair relations across the Atlantic. In his most explicit public argument, Bush said lifting the ban would allow the transfer of critical military technology to the Chinese that would "change the balance of relations between China and Taiwan, and that's of concern." The U.S. administration also fears that such technology, especially advanced radar and communications systems, might be passed on to other countries.
Wall Street Journal: Dollar Selloff Sends Shocks Through Markets
A selloff of the dollar Tuesday, fueled by persistent concerns over the currency's weakness, roiled financial markets world-wide. As the dollar registered its worst daily decline in two months, 1.4 percent against both the euro and the yen, stock markets in New York, London, Paris and Frankfurt all retreated. Gold and oil prices, which tend to move upward when the dollar is weak, rose sharply.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINE OUT OF 28 BEACHED DOLPHINS DIE IN TAINAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Nine of a pod of 28 cetaceans believed to be a species of dolphin that were found beached Wednesday morning on a beach in Tainan County's Chiangchun rural township, had died by later in the day, while the remaining 18 were still stranded on shore.
Veterinarians, coast guard officers and experts from the Taiwan Cetacean Society rushed to the scene to try to get the animals off the beach and back into the water.

The dead animals, believed to be either pygmy killer whales or melon-headed whales, will be transported to the Tainan County Livestock Disease Control Center for autopsy, said Hsieh Yao-ching, director of the center.
The 28 animals were found one day after eight others were found on the same beach. The experts are still trying to determine why so many have beached themselves over the last two days.
Hsieh noted that currently there are more than 10 theories about the mass stranding, but none had yet been determined.

Further adding to the mystery is the fact that the pygmy killer whales or melon-headed whales, which are actually a species of dolphin, are usually seen in the waters off Taiwan's east coast and rarely off the island's western shores.

Of the eight discovered on a sandbank in Chiangchun rural township the previous day, three have died, three have been returned to the sea in good health, while the remaining two have been sent to the Sitsao Reservation District of Tainan City for treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose slightly Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 14.35 points to close at 6,121.52.

The bourse opened at 6,082.34 and fluctuated between 6,048.63 and 6,128.70 during trading, with a total of 3.26 billion shares changing hands on a market turnover of NT$76.66 billion (US$2.44 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.0 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent and plastics and chemicals at 0.2 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp stocks moving up the most at 0.6 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent, cement shares and textile stocks, both at 0.3 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 389 to 375, with 219 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton will arrive in Taipei Sunday for a two-day visit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

MOFA officials said the government invited Clinton through the Republic of China's Representative Office in the United States and that the ministry will provide him with maximum security protection and treatment nearly on par with that accorded to an sitting head of state.
Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, who is currently on a visit to ROC allies in Central America, will return early Sunday so he can greet Clinton upon his arrival, the officials said.
Clinton is scheduled to deliver a speech Sunday on Asian democracy to be sponsored by the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, after which he will answer questions from the audience.
Later in the evening, he will attend a dinner party given in his honor by President Chen Shui-bian and both sides will exchange views on issues related to regional security.
On Monday morning, Clinton will attend an autograph session for his autobiography "My Life" before leaving that afternoon.

Since Clinton stepped down from the presidency, the government has wanted to invite him for a visit, but a planned trip failed to materialize due to the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on the United States, the officials said.

The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, a non-profit organization dedicated to the promotion of democracy and human rights in Taiwan and abroad, planned to invite Clinton to deliver a speech in November 2003, but that plan was also postponed.
Clinton wanted to make a stopover in Taiwan last September on an Asian tour to promote his book, but the plan was canceled when he suffered a heart attack.
Clinton visited Taiwan four times during his tenure as governor of Arkansas before being elected president in November 1991.

MOFA officials said recently that Clinton contributed a great deal to the promotion of substantive Taiwan-U.S. relations during his presidency, particularly his decision to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to patrol waters near Taiwan during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY CHAIRMAN ELECTION TO FOLLOW ESTABLISHED SYSTEM: KMT

TEXT.P: The election of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman will be held in accordance with the party's established system, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Wednesday.
Lin was commenting on a proposal by KMT Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao to postpone the election for one year.

With the next election set to take place this May, Lee claimed that the postponement would call a truce in the struggle between Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who are both vice chairmen of the KMT, for the chairmanship.
However, Lin said the KMT charter, which stipulates that the chairman is elected every four years, will guide the chairmanship election.
According to KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen, Lee's proposal is not feasible because it is too late to revise the charter now.

Also speaking on the issue, Ma said the system for the direct election of the party chairman was established by incumbent chairman Lien Chan more than four years ago and that he does not see any reason why this system should be changed this time.
Ma denied there is any rivalry between himself and Wang, saying he has maintained smooth communication with Wang to avoid unnecessary misunderstandings.
Ma said the purpose of his decision to run for the KMT chairmanship is to promote party reforms and that he hopes to change the KMT culture through a mechanism of fair competition.
Meanwhile, Wang said there is a consensus between himself and Ma to compete with each other based on mutual respect and to maintain the peace and unity of the party.
On the proposal to postpone the election, Wang said it would require a consensus within the party before any change could take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST MAINLAND CHINESE PILGRIM GROUP VISITS MATSU

TEXT.P: A 37-member group of pilgrims from mainland China arrived on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu Wednesday for religious and cultural exchanges.

It was the first mainland pilgrim group to visit Matsu since the Republic of China government initiated direct trade, postal and shipping links between the ROC outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland's Fujian Province port cities of Fuzhou and Xiamen in January 2001, better known as the "mini three links."

The group from Fuzhou City joined their Matsu counterparts in a ceremony worshipping the Shangshu God, which has been enshrined in a temple in Matsu's Peikan Isle for several hundred years. The pilgrims then joined a procession which made its way throughout the streets of Matsu.

Members of the Fuzhou pilgrim group, who are scheduled to stay on Matsu for three days, will also join Matsu residents in a ceremony to be held Wednesday evening to mark the Lantern Festival celebration.

The ceremony will be the second of its kind since last February, when people from Matsu and Mawei City, Fujian Province, celebrated the traditional festival simultaneously in the two port cities located opposite each other across the narrow channel that divides Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Tries To Allay E.U. Worry Over Iran.
President Bush said Tuesday that concern about possible U.S. military action against Iran "is simply ridiculous, " but he added at a news conference that "all options are on the table" in dealing with suspected Iranian attempts to acquire nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RICE DONATION TO IRAQ AUCTIONED OFF BY JORDAN CHARITY GROUP

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials confirmed Wednesday a 4,000-ton rice donation from Taiwan to Iraq has been auctioned off without Taiwan's knowledge by a Jordan charity group entrusted to deliver the shipment.

The rice, worth US$4 million, was sold by the Jordan Hashemite Charity Organization as animal feed for just US$600,000 after it had been left in the warehouse for one year owing to delivery difficulties, according to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu.
Lu said the government has protested to the organization over the matter and will seriously reconsider whether to continue its cooperation with the organization in the future.

Despite its dissatisfaction with the decision, the government has adopted the organization's recommendation to use the US$600,000 to purchase medical and relief supplies to help Iraqi refugees, Lu said.
He said the MOFA will closely monitor the procurement and delivery process to ensure the supplies are actually sent to Iraq.
Taiwan has provided relief supplies through various channels to help the Iraqi people in the aftermath of the U.S.-led war in Iraq.
In April 2003, it shipped a total of 5,000 tons of rice to Jordan, of which 1,000 tons had been successfully delivered to Iraq as of April 2004, according to the MOFA.
Delivery of the remaining shipment was obstructed by constant terrorist attacks, kidnapping of foreigners and soaring transportation fees in Iraq, ministry officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March grew 17 points to close at 6,114, with 3,0573 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for April moved up 23 points to finish at 6,119, with 141 contracts traded, while June futures increased 14 points to close at 6,114, with 23 contracts traded. September futures increased one point to finish at 6,036, with 36 contracts traded, while December futures lost 50 points to close at 5,980, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,097 for March, 6,096 for April, 6,100 for June, 6,035 for September and 6,030 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
March TE futures moved up 1.4 points to close at 234.4, with 6,398 contracts traded, while April TE futures grew 1.2 points to finish at 234.35, with 30 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for September, June and December.

March TF futures lost four points to finish at 1,009, with 4,299 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures declined 5.4 points to end at 1,007.2, with 43 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 1,005, with three contracts traded, while September TF futures lost 4.2 points to finish at 1,005, with two contract transactions.
December TF futures slumped 10.2 points to finish at 1,005, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar declined against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.133 to close at NT$31.199.
A total of US$1.13 billion changed hands during the trading session.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.332 and slid to a low of NT$31.160.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CUT BIGEYE TUNA FISHING FLEET BY 60 VESSELS

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration under the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday that it will cut 60 bigeye tuna fishing vessels from the fleet by the end of this year in response to an international trend toward tuna conservation and sustainable fisheries.
Fishery officials also said they will strengthen the management of tuna fishing operations so as not to violate the international norms.
In a meeting of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) last November, Japan and several other nations accused Taiwan vessels of poaching.

The Taiwan delegation admitted at the time that there could be "isolated cases" of poaching, but claimed the practice is not widespread. Taiwan promised to strengthen management and deduct the overfishing quota annually, and the ICCAT agreed to give Taiwan one year of probation and continue to impose quotas until a review next year.
The officials estimated that 24 fishing vessels can be cut in the Atlantic, 21 in the Indian Ocean and 15 in the Pacific by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Queen will not attend the Prince's wedding.
The Queen will not attend the civil wedding ceremony of the Prince of Wales, her son and heir, to Camilla Parker Bowles, Buckingham Palace said last night. The official explanation for the decision is that she respects the Prince of Wales' s wish for the occasion to be low key. But her refusal to attend the ceremony in the Guildhall, Windsor, discloses division at the heart of the Royal Household.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT CENTRAL AMERICA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Wednesday that she will lead a delegation of agricultural and business leaders next month on a two-week visit to El Salvador and Guatemala, two Republic of China diplomatic allies in Central America.

Lu told journalists at a tea party she hosted at her office for members of the delegation that the trip was initially set for Feb. 10 but was rescheduled to begin March 12, and is aimed at helping local businessmen find investment opportunities in the two countries, in addition to improving diplomatic ties with them.

Claiming that Taiwan's investment in mainland China and Southeast Asia has been restricted by what she described only as "unexpected difficulties, " the vice president said she has always urged the country's businessmen to explore the markets on the other side of the Pacific, especial Central and South America.
Lu said she hopes her forthcoming trip will help businessmen to build bridgeheads in the two countries.
During her stay in Guatemala, Lu said, she will also attend a regional conference of the Democratic Pacific Assembly, which she helped found in Taipei in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALENT SEARCH LAUNCHED TO MARK WORLD YEAR OF PHYSICS 2005

TEXT.P: The Physics Society of the Republic of China launched a physics talent search Wednesday to mark the World Year of Physics (WYP) 2005.

Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who is also a member of the society, said the purpose of the project is not to look for an Albert Einstein or excellent scientists but to arouse students' interest in physics.

Lee said that although Einstein is known today for his contributions to a number of physics discoveries including the theory of relativity, he was not an outstanding student in the eyes of his high school teachers.
According to Lee, while examinations might be a tool for evaluating the abilities of students, they are incapable of assessing the talent of a great scientist.
Lee said the talent search is a competition and does not mean that those contestants who are not selected are not talented in physics.
The competition is open to local elementary, junior high and senior high students aged between 10 and 18, according to the society.

Two male and two female senior high students, one male and one female junior high student, as well as one male and one female elementary student, will be selected to become "International WYP 2005 Physics Young Ambassadors," who will represent Taiwan in the WYP 2005 Conference to be held in South Africa.
Online registration for the competition is being accepted at http://wyp2005.taiwanschoolnet.org.

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURAL ASSOCIATION TO INTRODUCE TAIWANESE CULTURE TO THE WORLD

TEXT.P: National Cultural Association Secretary-General Tchen Yu-chiou pledged Wednesday to introduce Taiwan's fascinating culture to the world to make the island a shining star in the international community.
Tchen made the remarks in a speech given at a Rotary International Taiwan gathering held as part of the Rotary International's centennial celebrations.
Tchen, who is a former chairwoman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, likened Taiwan to a diamond with varied facets.

While natural resources are plentiful and there are many cultures in Taiwan, the island is also recognized for its democratic development, hi-tech industry as well as art and culture, she pointed out.
By singing their own songs, wearing their own clothes, writing their own history and living their own lifestyle, the people of Taiwan have rich artistic and cultural resources, she said.
She proposed that the Taiwanese people work to create their own brands and upgrade the island's international status with their creativity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO GATHER SIGNATURES AGAINST CHINA'S 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and a dozen civic groups announced Wednesday that they will launch an "anti-annexation" petition drive in Kaohsiung on Feb. 28, also known in Taiwan as 228 Peace Memorial Day.

Huang Chao-chan, TSU deputy secretary-general, claimed that mainland China will soon take action against Taiwan businessmen who support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the TSU, because of the parties' support for Taiwan independence, intimidating the businessmen from openly expressing their views.
The full session of Beijing's National People's Congress will also meet in March to review and is expected to approve a proposed "anti-secession law" against Taiwan independence, Huang said.
"If the people of Taiwan don't speak up against this 'annexation law,' the security of the island will be undermined," he said.

Tseng Kuei-hai, president of the Southern Taiwan Society, said that 228 Peace Memorial Day recalls a traumatic time in Taiwan's history and everyone should learn from that time and come out openly against the mainland bill.

The 228 Incident refers to events that led to a brutal crackdown by the Chiang Kai-shek Kuomintang government against the local people, particularly the elite and dissidents -- real or suspected. Tens of thousands of people were systematically killed.
There will also be a gathering in front of the 228 monument at Shou Mountain that night as part of the demonstration.
The TSU's southern Taiwan office also announced Wednesday that it will hold a 10,000-person "anti-annexation and protect Taiwan" march on March 6 in Kaohsiung between 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m.

Two groups will begin the march from separate points and meet up at the final destination, the Kaohsiung Cultural Center, where Lee Teng-hui, former ROC president and spiritual leader of the TSU, will give a speech.
Kaohsiung City Councilor Chao Tien-lin said that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should attend the march and clearly state the party's stance.
The TSU will invite Premier Frank Hsieh, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai to participate in the march and to speak on the issue of mainland China's proposed law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOLD PRIMARIES, WORK WITH ALLIES FOR LOCAL CHIEF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will hold intra-party primaries to select potential candidates for the year-end local chief elections and then decide on the final candidates after consultations with the party's two political allies, a KMT spokeswoman said Wednesday.
Cheng Li-wen said that the KMT expects the primaries will be conducted in an open, fair and democratic manner.

Regarding coordination with the People First Party and the New Party, she said the "pan-blue alliance" must agree on a "game plan" for selecting the final candidates, adding that this model is how the alliance will win the mayoral and magistrate elections.
She also said that the party will address the different needs of each city and county and seek the views of local party branches during the nomination process.
Basically, all incumbent KMT local chiefs will seek re-election, and the party will support them, she said.
In several hotly contested areas such as Taipei County, the KMT
will pull out all the stops to win, while the party is also hoping to regain lost ground in Changhua and Nantou counties, Cheng said.
The party also stands a good chance of winning back Pingtung County, she added.
She said the party hopes all aspirants will make known their intentions and make preparations early.
The party will also complete the nomination operations as early as possible so that newcomers will have enough time to prepare for the elections.
The local chief elections are fiercely contested, and the outcome will have a significant impact on the political landscape, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BELIZE MAYOR ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Belize Mayor William David Fonseca arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a five-day visit.
During the visit, Fonseca will meet with Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Francisco Hwang and other government officials, foreign ministry officials said.
He will sign a sister city accord with his Kaohsiung counterpart Feb. 25 when he will tour the southern Taiwan port city, the officials said.
Fonseca will also tour various economic and cultural establishments before departing Taiwan Feb. 27, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG TALKS START OF MEETING OF THE MINDS: YU SHYI-KUN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong are expected to move closer in their opinions about ties with mainland China after their Thursday meeting, a result that will be conducive to developing a mechanism to promote peace with mainland China, an aide to the president said Wednesday.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that it is not surprising that leading figures from different parties should have differing views about ties with mainland China, but this gap should narrow after Chen and Soong reach a meeting of the minds on Thursday.

Noting that Soong's party has initiated a bill to promote peace with mainland China, and President Chen is contemplating setting up a non-partisan commission as the supreme arbiter of the course of ties with mainland China, Yu said the two leaders ought to be able to find common ground in their views, which will pave the way for later negotiations between their aides until a firm consensus eventually emerges.
Yu said the two leaders, slated to exchange views on ties with mainland China, defense, and harmony among different ethnic groups, will discuss generalities rather than specific cases or rules.

As to the PFP's call for President Chen to set aside the goal of seeking Taiwan independence, a plank in the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's platform, Yu said the president spelled out his vision for the country's status and ties with mainland China in his second inaugural address, adding that these will not change.

Given that the aides from both camps spent considerable effort to make the meeting a reality, Yu said he feels that Chen and Soong are sincere in trying to reconcile their differences. He said he was confident the meeting would be the beginning of a coalescence of a common sense of purpose.

Preparations for a similar meeting between the president and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan are also underway, with one of Chen's aides having phoned Lien's chief of staff, Lin Fong-cheng, to explore the possibility, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PULLING ITS WEIGHT IN CUTTING OZONE-DEPLETING AGENT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan is in compliance with the 1987 Montreal Protocol regarding the production and use of hydrochlorofluorocarbons, or HCFCs, even thought the Republic of China is not a signatory to the agreement, the Environmental Protection Administration announced Wednesday.

The administration said in a statement that Taiwan's HCFC consumption has been cut to 414.8 tons, or 35 percent less than its 1996 consumption of 638.1 tons in line with the requirement of the Montreal Protocol which requires a gradual phase-out of HCFCs until 2030 when HCFCs must not be produced at all.
HCFCs contribute to the depletion of the ozone layer, which in turn is harmful to life and the environment by allowing an excess amount of harmful UV-B radiation through the atmosphere.
The country's economic and trade organizations, as well as technological research organizations helped in the reduction, the statement said.
In 1992, members of various sectors in Taiwan, including the government, set up the Taiwan Ozone Layer Protection Association to parallel requirements stated in the Montreal Protocol.
According to the protocol, HCFCs, which have been, among other things, used widely as a refrigerant, should be cut by 65 percent from the 1996 level by 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOSCO EMERGING MARKET REGIONAL TRAINING SEMINAR TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2005 International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO) Emerging Market Training Seminar will be held Feb. 24-25 in Taipei, officials of the Financial Supervisory Commission said Wednesday.
The main topics of the two-day meeting will be corporate governance and investor protection, the officials said.
Activities of the meeting will include keynote speeches, panel discussions and floor meetings, they added.

Prominent lecturers, panelists and moderators will include IOSCO Secretary-General Philippe Richard, Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission Chairperson Kong Jaw-sheng and Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng, Turkey's Capital Market Board Chairman Dogan Cansizlar, Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission Chairman Andrew Sheng and Stephen Harbeck, president and CEO of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORTS ON AIR FORCE'S PLAN TO BUY F35 FIGHTERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) denied reports Wednesday that the ROC Air Force plans to buy 200 F35 jet fighters in 2020.
A statement issued by the MND Military Spokesman's Office said that the reports are not true and that the air force is now evaluating programs for renovating its jet fighters.
The armed forces are focusing their efforts for the moment on acquiring submarines, P-3C submarine-hunting planes and Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.

The country's arms procurement follows a standarized process which is established in line with the results of a combined assessment on international situations, needs of the armed forces, new global trends in the development of jet fighters, the possibility of acquisition and the timing, it added.

The MND will begin to plan the acquisition of armored vehicles and attack helicopters for the army after the completion of the current arms purchase program for which budgets are pending to be approved by the Legislative Yuan, the statement revealed, adding that the program for purchasing the so-called third generation of jet fighters will be initiated only after the army's arms purchase is completed.
The F35 fighter is a joint strike fighter being developed by Lockheed Martin Aeronautics Co. for the U.S. Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps and the British Royal Navy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CELEBRATION OF LANTERN FESTIVAL BENEFITS CHINA: VP LU

TEXT.P: As the country exuberantly celebrated the traditional Lantern Festival by displaying various types of electric lanterns Wednesday, Vice President Annette Lu decried the way the holiday is celebrated in Taiwan as a waste of electricity and a benefit to rival China.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the 100th anniversary of the International Rotary Club in Keelung, northern Taiwan, Lu said she turned down several invitations from local governments to light lanterns because she said the exhibition of lanterns in the country consumes about 60,000 kilowatts of electricity per night.
What's more, the outspoken critic of mainland China said most of the lanterns sold in Taiwan were made in China, and the island is unwittingly contributing to Beijing's economic growth.
Lu also called on men in the country not to wear suit coats this summer so that the use of air conditioning can be reduced in offices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROMISES NOT TO PUSH FOR CONTROVERSIAL POLICIES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh promised in his first administrative report to the Legislative Yuan that he won't push for controversial policies.

According to an advance copy of the report which is expected to be read by the premier at the legislature on Feb. 25, the premier said he sincerely wants to cooperate with various parties in the legislature in hopes of creating a political symbiosis among various parties.

Hsieh said the agenda of his administration is to create a healthy Taiwan, including the health in physique, health in environment, health in government, health in economy, health in society and health in life.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 24, or the 16th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
2004: A Taiwan-developed hybrid car powered by an internal combustion engine and an electric motor is unveiled.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong began their much anticipated meeting at the Taipei Guest House at about 10: 30 a.m. Thursday, marking their second such meeting since Chen assumed the presidency in 2000.

The two leaders, slated to exchange views on ties with mainland China, defense, and harmony among the different ethnic groups in Taiwan, will discuss general principles rather than specific cases or rules, according to President Chen's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun.

The first Chen-Soong meeting was held on Oct. 19, 2000, during which the two exchanged views on political party cooperation, the development of cross-strait relations, the economy, crime and corruption control, as well as post-921 earthquake reconstruction.
Chen and Soong are expected to meet with the press for a question and answer session at around noon following their high-profile meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE CROSS-STRAIT TASK FORCE TO BE REACTIVATED: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The legislative cross-strait affairs task force, which has not been in active operation since 1999, will be reactivated to allow lawmakers to contribute more in efforts at accelerating the development of cross-strait relations, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced Thursday.

Noting that the mechanism of the task force still exists, Wang stressed that the legislature should grasp the "favorable" atmosphere across the Taiwan Strait, epitomized by the recent implementation of the special cross-strait charter flights for the Chinese New Year period, and reactivate the mechanism.

Wang said that he will take the initiative at the next round of inter-party consultations in reactivating the task force after its operations were suspended after 1999 following then President Lee Teng-hui's remarks defining cross-strait relations as special "state-to-state" relations.

The legislative speaker said it is hoped that all future cross-strait activities and relations will be included under the operations of the legislative cross-strait affairs task force, which he said he believes will allow Taiwan to get on better terms with the mainland eventually.
The Legislative Yuan will also make known its position, through the cross-strait affairs task force, on Beijing's proposed anti-secession bill and other crucial issues, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CAPITAL MARKET WINS INTERNATIONAL RECOGNITION: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's capital market has won recognition from international investment institutions for a series of reforms and continued market opening in recent years, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday.
Wu made the remarks while addressing the opening of the 2005 International Organization of Securities Commission (IOSCO) Emerging Market Training Seminar in Taipei.

He pointed out that Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) raised its weighting of Taiwan stocks, increasing Taiwan's Limited Investability Factor (LIF) from 0.55 to 0.75 last year, and that it will increase Taiwan's LIF from 0.75 to 1 at the end of this May.

In addition, the FTSE Group, a joint venture between the Financial Times and the London Stock Exchange, announced in September 2004 that Taiwan had officially been added to its Watch List and would be reviewed in 2005 for a possible upgrading to developed market status, Wu said.
All indexes show that Taiwan's economic environment and capital market have won recognition from international investment institutions, he added.

Wu said that through years of efforts, Taiwan's capital market has developed all the features of a developed market based on fairness, efficiency, transparency, the rule of law and respect for investors' rights.

Kong Jaw-sheng, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, (FSC) speaking on the same occasion, noted that the commission has since last month begun an islandwide tour to introduce the operations of the commission and help solve the problems faced by investors.

Andrew Sheng, chairman of Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission, said that Kong visited Hong Kong last month and came to the belief that bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong will be even closer in the future.
The main topics of this year's IOSCO emerging market seminar in Taiwan are corporate governance and investor protection.
More than 60 representatives from the securities institutions of more than 20 countries are attending the two-day seminar sponsored by the FSC.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING AIMED AT INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday morning prior to his meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong that the meeting is aimed at ending the hostile political wrangling among the domestic parties and boosting inter-party reconciliation.
Chen made the remarks at the Taipei Guest House, a government-owned estate near the Presidential Office, where the much anticipated meeting was being held.
Because of the "fragile state of trust" between the ruling and opposition parties, Chen said that arranging the meeting required strenuous efforts.

"In Taiwan's present political atmosphere, inter-party confrontation is easier than reconciliation. And this volatile situation necessitates today's meeting between myself and Chairman Soong, " Chen said.

Chen presented Soong with a calligraphic work featuring the two Chinese characters "chen cheng, " meaning "sincerity, " as a goodwill gift. The two then posed for a photo with the calligraphic work to symbolize their sincerity in tempering inter-party animosity and promoting mutual reconciliation.

For his part, Soong said his decision to meet with Chen is a response to the mainstream public aspiration for an end to the "war of attrition" between the ruling and opposition camps that has dominated the domestic political arena for more than four years.

"The people are fed up with the hostile inter-party wrangling. The main topic for today's meeting will focus on how to let our people live with dignity, how to sustain Taiwan's development and how to ease disputes across the Taiwan Strait," Soong said.

Chen and Soong hold diverging views on the development of cross-strait relations. Soong has accused Chen of lacking a consistent China policy and of provoking Beijing, while the president has accused the opposition of being too accommodating toward the communist giant.

Chen was also hoping to smooth over differences with Soong about several critical legislative bills, including a major arms procurement package, because the PFP is a key partner of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" that controls a majority in the Legislative Yuan.

In the 2004 presidential election, Soong was the vice-presidential candidate for the "pan-blue alliance" headed by the Kuomintang (KMT). After Chen narrowly won the vote, the PFP took part in rowdy protests against the result.

Since the opposition alliance retained a slim majority in the Dec. 11 legislative elections, Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has worked hard to engage the PFP to seek more dialogue and less confrontation.
Chen and Soong haven't met formally since October 2000, and the president has also expressed the wish to meet the other opposition leader, KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
In another conciliatory move, the DPP administration has recently said it could cut the price for the massive arms procurement package the opposition has described as too expensive.

Taiwan wants to buy advanced weapons, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PACIII anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft, from the United States worth NT$610.8 billion, but opposition "pan-blue alliance" lawmakers have held up a special budget for the package for months. They claimed that the deal could spark an arms ra ce with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Islamist Is Nominated as Iraqi Premier. Ibrahim Jafari, a Muslim scholar and leader of Iraq's oldest Islamist party, was unanimously nominated as prime minister by the Shiite-led alliance that carried the country's historic elections last month, and his confirmation by the national assembly seemed all but assured.

Manila Bulletin: CA confirms Cruz, Alabastro
The bicameral Commission on Appointments (CA) unanimously confirmed yesterday the ad interim appointments of Avelino J. Cruz Jr. and Estrella F. Alabastro as secretaries of the Department of National Defense (DND) and the Department of Science and Technology (DoST), respectively.
