TWO Indonesians and a Malaysian allegedly belonging to the Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) regional terrorist network have reportedly been arrested by intelligence operatives in Zamboanga City in connection with the Valentine's Day bombings that killed eight people and wounded at least 150 others.
The Philippine Star: Abu suspects planned to bomb Metro malls
Authorities have uncovered a plot by the Abu Sayyaf to bomb shopping malls and key commercial establishments in Makati City in an apparent follow-up to the deadly Valentine's Day attacks in three cities across the country.
The Manila Times: Gonzalez: Drilon behind smear job
A simmering row between Justice Secretary Raul M. Gonzalez and Senate President Franklin Drilon could boil over into a confrontation when Gonzalez comes up for confirmation at the Commission on Appointments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: New 'fare changes' formula proposed.
Public transport fares in Singapore could be lowered in future if economic conditions sour.
That is one dramatic provision contained in a new fare adjustment formula proposed by the Parliamentary Committee for Transport headed by MP Ong Kian Min.
Under the proposed formula, commuters could have enjoyed two cuts in transport fares since 1998, Mr Ong said. And the average fare increase since 1998, when the existing formula was implemented, would have been 1.9 per cent a year instead of the actual 2.3 per cent.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Public transport fares in Singapore could be lowered.
A new public transport fares adjustment formula proposed by the Parliamentary Committee for Transport yesterday, help to connect with the changes of economic performance, wage level, and production more.
That means the transport fare will not up only as past, it could be lowered in future if economic conditions sour.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Russia, Feb.24 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Thousands March on Red Army Day.
Thousands in Moscow marked Defender of the Fatherland Day, the holiday commonly known as Red Army Day, on Wednesday with the usual patriotic ceremonies in support of the armed forces -- and with protests against the monetization of benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING REPRESENTS 'ETHNIC RECONCILIATION' EFFORTS: SOONG

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong described his much anticipated meeting with President Chen Shui-bian Thursday morning as representing efforts at "ethnic reconciliation" in Taiwan.

Soong made the comments just prior to the meeting at the Taipei Guest House. He described the rendevouz between President Chen, a native of Taiwan, and himself, a mainlander who emigrated to Taiwan in the late 1940s, as a prime example of efforts at healing Taiwan's ethnic divisions.

The meeting is part of Chen's promise made at the beginning of this year to meet with opposition party leaders to try to work out a consensus on Taiwan's future and the development of cross-strait ties.
Soong said that reconciliation between President Chen and himself is meant to show that an end to divisions within Taiwan can only be achieved through mutual respect and trust.
The PFP chairman also stressed that before Taiwan can begin to deal with its internal divisions and the cross-strait political deadlock, it must recognize itself as the "Republic of China."
"How can you expect others or other countries to call us the Republic of China if we do not recognize ourselves as the ROC?" Soong asked.
Soong reiterated that Taiwan was a part of China -- a historical, cultural and psychological China that is not today's People's Republic of China.

"If Taiwan was not a part of China like some local politicians have argued, how could the Ching dynasty government have given the island to Japan after it signed the shameful Treaty of Shimonoseki (in 1895)," he ridiculed.

If there was no Ching dynasty, there would have been no revolutions initiated by Dr. Sun Yat-sun, and if there was no Dr. Sun Yat-sen, there would have been no Kuomintang, and if there was no Kuomintang, there would have been no Republic of China, " he continued.
"This is undeniable history," he stressed.

Soong said that he gave President Chen a glass work depicting a crawling snail in a gardon as a token commemorating the first Chen-Soong meeting since Oct. 19, 2000. The crawling snail symbolizes Taiwan's democratization in that "true democracy takes time to achieve and is worth the labor, like a snail crawling toward a beautiful garden," he added.

Soong said that he attaches great importance to the meeting with President Chen and expects that they will both be sincere and honest, not only during the meeting, but also on policies concerning the people's interests and livelihood.

Meanwhile, he also pointed out that Taiwan's two-way trade with mainland China totaled some US$50 billion last year, making mainland China Taiwan's largest export market. He said this proves that Taiwan's industrial sector cannot survive without the mainland Chinese market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING FIRST STEP TOWARDS RECONCILIATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is the first step towards reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties.
Before the meeting, Chen presented a work of calligraphy with two Chinese characters meaning "sincerity" to Soong, who in turn gave the president a lapis lazuli carving.
According to Chen, the two characters represent the spirit of his meeting with Soong and is the cornerstone of future cooperation between both sides.
Chen said as the national leader, he is worried about the political turmoil and social unrest following last year's presidential and legislative elections.

While politicians can choose between reconciling with each other and continuing to confront each other, reconciliation is the only choice from the perspective of the country and its people, Chen said.
Chen said after two major elections last year, the people of Taiwan are in dire need of a rest, and the country also requires unity and stability.

The voices of the people are sending a clear message to both sides that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should govern the country with humility, while the opposition should monitor the government with rationality, Chen said.

It was for this reason the president said that he put forth on Jan. 1 the idea of creating a new atmosphere via consultations which would result in stability in Taiwan. He also called for reconciliation between the ruling and opposition camps for the sake of political stability, people's well-being, ethnic harmony and cross-Taiwan Strait peace.
After the DPP and PFP have taken the first step towards ruling-opposition reconciliation and cooperation, they will stick to this path, Chen said.

Chen said the ideological differences between the DPP and PFP will not hinder their cooperation because he said inter-party cooperation will be based on the principles of agreeing to disagree and respecting different opinions.

For example, he said, ruling and opposition representatives managed to put their heads together to seek consensus during the economic development conference four years ago although they differed on various policies.
Even on the most sensitive issue of national identity, the differences between the ruling and opposition parties are not uncompromising, he said.

The president pointed out that Soong had a campaign slogan of "striving for Taiwan" during the 2000 presidential election, which he said was similar in nature to the DPP's ideas of "Taiwan first" and "Taiwanese identity."
Chen said inter-party competition is not a zero-sum game and that he hopes the Chen-Soong meeting is a beginning, not the end, to cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HOPES LIEN STAYS ON AS PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that he still hopes Chairman Lien Chan will stay on and lead the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Wang, while attending an orientation for new KMT legislators, also said that if Lien makes clear that he won't run for another term in the KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Friday, then he will consider running for the party chairmanship.
"I still hope that Lien will lead the party for another term, " politically savvy Wang said, adding that he has not yet campaigned for the party chairmanship.
Although Lien had said several times that he hoped for a generational power transition within the party, he has stopped short of publicly expressing his intention of stepping down.
As the new Legislative Yuan will open Friday, he said that he won't be able to attend the KMT meeting that day.

With the KMT party chairmanship election set to take place in May, some KMT legislators have called for a postponement of the election for another year to avoid a struggle between Wang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who recently made clear his intention to run, so as not to undermine the party's unity. Both Wang and Ma are currently KMT vice chairmen.
But two KMT legislators said the election system for KMT chairman through a popular vote was established after a great deal of effort, and everyone should follow the system.
Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said that if the consensus is for Lien to continue to lead the party, then he will seek another term via the established framework.

If the KMT can elect a chairman through a harmonious election, then the party will serve as a model for other parties, as chairman of other parties are either designated by the sitting chairman or other party heavyweights.
Legislator Wu Yu-sheng also said that the election should follow the established system to show that the party is superior to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's "one-man culture."
Wu said that the elections for mayors and magistrates at the end of 2005 and the elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung city mayors are very important, not to mention the 2008 presidential election.
"The election of KMT chairman every four years should not be postponed for specific considerations," Wu said.
However, KMT Legislator Liu Cheng-hung, who proposed the one-year postponement, said that the current party member structure makes some feel that it is not a fair system.

In addition, the new KMT chairman will take up the post in August after the May election, Liu said. There is not enough time for the new chairman to campaign for KMT candidates in the year-end elections, he added.

The Democratic Progressive Party has already selected Su Tseng-chang as its chairman and is gearing up for the year-end elections. "It would be unwise for the KMT to still be fighting over the chairmanship in May," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FURTHER RELAXES RESTRICTION ON TOURISM BY MAINLANDERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior has recently amended a regulation governing mainland Chinese people making sightseeing trips to Taiwan, further relaxing entry restrictions to certain mainland Chinese.

Mainland Chinese people who have permanent residency in a foreign country can now visit Taiwan alone without having to follow the "group in, group out" requirement that has been in effect since 2002. Their visits, however, will have to be arranged by a travel agency, said an official from the Bureau of Immigration.

The new regulation, to take effect Friday, is part of the government's efforts to attract more visitors from abroad to Taiwan to help realize the Executive Yuan's ambitious goal of doubling the number of tourists coming to Taiwan by 2008.

Officials from the Republic of China Association of Travel Agencies welcomed the amendment, saying that more solo travelers will be interested in visiting Taiwan if Taiwan makes more publicity efforts abroad.

A China Airlines public relations official concurred, adding that the current regulation requiring mainland citizens who have permanent residency in Hong Kong, Macau or other foreign countries -- mostly intellectuals with high incomes -- to travel to and leave Taiwan in groups and report their whereabouts to a police station every night is simply beyond the pale.

However, Chang Chih-yuan, an official with the Tourism Bureau in charge of mainland China affairs, said that the new rule will most likely not result in a significant number of new tourists coming to Taiwan from mainland China.
Chang noted that only when Taiwan opens its door wider to ordinary mainland citizens who travel to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau can Taiwan's tourism really begin to grow.

Also, the issue does not only hinge on the Taiwan side, Chang said, adding that mainland Chinese officials from the National Travel Bureau have made it very clear that all mainland citizens are prohibited from touring Taiwan, regardless of their situation.
Chang called for authorities from Taiwan and mainland China to talk about how to facilitate tourist exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan began to allow mainland Chinese citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan on a trial basis in January 2002. Mainlanders made a total of 38,766 person/visits to Taiwan during the period between January 2002 and December 2004, according to tallies from the Bureau of Immigration.

The Bureau of Immigration under the Ministry of the Interior classifies mainland visitors into three categories: ordinary Chinese citizens who travel from the mainland to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau as the first category; mainland Chinese who travel to Taiwan from a third country as the second category; and mainland Chinese who have been living abroad for years and have permanent residency in a foreign country as the third category.
The great majority of mainlanders who have visited Taiwan over the last three years were people from the second category, according to a Bureau of Immigration official.
Almost none from the first category have visited Taiwan since January 2002, while a large number from the second category absconded after entering Taiwan, the official said.
Only two people from the third category absconded after entering Taiwan, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange rose slightly Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 6.82 points to close at 6,128.34.

The bourse opened at 6,123.59 and fluctuated between 6,171.56 and 6,109.90 during trading, with a total of 4.08 billion shares changing hands on a market turnover of NT$98.36 billion (US$3.15 billion).

All but one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up 0.1 percent; plastics and chemicals up 1 percent; paper and pulp stocks up 0.8 percent; banking and financial shares up 0.1 percent; cement shares up 1.2 percent; textile stocks up 0.3 percent; and foodstuff issues up 0.6 percent. Machinery and electronics stocks were the only category that lost ground at an average of 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 481 to 290, with 214 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AND SOONG TO JOINTLY PROMOTE COMMON AIMS FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday reaffirmed his "five noes" commitment, including not to change the status quo between Taiwan and mainland China, as part of a 10-point agreement with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

The agreement was reached after more than two hours of discussions between Chen and Soong, which the president called the first step towards reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties.
Chen said he and Soong will jointly promote cross-strait peace, national security and ethnic reconciliation in the future based on this agreement.

According to a joint statement released after the meeting, Chen and Soong agreed that the national status of the Republic of China as stated in the ROC Constitution defines the de facto and de jure status quo across the Taiwan Strait, and that this sovereign status of the ROC deserves recognition and respect by both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the international community.

Abiding by the Constitution, maintaining the status quo and maintaining peace should be the guiding principles for cross-strait relations at present, and President Chen promised that during his term, he will not declare independence for Taiwan, change the official name of the country, include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo or abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council, the statement said.

Chen and Soong agreed that the ruling and opposition parties need to seek consensus on constitutional reforms to enhance the country's overall competitiveness and the government's efficiency, but the reforms should not involve changes to national sovereignty, territory and cross-strait status quo.

To normalize cross-strait relations and establish a framework of peace and stability, the two leaders decided that both sides will work together to institutionalize a mechanism for cross-strait peace.

They agreed that the government should seek negotiations with the mainland to expedite the launch of cross-strait charter cargo flights and the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links. The government should also review and amend restrictions that hamper industrial development and national competitiveness.

Chen and Soong determined that any changes to the cross-strait status quo must have the consent of 23 million people on Taiwan and that Taiwan will not rule out any possibilities in terms of the future development of its relations with the mainland.

On national security, the two leaders agreed that the government will procure armaments necessary to beef up the country's defense capabilities, under the strategic objectives of maintaining national security, cross-strait stability and regional peace.

They affirmed that Taiwan will not engage in an arms race with the mainland and will seek to establish a cross-strait military buffer zone and military confidence-building mechanism to temper cross-strait tensions.

On the issue of ethnic harmony, Chen and Soong agreed that anyone using language or behavior that is abusive and discriminatory against a particular ethnic group should be subject to punishment and that both sides will promote the enactment of a basic law to protect the rights of different ethnic groups and enhance ethnic harmony and equality.
Lastly, they agreed that the government should ensure that different ethnic groups enjoy equal rights and status regarding economic, social, educational, cultural and examination issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S.-Russia Pact Aimed At Nuclear Terrorism; Bush, Putin to Announce Plan to Counter Threat
President Bush and Russian President Vladimir Putin plan to announce a package of measures today to counter the threat of nuclear terrorism, a threat highlighted in a new U.S. intelligence report warning that Russian nuclear material could still fall into terrorist hands, according to U.S. officials familiar with the accord.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained six points to close at 6,120, with 31,205 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for April moved up four points to finish at 6,123, with 165 contracts traded, while June futures gained seven points to finish at 6,121, with 26 contracts traded. September futures gained 19 points to finish at 6,050, with 82 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,114 for March, 6,119 for April, 6,114 for June, 6,031 for September and 6,037 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
March TE futures moved down 0.45 points to close at 233.95, with 4,648 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 0.85 points to finish at 233.8, with 12 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

March TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 1,009.2, with 3,211 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved up one point to end at 1,008.2, with 77 contracts traded. June TF futures gained 0.2 points to finish at 1,008, with two contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar slid against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.024 to close at NT$31.175.
A total of US$1.06 billion changed hands. The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.199 and dipped to a low of NT$31.091 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO FORGE SISTERHOOD TIES WITH BELIZE CITY

TEXT.P: The southern port city of Kaohsiung will forge sisterhood ties with Belize City in Central America to boost bilateral cooperation in various fields, a Kaohsiung city government official said Thursday.

Belize City Mayor William David Fonseca arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a five-day visit. On Thursday, he traveled to Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city after Taipei, to attend Kaohsiung Lantern Festival activities.
Fonseca will sign an agreement with Kaohsiung acting Mayor Chen Chi-mai Friday on the establishment of sisterhood relations between the two cities, the official said.
Belize City is the largest city in Belize. The city has a population of about 60,000. Some 1,500 Taiwan expatriates reside there.
Belize City will be the 22nd foreign city to maintain sisterhood ties with Kaohsiung.

With a view to attracting foreign investment, Belize has enacted a statute encouraging foreign investment and has set up a free trade zone. Taiwan's investments in the country are concentrated in Belize City.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILL SUPPORT BILLS PROMOTING TO HI-TECH DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CAN) Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that he will support bills promoting the hi-tech industry to upgrade Taiwan's competitive edge.
The premier made the remarks while attending the opening ceremony of the 2005 Taipei Games Show at the Taipei World Trade Center.
Hsieh said that he could feel the dynamism of the private sector at the show, adding that the development of the hi-tech industry in Taiwan is rapid.

However, he noted that because of the constant bickering between the executive and legislative branches in the past, many important bills relating to the hi-tech sector have been stalled in the legislature.
This is the reason why he has decided to put aside controversial bills and focus on those crucial to industrial development.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCIDENTAL CAMPUS DEATHS REACH RECORD HIGH: EDUCATION MINISTRY

TEXT.P: A total of 755 people, including students, faculty members and administrative staffers, died from accidents on school campuses at various educational levels in Taiwan last year, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Thursday.
The figure does not include those who died from natural disasters or violent crimes on campus, MOE officials said.
According to MOE tallies, 7,378 other people were injured in campus accidents during the same year.
Traffic accidents outside schools was the top cause of accidental campus deaths, claiming 413 lives and resulting in 4,051 injuries.
Disease came in second, with 149 dying from various illnesses or communicable diseases.
Suicide was the third major cause, resulting in 67 deaths and 91 injuries.
Meanwhile, 56 people were drowned and 14 others received water-related injuries on campus.
Accidental falls from school buildings killed 13 people last year and injured 24 others.
Exercises and games on campus also resulted in eight deaths and 1,214 injuries, according to MOE tallies.

Wang Fu-lin, director of the MOE's Bureau of Students Military Training, said the number of campus suicides has been on the rise in recent years and that the ratio rose with age. Of the 67 suicides last year, 39 were university students, or 58 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGREEMENT OF CHEN-SOONG MEETING BETRAYS TAIWAN IDENTITY: TSU

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) criticized President Chen Shui-bian Thursday, claiming that he "betrayed the Taiwan identity" after he reaffirmed his "five noes" commitment, including no change to the status quo between Taiwan and mainland China.

As part of a 10-point agreement reached between Chen and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, Chen reaffirmed his long-standing promise that during his term, he will not declare independence for Taiwan, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council.
Strongly protesting the agreement, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming claimed that the president has "betrayed the founding ideals" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Chen Chien-ming said the fate of Taiwan should be decided by the 23 million people of the nation and that it is regrettable that the DPP has failed to assert Taiwan's sovereignty when the mainland is planning to enact an "anti-secession law" targeting the country.
He insisted that the DPP must not compromise its ideals and principles while seeking reconciliation with the opposition parties.

Unlike the DPP, he said, the TSU will continue to promote a campaign aimed at drafting a new constitution for the country and changing the official name of the country from the Republic of China to the "Republic of Taiwan."
Lo Chih-ming, convener of the TSU's legislative caucus, claimed that the agreement represents "the surrender" of the DPP to the pro-unification forces on Taiwan and the "one China" policy of Beijing.

By declaring the Republic of China as their largest area of common ground on the issue of national identity, Chen and Soong have dishonored the Taiwanese people's pursuit for a new name and new constitution for the country, according to Lo.

Also, by agreeing with Soong that constitutional reforms will not involve changes to national sovereignty and territory, the president has gone back on his promise to introduce a "relevant and viable constitution" for Taiwan, Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLARS URGE GREATER U.S. OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: U.S. scholars urged the U. S. administration Tuesday to display stronger opposition to Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law" at a seminar sponsored by the Heritage Foundation here.

Members from the Commission of the U.S.-China Economic and Securities Review Commission under the House of Representatives, including Commissioner Carolyn Bartholomew and various scholars, expressed grave concern over the proposed legislation and called for greater opposition from the U.S. government.
Bartholomew said Washington should clearly set forth its opposition to the Beijing's planned law and added that she is not satisfied with what the U.S. administration has done so far.

According to Bartholomew, Beijing might be thinking of using the legislation as an excuse to increase its military budget, or using it to pacify its hardliners, or using it as a chip in its bargaining with the United States.

Dennis Halpin, a senior staff official of the House's Committee on International Relations said various representatives have voiced strong disagreement to the proposed legislation by raising a resolution. But he pointed out that it will be too late for the House to press Beijing on the issue after the House reopens its session in the middle of March.

Harvey Fedman, a senior researcher at the Heritage Foundation who hosted the seminar, suggested that the U.S. government strongly make its stance known to Beijing, but he admitted that the chances are slim that Beijing will annul or postpone the legislation.

Liu Shih-fang, a former secretary-general of the Republic of China Executive Yuan who is currently a visiting researcher at the Brookings Institution, said at the seminar that the anti-secession law is devised to provide Beijing with a pretext to launch an attack against Taiwan at any time.
It will greatly hinder the freedom of speech of the many Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland, she pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR'S PLAN TO VISIT SOUTH KOREA ABORTED DUE TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Taipei, Feb. 24 (CAN) Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's plan to visit South Korea early next month has been aborted due to intervention from mainland China, a spokesman for the Taipei city government said Thursday.

Yu Tzu-hsiang, director of the city's Information Department, said that the mayor originally planned to attend an Asian leader's meeting in Seoul at the invitation of the Chosun Ilbo newspaper March 2.

But the head of the Korean daily sent a message Wednesday to the effect that the invitation was revoked because of "unpredictable technical problems" and because some participants were displeased with Ma's presence, Yu said.
Yu said that the Taipei city government expressed its stance on the matter through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Mainland China's delegates to the Asian leader's meeting include a professor from Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences and mainland China's ambassador to South Korea.

Ma would have delivered a speech and mingled with former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahatir and former Indonesian President Megawati Sukamoputri to exchange views on issues on Asian cooperation.
Because of the cancellation, Ma will move ahead his schedule to visit Japan by one day and will depart for Tokyo and Yokohama for exchanges on city development March 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAN-PARTY TALKS NEEDED IN NEW LEGISLATURE ON U.S. ARMS SALE

TEXT.P: Chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) James Soong said legislators from across the party spectrum must begin productive discussions on the controversial U.S. arms purchase plan when the new legislature opens Friday.

Soong made the remarks after his high-profile, two-hour meeting with President Chen Shui-bian. The two spoke on a variety of issues, including formalizing a mechanism for maintaining cross-strait peace, the national identity and mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law."

Soong stressed that his party was opposed to the arms procurement in the previous legislature because of differences over the items and price of the weapons, adding that the party's stance on the matter remains unchanged.

He was referring to an arms purchase package proposed by the Cabinet last June to buy six Patriot Pac-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines, and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.
At the time of the proposal, the deal was worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion).
Soong said that while he was in the U.S. he told those he met that if the cost was NT$610.8 billion, the package wouldn't pass the legislature.
But he also said that he agreed that Taiwan must maintain a credible defense force, and in the new legislature the PFP plans to have a good discussion with the ruling party on the weaponry sale.
"We cannot buy nothing, but we also cannot take everything as it is, " Soong said, adding that the PFP will fulfill its duty as an opposition party to monitor the budget.
Soong also said that he and the president agreed to formulate a framework to ensure continued peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

However, Soong said that President Chen did not invited him to head a cross-strait peaceful development committee proposed by the president himself despite widespread reports that Chen was considering such a move.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Eighteen more troops face Iraq abuse trials.
The army is bracing itself for four more courts martial involving 18 British soldiers after yesterday's conviction of three servicemen for the "brutal", "cruel" and "revolting" abuse of prisoners in Iraq.
The Times has learnt that army lawyers are considering charges against 11 more soldiers in addition to the seven members of the Parachute Regiment accused of the fatal beating of an 18-year-old Iraqi at a roadside in May 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO PROTECT TAIWANESE IDENTITY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will reaffirm his commitment in his first-ever administrative report to the legislature to safeguarding Taiwan's identity in the face of Beijing's planned "anti-secession" legislation.
Hsieh is scheduled to deliver an administrative report to the Legislative Yuan Friday -- the opening day of the new legislative session. It will be his first such report since assuming office Feb. 1.

According to a written version of the report sent to the legislature Thursday, Hsieh will reiterate insistence on Taiwan's identity as the basic stance of his Cabinet's policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait.

He will also declare the government's decision to promote convenient cross-strait cargo transportation services, such as the opening of direct cargo charter flights, in line with the cardinal principles of peace and parity.

Acknowledging that Taiwan is facing grave challenges, including mainland China's "magnetic effect" in attracting foreign investment, cross-strait tension, a widening gap between the rich and the poor, a shaky national health insurance program, environmental pollution, a rising crime rate and ethnic divisions, Hsieh will promise in his report that the administration will humbly listen to mainstream public opinion and respond to their aspirations.

He will also pledge to promote inter-party reconciliation through dialogue and consultations, as well as strengthen communications and cooperation with the legislative branch in formulating policy initiatives, in order to smooth over the implementation of major reform projects.

Meanwhile, Hsieh will promise to give priority to promoting sustainable and balanced economic development, with equal emphasis on social justice, environmental protection, cultural renaissance, community development and welfare services.

Wall Street Journal: Change of Command: A Marine Captain Trains Iraqi Colonel To Take Over Fight
The struggle to train a new generation of Iraqi military leaders is emerging as a crucial hurdle to bringing U.S. troops home. And U.S. officials say that whether an Iraqi force succeeds or fails often comes down to one person: its commander. In the old Iraqi Army, combat leaders were distant and autocratic. They stifled initiative and rewarded blind loyalty over competence, Iraqi and U.S. officials say. When the Iraqi Army was challenged, troops frequently deserted. Even with Saddam Hussein gone, U.S Military officials are finding the old culture hard to change.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF PLEDGES TO PUSH FOR PEACE WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Thursday he will push for peace with mainland China in his capacity as PFP head until such time as a legal framework and specific mechanism for this purpose is put in place.

Soong, who met with President Chen Shui-bian for two hours of talks earlier in the day, reiterated that he has no intention of heading a peace development commission proposed by Chen to improve ties with the mainland because its formation, function and authority are not provided for in any legislation.

Soong said the PFP, which has introduced to the Legislative Yuan a bill for promoting peace across the Taiwan Strait, would like to discuss its bill, as well as Chen's idea for the peace development commission, with the other political parties, including the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and to work out a peace-promoting mechanism acceptable to all participants.

Soong said he did not discuss with the president who should lead the work for peace with the mainland, adding that "I am not in a position to recommend anyone to the president for this post" even if the PFP-initiated bill is enacted into law, because the chief of the peace-promoting commission should be chosen by members of the commission, according to the bill, and "I am not certain that I would be elected."
Before the law governing the peace-promoting mechanism is in place, Soong said he will do his best to improve peace with the mainland in his capacity as PFP chief.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING NOT HELPFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: KMT

TEXT.P: The meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will not help deadlocked relations between Taiwan and mainland China, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Thursday.

Chang made the remarks at a seminar after Chen and Soong held a summit earlier in the day in response to high public expectations for political rapport and ethnic harmony after the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

Ten agreements were reached during the meeting between the two men with sharp differences regarding Taiwan's future, with Chen pledging to keep the Republic of China's status quo and reaffirming his "five noes" policy in terms of the mainland in a joint statement with Soong. Chen also expressed his hope of having meetings with other opposition leaders.

Claiming that the meeting yielded no new breakthroughs to help improve the fragile Taiwan-mainland ties, Chang said that the "five noes" policy outlined by Chen when he came to power for the first time in May 2000 have already been hollowed out by the president himself as a result of his pro-independence stance and ethnic-split election strategy.

If Chen really wishes to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, he should do something concrete to serve the people, Chang said, adding that the KMT will first heed the opinions of the "pan-blue alliance" supporters regarding the Chen-Soong meeting before considering a summit between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and the president.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party retained its majority in the 225-member Legislative Yuan with a combined 114 seats in the December elections, beating the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, which gained a total of 101 seats.

Ever since, the president has repeatedly called for compromise and ice-breaking between the governing and opposition camps in view of the tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He has tried hard to woo the crucial PFP -- the third-largest party in the legislature with 34 seats, lagging behind the DPP with 89 seats and the KMT with 79 seats -- to form a stable majority with the DPP.

Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang thanked Soong for his participation in the meeting and said the president's efforts to forge political stability and promote cross-strait peace through inter-party cooperation should win high approval from the public.
Byron S.J. Weng, a national policy advisor to the president, was optimistic about a positive response from Beijing in the wake of the Chen-Soong meeting.

Although mistrust and difficulties remain in the way of a thaw between Taiwan and the mainland, Weng told CNA in an exclusive interview that Beijing is expected to respond positively to the development in order not to further hamper cross-strait relations, since neither side is seeking to settle their dispute by waging war.

Despite his optimism about the prospects for bilateral ties, he was also of the opinion that it is impossible that Beijing will postpone its legislation of an anti-secession law aimed at Taiwan. The context of the law will be the key to gauging the future situation across the strait, he added.

Chang Wu-ueh, a veteran mainland affairs expert, claimed that the Chen-Soong meeting will be conducive to easing Beijing's worry about Taiwan to some extent, as the president reiterated his vow to maintain the ROC status quo in the joint 10-point statement.
Despite the fact that the meeting will not end all the problems at home and across the strait, it heralds a good beginning to serve that end, he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KMT CHAIR TO BE PRODUCED ACCORDING TO RULES: LIEN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Thursday that the new party head should be chosen in line with the party rules and he urged all KMT members to work according to the existing mechanisms.
Lien made the remarks at a seminar held by the KMT's Central Policy Making Committee.

According to Lien, the party's new chief should be named by August in compliance with the party rules. He also said that a vote for the new chairman can be held earlier in order not to affect the nomination operations for the mayor and magistrate elections set for December this year.
Only by so doing will the KMT be able to expand continuously and set an open and fair model for the party's sustainable growth while bracing for a new phase of development, he said.

The issue regarding the new KMT chairmanship has triggered rampant speculation over a competition between Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng -- both vice chairmen of the main opposition party.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX TAIWAN COMPANIES SIGN UP TO OPERATE IN TAICHUNG FREE TRADE PORT

TEXT.P: Six local companies signed letters of intent Thursday to operate in the Taichung Free Trade Port in the first round of an investor-seeking campaign sponsored by the port authorities.
The signatories agree to operate in the free trade port zone when it opens for business toward the end of this year.

Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng said at the signing ceremony that the free trade zone at Taichung Harbor, covering an area of 536 hectares, is the biggest of the country's three free trade ports in terms of size. It is offering tax breaks to investors, allowing them to boost their competitiveness on the international market.

Noting that the harbor is situated near the Central Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park with easy access by land, air and sea, Huang said the zone is an ideal destination for export-oriented industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY TO VISIT JAPAN IN MAY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first lady Wu Shu-jen is scheduled to make a six-day trip to Japan this May, mainly to visit the Expo 2005 Aichi, Fuji Television reported late Thursday.

Wu and her entourage are scheduled to arrive in Nagoya May 9 before proceeding to Aichi for a one-day visit to the international expo May 10. The first lady will also visit Tokyo before returning to Taiwan May 14, Fuji Television reported.

According to the report, Wu and her entourage will enjoy visa-free treatment as the Japanese government has decided to waive the visa requirement for Taiwan tourists in the period between March 25 and Sept. 30 this year.
The visa-free policy was adopted mainly to attract more tourists from Taiwan, one of the major sources of tourists to Japan, to visit the Aichi Expo, according to the report.

In related news, the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed welcome last week to Japan's decision to waive the visa requirement for Taiwan tourists and expressed the hope that the temporary measure will be made permanent.
A MOFA official said the measure, approved by the Japanese House of Councilors, or the upper house of the Diet, on Feb. 8, will boost exchanges between the two countries and will benefit both sides.

Under this measure, Taiwan tourists will be allowed to visit Japan without a visa for up to 90 days at a time between March 25 and Sept. 30. The Aichi World Expo is being held from March 25 to Sept. 25.

Since Taiwan has been offering Japanese tourists visa-free entry for the past three years, the official said, the ministry hopes Japan will reciprocate Taiwan's goodwill by making this temporary measure a permanent one after Sept. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STATE DEPARTMENT DECLINES TO COMMENT ON CHEN-SOONG STATEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department declined to comment on the 10-point statement signed by President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Thursday, saying only that it would push for Taiwan and China to engage in dialogue to solve their problems peacefully.

The statement on cross-strait relations, national defense and ethnic reconciliation was signed by Chen and Soong after they met Thursday morning at the Taipei Guest House for talks that lasted over two hours.

Six of the points focused on cross-strait relations and issues related to the nation's status, including agreement that the country's name is the Republic of China and that the government should set up a mechanism to promote cross-strait peace.

In response to media questions regarding the Chen-Soong statement, a U.S. State Department official said that it is the department's policy not to comment on the "domestic matters" of other countries.
However, he added: "We encourage both sides of the strait to engage in dialogue to reach a peaceful resolution."

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. SHOULD MAINTAIN ARMS BAN ON CHINA: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top envoy to the European Union and Belgium on Thursday urged European countries to pay more attention to Taiwan's security, saying that the E.U. should not lift its arms embargo against China.
Chen Chien-jen, ROC representative to the E.U and Belgium, made the appeal in his first news conference since becoming the nation's top official in Brussels Oct. 15 last year.
Noting that Taiwan has developed over the past forty years into a model of democracy in Chinese society, Chen said that the suspension of cross-strait political dialogue in 1998 is unfortunate.

Although the agreement reached by the two sides of the strait on direct charter flights during the Lunar New Year holidays seems to convey a positive message, the envoy said, China's deployment of more than 600 missiles targeting Taiwan as well as its proposed anti-secession law demonstrate that tensions continue to exist between the two sides.

Emphasizing Taiwan's strong opposition to a lifting of the E.U. ban on arms sales to China, Chen said that the United States, Japan and the ASEAN countries have voiced their serious concerns over the current situation in the Taiwan Strait and that the European countries should also pay more attention to security in the strait.

Claiming that enactment of the anti-secession bill would represent a unilateral move to alter the cross-strait status quo and would affect regional stability and security, Chen urged the international community to work to prevent Beijing from doing so.
