DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSMAN HELD FOR ALLEGEDLY SUPPLYING MISSILE COMPONENTS TO LIBYA

TEXT.P: A local businessman was taken into custody by Taoyuan district prosecutors Friday for allegedly supplying key Scud missile components to Libya.
According to the prosecutors, Hsieh Chin-yi allegedly provided Libya with turbo propeller components for Scud missiles in 1999, an act that is in violation of Taiwan's trade and anti-smuggling laws.

Some reports suggested that Taiwan authorities began investigating Hsieh after being informed by foreign intelligence agencies that some of Libya's Scud missile components were allegedly supplied by a Taiwanese businessman.

Prosecutor Hu Shu-teh carried out a raid on Hsieh's company in Taipei City on Thursday, seizing some customs declaration documents. No missile components were found. Hsieh has denied selling any such components to Libya.
Prosecutors' request to keep Hsieh in custody was approved by the Taoyuan District Court on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY HAS NO PLAN TO VISIT JAPAN IN MAY: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: Denying Japanese news reports, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said Friday that President Chen Shui-bian and his wife, Wu Shu-jen, currently have no plans to visit Japan in May for the Expo 2005 to be held in Aichi Prefecture.

Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, said that the first couple presently have no such plans as reported by two Japanese media organizations over the past two days.

Kyodo News reported Friday that aides to President Chen Shui-bian have been sounding out Japanese authorities since early February about the possibility of Chen and his wife visiting Japan this May, primarily for the Expo 2005 Aichi.
Fuji Television reported late Thursday that Taiwan's first lady Wu Shu-jen is scheduled to make a six-day trip to Japan May 9-14, mainly to visit the Aichi Expo.

It has been learned that Wu Shu-jen has expressed a desire to visit Japan, particularly during the cherry blossom season, to experience the culture and because Japan is located close to Taiwan and it would not be a difficult journey for the wheelchair-bound first lady.

Meanwhile, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) offered no comments on the Japanese news reports, saying only that they have no idea about the first couple's plans regarding visiting Japan.

According to the Fuji Television report, Wu and her entourage will enjoy visa-free treatment as the Japanese government has decided to waive the visa requirement for Taiwan tourists in the period between March 25 and Sept. 30 this year.
The visa-free policy was adopted mainly to attract more tourists from Taiwan, one of the major sources of tourists to Japan, to visit the Aichi Expo, the report said.

According to the Kyodo News report, Taiwan officials sounding out Japanese authorities about a possible visit by the first couple has placed the Japanese government in a dilemma as such a visit would inevitably invite protests from Beijing.
The MOFA expressed welcome last week to Japan's decision to waive the visa requirement for Taiwan tourists and expressed the hope that the temporary measure will be made permanent.
A MOFA official said the measure, approved by the Japanese House of Councilors, or the upper house of the Diet, on Feb. 8, will boost exchanges between the two countries and will benefit both sides.

Under this measure, Taiwan tourists will be allowed to visit Japan without a visa for up to 90 days at a time between March 25 and Sept. 30. The Aichi World Expo is being held from March 25 to Sept. 25. Since Taiwan has been offering Japanese tourists visa-free entry for the past three years, the official said, the ministry hopes Japan will reciprocate Taiwan's goodwill by making this temporary measure a permanent one after Sept. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE STUDENTS GOING ABROAD FOR ADVANCED STUDIES: MOE

TEXT.P: A total of 30,728 Taiwan students went abroad for advanced studies in 2004, marking a 25 percent increase from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Education (MOE) Friday.
The tallies showed that the United States remained the most popular destination for Taiwan students to pursue advanced studies, attracting 14,054 students.

The United Kingdom followed, receiving 9,207 Taiwan students for advanced studies, and Australia came in third, with 2,246 students. Other major destinations were Canada, Japan, France, New Zealand and Germany, in that order.

In terms of growth rate, Britain topped the list by registering a remarkable 38 percent year-on-year increase. The United States came in second with a 36 percent growth rate, followed by Canada with 19 percent growth and Japan with a 16 percent increase.
In contrast, the number of Taiwan students to Australia, Germany, France and New Zealand declined by 20 percent, 10 percent, 7.5 percent and 6.5 percent, respectively, from the 2003 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING NT DOLLAR ERODING CONFIDENCE IN BUSINESS PROSPECTS: TIER

TEXT.P: The continuing appreciation of the Taiwan currency against the U.S. dollar is eroding the Taiwan industrial sector's confidence in securing vigorous growth this year, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) reported Friday.

While Taiwan's business climate index for January slid to 99.77 points, the lowest level since June 2003, more companies expressed pessimism in a recent poll about their business prospects over the next six months, TIER's acting president David Hong said.

According to the latest TIER report, Taiwan's business climate index for January dropped to 99.77 points, down from December's 100.33 points, representing the sixth consecutive month-on-month decline.

In addition, although 28.5 percent of the manufacturing companies polled expressed optimism about business conditions at home over the next six months, up from last month's 23.3 percent, the percentage of companies that were pessimistic about their business prospects rose noticeably to 26.2 percent from last month's 14.9 percent.
Hong attributed the growing pessimism mainly to the substantial appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, a trend which is seen as continuing over the next several months.

According to Hong, the dollar has been flat due to the United States' trade deficits and budget deficits, with no improvement in sight for either, leading economists to believe that the greenback will continue to fall in the months ahead.

Based on this, as well as a speculation that China is unlikely to adopt a flexible policy against the U.S. dollar anytime soon, the Taiwan dollar is likely to continue to appreciate, although mildly, in the near future, Hong predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ATTEND OECD TRADE COMMITTEE MEETING AS 'AD HOC OBSERVER'
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been invited for the first time to attend the Trade Committee meeting of the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) set to be held March 10-11 as an "ad hoc observer, " a ranking ROC trade official said Thursday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, who is currently in Geneva to participate in the service sector negotiations of the World Trade Organization's Doha Round of trade talks, confirmed that he will go to Paris next month to attend the meeting and to hold bilateral talks with French officials.

Huang said that since this will be Taiwan's first time participating in an OECD Trade Committee meeting, his main goal is to understand the operations of the committee and to enhance contact and communication with the organization's secretariat and representatives of OECD member states, adding that he will also introduce Taiwan's current trade policies and situations during the gathering.

The OECD, which agreed last October to grant Taiwan "ad hoc observer" status in its March trade committee meeting, has not made a final decision on whether it will grant the island formal observer status in the committee. Taiwan has been bidding to obtain such status since September 2003.

According to OECD officials, the "ad hoc observer" status is a provisional arrangement that allows Taiwan, at the invitation of the committee and under the designation of "Chinese Taipei, " to attend the committee's special meetings with no obligations, including the paying of membership fees, and no rights.

Noting that he will appropriately express Taiwan's wish for active participation in the OECD's trade committee, Huang said he won't immediately push the island's bid for formal observer status as this will be the island's first time participating in such a meeting. He added that its better for him to first learn about the committee's operations and to establish good cooperation relations with the organization.
The OECD groups 30 member countries sharing a commitment to democratic government and market economy. Taiwan obtained observer status in the organization's Competition Committee Dec. 20, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-SOONG MEETING HELPS CROSS-STRAIT TIES: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng claimed Friday that an agreement reached between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong will help ease cross-Taiwan Strait relations and domestic political stability.
Wang made the remarks while attending the handover ceremony of the heads of a KMT subgroup in the legislature.

He noted that among the agreements reached between Chen and Soong Thursday was that the national status of the Republic of China as stated in the Constitution defines the de facto and de jure status quo across the Taiwan Strait and that this sovereignty status of the ROC deserves recognition and respect by both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the international community.

Both sides also said that abiding by the Constitution, maintaining the status quo and promoting peace should be the guiding principles for cross-strait relations, Wang observed, adding that the president also reaffirmed the "five noes" promises he made in his inaugural speech and did not rule out any possible development of cross-strait relations.

These factors, according to Wang, should help the mainland China authorities rethink their "anti-secession law." The proposed law, aimed at providing a legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan should it declare independence, will be put to review and is expected to be approved by the National People's Congress, the mainland's rubber-stamp parliament, in March.
"These factors should help China consider the postponement of its enactment, or even make its content less hostile toward Taiwan," Wang claimed.
He also said Chen's reaffirmation of his "five noes" has pointed out a clear path for the nation and should help stabilize domestic politics in the longer term.

The "five noes" refers to Chen's promise that during his term, he will not declare independence for Taiwan, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council.
Wang also said that the Cabinet's major military procurement project will have to follow set procedure.

The Cabinet should first send a proposed statute concerning the procurement and that after it clears the legislature, the Cabinet can make a special budget on the purchase and send the budget proposal to the legislature for review.
Wang's remarks came amid media rumors that the ruling and opposition parties might have clinched a deal on the arms purchase project following the Chen-Soong meeting.

Soong said after his meeting with the president Thursday that his party opposes the arms deal -- a proposal to buy six Patriot Pac-3 anti-missile batteries, eight conventional submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States -- in the last legislature because it disagreed with the items and price of the weapons.
Because of the opposition of the PFP and the main opposition Kuomintang, the arms purchase statute was not even put on the agenda in the last legislature.

But Soong said Thursday that "we cannot buy nothing, but we also cannot accept everything as it is." He added that his party will rigorously screen the budget proposal submitted by the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMER'S CONFIDENCE REGAINS GROUND: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan consumers have regained their confidence in the country's overall economic prospects over the next six months, particularly in stock market investment, an economic think-tank quoted the results of a recent poll as indicating Friday.

The Taiwan consumer confidence index (CCI) stood at 76.96 points in February, up 1.11 points over the January figure, according to a report by the Taiwan Economic Development Center under National Central University, which authorized the poll.
All six indexes used in the CCI composite factors showed gains in a poll of ordinary consumers conducted in mid-February, according to the center.

The index on the question whether it is opportune to invest in the Taiwan bourse in the next six months was up by 2.10 points to 61.30 points, marking the largest surge of all six indexes, the pollsters said.
Second to the stock investment climate index was the index on the economic prospects over the next six months, which rose 1.30 points over January's level to 76.40 points.

The four other indexes of the CCI also rose, by 1.05 percent, 1.00 percent, 0.80 percent and 0.40 percent, respectively, over questions on household economy over the next six months, the domestic employment situation, domestic commodity prices, and whether it is opportune to increase purchases of durable goods in the next six months, in that order, according to the poll results.

The telephone poll of 2,029 randomly selected adults islandwide was conducted jointly by Fujen Catholic University and the Taiwan Research Institute Feb. 18-22. It had a margin of error of 2.2 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO FOLLOW POLICY OF COEXISTENCE, RECONCILIATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh pledged Friday to follow a policy of "coexistence and reconciliation" to build up a "healthy Taiwan" and facilitate relations with mainland China.

Delivering his first policy report to the new legislature, Hsieh said that Taiwan must hold to the principles of peace and equality in terms of cross-Taiwan Strait relations in order to safeguard the Taiwan identity.

According to the premier, Taiwan must resolve the "zero-sum" partisan confrontation in domestic politics before it can stand united to demand that the mainland remove its military threat against the nation.

Expressing his opposition to Beijing's "one country, two systems" proposal for unification and its proposal to use an "anti-secession law" as the legal basis for an invasion of Taiwan should Taiwan declare independence, Hsieh said the people of Taiwan anticipate peace and stability across the strait and will defend the country's sovereignty, security and dignity.
The pursuit of the Taiwan identity should be based on solidarity rather than on confrontation and dissent, Hsieh said.

The premier said he expects coexistence and reconciliation to start from interaction between the Executive Yuan and Legislative Yuan, terminating the vicious struggle between the ruling and opposition parties, renewing hope for the people and creating yet another "Taiwan miracle."
The ideas of coexistence and reconciliation mean a balanced development of the economy, social justice and environment to form a "golden triangle," according to Hsieh.
To achieve this goal, the government will build up a "healthy Taiwan" backed by a healthy people, a vital economy, sustainable environment, peace, efficient government and trustful society, he said.

He said the Cabinet will humbly heed the opinions of all sectors for solutions to the various challenges, which include the magnetic effect of the mainland's booming economy, cross-strait tension, widening wealth discrepancies, the financial crisis of the National Health Insurance program, environmental pollution, ethnic conflicts and worsening law and order.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO PROMOTE FURTHER CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday that he will promote cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights on holidays and cross-strait charter cargo flights, as well as opening the mainland China market to Taiwan agricultural products.

Speaking during a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting, Lien said that with the successful completion of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday, the KMT will continue to push for similar charter flights during other holidays.

Charter cargo flights will help save costs for businesses and will provide great opportunities for airline operators, Lien said, adding that Taiwan farmers have also long hoped for an opening of the mainland market to their produce.
The KMT will promote the amendment of related bills in the legislature, Lien said.
The KMT legislative caucus will also organize a delegation to visit the mainland, he added.
Two KMT legislators also proposed Friday a "normalization" of cross-strait charter flights.

John Chang and Chu Fong-chi said that based on the experience of operating charter flights during Chinese New Year in 2003 and 2005, the KMT believes it can further promote cross-strait charter flight services.

Dependent on the market needs, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can open charter flights during weekends, and passengers aboard such flights should not be confined to mainland-based Taiwan businessmen but should be open to Republic of China nationals with valid travel documents to the mainland, mainland Chinese spouses who have yet to obtain ROC IDs, and mainland Chinese people who are permitted to visit Taiwan.
Chang also said that in addition to charter cargo flights, there should also be charter cargo shipping.
Meanwhile, an official of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) pointed out that the demand for charter flights during the Tombsweeping Day period are not as heavy as at Chinese New Year holiday.
Su Hsien-jung, TAA secretary-general, made the remarks after the Taiwan Affairs Office in mainland China called for speedy consultations on the flights for April 5 Tombsweeping Day.

Against the background of the executives of six Taiwan airlines recently being invited by Beijing's Civil Aviation Administration of China to a Spring Festival party in Beijing, and since Taiwan is promoting cross-strait cargo charter services, Su said only that the two sides are communicating on the issue.

But he added that as long as both sides of the Taiwan Strait can keep up the good atmosphere in the wake of the successful Jan. 29-Feb. 20 Chinese New Year holiday charter flights, it will represent "progress" in cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURAL INVESTMENTS IN CHINA GOVERNED BY NATIONAL POLICIES: COA

TEXT.P: Whether members of Taiwan's agricultural sector should be allowed to invest in mainland China or relocate part of their operations to the mainland is an issue to be decided in accordance with national policies, officials from the Council of Agriculture said Friday.

Council officials said that there are already established regulations governing Taiwan businesses who wish to make investments in the mainland, and Taiwan farmers or related companies should also observe the regulations regarding such investments.

Those individuals or businesses that want to invest on the mainland should do all they can to keep their roots in Taiwan as well as protecting their technologies and intellectual property, the council said, adding that investors should also avoid developments that may eventually compromise their rights and interests.

The council officials made the remarks in response to a news conference held by the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council where State Council Economic Bureau Deputy Director Tang Yi said that mainland China welcomes the Taiwan agricultural sector to make investments on the mainland and that mainland authorities would help Taiwanese farmers develop operations there.
The mainland authorities will also spare no effort to facilitate agricultural cooperation across the Taiwan Strait and promote sales of Taiwanese agricultural products on the mainland, Tang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained 99 points to close at 6,219, with 34,658 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved up 97 points to finish at 6,220, with 347 contracts traded, while June futures gained 94 points to finish at 6,215, with 18 contracts traded.
September futures gained 101 points to finish at 6,150, with 29 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 96 points to close at 6,139, with nine contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,120 for March, 6,123 for April, 6,121 for June, 6,049 for September and 6,043 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

March TE futures moved up 3.35 points to close at 237.3, with 6,140 contracts traded, while April TE futures gained 3.75 points to finish at 237.2, with 37 contract transactions. June TE futures gained 3.15 points to close at 236.3, with one contract traded, while September TE futures moved up 1.3 points to finish at 235.25, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

March TF futures gained 15.4 points to finish at 1,024.6, with 6,400 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved up 15.6 points to end at 1,023.8, with 57 contracts traded. June TF futures gained 12 points to finish at 1,019, with two contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 79.49 points to close at 6,207.83.
The bourse opened at 6,195.24 and fluctuated between 6,233.53 and 6,192.38 during trading. A total of 5.02 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$120.95 billion (US$3.88 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and machinery and electronics shares both at 1.2 percent, textile stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 1 percent and construction issues at 0.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 558 to 243, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday to close at NT$31.175.
A total of US$876 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.276 and hit a low of NT$31.150.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PROMOTES LIONS CLUB-SPONSORED SCHOOL IN CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu backed a Taipei-based Lions Club program Friday to build a school in a remote Cambodia province.

Addressing the Lions Clubs International District 300A2's 20th anniversary celebration, Lu said that love can jump political barriers to reach the country even though Cambodia has no diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Lu was invited by the Lions Club to promote its project, which is aimed at constructing a "school of hope" in a remote Cambodian province. The school will implement a six-year basic education system, according to the Lions Club.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PER-CAPITA GNP, GDP EXPECTED TO HIT NEW HIGHS FOR 2005: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's per-capita gross national product (GNP) and per-capita gross domestic product (GDP) for 2005 will hit new highs of US$15,639 and US$15,036, respectively, according to the newest government statistics.

Statistics worked out by the advisory members of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) in a Thursday meeting showed that Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) will grow by 1.67 percent this year and that GNP will reach NT$11.969 trillion (US$354.2 billion) -- a translation of a per-capita GNP of US$15,639 and a per-capita GDP of US$15,036 -- both record highs.

According to DGBAS Director-General Hsu Chang-yao, the advisory members adjusted downward their growth forecast for Taiwan's economy to 4.21 percent in 2005 from the previous prediction of 4.56 percent.
Taiwan's economy expanded by 5.71 percent in 2004, with its CPI increasing by 1.62 percent and GNP hitting around NT$10.5848 trillion -- equivalent to a per-capita GNP of US$14,032.

Hsu pointed out that Taiwan's foreign trade will slow this year due to a less vigorous global economy. However, he is still optimistic about continued expansion in the domestic economy, which will be sustained by local demand spurred by increased consumer spending and investment from the private sector.

According to the latest assessments made public by Global Insight, Inc. in February, the global economy will contract this year, with its expansion rate shrinking to 3.3 percent from the year earlier level of 4.1 percent. Growth in international trade volume will also drop to 4.2 percent from 8.9 percent year-on-year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush and Putin Mute Differences, Latching on to the Affirmative.
U.S. President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia chose to stand together and emphasize the narrowing areas where their nations could agree after their private meeting in Bratislava, Slovakia on Thursday. The presidents focused their remarks after the meeting on personal trust and on commitments to fight terrorism and control the spread of weapons or materials terrorists might use. Their private remarks remained, for the most part, private, but some political analysts took the public comments as evidence that Bush had ceded an opportunity to challenge Mr. Putin forcefully on his increasingly autocratic stand.
Wall Street Journal: Ripple Effect, In Putin's Backyard Democracy Stirs -- With U.S. Help.
Mike Stone, a former journalist from East Moline, Ill., runs a nonpartisan print press business owned by the U.S. government in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, which provides a crucial tool to the opposition activists trying to oust the autocratic regime there. As tension mounts ahead of key parliamentary elections this Sunday, Stone's shop provides the only print-media outlet for opponents of longtime President Askar Akayev.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: The Pope Undergoes Emergency Surgery; Tracheostomy Performed After Respiratory Crisis.
Doctors operated on Pope John Paul II Thursday night, attaching a breathing tube to ease a life-threatening respiratory crisis brought on by advanced Parkinson's disease aggravated by flu symptoms.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Rapes soar as convictions plummet to a record low.
Rape attacks are increasing rapidly in England and Wales, but the number of cases that end in a successful prosecution has fallen to a record low. According to government figures published yesterday, only one in 18 rapes reported to police ends with the suspect being punished, although government ministers have pledged to increase the number of convictions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Kasyanov Hints He May Run in 2008.
Breaking a year of silence, former Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov on Thursday slammed Russia's leadership for turning away from democracy and indicated he may run for president in 2008 in order to correct the nation's course.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ARMS PURCHASE SHOULDN'T BE LISTED IN ANNUAL BUDGET: DEFENSE HEAD

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Friday he is opposed to including the U.S. weaponry purchase package in the nation's annual budget.

Lee made the remarks in a question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan amid reports that the ruling and opposition parties have clinched a deal on the arms purchase after a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong Thursday,

The Cabinet proposed a special budget in mid-2004 to purchase six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, but the budget was not approved in the legislature because of opposition by the PFP and the Kuomintang.
Lee said that he has already arranged for a meeting with Soong to talk about the arms purchase, although when has yet to be decided.
Any request by the PFP to include the arms purchase in the regular annual budget would be unacceptable since the result would be that other budgets would be squeezed, Lee said.
He stressed that Taiwan should maintain an independent and credible defense force to safeguard the security of Taiwan.

The point reached by the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee meeting last Saturday, in which both sides agreed to the need for a peaceful solution of the Taiwan Strait issue, does not mean that Taiwan should forego the U.S. arms purchase, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE CROSS-STRAIT POLICY HINGES ON 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday the government's future policy regarding relations across the Taiwan Strait will hinge on the so-called "anti-secession law" expected to be enacted by Beijing in March.

Hsieh made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where Legislator Lin Ping-kun of the opposition Non-Partisan Solidarity Union demanded that the Cabinet work out a timetable for opening direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links, commonly known as the "three links."

Hsieh said promoting the "three links" has been the government's long-standing policy, but their implementation must take into consideration Taiwan people's feelings and whether mainland China can show goodwill toward Taiwan, the premier added.

As the National People's Congress -- mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament -- is scheduled to pass the "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan, Hsieh said the government will adopt a wait-and-see attitude before deciding on its future cross-strait work agenda.

"Taiwan has offered numerous olive branches. We must take into account our people's feelings before we decide on whether to take active steps to forge direct cross-strait 'three links.' We must now pause to see whether mainland China is willing to start constructive interactions with us or if it is going to intensify its intimidation and suppression of us. We must at least wait and see the contents of this 'anti-session law,'" Hsieh said.

Noting that the opening of direct cross-strait "three links" involves many complex technical issues, Hsieh said the two sides must negotiate first if anything is to happen. The smooth conclusion of the special Chinese Lunar New Year charter flights for Taiwan businessmen operating on the mainland was provisional in nature, Hsieh said, adding that the flights marked a modest breakthrough in long-stalled cross-strait ties.
In the future, Hsieh said, the government wants to promote convenient cross-strait cargo transport services based on the foundation laid out in the just-concluded lunar new year charter flights.
As a matter of fact, Hsieh said, the government already finalized a comprehensive evaluation of the feasibility of opening direct cross-strait shipping and air links last August.
"We are now waiting for mainland China's goodwill response and an opportune time to implement the policy," Hsieh said.

As to Lin's suggestion that the offshore island county of Penghu be used as an entrepot before the opening of direct transportation links, Hsieh said the Cabinet will not oppose such a proposal so long as national security will not be compromised and technical problems can be overcome.

At present, cross-strait transportation services must be conducted via a third place, usually Hong Kong or Macau. Lin, a lawmaker representing the Penghu constituency, suggested that Penghu be used as a cross-strait transit stop.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG, BELIZE CITY FORGE SISTERHOOD TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung forged a sisterhood tie Friday with Belize City in Central America to boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.
Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai and Belize City Mayor William David Fonseca inked the accord.
Chen noted that as both Kaohsiung and Belize are coastal cities and signed a fishing cooperation agreement earlier, the sisterhood ties are expected to make bilateral relations even closer.

Chen said the cooperative relationship was made possible by the visits to ROC diplomatic allies in Latin America last year by President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh, who was then Kaohsiung mayor.
The acting mayor, who has been an avid scuba diver for 10 years, said that he has dived in East Asian countries but hopes one day to be able to dive in Latin America.
Fonseca said that Taiwan has provided assistance on agricultural technology to Belize, and he is hoping that bilateral relations will be even strengthened after the sisterhood ties.
He also extended an invitation to Chen Chi-mai to visit Belize during his tenure.
Fonseca arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a five-day visit. He traveled to Kaohsiung on Thursday to attend Lantern Festival activities.
Belize City is the largest city in Belize. The city has a population of about 60,000. Some 1,500 Taiwan expatriates reside there.
Belize City is the 22nd foreign city to establish sisterhood ties with Kaohsiung since it first cooperated with Honolulu in 1962.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO SPEARHEAD SIGNATURE DRIVE FEB. 28 AGAINST 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will launch a petition next Monday against the so-called "anti-secession law" expected to be enacted by Beijing in March, the party's chairman announced Friday.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang said the party will set up booths at 19 locations around Taiwan, including the Lungshan Temple in Taipei, for people to sign the petition Feb. 28 against Beijing's anti-secession legislation targeting Taiwan. That day is a national holiday known as Peace Memorial Day.
Su urged people to come and support the party's campaign to show their Taiwanese consciousness and protect Taiwanese identity, which he said is separate from that of China.
The signature drive will be held from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Su said.

On that afternoon, the party will sponsor a "light up beautiful Taiwan" activity in cooperation with five pro-independence academic groups, including the Northern Taiwan Society, to underscore their commitment to protecting Taiwan from annexation by China, Su said.
In addition, Su said, the TSU will organize an "anti-annexation and protect Taiwan" parade in the southern port city of Kaohsiung March 6 to rally public support for the party's cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDER VALUE IN JANUARY WORTH OVER US$18 BILLION: MOEA

TEXT.P: The value of export orders placed for Taiwan companies in January totaled US$18.42 billion, a jump of 32.2 percent over the previous year's level, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.
MOEA officials said that the more than 30 precent growth was helped by a lower basis posted in January last year, when there were fewer work days due to the Chinese New Year holidays.

According to tallies released by the MOEA's Statistics Department, January orders for electronics products rose the most in value, some US$820 million, or a rise of 26.9 percent, as compared to the 2004 level. Orders for precision instruments registered the second-highest increase in value at US$630 million, or an annual growth rate of 118.8 percent.

The value of export orders for electronics goods was the highest among all orders at US$3.879 billion, followed by those for information technology and telecommunications products, which were worth US$3.01 billion, the statistics showed.
At the same time, the country's industrial index stood at 124.75 for January, an annual expansion of 13 percent but a 4.65 percent fall from the December 2004 level.
The manufacturing index also increased by 12.69 percent year on year to 127.06 in January, but was down by 4.5 percent as compared to the month-earlier level, according to the same tallies.

Statistics Department Director-General Chang Yaw-tzong said that the 12.69 percent growth rate is encouraging but added that it is worth noting that it is unclear whether this signifies that the manufacturing sector has effectively rebounded.

Expressing concern that the global economy will not be as brisk this year as it was last year and partly due to last year's good performance, Chang said that a growth rate of more than 5 percent in domestic manufacturing output value will be hard to achieve again in the near term.
Private sector investment and consumer spending will be needed to underpin its future course, he added.

Despite concerns that Taiwan's outbound shipments are likely to shrink for the whole of this year, he forecast that the value of export orders for Taiwan companies will still increase by around 10 percent on strong demand for raw materials for steel and plastics goods as well as for IT products and precision instruments.
Meanwhile, an MOEA survey showed that some 44 percent of the Taiwan businesses expected to receive fewer orders in February than in January, in contrast to 18.6 percent who foresaw better business.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER VISITS DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen concluded a two-day visit to the Dominican Republic Thursday and headed for Haiti to continue his Caribbean diplomatic tour aimed at cementing the Republic of China's relations with its allies in the region.
Chen met with Dominican Republic President Leonel Fernandez Reyna shortly after his arrival on Wednesday.

During the meeting, Chen expressed the ROC government's gratitude to the Dominican Republic for its support for Taiwan's cause in the international arena, including Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations. Chen also said the ROC is willing to assist the Dominican Republic in building a science-based industrial park and develop its high-tech industries. Chen further said the ROC government will encourage its entrepreneurs to invest in the Dominican Republic.

On behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, Chen invited Fernandez to include Taiwan on the list of stops in his Asian trip in April that will take him to Japan and Singapore. Fernandez accepted the invitation, saying that it will be his fourth visit to Taiwan. Fernandez assured Chen that he will continue to boost bilateral relations and cooperation in the future.

During his stay, Chen also met with many other Dominican Republic political heavyweights, including Vice President Rafael Albuquerque, Minister of Foreign Affairs Carlos Morales Troncoso and congressional leaders.

Chen and Morales signed a letter of intent expressing the two countries' intention to sign a bilateral free trade agreement to further expand trade and economic cooperation. On behalf of President Fernandez, Morales conferred a medal on Chen in recognition of his contribution to promoting bilateral ties.
This is Chen's first Caribbean trip since he assumed his current post last April.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER COULD RESHUFFLE CABINET IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that he will make an examination of all members of his Cabinet, including himself, in August in consideration of a possible reshuffle.
Hsieh told lawmakers during a legislative interpellation session that he will step down if the examination finds that all his colleagues are at odds with him.
However, if only a few of them do not see eye-to-eye with him, these few members will have to leave, Hsieh said.
Hsieh assumed the premiership on Feb. 1 with most members of the previous Cabinet led by Yu Shyi-kun being retained.

On the issue of national identity, Hsieh said the enactment of the Referendum Law in 2003 has established the meaning of Taiwan's identity because the law has virtually defined the nationals of the Republic of China as comprising solely the 23 million people on Taiwan.
This marks a clear difference from the past when the government used to claim that "the ROC has 1.2 billion or 1.3 billion people" including those on mainland China, Hsieh pointed out.
Hsieh said the ROC has been "Taiwanized" in reality and that the ROC system and the Taiwan system are often interchangeable.

Hsieh agreed that the ROC Constitution that is being implemented in Taiwan fails to reflect the reality that Taiwan and the mainland are two separate countries, and the regulations and organizations governing mainland affairs are also remnants of the "one China" framework.

However, Taiwan cannot change the Constitution at will to make it fit the status quo because of pressure from the international community led by the United States and Japan, which believe that Taiwan will escalate tensions with the mainland if it amends its Constitution to change the official name of the country, Hsieh said.

In light of the international and cross-strait situations as well as Taiwan's security, the campaign for a change to the official name of the country should be promoted by civic groups or the opposition parties, not by the government, he said.

Also, he continued, the name-change plan for organizations, schools and companies bearing the word "China" and "Chinese" should be carried out based on practical needs, such as to avoid confusion with those on the mainland.
For example, the state-run China Steel Corp. has always been mistaken as a mainland-based company, he noted.

Hsieh made the remarks one day after President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed his "five noes" commitment, which included no independence for Taiwan, no change to the official name of the country and no referendum on independence or unification during his term.
Chen also said that constitutional reforms will not involve changes to national sovereignty, territory and the cross-strait status quo.

The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union, which is promoting a campaign for a new constitution and calling the country "Taiwan, " has criticized Chen as betraying Taiwan's identity and the founding ideals of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for making such a declaration, which was released after a meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.
Regarding the criticism, Hsieh said the president's efforts to seek reconciliation with the opposition parties should not be mistaken as abandoning the ideals of the DPP.

Hsieh pointed out that the meeting between Chen and Soong has invited attack from supporters of both the pan-green and pan-blue camps, which he said proves that the DPP is on the right track -- the middle way.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS TO 44-MONTH LOW: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped to 4.06 percent in January, the lowest since May 2001, when the unemployment rate was 4.22 percent, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The January jobless rate is equal to an unemployed workforce of about 419,000 people, down by 3,000 from the December figure, or a fall of 0.03 percentage points month-to-month. It also marks a decrease rate of 0.47 percentage points from the previous year's level, the statistics show.

Liu Pei-cheng, a DGBAS deputy bureau chief, said that the January unemployment rate was lower than Germany's 12.1 percent, France's 9.9 percent, Canada's 7 percent, Hong Kong's 6.4 percent, the United States' 5.2 percent and Japan's 4.4 percent.
Singapore and South Korea outperformed Taiwan with 3.7 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively, while Great Britain had a low of 2.8 percent, he added.
In terms of educational background, workers who have a senior high school education were the most affected, posting an average unemployment rate of 4.62 percent in January.

Junior high school and elementary school graduates registered an average unemployment rate of 3.78 percent for the same month, followed by 3.68 percent recorded among those with a university undergraduate or advanced degree.

In terms of age, the jobless rate stood at a high of 9.77 percent among those aged between 15 and 24, the highest rate among the various age groups, against 3.71 percent of those aged between 25 and 44 and 3.68 percent of those aged between 45 and 64.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SUBSTANTIATE AGRICULTURAL PATENT RIGHTS PROTECTION

TEXT.P: Mainland China should offer concrete protection for Taiwan-developed agricultural biotechnology and patent rights, a senior mainland affairs official said Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-shan made the remarks after a mainland Chinese official said earlier in the day that Beijing authorities welcome Taiwan farmers to invest in mainland China.

Chiu said Taiwan has not imposed any restrictions on agricultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait. Judging from official tallies, Chiu said, Taiwan has imported more agricultural goods from mainland China than vice versa.

Stressing that Taiwan has enjoyed fame in the international community for its agricultural biotechnology development, Chiu said Taiwan's farmers and agriculturalists have been reluctant to invest in mainland China mainly because the mainland has failed to give strict protection for their patent rights and technological know-how.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 26 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Feb. 26:
09: 00, City and county heads around Taiwan will meet at Hotel Royal Chihpen in Taitung, eastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISSION TO LURE FOREIGN CAPITAL IN PRIVATIZATION OF PUBLIC UNITS

TEXT.P: An official delegation led by Minister of Finance Lin Chuan will depart for the United States and Europe next week to woo foreign investments in Taiwan's privatization of state-run banks and enterprises, a spokesman for the Finance Ministry announced Friday.
According to the spokesman, Lin is slated to hold large investment seminars and one-on-one meetings in New York March 3-4 and in London March 7.

Officials from the Ministry of Finance, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Financial Supervisory Commission, Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corporation (TTLC) and seven leading public financial services, such as Mega Financial Holding and Hua Nan Financial Holding, will form the mission to invite foreign capital to Taiwan, he said.

The delegation's trips to New York and London form part of the government's financial reform efforts, which focus on the merger of financial and banking institutions to increase domestic financial services' market shares and competitiveness in Asia and the rest of the world, he noted.

Executives of prominent international investment banks, investment agencies and financial consultancy companies in the two financial hubs will be invited to take part in the activities, he said, adding that the Taiwan delegates will address the government's privatization policy and its share releasing measures to help the guests gain a better understanding of Taiwan's state-run enterprises.
The delegation hopes to win foreign investments in Taiwan's privatization plan and create business opportunities by upgrading and enhancing foreigners' interest in the issue, he said.

Lin Teng-cheng, director of the Department of the National Treasury under the Finance Ministry, said that the privatization plan of the TTLC has stirred up keen interest from a large number of foreign counterparts. Many of them have voiced willingness to hold meetings with Taiwan officials to have a detailed understanding of various projects, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO CLEAR POLITICAL BARRIERS IN NEGOTIATING WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland policy planner urged Beijing to tear down the political barriers it has erected in negotiating with Taiwan and to facilitate the establishment of a framework for peaceful and stable cross-strait interactions, according to a statement issued Friday by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said in an interview with Reuters Thursday that it is necessary to establish a mechanism to regulate the conduct of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to avoid a crisis or conflict in the region.
Such a mechanism would also facilitate the establishment of mutual trust between the two sides and create a friendly environment for bilateral cooperation, Wu stressed.
He called on Beijing to abandon its military intimidation and diplomatic blockade against Taiwan and to enter good faith negotiations with Taiwan on matters of mutual concern.

President Chen Shui-bian's repeated initiative to set up a committee for cross-strait peace and development and guidelines for the stable and peaceful development of cross-strait ties is evidence that Taiwan has been working hard for peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, he went on.

Noting that the cross-strait status quo is based on the existing Republic of China Constitution, he said that the final arrangement of cross-strait relations should be subject to the consent of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

A proposal presented by Kenneth Lieberthal for Taipei and Beijing to negotiate a 20- to 30-year framework for stability across the Taiwan Strait could serve as a reference to a certain extent, he commented.

The top mainland policy formulator also urged the international community to help stop Beijing from enacting a proposed "anti-secession law, " which he said will unilaterally change the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 26, or the 18th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North-South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
2003: The world's oldest Asian elephant living in captivity Lin Wang dies at the Taipei City Zoo at age 86.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEFENSE DEP'T URGED TO SELL AEGIS DESTROYERS TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.c.tang)

TEXT.P: A member of the U.S. House of Representatives on Friday urged the U.S. Defense Department to sell destroyers equipped with the Aegis missile defense system to Taiwan to counter China's proposed anti-secession law.

Rep. Robert Andrews (D-N.J.) made the appeal in a letter sent to Douglas J. Feith, under secretary of defense responsible for formulating defense planning guidance and force policy as well as relations with foreign countries, to voice his support for the sale of the Aegis destroyers and the transfer of relevant technologies to Taiwan in light of China's recent announcement of its intention to enact such a law.

The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress adopted a draft of the proposed law last December. The draft will be reviewed at the congress's annual plenary meeting set to be held next month.

In the letter, the representative said: "The sale of Aegis to Taiwan would send a clear and direct message to China, showing that the United States will back the democratic nation and will not accept any type of military action as a form of resolution between the two countries."
"I believe this action can, and will, be seen by China as a directive that it approach Taiwan in a civil and non-threatening manner," he also said.

The United States has pledged in its Taiwan Relations Act to protect the island from any military threat and support the right to self-determination of its people, Andrews further said, adding that selling the Aegis missile defense system to the island "is clearly in line with this pledge and therefore, should be pursued as soon as possible."
The congressman also asked Feith to provide information regarding any steps that have been taken to advance the sale.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES BETTER CARE FOR DISADVANTAGED, BETTER SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged local administrative chiefs Saturday to work together with the central government to better care for the disadvantaged and to improve social order.
Hsieh outlined the goals for such cooperation while meeting in Taitung, eastern Taiwan with the chiefs of the municipalities, cities and counties around the nation.

The premier said that as a former Kaohsiung City mayor, he has experienced first-hand the relations between the central and local governments, adding that this is why he advocates "co-existence and cooperation" in his new Cabinet, particularly cooperation between the central and local governments.

Hsieh urged first and foremost that local governments take better care of the underprivileged. Noting that every city and country around Taiwan has had reports of impoverished school students who cannot afford to pay their lunch fees, Hsieh said such reports have hurt the government's image.

He urged the local governments to make early preparations to solve the problem as the central government appropriates NT$700 million (US$22.36 million) in subsidies annually to local governments, adding that some local governments should also make sure that the profits from their charity lotteries are used for social welfare programs.
The premier also urged cities and counties to step up tourism promotion, saying that each city and county should have a major project to promote tourism so as to be internationally competitive.

Hsieh also urged local governments to use their full authority to enforce the law thoroughly, saying that half-measures are meaningless. He pointed as an example to the low demolition rate for buildings erected without license or against building code provisions which he said has affected the look of many cities and counties.

Lastly, the premier called for an improvement in social order, saying that the central and local government must work together to better protect citizens and allow them to live their lives free from fear.
On March 1, there will be a "Everyone Working Toward Better Social Order" campaign, the premier said.

All the local chiefs except Keelung Mayor Hsu Tsai-li attended Saturday's gathering, the first such meeting since Hsieh assumed the premiership Feb. 1. The chiefs attending included Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, acting Kaoshiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu. Hsu sent his secretary-general to attend on his behalf.

In addition to Hsieh, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan, Finance Minister Lin Chuan, Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Ling-san, and other high-ranking officials attended the meeting.
