DOC.HEADLINE: HAITI PROMISES SUPPORT TAIWAN'S PARTICIPATION IN INT'L ORGANIZATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By M.H. Huang and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Top figures in Haiti's provisional government promised Friday that Haiti will do whatever it can to support Taiwan's participation in international organizations and the international community.

The Caribbean country's provisional President Bonniface Alexandre, as well as Premier Gerard Latortue and Foreign Minister Yvon Simeon made the commitment while meeting separately with Chen Tan-sun, ROC minister of foreign affairs, who is currently in Porte-au-Prince for an one-day visit.

Saying that the diplomatic and friendly relations between the two countries have been established on the basis of mutual respect and recognition, they promised that Haiti, which has maintained official diplomatic ties with Taiwan for more than forty years, will do its utmost to support Taiwan's bid to join the international community by giving all the necessary assistance.
The Haitian leaders also expressed their gratitude for Taiwan's aid over the past years, saying that the Haitians can perceive the friendship and generosity from Taiwan.

Pointing out at a press conference held after his talks with Chen, the Haitian premier said that the meeting with the ROC minister was a pleasant one, adding that he believes that the relationship between the two countries will be further strengthened.

In response, Chen said that the goal of his visit is to represent President Chen Shui-bian and the 23 million people of Taiwan to show their gratitude for Haiti's support for Taiwan's bid to join international organizations.
The minister further said that the purpose of his visit is also to gain a better understanding of Haiti's democratization process and to see what Taiwan can do to help the country.

Chen expressed the hope that cooperation between the two countries will be further enhanced in the future. He also said while meeting with local reporters later the same day that to the ROC, the most important thing is to help Haiti achieve sustainable development.

During the visit, Chen also invited the Haitian premier and foreign minister to visit Taiwan this year, and extended an invitation on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian to the Haitian president to visit the island during his term in the office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE URGED TO OPPOSE BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Leaders of several pro-independence groups said Saturday that Beijing is trying to demonstrate that Taiwan is part of China with its proposed "anti-secession law" and urged the people of Taiwan to unite to vehemently oppose the proposed legislation.
The pro-independence activists made the remarks at an "Anti-Annexation, Protect Taiwan" seminar held at National Taiwan Normal University's main campus.

The proposed "anti-secession law, " which is widely seen as an attempt to create the legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan should the island declare independence, is expected to be approved by the full National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, in March.

Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang said the Taiwan Strait status quo is "one country on each side of the strait, " adding that there is no question that Taiwan is not part of the People's Republic of China.
The main purpose of the anti-secession law is to bring Taiwan under the wing of "one China, " and the Taiwan people should be on guard against this scheme, he said.

Koo Kwang-ming, a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, noted that former U.S. State Secretary Colin Powell had said late last year that "Taiwan does not enjoy sovereignty as a nation," which Koo pointed out has sent the wrong message to China.

Beijing's "anti-secession law" aims to declare to the world that Taiwan belongs to China, Koo continued, adding that if the United States, Japan and other countries do not vehemently oppose the bill, then it will have a great impact on Taiwan.
Ng Chiau-tong, chairman of World United Formosans for Independence, said that Taiwan is already a de facto sovereign state, and that it must now fight for de jure statehood.

Juan Ming, an adviser to President Chen, said the Taiwan people must unite to build their own country, adding that the government should continue its drive to rectify the nation's official designation and to write a new Constitution.

Professor Liao Hung-hsiang of the National Defense University pointed out that Beijing has been observing the response of Taiwan and the international community for reference in formulating the anti-secession law. If Beijing decides to adopt the toughest version, former President Lee Teng-hui could even be extradited to China for trial should he go overseas, Liao added.
Participants in the seminar also included professors from various colleges and universities around Taiwan as well as Reverend Kao Chun-ming of the Presbyterian Church in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO PRESENT BILL REGULATING EXERCISE OF NATIONAL ASSEMBLY'S POWERS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will present next week a draft bill regulating the exercise of the mission-oriented National Assembly's powers.

Ker Chien-ming, executive director of the DPP's policy committee, noted that the party will consider the bill as a priority as the Central Election Commission plans to elect some 300 National Assembly delegates on May 14. The delegates will be assigned exclusively for the job of reviewing a draft package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last year.

The Legislative Yuan passed several constitutional amendment proposals in August last year, including the halving of the number of seats in the current 225-seat legislature, the adoption of a "single seat, two votes" legislative election system, and the abrogation of the National Assembly.

As the ruling and opposition party lawmakers were divided on what percentage of National Assembly delegate votes should be required to approve a constitutional revision, the National Assembly operation bill did not clear the previous legislature.

Ker said his party will again send the draft bill to the legislature next week and will ask Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng to hastily call the legislators of the various parties together to discuss the bill in order to facilitate quick passage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC WILL RECOGNIZE PRESIDENT'S EFFORTS AT RECONCILIATION: AIDE

TEXT.P: The general public will recognize and understand the efforts made by President Chen Shui-bian in promoting inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, a Presidential Office official said Saturday.
James Huang, vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office, was referring to Thursday's meeting between President Chen and opposition People First Party (PFP) James Soong.

Huang's remarks came in response to former President Lee Teng-hui's comments ridiculing the meeting between the head of state and the chairman of a "minor party" as "lacking legitimacy and rationality."

Huang said that President Chen has gone out of his way to promote inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, knowing that the public has grown tired of the constant wrangling between the ruling and opposition parties during his time in office.
"The president hopes to do more for Taiwan, " Huang said, adding that he believes the public will understand the president's true intentions of reconciliation and cooperation.
"In fact, the president's approach is in line with the aspirations of the mainstream public," Huang continued.
Former President Lee, while attending an "anti-annexation" seminar sponsored by local pro-independence groups Saturday, referred to the Chen-Soong meeting as "ridiculous" and "wrong."

Lee said the problem with the Chen-Soong meeting lies in the 10-point consensus they reached, in which President Chen reaffirms his "five noes," including "no declaration of independence, no change of the nation's official name, no referendum to change the status quo of the Taiwan Strait, no inclusion of the 'state-to-state' theory on cross-strait ties into the Constitution, and no revocation of the National Unification Guidelines or National Unification Council."

The pro-Taiwan independence former president mockingly asked whether President Chen was representing himself or the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, or perhaps the PFP or Soong, in the joint statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS 1947 'A TRAGIC YEAR FOR TAIWAN'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday called 1947 a tragic year for Taiwan which marked the occurence of the 228 Incident and the declaration of martial law on the island.

Lu made the remarks while addressing a gathering to release an investigative report by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation on who bore responsibility for the incident which led to the arrest and killing of thousands of native Taiwanese by Kuomintang (KMT) troops sent from mainland China.

The vice president claimed that although a number of large-scale 228 commemorative activities calling for ethnic harmony have been held on the island in recent years, many young people are not aware of the truth behind the 228 Incident, with some even mistaking it as the bombing of Taiwan by U.S. forces.

In the past, for fear of offending the KMT government, the 228 Incident was remembered in a low-profile way through a "peace day, " which Lu said was "not at all a peaceful day, but instead one of national mourning."
The purpose of promoting 228 commemorative events is not to reopen a historical wound but to seek historical truth, Lu said.

Lu expressed the hope that a complete study on the year 1947 will be available in the future, because in addition to the occurence of the 228 Incident on Feb. 28 of that year, martial law was declared on the island on May 19 in the same year.

With the 60th anniversary of the declaration of martial law coming two years from now, Lu said she hopes various sectors of society will work together to restore the story of 1947 to let the people of the nation understand the tragedy that took place that year.

She noted that a round-the-island exhibition is set to start on May 19 at the Taipei Railway Station, in which the top 10 cases of political miscarriage of justice during the martial law era will be publicized.
Lu clarified that the exhibition is not meant to spark ethnic strife, saying that the victims of the KMT's authoritarian rule came from every ethnic group.
She said that this is a human rights issue and that the wrongdoers must be held accountable to history.

According to the investigative report, which was drafted by a team of historians led by Chang Yen-hsien, late Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek, who dispatched the KMT troops to Taiwan, should bear the largest share of responsibility for the 228 Incident.

Chen Yi, governor of Taiwan at the time, and Ko Yuan-fen, who was the Taiwan Garrison Command chief, as well as Peng Meng-chi, the Kaohsiung garrison commander, also bear some of the responsibility for the incident, according to the report.
Others bearing responsibility include individual and organized whistle-blowers, journalists and members of some civic organizations, the report said.
Taiwan was handed over to the KMT-led ROC government by the Japanese colonial rulers in 1945 following Japan's defeat and surrender in World War II.

Bad administration by the KMT rulers caused widespread resentment among native Taiwanese, which finally erupted into violence after a tobacco seller in Taipei was beaten while resisting arrest for selling untaxed cigarettes on Feb. 28, 1947, with a bystander being shot.
Riots were reported around the island in the wake of the incident, and additional troops were dispatched from the mainland to suppress the uprisings.
Thousands of people, most of whom were elites in Taiwan society, were arrested or killed in the months that followed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP TO PROMOTE REFERENDUM ON ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: The Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) said Saturday that it will promote a referendum on two major issues for the country, namely the huge arms purchase plan and several constitutional revisions passed by the legislature last year.

DAA convener Chang Ya-chung expressed the hope that a referendum could be held on May 14 when local voters will go to the polls to elect some 300 delegates of the mission-oriented National Assembly who will be assigned exclusively for the job of reviewing a draft package of constitutional amendments passed by the legislature last year.
According to Chang, the promotion of the referendum is aimed at allowing the people to have a say on issues of great importance.

Under the NT$610.8 billion arms purchase plan, Taiwan plans to buy eight diesel-powered submarines, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six PAC-3 Patriot anti-missile batteries from the United States. The budget plan is still pending approval in the opposition-controlled legislature.

Referring to the much anticipated constitutional reform, the Legislative Yuan passed several constitutional revision proposals last year, including the halving of the number of lawmakers in the 225-seat legislature, the adoption of "single seat, two votes" legislative election system, and the abrogation of the National Assembly.

Noting that the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement project will be a huge burden on taxpayers over the coming ten years, Chang expressed regret that the project has been decided by only a few political figures in closed-door meetings.

Also to express their opposition to the constitutional amendment proposals passed in the legislature, the DAA will invite 151 elites from around the country to vie for seats on the mission-oriented National Assembly in order to block the constitutional revision package.

Chang said the Legislative Yuan held four public hearings late last year to hear the opinions of some 60 scholars and experts on the constitutional reforms, in which more than 80 percent of the participants expressed their disapproval with the constitutional revisions concerning the legislature.
However, Chang added, the Legislative Yuan passed the constitutional revision bill in a day, which he said was an insult to the experts' knowledge.
Chang also solicited the public's support for the alliance's suggested National Assembly candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CALLS FOR MECHANISM TO DEAL WITH CROSS-STRAIT FISHING DISPUTES

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should establish a viable mechanism to reasonably resolve bilateral fishing disputes, the Fishery Administration of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said Saturday.

The Fishery Administration made the call after a Kaohsiung-based fishing boat was forced to sail to a mainland Chinese port a day earlier after colliding with a mainland fishing boat while operating in the open sea south of Hong Kong.
COA officials said cross-strait fishing disputes have occurred frequently because fishing boats from the two sides have often operated in the same waters.
Against this backdrop, the officials said, the two sides urgently need to forge a viable mechanism to settle cross-strait fishery disputes and better protect the rights of fishermen on both sides.

The officials said the COA has asked the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to assist in resolving the disputes. The SEF has in turn asked its Beijing counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- to push mainland authorities to protect the safety of the Taiwan fishing boat and its crew members, the officials said.

According to the officials, the Kaohsiung-based coastal fishing trawler "Ching Chi Feng" collided with a mainland fishing boat, the "Yangxi 22133, " while operating in the open sea south of Hong Kong Friday. The 19.96-ton "Ching Chi Feng" left the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung Feb. 22, with six crewmen on board.

A crew member aboard the "Ching Chi Feng" was forced onto the mainland boat after the two sides failed to reach an agreement on the amount of compensation. Three mainland crewmen also boarded the Taiwan fishing boat to force it to trail behind the mainland vessel into Yangjiang port in the southern mainland province of Guangdong for further negotiations.

"All the Taiwan crew members are safe and remain free. Both the Taiwan and mainalnd fishing boats sustained only minor damage in the collision. The two sides are still negotiating compensation terms, " a COA official said.
Meanwhile, a SEF official said the quasi-official intermediary body already sent a message to its mainland counterpart asking Beijing to clear up the case.

Taiwan and mainland China split at the end of a civil war more than five decades ago, and have no official relations. The 160-kilometer-wide Taiwan Strait separating both sides is often the scene for fishing disputes and smuggling.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE EXPRESSES WORRIES ABOUT TRADE AND ECONOMIC POLICIES TOWARDS CHINA

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui expressed worries about the government's trade and economic policies toward mainland China Saturday, cautioning against an attempt by Beijing to use its economic might to advance its goal of annexing Taiwan.
The former president made the remarks while attending an "Anti-Annexation, Protect Taiwan" seminar held at the National Taiwan Normal University's main campus.

Lee said that he is worried that through rapid cross-strait "economic integration, " Taiwan could fall into Beijing's trap of using its increasing economic clout to advance its goal of unification with Taiwan.

If Taiwan's China policy is viewed by other countries as "moving toward unification sooner or later, " why should they bother helping Taiwan to beef up its national defense and to reach out to the international community, Lee asked.
Lee noted that the present government's trade policy toward mainland China is "active opening, effective management, " but he questioned the "extent of the management."
He stressed that economic policy should not be separated from politics, and that "the government should not be all ears to the views of the businesspeople."

The government should stand on the side of all the people of Taiwan, taking full consideration of the nation's interests, Lee said, adding that the government's China policy should have in mind the nation's economic security and safeguarding the people's "living rights."

He also urged the public to speak out against China's proposed "anti-secession law" so as not to allow China to unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait as well as to allow Taiwan to become a "normal" country soon.
The "anti-secession law" is set to be approved by the full National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament, when it meets next month.

The former president also said that the 228 Incident in 1947 and the ensuing period of martial law rule had prevented a great majority of the Taiwan people from "speaking their minds" for many years, which he said had a detrimental effect on Taiwan's society.

However, he added that the 228 Incident, which refers to the events that led to a brutal crackdown by the Kuomintang government troops against the local population, particularly the elites, also provided the Taiwan people with a valuable historical lesson, making them rethink their "illusions about the motherland" and clarify what Taiwan's relationship with China should be.

Lee said that with the enormous political, economic, social and cultural divides that exist between Taiwan and China, forcing the two sides together in an unnatural way would have tragic consequences. He claimed that especially following their separate developments over the last half century, Taiwan and China are indeed separate countries on each side of the strait, politically and culturally.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING VESSEL SINKS OFF TAMSHUI

TEXT.P: A Suao-registered fishing boat sank in waters off Tamshui in northern Taiwan Saturday, killing one crew member, the Suao Fishery Broadcasting Station reported.
One crew member was rescued while two others remain missing, according to the report.
The fishing boat began taking on water when the vessel's hull broke at around noon. The crew radioed the station for help, which in turn immediately notified the Cabinet-level National Rescue Center.
Local coast guard teams were dispatched in helicopters and patrol boats to the scene.
At about 12:30 p.m., the whole vessel submerged, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPIRIT OF AGREEING TO DISAGREE KEY TO TAIWAN'S UNITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the spirit of agreeing to disagree is crucial to ending partisan confrontation and bringing about unity and stability in Taiwan.
If viewed from this perspective, Chen said, his meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong two days ago was of great significance.

Chen made the remarks while addressing a luncheon between Executive Yuan officials and local government chiefs. The comments were apparently aimed at clarifying criticism by pro-independence groups in the wake of the Chen-Soong meeting that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has betrayed its founding ideals and Taiwan's identity.
The president said agreeing to disagree means seeking common ground, but this is not tantamount to the abandoning of ideals and principles.

Chen pointed out that he and Soong agreed during the meeting that the Republic of China as stated in the ROC Constitution is the largest area of common ground on the issue of national identity between both sides, although different political parties differ on their interpretations and beliefs regarding the meaning of the ROC and the Constitution.

Such differences should be respected, reserved and put aside to facilitate the search for common ground, which will be the basis and starting point of reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, Chen said.
According to the president, there are only two choices for Taiwan -- either to continue along the old path of partisan confrontation or to seek inter-party reconciliation and cooperation.
The people have made a choice and sent a clear message that they want unity and cooperation instead of division and confrontation, Chen pointed out.

He said it would be impractical to expect the longstanding differences between the ruling and opposition parties to be resolved completely in only a few meetings, but it is necessary for them to do their best to look for points that are acceptable to both sides.

While political parties used to interact with each other through competition and lacked any experience in cooperation in the past, the Chen-Soong meeting marked the beginning of a new era and a new milestone for reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, he said.
The president said the objective of this new model of inter-party interaction is to make the people of Taiwan the major, final winners, because it is for the people that political parties exist.
This small island of Taiwan cannot afford continued division and confrontation and requires solidarity in order to stand out in the world, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 4TH IN WORLD IN U.S. PATENT APPROVALS

TEXT.P: The U.S. government approved 5,298 patents applied for by Taiwanese inventors in 2003, ranking Taiwan fourth in the world behind only the United States, Japan and Germany, Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) officials said Saturday.
The officials noted that the number of patents approved is important indicator of the level of a country's research and development. Taiwan placed fourth on the list in 2002.

According to the statistics, the number of patent applications in Taiwan totaled 65,742 in 2003, marking an increase of 7.1 percent over the previous year. A total of 53,034 applications were approved, for an increase of 17.7 percent over the figure for 2002, with applications involving high-tech inventions increasing by three percent over the year-earlier level.

Meanwhile, a total of 12,392 scientific reports written in Taiwan were published in the world's major scientific journals in 2003, ranking Taiwan 18th in the world, according to the Science Citation Index.
A total of 8,266 engineering articles were published in major journals, ranking Taiwan 10th in the world, according to same the index.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING BOAT SINKS, AT LEAST FIVE DEAD

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat sank 40 nautical miles off Tamsui, northern Taiwan, Saturday morning, killing at least five crew members, Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials said.
Two other crew members were rescued, while one remains missing, the COA officials said.

The officials said they received a call for emergency assistance from the Suao-based fishing boat "Sea Dragon No. 001" at 10: 54 a.m., by which time the vessel was already taking on dangerous amounts of water due to a breach in the hull.
The CGA immediately sent seven rescue boats and a helicopter to the scene upon receiving the distress call. The search for the missing crew member continues, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-FIFTH OF TAIWAN ADULTS CONSIDERED OBESE: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: One-fifth of adults in Taiwan are considered obese owing to excessive protein and fat intake and a lack of exercise, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday.

Lu announced the figure during an Asia-Pacific conference held in Taipei on the problem of obesity. She based her figure on a standard established in 2002 under which someone with a body mass index (BMI) over 24 is considered overweight and someone with a BMI over 27 is defined as obese.

Lu pointed out that 70 percent of diseases are related to obesity, including diabetes, hyperlipemia and breast cancer, and that the government has put forth some long-term programs to try to improve the health of the Taiwan people.

According to a report released by the Taiwan Medical Association for the Study of Obesity at the conference, not getting enough sleep and working overtime over a long period of time could lead to obesity.
The report was based on a survey of 3,847 workers at electronics companies in northern Taiwan.

It was found that 37 percent of workers who work 12 hours a day on a rotation basis for more than two-and-half years are obese, which is higher than the figure of 31 percent among workers who do not work on a rotation basis.
While 36 percent of workers who sleep less than six hours a day are obese, the figure climbs to 42 percent among those who sleep less than four hours a day, the report said.
This compared with an obesity rate of 29 percent among workers who sleep at least eight hours a day.
Association member Hsiao Tun-jen explained that getting enough sleep is necessary for the production of leptin in the human body to control appetite and enhance metabolism.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEREMONY HELD FOR VICTIMS OF 228 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Amid drizzling cold rains, nearly 100 family members of victims of the 228 Incident gathered in a park in downtown Taipei for a religious service Saturday.

A Buddhist master read from Buddhist scriptures in the service at Taipei 228 Memorial Park for the victims of the 228 Incident, which refers to the series of events in 1947 that led to the brutal crackdown by the Kuomintang government against the local population.
Before the service, Liao Teh-hsiung, president of the Taipei 228 Incident Association, presented an orchid to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

The orchid from Japan is a symbol of peace. In Aug. 6, 1945, all plants withered after the bombing of Hiroshima, and only a few orchids only two kilometers from the bombing site survived. The orchids were later planted in Hiroshima Peace Park. They have become symbols of peace. This was the first time that any have been sent to Taiwan.
Mayor Ma received the orchid, which will later be planted in front of the 228 memorial hall in the park, and observed one minute of silence with the family members.

Ma, addressing the gathering in the Taiwanese dialect, said that although 58 years have passed since the tragic event, his heart is heavy for the suffering of the victims' family members over the years.
He said that the significance of the 228 Incident is that everyone should pursue and support peace, not just ethnic, but also cross-strait and world peace.
Meanwhile, Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that she will promote the unveiling of the truth behind the 228 Incident so that those who bear responsibility are held accountable to history.
Lu made the remarks while attending the inauguration of the Formosa Heart Association's Kaohsiung chapter in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSPEOPLE IN U.K. URGED TO HELP TAIWAN'S DEVELOPMENT
DOC.DATELINE: London, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By N.K. Han & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China representative to the United Kingdom Edgar Lin on Friday urged Taiwanese businesses operating in Britain to help promote the stable and harmonious development of Taiwan.
Lin made the call at a regular dinner gathering of Taiwanese businesspeople living in the United Kingdom at a Chinese restaurant on the banks of the Thames River.

The diplomat said two factors have contributed to Taiwan's continued economic development, namely the government's proper and efficient polices, and the fighting spirit and efforts of Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises.

Before assuming his current post in London this January, Lin was the ROC ambassador to the west African nation of Gambia. He also previously served as the head of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration.

During the dinner party attended by about 80 people, an expert on industrial sustainable development delivered a speech on the emerging global environmental protection consensus in the electronics industry.

The speech was part of the Taipei Representative Office in the U.K.'s efforts to help Taiwanese businesses in Britain -- mostly in the electronics and information sectors -- deal with the increasingly strict European environmental regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-PARTY RECONCILIATION SHOULD FOCUS ON POLICY ISSUES: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of respondents in a recent public opinion poll said inter-party reconciliation should focus on public policy issues, a spokesman for the Association of Taiwanese of Mainland Chinese Origin said Saturday.

According to the same survey, 52 percent of the respondents said they feel that Taiwan faces serious ethnic issues, and nearly 80 percent said they agree with the claim that ethnic issues have mainly instigated by political figures for partisan interests.

The association conducted the survey in Taipei City and Taipei County, or the greater Taipei area, between Jan. 28-29 to explore different ethnic groups' views on the 228 Incident and inter-party reconciliation.

Except for Taiwan's 400,000 or so aboriginal citizens, most of the island's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese. However, this latter population can be divided into two sub-ethnic groups: the "mainlanders" whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese Communists took over the mainland in 1949, and the "native Taiwanese" whose ancestors began arriving on the island in the 17th century or earlier. Most mainlanders live in northern Taiwan, particularly in the greater Taipei area.
The survey results showed that 52 percent said they think ethnic issues are serious in Taiwan, while 39 percent said they think otherwise.
A total of 1,042 valid replies were collected in the random telephone poll on adult residents. The survey is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

Nearly 40 percent said they feel that review or reflection of the 228 Incident, which refers to the events that led to a brutal crackdown by the Kuomintang (KMT) government troops against local population, particularly the elites, would aggravate tension among different ethnic groups, but 36 percent said they think rational discussion of the tragic incident would contribute to ethnic harmony and mutual understanding.
A cross analysis of the survey results showed that nearly 50 percent of the "mainlander" respondents think discussion of the 228 Incident would deepen ethnic tensions or rifts.
While 79.7 percent of the respondents said they agree with the statement that political figures are to blame for ethnic tensions, 11.5 percent said they disagree with such a claim.

Asked whether "mainlanders" should be held responsible for the 228 Incident or the "White Terror" during the KMT government-imposed martial law era, 68.3 percent said they don't think so, but nearly 20 percent gave a positive reply to the question.

Meanwhile, 80.1 percent said inter-party reconciliation should be based on stances toward major public policy issues, only 5.9 percent said reconciliation among political parties should be based on their stances on Taiwan's future relations with China -- unification or independence.

In addition, 68 percent said they support the proposal that the two domestic political camps -- the "pan-green" camp of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) -- transcend their divides and work for reconciliation.
Moreover, 72 percent said they believe that inter-party reconciliation will help ease ethnic tensions, but about 20 percent said they think otherwise.

About 45 percent said they feel the mainlanders' political status has worsened since the DPP gripped the presidency in 2000; 40 percent said they feel nothing has changed about the mainlanders' political status; 6.2 percent said they feel mainlanders' political status has improved.

More than 50 percent said they feel native Taiwanese's political status has improved; 35 percent said they feel native Taiwanese's political status remain almost the same; only 8 percent said the status has worsened.
Meanwhile, 53 percent said they feel Hakka people's political status has improved; 34 percent said they see no major change; but 2.9 percent said Hakkas' political status has declined.

About 42 percent said native Taiwanese have benefited most from Taiwan's democratization; followed by aborigines (5.8 percent) ; Hakkas (5.2 percent) ; and mainlanders (3.2 percent) ; while 44.3 percent said they didn't know which ethnic group has benefited most from democratization.

Only 17.4 percent said a presidential candidate's ethnic background matters in their voting choice, while 81.3 percent said the candidate's ethnic origin doesn't matter. As to the mainlanders' general image in local society, 78.5 percent said they hold a positive view of mainlanders, while 10.5 percent said they hold a negative impression; the remaining said they didn't have any special feelings.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC TO PUSH FOR DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT CRUISE BY FOREIGN OCEAN LINERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) suggested Saturday that the government allow foreign ocean liners to make direct cruise across the Taiwan Strait to help boost tourist arrivals.

Lin Chih-ming, an MOTC department chief in charge of navigation affairs, said major domestic ports, such as Keelung Harbor, Taichung Harbor and Kaohsiung Harbor, all have passenger wharves to accommodate ocean liners.

"Taiwan is now not a major stop for foreign ocean liners. If we allow them to make direct cross-strait cruise, we'll be able to attract foreign tourist liners to include Taiwan into their itinerary," Lin said.
Should that be the case, Lin said, local travel agencies can organize half-day or one-day tour package for passengers aboard the foreign ocean liners.
"We believe the opening measure will help the government realize its goal of doubling tourist arrivals by 2008," Lin said.

According to Lin, a Southeast Asia-based ocean liner once planned to make a port call at Taiwan and then sail directly to Shanghai, but the plan was later dropped due to Taiwan's ban on direct cross-strait shipping links.

As the new opening measure is related with the government's mainland policy, Lin said the MOTC will discuss the proposal with the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA HAILS SUBSTANTIAL DECREASE IN STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday that the number of stray dogs in Taiwan has declined substantially in recent years thanks to concerted efforts by the private and public sectors.
According to statistics released by the COA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine Bureau, Taiwan had 667,000 stray dogs in 1999, but the number had dropped to 179,000 by 2004.

The quarantine bureau said that both the 1999 and 2004 figures were based on surveys conducted by Fei Chang-yung, a professor at National Taiwan University's veterinary medicine department, in line with methods designated by the World Health Organization.
"The results of both surveys are objective, fair and impartial," a bureau official said.

Fei pointed out in his 2004 survey that the significant decrease in the number of stray dogs can be attributed to a combination of factors, including a change in local people's attitude toward keeping pets as well as the government's encouragement of pet owners to have their pets sterilized and better management of stray dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEARCH FOR MISSING FISHERMEN CONTINUES

TEXT.P: Two fishermen from a sunk Suao-based fishing boat remained missing as of Saturday evening, while five other crew members died, fishery officials with the Council of Agriculture (COA) said.

The fishing boat, with a Taiwanese skipper and seven mainland Chinese sailors aboard, sank 40 nautical miles north of Fukueichiao on Taiwan's northeastern coast, because of a breach in the hull, COA officials said.

The National Disaster Relief Command Center immediately sent seven rescue boats and helicopters to the scene upon receiving the distress call. As of 5 p.m., two were rescued, but one died after being rushed to a nearby hospital. The other one is in stable condition after receiving emergency treatment.

Coast guard officers also recovered four bodies of the crewmen. None of them showed signs of life. COA officials said the search for the two missing crew members will continue despite bad weather. Disaster relief staff said they received a call for emergency assistance from the Suao-based fishing boat "Sea Dragon No. 001" at 10: 54 a.m., by which time the vessel was already taking on dangerous amounts of water due to a breach in the hull.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 27 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Feb. 27:
05: 15, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will return to Taipei after visits to the Dominican Republic and Haiti.
14:00, The opposition Kuomintang will hold a news conference on the 228 Incident at its headquarters in Taipei.
14:30, Premier Frank Hsieh will hold an informal meeting with local journalists at the Taipei Mayor's former official residence.
18:00, Former U.S. President Bill Clinton will deliver a speech at the Taipei International Convention Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 4 at Tel Aviv Club
A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up amid a crowd of young Israelis waiting to enter a nightclub near the Tel Aviv beachfront Friday night, killing at least four, wounding dozens and threatening to shatter a truce that had largely been holding. The bombing was the first major attack since Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, called for an end to violence at a Feb. 8 summit meeting in Egypt.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 27, or the 19th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the-troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Dennis Theike, commander of Pacific Areas of the U.S. Veterans of Foreign Wars.
1980: Taiwan Power Co. signs a syndicated loan of US$100 million with ten foreign banks to finance development projects.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the ROC, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian promises to create 100,000 jobs to benefit 100,000 families and one million people if he is elected president on March 18.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lian Chan meets with People First Party Chairman James Soong, with the two agreeing to bolster future cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: Four killed in the fire engulfing a high-rise in Taichung.
The United Daily News: Four killed in inferno gutting Taichung's landmark hi-rise building.
The Liberty Times: Four killed, three injured in blaze of hi-rise in Taichung.
The Taiwan Daily: Chen Yi recommended to speed up the integration of Taiwan into China after Feb. 28, 1947.
The Central Daily News: Lien to call for reconciliation between various political parties, ethnic groups and two sides of Taiwan Strait.
The China Post: Chen defends reconciliation with Soong after criticism.
The Taiwan News: President denies meeting Soong betrayed values.
The Taipei Times: Lu said 228 murders should pay.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Prayers offered for Pope.
Pope John Paul II spent a second night in hospital, breathing through a hole in his neck, as Catholics around the world prayed for his recovery from acute respiratory problems, while medical experts feared the worst.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Ex-Reds 'radicalizing' Muslims.
Ex-communist rebels who converted to Islam are providing the "ideology" that has "radicalized" a small group of Islamic converts, including one suspected of involvement in the Valentine's Day bombings, according to an Inquirer source in a Muslim non-government organization.
The Philippine Star: No ceasefire in Sulu.
A senior military official denied yesterday that the military has suspended its offensive against Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) renegades in Sulu, and belied claims by a local official who said he had brokered an informal ceasefire between government troops and Muslim rebels in the province.
The Manila Times: Informal cease-fire with Jolo rebels frees military to chase Sayyaf.
The Armed Forces has reached an informal truce in Jolo with Muslim fighters loyal to Nur Misuari, allowing troops to concentrate on pursuing Abu Sayyaf extremists, an official said Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Attack Shatters Calm in Mideast.
A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up outside a crowded beachfront bar late Friday in an attack against Israel that shattered a month- long period of relative calm and instantly threw a shadow over tentative but promising steps toward peace talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iran's Nuclear Program Traced to 1987 Meeting.
New evidence shows Iranian officials met secretly with Pakistani scientists, but Tehran says it turned down parts required to make core of a bomb.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: H-11A rocket successfully places satellite into orbit.
Fifteen months after Japan's last liftoff ended in a spectacular fireball, an orange and white H-11A rocket blasted off Saturday on a mission officials hope will revive this country's once-proud space program.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM DESCRIBES TRIP TO HAITI, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC AS SUCCESSFUL

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen, who returned to Taiwan Sunday from a trip to Haiti and Dominican Republic, described his visit to the two Republic of China allies as "successful."
He told journalists at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport he felt pleased that he met the people he was hoping to meet and had successfully completed his mission.
However, he refused to elaborate on the exact nature of his mission, which began Feb. 22.

He made transit stops in Tokyo and New York on his way to Haiti, giving rise to media speculation that he might have exchanged views with Japanese and American officials, in light of the fact the two countries issued a joint statement for the first time Feb. 19 calling for the peaceful resolution of disputes between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT INVESTMENT POSTS FIRST POSITIVE GROWTH IN FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: The government's fixed investments will post a growth rate of 1.1 percent in real terms this year for the first time in five years, according to a forecast made Sunday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.

The DGBAS said the growth, attributed largely to the "ten new major construction projects" program launched by the government, is especially significant when compared to the minus 4.2 percent growth in the previous year.
The growth would be 3.2 percent in nominal terms owing to the rise in building materials.

The state-owned enterprises, which are estimated to register a growth of 10.9 percent in fixed investments this year, claim a major part of the credit, mainly because of the Taiwan Power Company's investment in the Fourth Nuclear Plant in Taipei County, its Sixth Electricity Distribution System and its Tatan Thermoelectrical Power Station, in Taoyuan County.
Private sector fixed investment is expected to grow by 8.9 percent this year, thanks to the start of construction of the country's Sixth Naptha Cracker and the Taiwan High Speed Railway.
However, the DGBAS holds out a dim prospects for the country's international trade this year owing to the slowdown in international economic growth.

According to the forecast, the growth in the country's exports will decrease from 20.7 percent last year to 6.7 percent this year, while imports will decrease from 31.0 percent last year to 5.7 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO MAKE CASE FOR TAIWAN TO EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to make a strong case for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) to members of the European Parliament via a teleconference March 1, government sources said Sunday.

The sources said Chen will made an appeal for the European Parliament's help for Taiwan's bid, and will emphasize the contributions the island, if admitted to WHO, could have made to the world health body in combating epidemics such as severe acute respiratory syndrome.
Chen will also try to win the support of European states in Taiwan's disputes with mainland China.

The Presidential Office refused to confirm the teleconference Sunday, but the country's representative office in Brussels confirmed the teleconference by disclosing that two European parliamentarians -- Graham Watson from Britain and George Jarzembowski from Germany -- as well as media correspondents, will talk with the president in the teleconference.

Chen cast the country into the international spotlight last September when he gave an interview via teleconference to members of the United Nations Correspondent's Association in New York to appeal for support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations when the U.N. Assembly was gathering for its annual session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATRIATES IN U.S. PROTEST AGAINST BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan expatriates in the United States staged a protest Saturday in front of mainland China's embassy in Washington, DC against Beijing's proposed anti-secession law.

The demonstrators, organized by the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), erected placards and chanted "China Hands off Taiwan!" "Taiwan, China, Two Countries!" "Taiwan Democracy!" "'Yes' to Democracy, 'No' to Dictatorship" and other slogans in both English and in Chinese during the protest, which ended peacefully.
The protesters also tried to present written petitions to the Chinese embassy, but it was closed for the weekend. They left the letters at the embassy's front gate.
The petitions expressed the demonstrators' opposition to Beijing's attempt to annex Taiwan by enacting the proposed anti-secession law, the organizers said.
Similar demonstrations were held in New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMBINED MARKET VALUE OF LISTED COMPANIES IN TAIWAN UP OVER LAST WEEK

TEXT.P: The combined market value of listed companies in Taiwan hit NT$14.249 trillion (US$452.36 billion) at the close of trading Friday, up NT$214.27 billion, or 1.53 percent, over the week-earlier level, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange Co. (TSEC).
The weighted index -- the benchmark of the domestic bourse -- moved up 92.4 points, or 1.51 percent, for the whole week to finish at 6,207.83 Feb. 25.
The surge was mainly due to an inflow of foreign capital due to an increasing appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar, according to the TSEC report.
Share prices of the 20 main categories, except for paper and pulp issues, gained ground, with glass and ceramics stocks moving up the most at 7.4 percent.
There have been 34 trading days on the Taiwan Stock Exchange so far this year, with a combined turnover of NT$2.312 trillion, or a daily average of NT$66.89 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICEER 2005 TO BE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The International Conference for Engineering Education and Research (ICEER) 2005 will open March 2 at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan, the organizers of the event announced Sunday.
The organizers described the theme of the conference as "Progress through Partnership: Exploring Innovation in Education and Research."
A total of 185 engineers from 27 countries have confirmed that they will take part in the four-day meeting, they added.

The participants will present papers covering a wide range of topics, including disaster prevention, digital learning, information technology, certification of international education, education in the field of nanotechnology, new trends in engineering education, programs for engineering education, cooperation in engineering education and cooperation in industrial development.

The ICEER conference is focused on promoting international collaboration on engineering education and research. The first conference of its kind was held last year at Bouzov Castle in the Czech Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATION TO VISIT SUN YAT-SEN'S MAINLAND CHINA MAUSOLEUM

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang will lead a party delegation to visit the mausoleum of Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing, eastern mainland China next month, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said Sunday during a ceremony held by the party in memory of Feb. 28 Peace Day.
Sun is the founding father of the Republic of China and of the KMT.

Lien said Chiang and his delegation will also visit the tomb in Kwangzhou, southern China, of 72 martyrs who were killed in a KMT-led uprising against China's last feudalistic regime, the Ching dynasty, in 1911.
The country set aside the day of their deaths -- March 29 -- as the nation's Youth Day.

Lien said people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait have paid heavily for the military confrontation between Taiwan and the mainland in the four decades between 1938 and 1987, although reconciliation began to take place between the two sides after 1987, when Taiwan reached out to the mainland, Lien claimed.

Unfortunately, Lien went on, the "steady tendency toward detente" was interrupted and replaced with tense military confrontation after 2000 because of Taiwan political leaders' claims of "two states on each side of the Taiwan Strait, " and their calls for writing a new constitution, deciding the country's future via referendum, and changing the country's official name.

Claiming that getting rid of hostility and seeking rapport is the common desire of most people, Lien said the reconciliation called for by President Chen Shui-bian among political parties in Taiwan is not enough and that his party wants also to proffer an olive branch to Beijing, with Chiang's trip to the mainland the first step of the process.

Before Lien announced Chiang's trip, Chen Min-chung, a victim of the 1947 Feb. 28 incident, made the bizarre claim that the incident was really apart of the civil war between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party rather than a conflict between the Taiwan people and the KMT authorities at the time.
In that incident, Taiwanese residents rose up to protest the KMT's brutal rule, a move that led to a bloody crackdown by the KMT government, which killed thousands of Taiwanese.

Chen, who led a communist squadron that attacked a fort at Sun Moon Lake in Nantou during the incident, was later arrested and sentenced to death, but was spared eventually and released in 1987 because of his poor health.
The incident has been characterized by the island's pro-independence groups as yet more proof of the KMT's brutality and a justification of their political cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL CYCLING RACE TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Elimination Road Race 2005 will be held March 6 with the participation of 40 athletes from 14 countries, officials of the Taiwan Foreign Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Sunday.
The competition is part of TAITRA's efforts to promote the annual Taipei International Cycle Show, which will be held this year at the Taipei World Trade Center March 4-7, the officials noted.
The venue of the competition will be a circuit of around 1.6 km around the Taipei World Trade Center Hall 3.
The winner of the race will win NT$100,000 (US$3,175) in cash, they added.
More than 600 companies have registered to take part in this year's cycle show to introduce their products in 2,000 booths established at the exhibition venue, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON ARRIVES FOR WHIRLWIND VISIT

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton arrived Sunday in Taipei from Japan for a 24-hour whirlwind visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
Shortly after his arrival at Taipei's Sungshan Airport, Clinton delivered a keynote speech about global security and prosperity in the 21st Century at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Legislative Yuan speaker and foundation chairman Wang Jin-pyng and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen gave welcome addresses at the event, which was hosted by Hsiao Bi-khim, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker and a board member of the foundation.
After Clinton's speech, President Chen Shui-bian feted with a dinner in his honor.

Clinton will hold a book signing session Monday morning at the Taipei Financial Center -- better known as Taipei 101 -- for his autobiography, titled My Life, before leaving Taiwan later that day for Singapore. Clinton is currently on a world tour to promote his book.
Officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said the ministry has imposed tight security for Clinton's visit.
However, the officials were tight-lipped about whether Lien Chan, chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang, will pay a visit to Clinton Monday at his hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP URGES RECONCILIATION AT NEW LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) appealed Sunday for reconciliation with the start of the new session last Friday, saying that the DPP caucus is poised to serve as a peace messenger in rapport with the opposition parties.

William C.D. Lai claimed that the DPP caucus is willing to help pass to the opposition parties the olive branch extended by President Chen Shui-bian in a meeting last Thursday with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.
Forging reconciliation and fostering cooperation will be the caucus' top priority at the sixth Legislative Yuan inaugurated Feb. 1, Lai said.

Lai said that the DPP caucus will also step up its communications with the Executive Yuan and the opposition parties to push for major bills regarding a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for a major military procurement plan, national insurance system reform, the operation of National Assembly and the restructuring of the Executive Yuan.

The DPP caucus will also do its best to seek support from the opposition parties and their consent to the nomination list of the Control Yuan members forwarded by the president in the last session, he added.

Stressing that a united Taiwan is extremely important when the nation is facing enormous competition and pressure from other countries, he claimed that the DPP needs tremendous courage to make peace with the opposition.

Meanwhile, legislators Chen Jie and Cho Po-yuan, new caucus whips of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), echoed Lai, with calls for compromise and a "win-win" situation between the governing and opposition camps.

Chen pledged to continue collaborating with the PFP to provide an effective system of checks and balances in the government and promised to negotiate with the PFP while seeking a common stance on key issues.
Cho said that the KMT agrees with the ideas of co-existence and reconciliation aired by Premier Frank Hsieh, who took over the post from his predecessor Yu Shyi-kun Feb. 1.

Cho said that the KMT will respond rationally and positively in cooperation with the PFP to policies forwarded by the Cabinet if Hsieh is reasonable and flexible in communicating with the Legislative Yuan with regard to bills.
He also urged the executive branch to focus its attention on issues pertaining to the public good and people's livelihoods while shelving sensitive political and ethnic disputes.

PFP legislative leader Li Yong-pin made it clear that the PFP will not loosen its stance on sensitive issues in its capacity as a responsible opposition party and will without fault stick to the 10-point joint statement made public during the Chen-Soong meeting.
Looking ahead, Li voiced her hope for smooth legislation and called for a change to the Cabinet's "attitude" toward pushing bills through the legislature.

Dismissing reporters' rumors that the PFP will form an alliance with the DPP at the Legislative Yuan after the Chen-Soong meeting, Li described that rhetoric as misleading and reiterated that the PFP will vigorously scrutinize bills related to public welfare in conjunction with the ruling party.

But she added that the PFP will not alter its position as regards cooperating with the KMT on most issues, including screening the nominations for Control Yuan members. She also pointed out that PFP-initiated drafts devised to bolster peace across the Taiwan Strait and to set up a national communications commission must clear the Legislative Yuan after negotiations with other parties.
At the same time, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a one-time ally of the ruling DPP, claimed that the TSU will seek inter-party cooperation to promote economic and public interest bills.
TSU legislative caucus whip Lo Chih-ming said that the party will even consider to collaborate with the KMT or the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union in this field.
However, Lo said that the pro-independence TSU will walk its own way regarding Taiwan's future course, insisting that Taiwan's identity cannot be compromised under any conditions.

The TSU accused Chen of betraying the Taiwan people by signing the 10-point joint declaration with Soong, which focuses on keeping the Republic of China's status quo intact and boosting ethnic harmony.

In view of the fragile cross-strait situation, President Chen tried hard to woo the PFP after the Dec. 11, 2004 legislative elections, in which the DPP failed to form a stable majority with the TSU in the 225-member Legislative Yuan.
The DPP gained 89 seats at the legislature, followed by the KMT with 79 and the PFP with 34. The TSU captured only 12 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIT-IN HELD OUTSIDE CLINTON SPEECH VENUE OVER 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: A group of opposition supporters staged a sit-in Sunday outside the Taipei International Convention Center to underscore their resolve to find out "the truth" behind the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the March 20 presidential election last year.
New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming and Legislator Joanna C. Lei led the protest outside the venue of a speech by visiting former U. S. President Bill Clinton.

Chanting slogans calling for international attention to help dig out what they described as "the truth" behind the election-eve shooting, which many opposition "pan-blue alliance" supporters believe unfairly changed the result of the election, Yok said the sit-in was only a warm up for a series of similar activities as the shooting's anniversary approaches.
He said the New Party will stage protests every year in the future as long as the shooting remains unsolved.
Lei issued a declaration in Chinese and English claiming that "there is no president nor democracy if the truth is not discovered."
Chen narrowly won the March 20 presidential race after being attacked by an unknown gunman a day earlier. No-one has been arrested so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Mubarak Pushes Egypt to Allow Freer Elections.
Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak asked Egypt's Parliament on Saturday to amend the Constitution to allow for direct, multiparty presidential elections this year for the first time in the nation's history. Some opposition politicians and analysts hailed the proposal as heralding a new political era for Egypt, the Arab world's most populous nation, while skeptics said they wanted to await the details to be sure that the eventual constitutional amendment would not create only the appearance of democracy, a common problem in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS URGED TO STEP DOWN ON DECIDING TO RUN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The politically-appointed government officials should step down if they decide to run elections for public offices, Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday.

For running the year-end elections of city and county heads, the government officials should quit not later than March 28 when the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will start registration of candidates, Hsieh noted.

It is a good arrangement for both the administration team and individuals because it would not affect the government operation nor create a unfair electoral environment for other candidates, the premier stressed.

Hsieh told lawmakers Friday during a legislative interpellation session that he will make an examination of all members of his Cabinet, including himself, in August in consideration of a possible reshuffle.

The premier said that he will step down if the review finds that all his colleagues are at odds with him. However, if only a few of them do not see eye-to-eye with him, these few members will have to leave, he added.
Hsieh assumed the premiership on Feb. 1 with most members of the previous Cabinet led by Yu Shyi-kun being retained.

Hsieh said that he did not make a large-scale Cabinet reshuffle on assuming to the premiership given that Yu's Cabinet was in a good operation and that he needs more time to observe all Cabinet members' performances.

He proposed a possible Cabinet reshuffle in August last week based on a consideration that the new Legislative Yuan will then finish its first session, the premier explained, adding that it will be an opportune moment for the Cabinet reshuffle, if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON AFFIRMS TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY AND PROSPERITY

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton affirmed Taiwan's democracy and prosperity in a speech in Taipei Sunday.

He also lauded the direct charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China last month during the Chinese New Year holidays, saying he was amazed to learn from the British weekly the Economist that Taiwan businessmen have employed more than 10 million people on the mainland despite the bitter political disputes between the two sides.

The former U.S. president used this to dress home the message of his speech about the peace and prosperity in 21th Century that the increasing interdependence among different countries is driving them to work together, and the challenge the world faces in this century is to establish a stable international society wherein the people share responsibility, benefits and basic values.

At the invitation of the government-financed Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, Clinton flew in from Japan Sunday evening four hours behind schedule and was whiskered to the Taipei International Convention Center to deliver a speech to a packed auditorium.
He met with President Chen Shui-bian Sunday evening at a dinner and was scheduled to sign copies of his autobiography "My Life" for local readers Monday morning before leaving Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR FEB. 28 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Monday, Feb. 28:
08: 30, Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai will officiate at a ceremony in commemoration of the 58th anniversary of the 228 incident in the southern Taiwan port city.
10:00, The Taiwan Solidarity Union will hold a news conference on the launch of an "anti-annexation" signature drive at the Longshan Temple in Taipei.
10: 00, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet with victims of the 228 incident and their families at the restaurant of the 228 Memorial Hall in Taipei.
11: 00, Former U.S. President Bill Clinton will begin to sign copies of his autobiography at the City Square of the Taipei 101 tower.
14: 00, A ceremony in memory of the 58th anniversary of 228 incident will be held at the 228 Memorial Park in Taipei.
17: 30, A ceremony of lighting up the Fukuei Cape light house to start the global "lighting up Taiwan" activities will be held at the 228 Memorial Park in Taipei.
20: 00, A "lighting up Taiwan" activity will be held at the 228 Memorial Park in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 28, or the 20th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
2004: More than 1 million people held hands together to form a human chain that stretched the length of Taiwan from Hoping Island in the northern tip to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip to demonstrate their love for Taiwan and their desire for peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The China Times:
Clinton claims 'one China' is designed to protect Taiwan.

Clinton claims peaceful solution to Taiwan Strait issues requires the consent of the people on both sides.

Taiwanese expatriates around the world stage protests against Beijing's anti-secession law.

Taiwan commemorates the 228 Incident.

KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang to head a delegation to visit China.
