Clinton cites risks, benefits of global ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SIGNS COPIES OF AUTOBIOGRAPHY FOR TAIWAN READERS

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton, who arrived in Taipei Sunday evening for a whirlwind 24-hour visit, met Taiwan readers by signing copies of his autobiography at the Taipei 101 tower Monday to promote his new book.
Readers began lining up before 9 a.m. for the book signing session slated for 11 a.m. Security was tight, inevitably making entry into the venue time consuming.
More than 50,000 copies of the 900-page Chinese version of Clinton's autobiography "My Life, " published by the Taipei-based China Times Publication, have been sold so far.
Clinton's current book promotion tour to Asia has already taken him to Hong Kong, Beijing, South Korea and Japan. He is scheduled to depart Taipei for Singapore later Monday afternoon.

On Sunday evening, the former U.S. president delivered a 30-minute speech at the Taipei International Convention Center, during which he spoke of the dangers and benefits of living in a more interdependent world. The appearance was sponsored by the government-financed Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, a non-profit organization dedicated to the promotion of democracy and human rights in Taiwan and abroad.

Clinton met with President Chen Shui-bian over dinner later Sunday, during which Chen presented him with a saxophone as a gift. Clinton appeared pleasantly surprised by the gift which also had a quote by the late Martin Luther King engraved on it.
Although Clinton is no longer president, he has been accorded treatment befitting a head of state during his visit in Taiwan.
Clinton, who has remained an internationally important figure since his retirement, now acts as a special envoy of the United Nations appointed by U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan.
Before starting his book tour around Asia, Clinton joined former U.S. President George H.W. Bush on a tour of South and Southeast Asian countries battered by December's devastating tsunami disaster.

Clinton originally planned to come to Taiwan in November 2003 but was forced to cancel the visit due to a tight schedule. He was also scheduled to visit Taiwan Sept. 12, 2001, but failed to make it due to the 911 terrorist attacks.
He visited Taiwan four times during his tenure as governor of Arkansas before being elected U.S. president in November 1991.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that Clinton contributed a great deal to the promotion of substantive Taiwan-U.S. relations during his presidency, particularly his decision to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to patrol waters near Taiwan during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: President of Egypt Calls for Open Election. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak called for a constitutional amendment to allow other candidates to run against him for the first time, a surprise move that could be a historic turning point in a country that has endured decades of repressive rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Armed Navy escorts for suspect ships.
Singapore's anti-terrorist battle will take to the seas next month with the deployment of armed security teams by the Republic of Singapore Navy on board some merchant ships.
The uniformed security teams will escort vessels entering or leaving the port, but only within Singapore waters.
Selected merchant ships, including cruise liners, would be identified for escort. The ship's previous ports of call, the cargo on board and other shipping data, would be looked at for hints of possible threats.
The Lianhe Zaobao:Singapore's Accompanying Sea Security Teams escorts for merchant ships in Singapore waters.
For enhancing the security of Singapore waters, the Navy will reorganize the Coastal Command, expand the establishment of the Shipping Control Squadron, and establish the Accompanying Sea Security Teams (ASSeT) next month.
The uniformed security teams will get aboard and escort vessels entering or leaving the port, but only within Singapore waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Support for mining sought
TACLOBAN CITY -- President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo on Saturday called on the vice mayors of Region 8 (Eastern Visayas) to help ensure the success of the government's responsible mining program to protect the government and, at the same time, raise funds for vital development projects.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Pal pins blame on Roldan
A SUSPECT in the kidnapping of a 3-year-old Chinese-Filipino boy said he was driving Dennis Roldan in a van when the former lawmaker talked to the boy's family by mobile phone, demanding a P3-million ransom.
The Philippine Star: AFP presses attacks in Sulu
Fighting has intensified for the third straight week as government forces mounted new offensives against Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) renegades in Jolo, Sulu.
The Manila Times: Pray for me, Pope pleads to faithful
ROME: Pope John Paul II made a surprise appearance at his hospital window Sunday, his first since undergoing surgery on his throat on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: World antismoking treaty enters into force
A landmark treaty aimed at cutting deaths and illness caused by smoking came into force Sunday after 57 countries including Japan ratified intenational restrictions on tobacco producers and smokers, the World Health Organization said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON PRAISES CHEN FOR HIS COURAGE IN MEETING WITH PFP HEAD

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton praised President Chen Shui-bian Sunday for his courage in meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, saying the meeting has promoted reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties and made the Taiwan people stronger and more confident.

Clinton made the remarks while meeting with Chen at a dinner party held in his honor after he delivered a speech on global stability and prosperity in the 21st century at the Taipei International Convention Center earlier in the evening.

According to Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu, who also attended the dinner party, the former U.S. president said while commending Chen for his meeting with Soong Feb. 24 that a brave man is willing to communicate with those with whom he has differing opinions.
Clinton also emphasized that the reconciliation demonstrated through Chen's meeting with his political opponent will make Taiwan's democracy stronger and more confident.

For his part, Chen equated his reconciliation with Soong to Clinton's reconciliation with former U.S. President George H.W. Bush, his former political adversary. The two former presidents are now serving together as U.N. envoys for tsunami reconstruction in South and Southeast Asia.

Touching on the various similarities between himself and Clinton regarding the background of their political careers, Chen said that both he and Clinton are followers of the "middle way doctrine" and supporters of reconciliation.

Also attending the dinner party were Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Premier Frank Hsieh, Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General General Su Tseng-chang, Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Tan-sun and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Huang Chih-fang.

Clinton, who arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a 24-hour whirlwind visit, held a book-signing session Monday at the Taipei 101 tower for his autobiography "My Life." He is set to depart Taipei for Singapore later in the afternoon to continue his book promotion tour in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS WELCOME CLOSER CROSS-STRAIT FINANCIAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan should strengthen financial exchanges with mainland China, a move which would benefit the island more than the mainland, a finance professor at National Taiwan University said Monday.

Commenting on reports that Taiwan will soon allow mainland Chinese banking institutions to open representative offices in Taiwan, professor Huang Ta-yeh said that it is a welcome policy even simply from an economic perspective.

Taiwan's financial service sector -- which has lost a lot of loan services business due to the mass exodus of Taiwan companies to the mainland -- would enthusiastically welcome an acceleration in cross-strait financial exchanges and cooperation, Huang noted.

Huang also expressed welcome to the recent meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, during which Chen vowed to push for closer business, cultural and academic exchanges with mainland China. The professor said President Chen's promises are conducive to improving cross-strait relations.

Noting that an easing of cross-strait tensions will help facilitate financial exchanges, Huang said Taiwan's financial service sector should grasp the opportunity of bettering cross-strait relations to make inroads into the mainland.

Meanwhile, professor Yeh Yin-hua from Fujen Catholic University said that it is only normal that mainland Chinese financial institutions be allowed to set up representative offices in Taiwan as their Taiwan counterparts have already been allowed to do so on the mainland for years.

Yeh noted, however, that Taiwan faces relatively greater risks than mainland China does in the exchange of banking representative offices, making it necessary for Taiwan to work out control measures prior to implementation.
According to Kung Chao-sheng, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission under the Executive Yuan, Taiwan will soon open its door to mainland Chinese banking and financial service institutions.
Accordingly, Kung said, Taiwan must accelerate its moves to overhaul related laws and regulations to cope with the new situation.

Lu Tong-ying, vice chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, said that plans on allowing mainland banks to open representative offices in Taiwan have already been worked out. If the government gives the green light, the plans could be put into effect within a week, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REP TO U.S. URGES BEIJING TO ABANDON 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative to the United States on Sunday urged mainland China to take the initiative and give up its plan to enact an "anti-secession law" so as not to raise cross-strait tensions.

David Ta-wei Lee made the remarks during a commemoration ceremony for the 228 Incident held in Washington, D.C., which was sponsored by Taiwan civic groups such as the Presbyterian Church and the Taiwanese Association in the D.C. area and which was attended by around 300 Taiwanese expatriates.
The "anti-secession law" will soon be put to review and is expected to be passed by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament, when it meets in early March.
Lee said that President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly extended olive branches to mainland China, urging Beijing to resume talks for the peaceful coexistence of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

But Beijing has ignored the aspiration of the 23 million people on Taiwan and the international community for world peace and is planning to enact the "anti-secession law, " which could be used as a legal basis for its policy toward Taiwan, Lee said.

He noted that there is no precedent of formulating such a law in the world, and Beijing's purpose is to unilaterally define the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, deny the de jure existence of the ROC and provide a legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan should the island declare independence.
Lee pointed out that the "anti-secession law" is a law to authorize war and is dictatorial.
He urged the international community to address Beijing's attempt to use force against Taiwan and use its influence to prevent Beijing from making any moves to sabotage regional peace and stability.

He said that the "anti-session law" has no substantive benefits and will be ill-received by the people of Taiwan. It will destroy the basis on which both sides can have further exchanges and resume bilateral talks, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ON U.S. MILITARY SUPPLY PROCUREMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) refrained from making any comment Monday on media reports that the U.S. military is considering procuring military supplies from Taiwan as part of its efforts to reduce costs.

According to media reports, a delegation organized by the Comparative Testing Office (CTO) of the U.S. Department of Defense is scheduled to arrive in Taipei this weekend to assess Taiwan's capability of supplying military equipment. The delegation reportedly will meet with officials of the MND's military supply bureau and senior executives of local high-tech companies.
Responding to media inquiries, MND spokesman Liu Chih-chien said the MND has customarily not made any comments on reports about military procurement deals.

Other MND officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the upcoming visit is part of the U.S. military's regular global business trip aimed at negotiating terms or placing orders for procuring military equipment components, spare parts and other supplies, such as military boots.

With a view to cutting costs and diversifying supply sources, the officials said the Pentagon has usually purchased military supplies from Asian countries, including Taiwan, Vietnam and the Philippines.

According to media reports, the U.S. delegation, to be composed of five military officers and a civilian official, would meet Taiwan defense and economic officials and high-tech firms in a five-day visit.

They will bring with them a shopping list of over 300 items, ranging from aircraft components, ammunition, laptop computers to satellite telephones and infrared equipment. The delegation is expected to submit a report to the Pentagon in June on the outcome of their evaluation, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP SWISS COMPETITION LAW OFFICIAL VISITING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Dr. Walter A. Stoffel, president of the Swiss Federal Competition Commission, arrived in Taiwan Monday for a five-day visit, mainly to give a lecture on competition laws and policies.

Stoffel, who is also a full professor at the University of Fribourg, Switzerland, is scheduled to deliver the speech, "Competition policy in small economies, " at the headquarters of the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission (FTC) Tuesday, FTC officials said.
Following the speech, Stoffel will join local officials and members of Taiwan's legal community for a seminar, which will include a question and answer session.

FTC officials who invited Stoffel to Taiwan said that Stoffel's visit will be conducive to strengthening mutual understanding between Taiwan and Switzerland. His visit is also poised to bolster ties between Taiwan and European countries in matters related to competition law, the officials added.

An academic whose expertise includes commercial law, bankruptcy law and competition law, Stoffel has held many other posts including director of the International Association of Legal Science, a UNESCO-affiliated, worldwide organization devoted to the promotion of the study of foreign laws and the use of the comparative method.
During his stay, Stoffel is also expected to call at the Judicial Yuan, the Institute of Law under National Taiwan University and meet with local academics in competition law.
Switzerland is the fourth-largest European country in Taiwan in terms of foreign investment.
Promoting cooperation and exchanges with authorities governing competition law and implementation in foreign countries is an established policy of the Fair Trade Commission, FTC officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Moscow Puts a Rosy Spin on Bush Talks.
After escaping public criticism over the state of democracy in Russia, Moscow is portraying the meeting between President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President George W. Bush in Slovakia as a big diplomatic success.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE BUREAU TO REWARD NON-USERS WITH PRIZES

TEXT.P: Being healthy can pay off, especially if you're one of the estimated 57,000 people who have never used the national health insurance system, as the insurance bureau will reward over 1,100 non-users with prizes in a draw Tuesday.

The National Health Insurance Bureau was begun 10 years ago, Hsu Chung-I, a division chief at the bureau said, adding that the bureau will reward those who have never taken advantage of the insurance program, although they have had to pay into it.
The biggest prize in the lottery will be a 29-inch television, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SAYS HOLIDAY DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT FLIGHTS GOOD FOR RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Visiting U.S. former President Bill Clinton on Monday praised the landmark two-way, non-stop cross-strait charter passenger flights during the just-concluded Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

Clinton said that the cross-strait charter flights were a positive move that is conducive to enhancing symbiosis and co-prosperity of global economies, according to Stephen Chen, formerly top Taiwan representative in the United States who accompanied opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan during a brief meeting with Clinton Monday afternoon.

Stressing that the world is becoming increasingly interdependent and people around the world must join hands for co-existence and co-prosperity, Clinton was quoted by Chen as saying that closer exchanges across the Taiwan Strait would help enhance mutual understanding and consolidate cooperation between the two sides.

Clinton met with Lien for a closed-door talk that lasted about 40 minutes, according to Chen. During the talk, Clinton reiterated the importance of cross-strait issues being resolved peacefully and the significance of the launch of the direct cross-strait charter flights.
During the talk, Clinton offered Lien a copy of his autobiography, titled "My Life, " as a gift, while Lien gave the former president a blue-white china vase, Chen said.

According to Chen, it was Clinton who invited Lien to meet. Clinton, who has become well acquainted with Lien since 1988 when he visited Taiwan in his capacity as the governor of the state of Arkansas while Lien was the foreign minister, addressed Lien as an old friend.
Soon after the meeting with Lien, Clinton headed to Taipei's Sungshan airport, wrapping up his whirlwind 24-hour visit in Taiwan.

Clinton met with President Chen Shui-bian once again Monday morning for a closed-door meeting that lasted for about an hour following their first meeting Sunday evening over a dinner that President Chen hosted in honor of Clinton.
Clinton met Taiwan readers and signed copies of his autobiography at the Taipei 101 tower around noon Monday.
More than 500 people began lining up before 9 a.m. for the book signing session slated for 11 a.m. Security was tight, inevitably making entry into the venue time consuming.
More than 50,000 copies of the 900-page Chinese version of Clinton's autobiography, published by the Taipei-based China Times Publications, have been sold so far.
Clinton's current book promotion tour to Asia has already taken him to Hong Kong, Beijing, South Korea and Japan. He departed Taipei around 5 p.m. Monday for Singapore.

On Sunday evening, Clinton delivered a 30-minute speech at the Taipei International Convention Center, during which he spoke of the dangers and benefits of living in a more interdependent world. The appearance was sponsored by the government-financed Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, a non-profit organization dedicated to the promotion of democracy and human rights in Taiwan and abroad.
Although Clinton is no longer president, he was accorded treatment befitting a head of state during his visit in Taiwan.
Clinton, who has remained an internationally important figure since his retirement, now acts as a special envoy of the United Nations appointed by U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan.
Before starting his book tour around Asia, Clinton joined former U.S. President George H.W. Bush on a tour of South and Southeast Asian countries battered by December's devastating tsunamis.
He visited Taiwan four times during his tenure as governor of Arkansas before being elected U.S. president in 1991.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that Clinton contributed a great deal to the promotion of substantive Taiwan-U.S. relations during his presidency, particularly his decision to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to patrol waters near Taiwan during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LAUNCHES PETITION DRIVE AGAINST BEIJING'S 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) launched an islandwide 10,000-person petition drive Monday to highlight its call for the people of Taiwan to oppose mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law."
The one-day signature drive on 228 Peace Memorial Day was held in about 30 places around Taiwan and was called "oppose annexation, protect Taiwan."

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang led party officials and legislators to Lungshan Temple, one of the designated places in Taipei to solicit signatures, and used a bullhorn to call for the public to join the drive.
TSU officials said that Beijing is attempting to use the "anti-secession law" to lay a legal basis to employ force against Taiwan should the island declare independence.
For this reason, it is urgent to define clearly the status of Taiwan and mainland China and laws governing the rights and obligations of those participating in bilateral exchanges, they said.
The TSU will propose an "anti-annexation law" to counter Beijing's "anti-secession law," they added.
The "anti-secession law" will soon be put to review and is expected to be passed by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament, when it meets in early March.
Su said that Taiwan faces the threat of annexation from mainland China, and the only way to counter this is for Taiwan to stand up against the proposed law.

He also said that two million people took part in the hand-in-hand campaign for peace on Feb. 28 last year, and the theme of this year's activity was still peace, but he wondered why some political figures who took part in last year's movement didn't come out this year.
The TSU's Youth Department officials also performed skits to ridicule some political figures in Taiwan as seriously tilting toward mainland China and not standing on the same side as the people.

TSU Legislator Huang Shih-chou said that the TSU wants to make the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) aware that the TSU will rigorously monitor the administration and actively promote a new constitution and the rectification of the nation's name.
TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming also said that the TSU will prove with action that it will by no means accept mainland China's attempt to annex Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Huge rise in maternity costs attacked by businesses.
Plans to extend maternity rights were condemned by business leaders last night who said that they could "cripple" hundreds of thousands of companies. Tony Blair will announce today that millions of parents with school-age children could soon have the same right to part-time work as families with infants. The "right to request" flexible work would also be extended to 1.8 million women who book after sick or disabled relatives.
Financial Times: Labour election tension rises.
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown were yesterday scrambling to inject momentum into Labour's faltering pre-election campaign amid ominous signs of tension over the chancellor's diminished role. Alan Milburn, who as Labour's campaign co-ordinator is doing the job Mr Brown performed in the party's two landslide victories, joined forces with friends of the chancellor in a concerted attempt to dismiss reports of a furious row over the timing of Friday's announcement of a rise in the minimum wage.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS FORECASTS 2005 ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE AT 4.21 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to post an economic growth rate of 4.21 percent for the whole of 2005, while the first quarter rate will register 4.03 percent, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Monday.
Affected by a global economic slowdown, the DGBAS forecast that the economic growth this year will not achieve the 5.71 percent seen in 2004.
The DGBAS statistics also showed that the economy is expected to grow by 4.08 percent in the second quarter this year, with third quarter at 4.24 percent and fourth quarter at 4.46 percent.
The service sector will contribute 2.51 percent to first quarter growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILES CONCERNING 228 INCIDENT MUST BE OPENED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the archives related to the 228 Incident must be made public to help learn the complete truth about the tragic event.
Chen also said a national human rights commission should be provided for under the Constitution in the constitutional re-engineering project to avoid such tragedy from taking place again.
The president made the remarks when he attended the 58th anniversary of the incident at the 228 Peace Park in downtown Taipei.

Chen noted that the incident -- civil disorder and a brutal crackdown by the government that began Feb. 28, 1947, triggered by a dispute between an unlicensed cigarette vendor and an anti-smuggling officer the day before, and the ensuing period known as the "White Terror" was a "massive and systematic encroachment on human rights by the nation in an authoritarian period."
"Despite the fact that the victims and those involved came from every ethnic group, " Chen said, it nevertheless sowed the seeds of mistrust and hatred between the various ethnic groups.

Under the long period of Kuomintang martial law, no one dared to address the issue, Chen noted, and there was no investigation of the truth, no resolution of misunderstandings and hatred and no help for the various groups to understand or even reconcile amongst themselves.

For half a century, everyone in Taiwan has been affected by the tragedy so that they cannot open up their arms and hearts to embrace their different historical memories and cannot share common experiences and traumas.

To ensure there is no repeat of a similar tragedy in the future, Chen said that the two major goals at present are to open the government's secret files related to the 228 Incident so as to expedite the finding of the truth.

As this was a human rights incident, he said, in the constitutional re-engineering project a national human rights commission should be provided for and that the protection on human rights should also be expanded in the Constitution in line with the highest standards of international human rights.
The president reaffirmed that reconciliation must be based on truth and said the government will work toward finding the complete truth of the tragic event as soon as possible.

The president also led Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, 228 Incident Memorial Foundation Chairman Chen Chin-huang, and family members of some of the victims in laying wreaths and paying their respects before the 228 memorial.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR WORLD ATTENTION TO BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the international community Monday to show concern over mainland China's proposed anti-secession legislation that would provide a legal basis for Beijing to attack Taiwan.

Chen made the appeal while attending a ceremony to mark the 58th anniversary of the 228 Incident, which refers to the events that led to a brutal crackdown by Kuomintang (KMT) government troops against the local population, particularly the intelligentsia, Feb. 28, 1947.

"The people of Taiwan have deep conviction and commitment to peace and human rights. We are willing to protect the peaceful and stable Taiwan Strait status quo in a sincere and responsible manner," Chen said.

While the smooth conclusion of the recent Chinese New Year cross-strait charter flights provided a glimmer of hope for permanent cross-strait peace and opened up a window of opportunity for constructive cross-strait interaction and dialogue, Chen said the people of Taiwan still live in the shadow of the threat of the 700-plus ballistic missiles deployed by mainland China against the island. Worse still, Chen said, the mainland's so-called anti-secession law, expected to be enacted in March, has dropped a time bomb into cross-strait relations and Asia-Pacific regional peace, security and stability.

Noting that major countries around the world, including the United States, Japan and the European Union, have traditionally been concerned about the cross-strait situation and support Taiwan's pursuit of democracy, Chen said he keenly hopes the international community will pay equal heed to the mainland's planned anti-secession legislation.
As part of the 228 Incident commemoration at the 228 Peace Park in downtown Taipei, Chen tolled a bell to symbolize peace and called for an end to Taiwan's ethnic divisions.

"This is a painful day for the Taiwan people, " Chen said after ringing the large bronze bell near a monument dedicated to the victims of the massacre. "Our people and future leaders should learn from the incident and remember that real peace is based on full communication, understanding, respect and reconciliation," he said. Throughout Taiwan, people gathered at memorial parks to mourn those killed in the 228 Incident and vigils were planned in several cities for later that day.

The bloody crackdown took place in a turbulent period of Taiwan's history. In 1945, the mainland China-based Kuomintang (KMT) government reclaimed Taiwan, which had been a Japanese colony. But the KMT's rule was brutal and corrupt, leading to a massive protest Feb. 28, 1947, by the native Taiwanese. More troops were sent from the mainland to crush the demonstrations and in the following months, soldiers arrested and killed thousands of people they claimed were communists or saboteurs trying to overthrow the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S VISIT RAISES TAIWAN'S PROFILE: MOFA

TEXT.P: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton is a friend of Taiwan and his visit to Taiwan will raise Taiwan's profile internationally, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) claimed Monday.
Michel Lu made the remarks after Clinton wrapped up a whirlwind visit to Taiwan Monday afternoon and left for Singapore to continue his Asian tour promoting his autobiography, titled "My Life."

During his less-than 24-hour stay in Taiwan, Clinton met with President Chen Shui-bian twice, attended an autograph session for his book and delivered a speech at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Lu said that the ministry invited Clinton to visit Taiwan mainly to express appreciation for his support of Taiwan's democracy and his assistance in Taiwan's efforts to play a positive force of peace and stability in the Asian region during his term.
Clinton is very concerned about the development of Taiwan and cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Lu said, adding that remarks he made during his stay were for the good of Taiwan.

He also noted that Clinton is an internationally renowned figure and claimed that his visit will not only raise the profile of Taiwan internationally but will also enhance exchanges between Taiwan and the international community and let the world learn about Taiwan.

He reaffirmed that the MOFA will continue to promote the policy of inviting former U.S. presidents, political figures of countries friendly to Taiwan and the heads of state of the nation's allies to visit.

Clinton, who has remained active in politics after stepping down in 2001 as a two-term U.S. president, now acts as a special envoy of the United Nations appointed by U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan.
Before starting his book tour around Asia, Clinton joined former U.S. President George H.W. Bush on a tour of South and Southeast Asian countries battered by the devastating tsunamis Dec. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Suicide Car Bomb Explodes in Hilla, Killing More Than 100.
A suicide car bombe killed 105 people and wounded 130 near a crowded marketplace south of Baghdad on Monday in the single bloodiest attack in Iraq since the fall of Saddam Hussein. Reuters television footage showed a pile of bloodied bodies outside the building. Smoke rose from the wreckage of burnt-out market stalls as bystanders loaded mangled corpses on to wooden carts, usually used to carry fruit and vegetables.
Wall Street Journal: Out of Patience, How Lebanese Drive to Oust the Syrians Finally Caught Fire.
The giant bomb blast that took the life of a towering political figure here unleashed a deep-seated anger over Lebanon's occupation by a foreign power: Syria. Syria. Religious and ethnic groups demonstrated against Syrian domination. The vocal surge is the biggest challenge to the Syrian presence in Lebanon since the occupation began three decades ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE WORLDWIDE OBSERVES 228 PEACE MEMORIAL DAY

TEXT.P: Taiwanese all over the world observed the country's Feb. 28 Peace Memorial Day with a variety of activities Sunday.

In Washington, D.C., a ceremony jointly sponsored by the Taiwan Presbyterian Church and the Taiwanese Association in Washington, D.C., was held at the Twin Oak Garden, drawing a bout 300 Taiwanese attendees.
The ceremony began with a prayer led by pastors Hsu Min-chao and Chen Min-hsien from the Taiwan Presbyterian Church.

Chen said that the ceremony was aimed at soothing the grief of the victims of the tragic incident and their families, encouraging them to accept that those mainland Chinese who moved to the island after the 1947 incident are innocent and should not be blamed for the incident.
Huang Mei-yueh, the president of the Taiwanese Association in Washington, D.C., echoed Chen's opinion and called for unity among the Taiwanese to defeat the mainland's attempts to annex the island.
David Tawei Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, also spoke and urged Taiwanese to draw a lesson from the 228 incident to learn to accept ethnic variety with tolerance.
He also took the opportunity to lambaste Beijing's attempt to define its disputes with Taiwan as an internal affair by enacting a so-called anti-secession law.
In Los Angeles, about 300 Taiwanese gathered at the Taiwan Center to observe the 228 Peace Memorial Day.
Braving chilly wind, they gathered in front of the center to sing Taiwan folk songs then lit white and green candles and observed silence in memory of the dead.
A slogan written on a big billboard on the front of the center read: "Chinese Missiles not only target Taiwan but all of East Asia."
In Dallas, Texas, the observation was organized jointly by the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) and the local Taiwanese Association.

Lin Chien-lung, a professor of Soochow University in Taipei, known as a loafer before he determined to mend his ways and worked his way through university, gave an account of his wild teenage days during the ceremony.
Lin said he was invited by FAPA on a lecture tour in the United States to raise funds and that Dallas was the last leg of his U.S. trip.
In Ottawa, Canada, more than 200 Taiwanese gathered at the city library to observe the 228 Peace Memorial Day.
The ceremony began with a prayer for the victims of the incident followed by a speech by Yen Kung-chang, president of the Taiwanese Association in Ottawa.
Yen urged the Taiwanese to "follow the 228 victims' examples" by fighting for democracy and human rights in Taiwan.
Taiwan's representative to Canada, Thomas Chen, also gave a speech in which he called on all Taiwanese to value the island's hard-earned democracy.
The participants issued a statement at the end of the ceremony, decrying the mainland's attempts to take over Taiwan.
In London, Taiwanese marked the day by gathering in the freezing square in front of Parliament to protest the mainland's anti-secession law.
They unfurled a banner reading "Taiwan is not a part of China" and waved posters calling on Beijing to withdraw its missiles deployed across the Taiwan Strait from Taiwan.
In Tokyo, Taiwanese and pro-Taiwan Japanese marked the day by taking to the streets on Monday to protest against the anti-secession law, which is intended to prevent Taiwan from seeking independence.

During the demonstration, the protesters read a letter from former President Lee Teng-hui, who prodded Taiwanese to remember the 228 Incident, which he claimed "woke them up to the cruelty of the Chinese regime."
Lee also appealed to Japan to help ward off Beijing's attempts to take over Taiwan, which will threaten the stability and peace in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE WANT RULING, OPPOSITION CAMPS TO COMPROMISE: CLINTON

TEXT.P: The results of last year's presidential and legislative elections show that the people of Taiwan want the ruling and opposition camps to compromise, former U.S. President Bill Clinton said Monday.

In an interview with ET Television, Clinton noted that the people of Taiwan re-elected President Chen Shui-bian in the March 20 presidential election and then gave the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) a narrow majority in the parliamentary body in the Dec. 11 legislative elections.

"I think what they're saying is: We put you in the same boat together. We want you to row. We want you to work together. We want you to move us forward together. And if both of you have to compromise, that's good, that's what we intended," Clinton said.

Clinton said he met Chen and KMT Chairman Lien Chan during his stay in Taiwan and found them both to be "highly intelligent, completely patriotic, devoted to the interests of the people of Taiwan and not so far apart on some issues."
What happened in Taiwan, Clinton said, was basically what happened to him when the American people elected him and then put the Republicans in charge of Congress and then re-elected him.

Many elections are close, which he said is the result of the uncertainties of the modern world and people wanting political leaders to find the consensus that will move them forward rather than leaving them where they are.
Politicians should be as clear as they can about their differences but should not attack their opponents personally, Clinton said.
He quoted Benjamin Franklin, saying: "Our political enemies are our friends for they show us our faults."
Chen defeated Lien in last year's presidential election by a slim margin of less than 30,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast.

However, the opposition "Pan Blue Alliance" formed by the KMT and its political allies, the People First Party and the New Party, won 114 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan in December's legislative elections, outnumbering the 101 seats obtained by the "Pan Green Alliance" formed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
Clinton arrived in Taipei Sunday evening for a whirlwind 24-hour visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SON OF 228 INCIDENT VICTIM DONATES PRECIOUS SOUVENIR

TEXT.P: The son of a 228 Incident victim presented a gift from the Republic of China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen -- a bottle of scotch whisky -- to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Monday.

Liao Teh-hsiung, president of the Taipei 228 Incident Victims Association, presented the precious gift to Ma during a tea party hosted by the Taipei city government as part of the commemoration of the 58th anniversary of the tragic 1947 incident.

Liao recalled that Sun gave the whisky to his father Liao Chin-ping during a visit to Taiwan in the latter years of the Ching Dynasty. Sun was making a transit stop in Taiwan on his way to Japan after his "second revolution" to overthrow the corrupt Manchu government failed.
"Dr. Sun gave the whisky to my father in appreciation of his presentation of 60,000 yen in cash to support Dr. Sun's cause, " Liao said.
According to Liao, the money was raised from wealthy families in central Taiwan. At that time, Liao said, 1,000 yen could buy a house in Taipei. Taiwan was then under Japanese colonial rule.

Liao's father was killed in the 228 Incident, which refers to a series of events in 1947 that led to a brutal crackdown by the Kuomintang (KMT) government against the local population, particularly the intelligentsia.
Ma said the precious bottle of whisky will be displayed in a new Taiwan cultural movement memorial hall to be built in the near future.

During the tea party, Liao also presented Ma with a Wenshu-strain orchid from Japan that symbolizes peace. On Aug. 6, 1945, all plants around Hiroshima in southern Japan withered when the atom bomb was dropped, but a few Wenshu orchids only two kilometers from ground zero survived. The orchids were later planted in the Hiroshima Peace Park. This special orchid strain has since become a symbol of peace.
Liao told Ma that this is the first time that Wenshu orchids have been sent to Taiwan.
Ma said historic wounds can be forgiven but can never be forgotten.

"Tragedies like the 228 Incident should never happen again. The 228 Incident Memorial Hall has recently completed biographies of 168 of the victims. We hope the publication of these biographies can help local people understand the truth about the incident," Ma said.

The bloody crackdown took place in a turbulent period of Taiwan's history. In 1945, the mainland China-based Kuomintang (KMT) government reclaimed Taiwan, which had been a Japanese colony. But the KMT's rule was brutal and corrupt, leading to a massive protest Feb. 28, 1947, by the native Taiwanese. More troops were sent from the mainland to crush the demonstrations and in the following months, soldiers arrested and killed thousands of people they claimed were communists or saboteurs trying to overthrow the government.
President Chen Shui-bian said at a ceremony in memory of the 228 Incident victims earlier in the day that this is a painful day for the Taiwan people.
"Our people and future leaders should learn from the incident and remember that real peace is based on full communication, understanding, respect and reconciliation," he said.
Throughout Taiwan, people gathered at memorial parks to mourn those killed in the incident and vigils were also held in several cities later in the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LIGHTING UP TAIWAN' ACTIVITY HELD AT 228 MEMORIAL PARK

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui helped start a "lighting up Taiwan" activity at the 228 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei Monday evening.

Braving a cold rain, large crowds gathered at the square of the 228 Monument, erected to commemorate the brutal crackdown by the Kuomintang government that began Feb. 28, 1947, to take part in a "Taiwan's light will shine over the world" activity sponsored by the pro-independence civic group Hand-in-hand to Protect Taiwan Alliance.

Although relations between the pro-Taiwan independence supporters and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) became frosty after President Chen Shui-bian's meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Thursday -- in which the president reaffirmed his promises of no declaration of Taiwan independence and no change of the nation's official name -- Chen, Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh all attended the activity.

Other attendees included Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and Labor Affairs Council Chairwoman Chen Chu, as well as pro-independence Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Senior Adviser to the President Koo Kuan-min, and World United Formosans for Independence Chairman Ng Chiau-tong.
While addressing the crowd, Lee vehemently attacked a proposed "anti-secession law" in mainland China as a "barbaric and invasive" act.

The law, which is aimed at laying a legal basis for using force against Taiwan should it declare independence, will soon be put to review and is expected to be approved by the National People's Congress -- Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament -- when it meets in early March.

Lee said that if the law is enacted, it will have a major impact on Taiwan's existence and development. He said that not only the United States and Japan are opposed to its enactment, other peace-loving countries are also strongly condemning the proposed legislation and that the Taiwan people should protest strongly.
The Taiwan people must not remain silent, as this would send the wrong message to the international community and China's government that they can accept the law, he said.
He reaffirmed that Taiwan is not part of China and that as such, there has never been a question of it splitting from China.
After the speech, the former president and other guests lit the light of Fukuei Cape Lighthouse, located at the northern tip of Taiwan, by remote control.

At around 8 p.m., 19 designated places in Taiwan as well as 16 locations in other cities in the world held simultaneous lighting up activities for 30 minutes to symbolize a prayer for Taiwan and the passing of Taiwan's light to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, March 1:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
10: 30, The Central Election Commission will issue a National Assembly election proclamation at the CEC headquarters.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10: 30, Senior Advisor to the President Koo Kuan-min will hold a news conference at the Sheraton Hotel Taipei.
10:30, The Taiwan Solidarity Union will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive board members of the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International at the Presidential Office.
16: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive Dennis Oswald, a member of the Executive Committee of the International Olympic Committee, at the Presidential Office.
16: 00, The Council for Economic Planning and Development will issue reports on Taiwan's economic performance in January at the council's headquarters.
16: 20, The Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 30, The Ministry of the Interior will open the special telephone line 0800-088885 to serve foreign spouses of Taiwan residents in a ceremony at the ministry's press room.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP QUESTIONS KMT'S WISDOM IN NEGOTIATING WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) questioned Monday the wisdom of an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decision to send a delegation to mainland China to negotiate cross-Taiwan Strait air links.
The KMT legislative caucus is scheduled to organize the delegation to visit Beijing to discuss the opening of regular charter flights across the Taiwan Strait.
"I don't think it's a wise decision for the KMT to negotiate terms for opening regular cross-strait charter flights with the mainland at the moment," DPP legislative whip Lai Ching-teh said.
Cross-strait negotiations should not take place until local people have forged a consensus on relevant issues, he said.
As an opposition party, Lai said, the KMT has neither the mandate nor the authority to negotiate with the Beijing authorities on the issue.
Lai also criticized former U.S. President Bill Clinton's remarks that any solution to the cross-strait dispute requires the consent of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"Taiwan is an independent sovereign country. Its destiny should be determined by its 23 million people, not anybody else. Clinton's statement indicates his ignorance of Taiwan's sovereign status, " Lai claimed.

Noting that Clinton's current Asian tour is mainly aimed at promoting his autobiography "My Life, " Lai said he was not surprised by what he described as Clinton's "pro-Beijing rhetoric." If Clinton were to make a pro-Taiwan statement, Lai added, Beijing might ban the sale of his book on the mainland.
Since Clinton has retired, Lai continued, his remarks in any case do not represent U.S. policy.

Clinton arrived in Taipei Sunday evening for a barely 24-hour whirlwind visit. During his stay, he delivered a speech on Asian democratic development. He also held two rounds of closed-door talks with President Chen Shui-bian on cross-strait ties and other matters of mutual concern. He signed copies of his autobiography for local fans before departing for Singapore Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES SHOULD BE INCREASED: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should be increased, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.
Taiwan should further promote cross-strait exchanges to improve mutual understanding between the two sides and avoid possible misunderstanding by Beijing on the Taiwan independence issue, Ma said.

The mayor, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said he has found there exist many misunderstandings between the two sides of the strait after observing the recent development of cross-strait ties, particularly on the Taiwan independence issue.

Beijing may not be aware of the operation of a democratic regime in which political differences should be tolerated, Ma pointed out, adding that tolerance of Taiwan independence rhetoric should not be translated into support for the independence movement.

Noting that cross-strait relations are a major factor that affects the sound development of Taiwan's politics and economics, Ma said stability in the Taiwan Strait can be secured only when a reconciliation between the two sides of the strait is achieved.

Commenting on former U.S. President Bill Clinton's remarks that a peaceful resolution to the cross-strait issues should be subject to the consent of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Ma said that Clinton should learn more about Taiwan's situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARK 228 BY GUARDING AGAINST ALIEN REGIME'S INVASION: DPP CHIEF

TEXT.P: To mark the Feb. 28 Peace Memorial Day, Taiwanese should unite together to guard against an alien regime moving in, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Monday.

In a ceremony at the Sun Yat-sen Hall in downtown Taipei, Su said mistakes can be forgiven but history cannot be forgotten. The 228 Incident, he said, was a bloody Taiwanese uprising against the rule of a corrupt alien regime.
In order to avoid a repeat of the incident, Su said, Taiwanese should unite against mainland China's military threat.

The DPP chief said his party decided to mark the day at the Sun Yat-sen Hall because it was once the office of the Japanese governor when the island was ruled by Japan prior to 1945, and then become the office of the National Assembly when the Chinese Nationalist government, or Kuomintang, fled to Taiwan in 1949.

Fifty-eight years after the 1947 incident, Su said, Taiwanese have eventually become their own masters and the DPP marked the day at the building that once symbolized the authority of alien rulers to prove that they are finally their own rulers.

He rebutted a statement attributed to opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong that Beijing proposed a so-called anti-secession law after being angered by the radical pro-independence activists in Taiwan, arguing that the mainland is not proposing the anti-secession law -- which would provide a legal basis for an invasion of Taiwan -- because of Taiwan's provocation.

Premier Frank Hsieh also gave a speech to similar effect at the ceremony, saying the country set aside Feb. 28 as Peace Memorial Day with the purpose of helping the various ethnic groups in Taiwan to get along in harmony.
"We should mark the day by raising the consciousness of Taiwan and stressing Taiwan's political identity independent from that of other countries," the premier said.

Claiming that the mainland is united when dealing with foreigners, Hsieh said Taiwan is a free but splitting society and that "the island would be secured forever if only 70 percent or 80 percent of its people could work together."

Vice President Annette Lu said at the ceremony that as the ruling party, the DPP should view the 228 Incident in perspective. Although the incident has done permanent injury to the country, Taiwanese should not attempt to take revenge on those who imposed the suffering on them," she said.
